name: President. -
text: The next item is the vote on the request for urgent procedure under Rule 154 on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom on the system of the European Communities’ own resources (COM(2014)0704 – C8-0250/2014 – 2014/0332(NLE)) Committee on Budgets.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the Budgets Committee. Madam President, this request for an emergency procedure inspires me to make three points of misunderstanding.  First, during the three weeks of conciliation on the draft 2015 budget and the 2014 amending budgets, the Council was fully mobilised by this issue. He was so mobilized that he was only able to take a position on conciliation a few hours before its closing, and it was under these conditions that conciliation failed. In a way, this issue has cannibalized the Energy and Intelligence of the Council. The second reason for misunderstanding: in the event of this operation, the Commission proposed to allocate an additional 420 million resources related to customs duties and certain other taxes, not to help settle unpaid bills but to return this sum to the Member States of the European Union. Finally, I would like to say that in this area, between retroactivity and urgency, we must choose. Since retroactivity has been chosen, there is no emergency reason.  These are the three reasons for misunderstanding that I wanted to share with our Parliament.

name: President. -
text: We now have two co-rapporteurs on the issue. Sorry, Mr Nart, I did not see you there. You have the floor on a point of order.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, there is a problem, which is that members of Parliament cannot arrive, because traffic is collapsing and, consequently, there are no voluntary absences. There are involuntary absences because, because of the Pope's visit, there has been a collapse of traffic. We are therefore in an incomplete parliamentary session and this is a fundamental issue.

name: President. -
text: Thank you for your point, but there are plenty of colleagues in the Chamber at the moment and I see many more coming in. But I take your point.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I assure you that the Socialists and the Democrats do not sleep later than the others. Matteo Renzi was in a group meeting with us, they will all arrive almost in one block. I wanted to reassure you, Madam President.

name: President. -
text: Thank you for your reassurance. We will continue with the contributions on this voting procedure. We have two co-rapporteurs, and I will first give the floor for one-and-a-half minutes to Mr Deprez.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council is calling for an urgent need to actually allow certain Member States to spread out the payments they should have made before 1 December to the EU budget under the rules they themselves have set themselves. Colleagues, the urgency today is not to grant payment facilities to certain Member States, even if, for some, the pill can be bitter. The urgency today is to approve an EU budget for 2015 that will enable the Union to function properly and to honour the commitments and priorities it has set out. The urgency today is to approve the 2014 amending budgets, an essential step in stabilizing, I mean, stabilizing, not reducing, the amount of unpaid bills which, without it, will reach EUR 30 billion by the end of this year. The urgency today is to agree on a multi-year plan to phase out unpaid debts to avoid the impending suffocation of the Union's budget in the future, either through a drastic reduction in commitment appropriations, which is the wish of some, or by unbearable delays in the liquidation of bills.  The urgency requested by the Council is not justified in any way. To vote urgently would be to give the Council a bonus for taking more care of its internal balances than the credibility of the Union in honouring its commitments.

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this is my supplement to the previous statements to shed light on the content and context of the request for the urgent procedure to amend the regulation on own resources. As Parliament has stated, the real emergency is to address the dramatic shortfall of payments in the European budget in order to meet the legal obligations of the European Union. As for the own resources decision, this was the unanimous decision of the Member States, with revisions which mean overpayment for some and underpayment for other Member States. So far, all the Member States are ready to deliver what they should, in due time and in the full amount. This is a paradox. We are asked for an urgent procedure for the benefit of one or two countries and also for flexibility – there was never flexibility – and for a slow track in delivering what was needed to the European budget in order to solve the problems of the European budget. We are ready to do this – not on a fast-track basis, but in reasonable time and in the framework of the overall solution to the difficulties of the European budget. Honouring the bills of our research institutions, regions and businesses is a matter of principle for Parliament. The credibility of European Union institutions is at stake.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Council has asked for this matter to be treated as an urgent matter: I can also agree that this is an important issue, but this request is unacceptable, both substantively and formally. For about a month now, Parliament and the Council have been discussing the approval of certain amending budgets for 2014 and the EU budget for 2015. In fact, it is perhaps time to put aside this sterile conflict between Parliament and the Council, between our priorities and their responsibilities. What I do not understand is how we do not realise that all these debates have a real impact on the lives of all European citizens, and should therefore be treated with the utmost care and dedication. The Renzi government would like to herald this change in the own resources system as a victory for the Italian Presidency of the EU: we are truly paradoxical, because unfortunately we understand from this issue too that our country counts for very little in Europe, and that it is systematically dictated by others.

name: President. -
text: The next item is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000076/2014 – (2014/2779(RSP)) – B8-0035/2014), – the oral question to the Commission on employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000077/2014 – (2014/2779(RSP)) – B8-0036/2014).

name: Marita Ulvskog
text: questioners. - (C) When the European Parliament decided on the 2020 strategy, there were very high hopes. The crisis would be halted, the financial market would be regulated, jobs would come and welfare would grow. Since then, however, things have gone in the opposite direction. Today, some 25 million people in the EU are out of work. About six million of them are young people, who thus start their adult lives in unemployment. In the wake of the crisis, social security and other social security systems have been eroded, inequalities have increased. The 2020 strategy wanted us to go in the opposite direction, but since 2008 the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased by 10 million, so that today there are over 122 million people in Europe at risk of poverty or are already poor and vulnerable. In our discussions today, but also in the run-up to the Commission's proposal for an investment package, it is therefore important to underline that we must not forget to invest in what can take people out of unemployment and poverty. Of course, we say yes to investment in infrastructure, in research and in a sustainable climate, but we must also invest in education and in increasing the participation of women in the labour market. This requires us to build a functioning childcare system that is universal and accessible to all. We must invest in the integration and inclusion of the people who are furthest from the labour market and, of course, we must do everything to ensure that no young person has to start his life by becoming long-term unemployed. Youth unemployment has reached alarming levels today. It is now over 20%, more than one in five young people in Europe, and we did not believe that when we in this House decided on the 2020 strategy. In some cases we see more jobs being created and more being added, but, unfortunately, the increase in the employment rate has unfortunately proved to be partly the result of an increase in the very precarious and frivolous forms of employment, i.e. zero-hours contracts, bogus self-employment and involuntary part-time. What would become flexibility has become a shackle of insecurity and exploitation. Loosening and abuse of labour law rules mean that people have never really managed to get to solid ground in the labour market in recent years. Among the many who still actually have jobs, over 40% go on temporary contracts, and as many as 25% work part-time. I meet some of these young people who are basically chained to their cell phones, because what if someone calls and offers them a few hours of work. Then they can't miss that call. Thus, increasing economic growth is not in itself a guarantee of more quality jobs, of poverty reduction or of reducing social inequalities. The right political choices must be made in order to achieve these objectives. We must make the internal market work for people so that it serves the life and societies in which we want to live. The benefits of growth must be spread throughout society in order to be sustainable. Otherwise, we are sitting on a ticking bomb of inequality and people's frustration with all the consequences that this entails for both individual life destins and our democratic society as a whole. We can never compete with the world around us by having low wages, poor education, poor precarious working conditions, slave contracts, exploitation, weak trade union rights. We can only compete with being the absolute best at what we do. It requires a great deal of thought and activity in this House.

name: Sandro Gozi
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is certainly an important moment, it is a timely time to discuss the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and to discuss it in those priorities that are fundamental for the rotating Presidency, but are also fundamental to the work, in general, that we are doing in the Council. You know that the review of the 2020 strategy has always been a priority of the Italian Presidency since the beginning of our six-month period, because we believe that this strategy must be relaunched and made more effective and because we believe that there is a dramatic level of economic and social crisis in Europe to which the European institutions must give faster and more effective answers, first and foremost around horizontal strategies , as is the Europe 2020 strategy.  In your question, you have raised a very large number of issues in your work, and that is at the heart of the strategy. The 2020 strategy cannot be linked only to one issue, but touches on many important issues to promote growth, to combat poverty, to create jobs. They range from energy policy to a new knowledge policy, to a sustainable development strategy. These are all issues that are linked horizontally at a time when we are talking about the new Europe 2020 strategy. We wanted to include the debate on mid-term evaluation and the identification of new priorities and the new method and within all the formations of the Council of Ministers. And already this was a choice that was not only of work organizations but is a clear choice of political approach.  We believe that all formations of the Council of Ministers must be active, proactive and should make their contribution to achieving the results of Europe 2020. We cannot continue – and this is a priority that we have generally placed on the functioning of the Council of Ministers, but which is particularly true with regard to the Europe 2020 strategy – we cannot continue to work with a compartmentalised Council. On the one hand, we cannot develop major horizontal, mainstream strategies, which touch on various policies and then have a Council of Ministers that continues to work in compartmentalised areas or that deals with Europe 2020 only in one or two Councils. No, this is the work we have to do, horizontal work. That is why we have discussed the main features of this strategy in all council formations. This work will then be continued and finalised, as you know, by the Latvian Presidency, which will follow the Italian Presidency. There are a number of sticking points from the discussions we have had in the Council. Some firm points that are first and foremost the objectives. We must maintain them and be more effective in achieving the objectives that we have set out in this strategy and that we have not achieved: growth, employment, the fight against poverty. We must be ambitious, we must be more ambitious. There are positive results in some areas, such as education. There have been totally unsatisfactory, I would say very worrying, results, not least as regards the credibility of what we are and the credibility of our work, as regards the fight against poverty, as regards the fight against unemployment. It is clear that we must move forward more decisively and more effectively. The third important message I want to give you is the issue of governance. It is clear that we also need to rethink the way in which the Europe 2020 strategy has been managed, starting with greater alignment of the Europe 2020 strategy and the European Semester. This is another point on which, in the new parliamentary term, I believe that we must make a difference together. We cannot continue in the economic, social and development field to have parallel processes that we meet and sometimes talk to each other from time to time. On the contrary, it is clear that we need to develop in a much more integrated way all those strategies which, in the economic field, tend to achieve the results that you and we want and, above all, the results of job creation and the fight against poverty.  Therefore, we certainly need to work better to integrate the processes that we have developed so far under the Europe 2020 strategy and those that we have carried out within the framework of the European Semester, and this is clearly a work for which we need more dialogue and greater interaction. We are working - some progress has been made and I believe that we need to do much more - to coordinate the work that is being done in Ecofin and the work that is being done in the Employment and Social Affairs Council. We know very well, I do not have to remind this House, that this is also due to a lack of competence, a difference in powers of competence. On the one hand, we have a process managed by the Ecofin Council within the framework of the European Semester, which is made up of binding processes and possibly also sanctions, and on the other hand we are still at the so-called open method of coordination with regard to social aspects of work.  It is clear that there is an imbalance on which we must work and we can begin to work through greater integration of the policies and priorities pursued in the social field and together with the priorities and processes that are already well regulated within Ecofin. This is certainly a very important point.  Just as it is very important – it was also raised by Mr Syley on be it – it is not a question of the european Union. Ulvskog – the theme of the involvement of the social partners. Greater involvement of the social partners is essential for the success and strengthening of the social dimension of the Europe 2020 strategy at national and European level. That is why we wanted to focus precisely on the very subject that we are discussing this morning at the trilateral social summit that we held during our presidency on 23 October. However, the process of consulting the social partners must be more lean in order to be effective. It can't have the long time you've had so far. From this point of view, therefore, we must make the dialogue between the social partners more leaner, more effective and, I would say, more interactive. We cannot limit ourselves to large summits of many hours in a day which then do not have the effect they must have in the impact on the process as a whole. The other very important issue on which we need to do more and which we have identified as a priority is the evaluation of employment and social indicators. It is certainly a step forward, it is a good starting point. Let us now give greater visibility to employment and social aspects. In addition to this visibility, more effective concrete actions will also be needed.  In the same way, we must make a much more determined commitment to gender equality. It is clear that the role of women in the labour market is part of one of those great objectives that we must continue to pursue within the Europe 2020 strategy after its review next spring. I would also like to refer to a letter signed by 22 ministers insisting on this issue, stressing the need for gender equality to be reflected more strongly in the revised strategy. We as presidency have fully supported the initiative of these 22 ministers. In conclusion, Mr President, because I want to make room and listen to the speeches, I would like to remind you of the subject of investment, the issue of growth, rehabilitation, structural reforms and investment. I am absolutely convinced that the real response to the fight against poverty, together with all the things I have just mentioned, is a new investment policy. A new investment policy which, in our view, we will see tomorrow, and the idea of the investment plan, an idea which was the view of the Italian Presidency and which Mr Juncker wanted to take on his own and which he will present tomorrow, so I cannot comment today on a plan that will be presented tomorrow. But, it seems to me, we wanted a fresh start, we wanted a whole new start. Juncker has committed to a new start, a new beginning. We believe that the investment plan is a good start, it is a positive start to develop an investment policy that must concern European policies around that plan, in particular the Europe 2020 strategy, but it must also concern national policies that must be consistent with the new choice, which we are making at European level, to aim to do what Europe has not wanted or been able to do in recent years.  What has been lacking in recent years has been an active European demand policy, active for growth, through investment. We now have this new priority and this is the real response to the fight against poverty, to job creation: public investment and private investment. Tomorrow we will have a debate in this House in which the Presidency will also take part, but this, Mr President, is certainly the most concrete, most tangible and comprehensible response for our citizens that we as the European Union can give.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, since the Europe 2020 strategy was adopted, we have indeed been moving away from the EU’s headline employment and social targets. For instance, the number of people living in or at risk of poverty has increased by more than 6 million. The economic and financial crisis has taken its toll: social hardship and the rise in equality call into question the fairness and effectiveness of our social market economy. However, the crisis should not make us overlook long-term social structural issues. It is accepted now that more and smarter investment in jobs, growth and competitiveness is needed. For this reason, the Commission will present a EUR 300 billion investment plan, which should mobilise money for much-needed projects to support job creation and improve living standards. I am happy that the Council has already welcomed this wholeheartedly. As regards progress towards the Europe 2020 targets, the modernisation of national labour markets and social protection systems is crucial. The European Semester with the country-specific recommendations is a key venue for calling on the Member States to make good on their commitments and deliver on their targets. The Multiannual Financial Framework supports this ambition. A greater share – at least 23% – of cohesion policy funding has been ring-fenced for the European Social Fund, of which at least 20% will be specifically allocated to promoting social inclusion and combating poverty. The globalisation fund and the fund for the most deprived can also contribute to the employment and social targets. They support workers made redundant to find jobs, and they help the most deprived maintain a level of decency. Both the existence and the distribution of these financial instruments were only secured with the very outspoken support of the European Parliament. The Youth Unemployment Initiative has been frontloaded in the first two years of the programming period, and we are working with the Member States to get the funding on the ground. As to the new Commission, there is an explicit agreement that employment and social policies and the related indicators need to be better taken into account in the European Semester. Indeed, they need to be better coordinated with economic and fiscal policies. As President Juncker said, social fairness is as important as the stability of the single currency and the solidity of public finances. We must – and we will – also work more closely with social partners. As to the Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission is analysing the results of the public consultation, and it will present its follow-up in spring 2015.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The credibility of the EU 2020 targets is at stake. Instead of 20 million fewer people, there are now seven million more people affected by poverty and social exclusion. It does not work to agree ambitious targets for job creation or poverty reduction, while at the same time enscribing strict savings to Member States. The reality in Europe shows that this is not working. We must not use crises as excuses. Rather, they must be an incentive for more ambition to achieve the objectives. It is time for the social and employment objectives to be made binding on the Member States. As well as economic and financial policies, social and employment objectives need to be reviewed in the context of the European Semester. As has already been said, we urgently need investment, including social investment, and it is essential that they lead to good, decent, decently paid jobs. People are calling for a more social Europe, otherwise they will turn away. They expect good work from Europe, they expect a social dimension and a Europe that has no less focus on the interests of the people than on the interests of corporations and banks. We will only achieve this if we take the social and employment objectives seriously, just as seriously as economic objectives.

name: President. -
text: Colleagues, we are running very late on this debate, which is a function of a slightly late start, and I know Mr Etheridge has indicated a blue card. I am going to make a ruling that we will not take blue cards in this debate because of our time schedules with the address of His Holiness the Pope, so thank you for your understanding on that issue.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her That is where I want to start. Money and the market must serve us, not rule over us. This quote is not of me, it is from Pope Francis, whom we can welcome in a few minutes in this House as a special guest of honour, hopefully giving impetus. However, his quote also fits with the ongoing debate on the mid-term review and the social significance of the Europe 2020 strategy. The market must serve the people. I believe that the report gives a very good impetus here. Some of them come from the pen of the ECR. Firstly, we want the EU 2020 strategy to take into account and promote the potential of young people. We need the entrepreneurial courage of the young generation, who shoulder the economic and social benefits of the future. Work does not create politics, work creates small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurs. Secondly, we want the EU 2020 strategy to emphasise red-tape policy even more than before, less bureaucracy. This must apply to businesses, but it must also apply to all citizens, to families: less bureaucracy, more identity. Thirdly, Europe's competitiveness needs healthy sustainable demographic development. We need young people, and young people need family. So far, this demographic factor has been far too short. All in all, my group will vote against the report today because it often goes too far, provoking inefficiencies. Our message to the citizens and the new EU Commission is: no debate, no lamentation, no texts, but deeds!

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, last March the Commission produced a document which took stock of progress on the EU2020 Strategy, and the document itself makes very sobering reading. We are informed that levels of private debt among households and companies – already high in some Member States – have increased significantly during the crisis. It points to rising levels of unemployment and poverty, with the long-term unemployed – those out of work for more than one year – increasing by over 80% between 2008 and 2012. Now there are some positives in the report, in that the share of young people in tertiary education has increased and the percentage of early school leavers has dropped. But equally, the share of NEETs – at 13% in 2012 – is a major source of concern. Alarmingly, it also points out that, although significant inequalities already existed in some Member States prior to the crisis, those divergences have amplified both within and between Member States. From a social perspective it warns that, while GDP and wealth have marginally increased overall, the crisis has constrained redistributive effects. So, on my part at least, all of this gives rise to a growing alarm – even panic – at what is happening across the EU, a continent that I believe is fracturing economically and politically. Those of us who support the EU as an entity need to find ways to help and support Member States to deal with this immense challenge. Some of the challenges are fiscal – are debt-related – and while they are crucial, we are not discussing them here this morning. This morning we are trying to see how we can strengthen the employment and social aspects of the EU2020 Strategy. Even though citizens will not see an immediate impact, if we can find agreement on proposals to help Member States achieve those targets, then I believe we will have done valuable work. So that is why we welcome, for the first time, the use on the scoreboard of key employment and social indicators such as child poverty levels, access to health care and homelessness. But crucially, we ask that the scoreboard be used as an early warning mechanism in order to develop suitable policies, otherwise we are just number-crunching, we are box-ticking, and that is less than useless. We also ask that employment and social considerations be put on a par with macroeconomic ones. I personally support this proposal. I know there are issues about a legal base, but I want to ask the Commissioner: What is your view on this, how do you see the possibilities of rebalancing the economic and the social, how can we make it real rather than just talking about it? This is not just about spending money. Yes, we will have the details of Juncker’s package tomorrow, but we need to be sure first of all that it is growth-friendly investment, and secondly that there is a redistributive effect from this growth. So I am asking the Commissioner: How specifically do you propose to deliver on those objectives? I was interested to hear the Council speaking earlier about integrating the 2020 objectives into the European Semester. You said yourself there is an imbalance there. We need to see how to get rid of that imbalance. Finally, job creation is crucial, and in that, ALDE strongly supports the elimination of bureaucracy and unnecessary burdens for SMEs. But equally, we must target decent jobs. I agree with my colleague Casa: it is crucial to address the abuse of vulnerable people.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, there is no point here in multiplying the rhetoric of lamentation which in fact reveals the failure of European policies: they must be changed.  Social objectives must stop being wishful thinking and the remnants of economic policies; on the contrary, economic efficiency stems from choices of social and ecological efficiency of human well-being. We cannot hope to make progress towards more jobs without a development project, without getting out of austerity, without a credit policy of the European Central Bank that must first serve the real economy and work. Experience shows that flexible work does not create jobs, it develops social insecurity and creates poor workers. The future of a new human European project depends on debate and decisions here to invent a system of security in employment and lifelong learning, with a top priority for young people. Similarly, we will not reduce poverty without defending public services, without improving social protections instead of destroying them, without a minimum income within the European Union and without the incentive to create a guaranteed minimum wage in each country.  The reorientation of the 2020 strategy must be clear in order to consider education, social protection, public employment services as priority investments, the preservation of the climate and the ecological transition of productive systems as priority guidelines, which should no longer be taken into account in budgetary calculations on deficits.  More fundamentally, we propose to include in the work programme of Parliament, the Commission and the Council the draft of a new initiative which would be a European pact for human development, social and ecological progress by otherwise mobilising the European Investment Bank and the European Central Bank.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, today we are looking at the employment and social aspects of the EU 2020 strategy, but our resolution also reminds us that the strategy is designed to cover three elements: the smart, the sustainable and the inclusive. If we are not bearing all three parts in mind, as our resolution recalls, we are not actually going to be moving forward, because it is that integration and cooperation which gives us that direction. We are also very clear that the search for growth is not an end in itself. It is more about political choices to reduce inequalities and to tackle poverty. The benefits need to be spread throughout society and not just concentrated in the hands of those that are already rich. It is clear that we are moving away from what, in our view, were already pretty unambitious poverty reduction targets. But it is also clear that work in itself is not the answer. If you look, for example, at the report of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation which was published yesterday in the UK, 50% of those in the UK who are in poverty or at risk of poverty are in work. Social security benefits are important; they are a key stabiliser, and they actually give people a base from which to be able to move forward. As others have also been saying, the quality of work – decent work, a job you can build a life on – is also a key element of a job-rich recovery and this strategy. So we do need to look at the abusive practices that we have. We need to look at the way in which people are working many, many hours and still actually cannot afford to live a decent life. It is not enough for us to end the biting austerity measures – which have had such a destructive effect on so many lives – if we are not engaged in a socially-just transition which is going to tackle inequality and move us towards a low-carbon economy, which is also part of the EU 2020 strategy. The issue of bureaucracy and administration costs for businesses is important, but removing that does not necessarily give you a better society with decent work either. You have to look at the outcome of what you are doing. We very much welcome the Council’s words about the balancing of the social and economic dimension, because we think that the reaction to the financial crisis has been one of stand-alone economics and that it has not taken into account the need to actually develop people’s lives. So, yes, we would agree that new investment is needed, but we should not forget – as the Commissioner has said – that we need to make the money that we are already spending through the structural funds – including the social fund – work properly. Parliament has an oversight role there too. And finally I also very much welcome the words of the Council on the reference to governance. It is not just about social partners and the engagement of local and regional authorities; civil society also has a key role to play in this area, and it needs to be there as part of the discussion as well as part of the delivery.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against poverty and marginalisation is a key aspect of the Europe 2020 strategy, as is job creation, but if there is no job, citizens must still be guaranteed a decent life. That is why it is necessary to break up work and income, and that is precisely what citizenship income is for.  In Italy, we in the 5-star Movement have proposed a citizenship income that we want to export to Europe, so that a minimum monthly fixed income is a right of any European citizen. This is not a welfare measure but a form of legal civilisation that pays for itself and that guarantees the weakest at a time when work can no longer do so. Many European countries have already implemented such a measure, but in Italy our proposal has been mocked. But instead of stopping, we decided to think big and suggest it here in the European Parliament, where you received the support of the European Commissioner for Labour, Marianne Thyssen, during her hearing.  In order to give concrete form to the solidarity dimension of Europe, we must therefore give economic and monetary union a social pillar and raise social objectives to the same level as economic objectives. In order to achieve the eu 2020 strategy's poverty-fighting objective, we need an income of European citizenship.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Madam President, I would like to draw attention to point w of the report, which clearly points out that the income gap between Member States would not only decrease, as we were promised, for example, to Hungarians when asked whether we wanted to join the Union. So not only do these differences diminish, they grow specifically. Point (w) points out that there are fivefold income differences, which is about right as well. A Hungarian nurse, firefighter, factory worker or department store salesman earns at least five times less than, say, up to 50 km away in Austria in the same occupations. My question is very simple, and I hope that the Hungarian people and the people of the peripheral countries will finally get a straight answer. I ask the representative of the Commission and the Council: what concrete measures do you wish to take to reduce or eliminate the burning income gap between the centre and the peripheral countries, the old and the new Member States, east and west?

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. This resolution, as a kind of early response to the EPSCO Council in November, very clearly defines the position of the majority of the Employment Committee in the European Parliament. It demonstrates dissatisfaction with the status quo and reiterates our call for even more effective measures to be taken to address the alarmingly high levels of unemployment, youth unemployment and the risk of poverty in the EU. It is obvious that too little is still happening! In particular, it is up to those Member States that are not determined enough to take the reform course. I highlight a number of areas: in particular vocational training for secure employability, the Youth Guarantee, the qualification of older workers, the creation of efficient labour market administrations and the necessary structures for small and medium-sized enterprises. It is time for benchlearning to become a binding political principle within the Union. It doesn't always have to be reinvented. Member States should make successful examples from other countries their political premise.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D). -
text: Madam President,  (beginning of speech inaudible as microphone switched off) the Commission coming from this House and welcome to the very promising Italian Presidency. One of the central targets of the Europe 2020 Strategy is to raise the employment rate to 75%. We are very far from this and we know that, in order to reach this target, we have to create more than 16 million jobs by 2020. So far this is not working. We need to recognise this. Job destruction is now more important than job creation, and we need to reverse this trend. This is a huge task, which I believe is not only for labour market policies but for a comprehensive and balanced strategy in which economic, social and fiscal policies are combined. I believe that in order to reverse this trend we need to raise European demand by proper economic coordination. We need to have this big push for investment in forward-looking areas and we need to complete economic and monetary union in order to reduce the economic and social divergences which are there. We need to make sure that all Member States have the necessary conditions to implement the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR). -
text: Madam President, in this review I think we must really focus on areas where the EU can add real value in helping Member States achieve the 2020 targets. I am happy to see some of our ECR amendments included in the text. It is so important that we improve the leadership and the management and the entrepreneurial skills among young people so that young people can actually start their own businesses; they can become employers and not just employees. I started my first business when I was 22, and there are others in this House that started businesses in their teens. I think that there is no shortage of ideas and inventions across Europe. Do you know that in the United Kingdom – my country – four thousand inventions are copyrighted every year, and three-quarters of them come from Birmingham and the West Midlands region? So let us make sure that these innovations can lead to real businesses and real jobs by enabling those young people to have those entrepreneurial skills.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe 2020 strategy can only lead Europe to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth if it begins to attach more importance to social and employment objectives.  We note, however, that the five ambitious objectives set for 2020 are education and social inclusion, which have been the least attention to the Union institutions and the Member States, and which, on this floor, will hardly be achieved by 2020. The truth is that, so far, the strategy for exiting the crisis has met fiscal consolidation criteria, leaving behind measures aimed at stimulating economic growth.  In this battle, social cohesion and the fight against unemployment are the main victims. Iniquity between Member States is clearly visible and continues to increase. Europe cannot continue to operate at two speeds. We have to create more jobs, we have to put an end to job insecurity, we have to create more decent jobs, the internal market has to be a reality for the future of Europe. We can't wait any longer. It is imperative to implement the programme for jobs, growth and investment that Mr Juncker will present in this House tomorrow.  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has to invest more vigorously in the areas of physical and human capital, innovation and technological development, and this necessarily involves more effective support from the Union for the Member States.  There is a new generation that feels it has no future in Europe. They finish their school run to thicken the unemployment queues. Europe is getting old, its young people are fleeing and they will rejuvenate other continents. Ms Thyssen rightly said that the funds for globalisation and for the most unprotected have to be more carefully managed. That's true, but that's just not enough. We must provide the business fabric of the Member States with effective support mechanisms and instruments. We need to improve access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, as they create jobs and sustain the economy, as well as focus more heavily on competitiveness factors in order to promote real sustainable reindustrialisation. I believe that the only way we have left to go is precisely that of a stronger, smarter, more supportive and inclusive investment. The Europeans can't take it anymore and they won't wait any longer.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President! There are currently over 24 million unemployed in the EU. More than one in five young people are unemployed and in some countries youth unemployment is over 50%. At the same time, the number of people who have a job but are still poor is increasing. It is increasing because people are increasingly being pressured into accepting jobs they cannot live on. Yes, some people even have two jobs, but they still can't afford the day and the road.  Today, more than 122 million people in the EU are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. For particularly vulnerable groups such as people with disabilities, the poverty rate is 70% higher than the average. Inequality between rich and poor is on the rise. In 2012, the top fifth earned five times as much as the bottom fifth. In other words, this is not a success story.  If jobs are to be created for people to live on and if poverty is to be combated, it requires, first and foremost, a showdown with the eu's current policy. This requires a showdown with the EU's policy of cuts, with the EU's one-sided focus on competitiveness. This requires a showdown focusing on economic growth, without the recognition that the whole of society should benefit from growth.  There's other buns on the soup. We need better and more jobs at the heart of it, and we must recognise that labour markets and welfare communities are very different in EU countries. Therefore, it does not make sense that one solution should suit everyone. We owe it to citizens to make room for each Member State to invest in jobs and welfare. That's what's needed.

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President! I come from local politics, and I would like to tell you how much I have seen the Europe 2020 objectives as progress, especially in my daily work compared to the previous Lisbon Strategy. Quantifiable targets for employment, for equality, for education, for the fight against poverty: the importance of these issues cannot be overstated, and I think that brings us a considerable step closer to economic and social cohesion in Europe and is an important contribution to a more social Europe. Because I believe that the citizens need this social Europe. We need a social union, especially as a counterweight to economic and monetary union. It is precisely the citizens who must no longer see Europe as a vehicle for austerity or the assertion of neoliberal interests, but must also see Europe as a guarantor of social rights and their personal social rights. However, as we have heard, the reality is different. There is record unemployment, life-saving jobs are already becoming a luxury, women are often deported to involuntary part-time work, and in many Member States young people are already talking about a so-called lost generation. This is an alarming state of affairs. I am not really surprised that we are sitting here today talking about the failure to achieve the Europe 2020 targets. We have a fundamental design flaw in the whole matter. Anyone who believes that austerity can combat poverty or create jobs must go astray, and that must fail. We need a holistic approach to reform, a change of course away from austerity policy, a reform of the Stability and Growth Pact and a rethinking of our crisis-fighting policy to date, which has not actually fought the crisis at all, but has exacerbated it even further, especially for the most vulnerable. I think that this resolution, which we are adopting together today, is a very important step, because it brings a holistic, broad approach to combating poverty, how to create sustainable growth and green jobs. There is also talk of a reform of economic and monetary union, of the importance of public services, of the need to involve civil society in social Europe. I think this is a very broad and important resolution with the aim of inclusive and inclusive growth. Social Europe must not continue to be an empty promise for Europe's citizens.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, if I could sum up the Europe 2020 programme so far, I think it would be with one word, and that would be ‘shambles’. If it was not such a serious subject it would be a joke. Your headline targets of 75% of 20 to 64 year olds being in employment, and of wanting 20 million fewer people at risk of poverty, are looking a little bit shaky, aren’t they? I would urge you to have a tour of southern Europe and ask how it is getting on. This top-down model of EU control backed by billions being thrown at every crackpot project you can think of is helping absolutely nobody. The money would be better spent by accountable politicians in our own countries. The UK currently gives GBP 55 million a day to the EU, while it is cutting back frontline public services and jobs. It is as an absolute disgrace, and this, added to all the red tape and bureaucracy that the EU spews out, holds back the economy and businesses from creating jobs and growth. It is the EU that is responsible for this lack of growth. But this sums up the EU because whatever it touches goes bad; its targets are missed and its rules are either broken or, even worse, ignored.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI). -
text: Madam President, employment for everyone, regardless of age, training, quality or education, is an absolute right. It is work that gives a place in society and, therefore, a dignity for oneself as well as in the eyes of others. One of the foundations of the Union should have been a job for all and not a currency for all.  Of the three scenarios developed in 2010, we are in the lost decade. Forgotten recovery and slow growth, you agree yourself. The employment rate in Europe has not increased in ten years, growth is zero, all because the employment that allows everyone to exist and consume has been systematically flouted. It was designed only as a tool, a variable for adapting profits. The whole human dimension has been erased, and the 2008 crisis was only a sign of the structural failure of European integration. The ever-increasing and more restrictive regulations have ended up stifling SMEs and big business alike, and President Juncker's $300 billion is likely to get stuck in Santa's hood. The right to work, not labour law, is the only key to growth.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I heard the Council's proactive speech this morning, but I have not forgotten the battles we have had to fight in order to preserve the European Social Fund as a priority instrument for entering professional life.  I have not forgotten that we also had to fight against the Heads of State or Government to preserve 20% of the European Social Fund in order to fight poverty. So I can see that progress has been made, but I think today the ball is really in your court because I heard the mobilization of Mrs Thyssen — our Commissioner on the subject. I believe that what we need today is for you to mobilise member states on operational programmes and action on the ground.  Yes, the programmes are there, we have to take action, we have to judge your commitment to future results, and we will be very attentive.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, the Europe 2020 Strategy was a political commitment to which the European Union and the Member States aligned the objectives of creating jobs, quality employment and eradicating poverty on our continent. Today that strategy is wet paper. The sum of economic prescriptions in the face of crisis, economic austerity and structural reforms has dynamited the Europe 2020 Strategy. And it has done so because we have repeatedly confused europe's policies to get out of the crisis with the policies that citizens needed to pass fairly during the economic crisis. And how can we get closer to those goals again, Mrs. Thyssen? Because, of course, I agree with you, with your big headlines, with the social triple A to which Mr Juncker refers, with putting at the same level the efficiency of the euro and the sustainability of our social model. The problem is that the Commission has the power of the fine print. And it has it with the mechanism of the European Semester, with which you, the European Commission, have been promoting, through your structural reforms, that labour poverty become structural; that millions of workers today, even if they have a job, fail to make it to the end of the month. They have made labor precariousness structural. Inequality has become structural. This week you have the opportunity to show us that the European Commission wants to change and regain the path of the Europe 2020 Strategy for the European Union as a whole with the annual growth study. Present us with binding social indicators. Present us with European minimum wages. Present us with a strategy to recover the social model.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR). -
text: This motion for a resolution draws attention to the importance of not forgetting the social aspects and social rights of workers when designing economic strategies for the future. Today, in the wake of a crisis that has particularly affected southern European countries, we are aware of how often fundamental social rights are being violated, how often the costs of reform are borne by the poorest, the weakest. However, I would like to remind you that this has already happened before, without provoking an adequate response, when the countries of Central and Eastern Europe were transforming, integrating into the Union.  In connection with today's visit by Pope Francis, I would like to remind you to recommend to read again, especially to colleagues on the left of the chamber, the great encyclicals of the predecessor, John Paul II, Labor Exercens, Centesimus Annus, Sollicitudo Rei Socialis. If Europe were built on this foundation, we would have avoided many problems and injustices and we would not have to talk about the Juncker system today. Thank you very much.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE). -
text: Thank you, Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her thorough work. Employment and social affairs are one of the key elements of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to ensure inclusive growth. We stand by efforts to secure employment for 75% of the European Union's population aged 20 to 64, reduce the share of early school leavers below 10%, and reduce the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million.  But at the same time, we realize that Europe's biggest scourge remains unemployed young people. In March 2014, there were nearly 5,340,000 young people under the age of 25 unemployed in the European Union. We cannot expect young people to participate in Europe's political life when they are unemployed. Among other European Union mechanisms, small and medium-sized enterprises are one of the main tools for successfully tackling youth unemployment. They have significant job creation potential and play a crucial role in the transition to a new sustainable economy. That is why I would like to emphasise the need to create an environment conducive to small and medium-sized enterprises by providing easier access to credit, removing unnecessary administrative barriers and, of course, the need for their connectivity and internationalisation. I therefore call on the European Commission: - to promote mobility mechanisms, in particular the European Job Mobility Portal. A number of studies have shown that mobile labour brings benefits to both parties. The European Commission estimates that 2 million jobs in the European Union cannot be filled due to low mobility; - to support the formation of cooperation with the private sector, as well as to ensure the link between education and the labour market.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, we cannot really be surprised at the non-achievement of the targets set out in the 2020 Strategy. Let us see, a strategy that places flexibility in labor relations, that is, precariousness and insecurity for workers as a guiding matrix throughout the document, this strategy can never combat unemployment.  We all know, or at least those who go through this, the thousands and millions of young people in Europe know that every contract with a precarious relationship has as its horizon more or less immediate an unemployment situation. Recent studies by the European Commission confirm: part-time work and temporary contracts have increased and make up a large part of so-called new jobs.  But let us be honest, is that not the real objective of the European Union in order to satisfy economic monopolies? It is that, if it is not, they have to explain why it was precisely the recommendations to the countries in the framework of the European Semester, as well as the troika memoranda, as the European Commission itself confirms, to impose changes to collective procurement systems in at least 12 countries in recent years. Yes, the number of collective agreements of signed work that protect workers has decreased dramatically in recent years, because governments and the European Commission and the European Union have imposed it.  The struggles of workers, strikes multiply in every country every day and it is this struggle that will demonstrate who really has the real strength.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD). -
text: Today, we will talk again about the Europe 2020 strategy, and life will apparently go back to its furrows as it has gone on and gone. The reduction of social exclusion and various measures have been repeatedly addressed in the Lisbon Strategy, but the objectives set have not been achieved. Poverty and social exclusion are increasingly starving the eye, and this cannot only be seen blindly. Millions of people in Europe live below the poverty line. I believe that I am convinced that a common criterion for a single person's minimum income must be established in the countries of the European Union, and that minimum income should be guaranteed by a special European fund, the establishment of which could be a concern of the Commission. The Commission could also take a legislative initiative to set a minimum wage corresponding to the standard of living throughout the European Union.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: Madam President, the resolution and strategy 2020 of the European Union and the urban governments for a weak labour force and for gains in capital call for subsidies and the transfer of taxes and contributions from employers to the people who pay with savage taxes and by reducing wages, pensions and social benefits. The generalisation of flexible underpaid work divides unemployment among more. There is: submission of education to business planning; unpaid work with training and apprenticeship programmes; a generalised poverty line with a minimum guaranteed income; social partnership and dialogue between employers and employers' trade unions in order to get through the process; implementation of this policy with permanent supervision and memoranda for all Member States. On the pretext of unemployment, they are also tearing up unemployed young people and workers. This policy cannot have social aspects; is a cause of war in the capital, in the European Union and in the parties that support and beautify it. The general strike on 27 November in Greece will provide an answer.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE). -
text: Madam President! 16 million people in the EU are expected to find work in the next few years. We want and must achieve one of the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy: an employment rate of 75%. To achieve this, we need an active employment and social policy, in addition to strengthening competitiveness and stimulating investment. In his candidacy speech to us in the European Parliament, Jean-Claude Juncker called for social fairness not to be neglected. Agree! We must weigh the social impact of structural reforms. But it would be wrong to play off social objectives against the consolidation of national budgets. The rebalancing required must not call this principle into question. I consider the introduction of an EU unemployment insurance scheme to be problematic. Taxpayers cannot be financially involved for the unemployed in other countries. We do not have a single labour market, we do not have collective agreements valid throughout Europe and we do not yet have a central EU employment agency. We are against a transfer union. However, I welcome employment and social indicators as useful tools for identifying facts. They must not create automatisms that free them from the consolidation efforts mentioned above at national level. These are ultimately worthwhile for a real opportunity for the future of workers.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D). -
text: Madam President, poverty is on the rise across Europe. This is a fact, even in countries that say or seem to be doing well. For example, in Germany, poverty has never increased as much as in the last ten years compared to the Second World War. So we can see that this is a global phenomenon.  I would like to reflect on the notion of structural reform that we are constantly focusing on, because the flexibilization and precariousness of labour markets and social systems leads to the increase in the working poor and therefore real poverty.  I believe that the report before us is an act of lucidity that advocates a new model of development based on the real well-being of citizens, and not just on flattering statistics that, in fact, do not reflect reality. I would like to end with what was said by our colleague from the EPP Group. On the contrary, a European unemployment insurance system which would not, I was to say, be daily, but which would simply be there in exceptional moments, would precisely reduce poverty and not fight it in a sustainable way for ten years.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, I would like to thank Mrs Thyssen for her excellent work on this If I had planned to save the EU project or the Euro project at all costs, I might have designed the Europe 2020 strategy in a similar way. It is ambitious, but it will fail. The Commission's March stocktaking takes into account three growth paths. The first shows strong growth, the second low growth and the third stagnation. In southern Europe, however, we are actually seeing recession, laboriously covered by trickery by statisticians. Since the beginning of the euro crisis – and the Europe 2020 strategy is a direct response – no change has been achieved in Europe. The Europe 2020 strategy, originally designed to combat the crisis in the short term, is becoming the strategy of the permanent institutionalised crisis. And why do all these concepts fail? The key problem is the euro, the excessive public and private debt and the loss of competitiveness and industry in southern Europe. As the European Commission talks about smart growth... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I note, in most speeches, the recognition of a failure. Stable and quality employment is not created and poverty and inequality are increasing, especially in the states intervened or subject to the supervision of the European institutions. The Commission and the Council already know that their policies are the cause of rising inequality, unemployment, precariousness and misery. They know, therefore, that new social objectives, while necessary, will not be met if they continue to be subjected to fiscal austerity and job unprotection. Faced with the temptation to offer patches that become failures, such as the Youth Guarantee Programme, Europe 2020 must be rethrated as a whole. The role of the European institutions is to coordinate and not replace the democratic initiative of the Member States, allowing them flexibility to increase social spending, public investment, labour rights and fair labour sharing. Otherwise, Europe 2020 only reinforces the neoliberal order responsible for the crisis.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, in March 2000, EU Heads of State and Government agreed on an ambitious goal: making the EU the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world; the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-driven economy by 2010, capable of sustainable economic growth with more and better jobs and greater social cohesion – and where are we now? A huge crisis in the EU after this brilliant idea of the Lisbon Strategy. So what are we going to create now? Of course, a new strategy! The EU is again promising a golden future, but after all these strategies we have the proof already: this House failed with these strategies, wasting money – wasting other people’s money, tax money. You do not even have the people in Europe behind you. Less than 43% voted in the last election. But as a Socialist, of course, it is very easy to spend other people’s money.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has been talking about strategy for decades. It did so in the past when it emphatically launched the Lisbon Strategy, it did so again when it launched the 2020 strategy with equal emphasis, a miracle cure that should have guided everyone out of the crisis by the end of the decade.  Today, not even halfway through, the failure of Europe 2020 is before everyone's eyes. This is what Eurostat says, certifying 25 million unemployed citizens and 120 million citizens at risk of poverty. The unemployed and entrepreneurs in crisis say so. Lisbon and Europe 2020 are just empty and useless words.  If Europe really wants to help its citizens, it must be ready to make courageous choices. It must put European citizens at the centre of its policies first and all, not banks, finance and multinationals. It must loosen the absurd parameters of the wrong treaties. To say that the euro has failed and brought our economy to its knees. If Europe is not in a position to propose solutions, but rather knows how to create problems, it is better to declare the European project bankrupt and to start from scratch with a new Europe.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the economic circumstances we have suffered have prevented us from moving towards the social objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. However, from the European Union we cannot and should not be discouraged. Nor can we fall into the mistake of thinking that the Europe 2020 Strategy has failed or that the European Union does not ensure the well-being of its citizens and only looks for economic growth. It is true that tough measures have been taken, but they have been taken to ensure the sustainability and viability of the Union as a whole, thus avoiding a situation that would have been much worse. Today, despite the difficulties, Member States can and should focus their efforts on achieving all those ambitious objectives, which are the basis of this strategy. This is the time to renew your efforts and move on. Our objectives have to be to preserve the welfare and job creation state. That is, to show citizens that they are our priority. President Juncker's growth plan will help, I am convinced, to achieve this, but we cannot forget that the ones that actually create jobs are SMEs, and I hope that within the Employment, Growth and Investment Package all those measures we are calling for for them will be clearly contemplated.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no point in hiding the fact that the social and employment dimension of the Europe 2020 strategy, which should have led Europe towards strong inclusive growth, must necessarily be reviewed, if not rethought.  Its objectives have sadly remained on paper as the economic crisis looms. The recipes put into practice by the EU in recent years and by the Member States have in some cases even made the situation worse. It is therefore urgent to reinvest, because this is what it is all about: an investment in the social dimension of the Union, which must necessarily move from the relaunch in the European Council of that social pillar (as defined in the document of the four Presidents) towards a genuine economic and monetary union, as well as the review of the Union's spending policies within the framework of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. It is a disgrace that the last financial framework was cut for the first time in history, given the circumstances. The situation of the debate on the 2015 budget, which is still stalled, is also depressing. New instruments will therefore have to be put in place to deal with the increasingly obvious socio-economic polarisation from which our economy is suffering, both within the individual Member States and at European level. In order to have a social Europe of triple A, it is necessary to create automatic stabilization mechanisms capable of dealing with these macroeconomic and social imbalances. The survival of the single currency is at stake, and fortunately the Italian Presidency has put this issue on the agenda.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR). -
text: Mr. President, I share my concerns about the increase in the number of unemployed and the growth of poverty in the European Union and the growing disparities between Member States. Achieving our employment and poverty reduction objectives must indeed be a priority for us.  But I do not believe that we will come to this by increasing the regulatory burden, which to date is stifling small and medium-sized enterprises that are carriers of economic growth and whose stability and good business are the main impulse for employment. A good part of colleagues advocate higher social benefits to combat poverty, while demanding a rejection of fiscal consolidation.  The Croatian example shows that without fiscal consolidation and tax relief for businesses, any impact is absent, because the closure of private companies leads to a budget deficit that would only deepen unrealistically high social benefits. This is not a path to equality or prosperity, but to debt bondage.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to achieve the objective of combating poverty in the 2020 strategy, we need an income of European citizenship. It can no longer be argued that these measures are exclusively the responsibility of the nation states. Europe must take responsibility for its citizens and not think exclusively about budgetary rules. Citizenship income would clearly have added value if achieved on a European scale, because it would be an excellent stabiliser of asymmetric shocks that since we have the euro can no longer be absorbed by varying the exchange rate.  I would like to see a Europe where social objectives are just as important as budgetary objectives. My colleagues and I will work hard to achieve a Europe with an income of citizenship. A Europe that is actively concerned with social objectives. A Europe that imposes measures against social exclusion and poverty rather than imposing cuts and sacrifices. I call on the Commission to take an active part in this issue, because yes, it would be a Europe to be proud of.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI). -
text: Madam President, as is evident from the indications so far, the economic programme of the European Union's 2020 strategy risks being brought to failure because the measures it proposes have an adverse effect on the societies of almost all the Member States of the European Union. Youth unemployment has skyrocketed everywhere but especially in the countries of the European South. The situation is even worse in my own country, Greece, whose people are suffering from the austerity measures imposed on them by the implementation of the Memorandums. The destruction of the primary sector, the destruction of small and medium-sized enterprises, the lack of investment, the restriction and lack of social policy, the restriction of jobs, the medieval working conditions and the entry of migrants from third countries have created an unacceptable state of poverty in the once prosperous Europe. This is because the people who draw up these programmes are bureaucrats... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE). -
text: Thank you very much for the floor of the honourable President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner Thyssenova. When we adopted the objectives for the future, The Strategy 2020, we were very optimistic and ambitious. However, in this situation, when some countries have not yet recovered from the economic crisis, we have distanced ourselves from these objectives, but we must not forget them. Such a high youth unemployment rate is unacceptable for a developed Europe, so all policies in Europe must be aimed at making changes in this area and we must once again secure the future for young people. Social and social policy are, of course, very important elements, but a healthy economy is equally important, which only brings us new jobs. We must therefore focus our efforts on ensuring healthy conditions for the economy. It is also a fact that those countries that have successfully implemented structural reforms are on a better path to achieve their objectives more quickly. However, of course, we do not want a two-speed Europe, so it is important that we come together here too. And there's one thing that seems to me to be of paramount importance. In this time when we are doing well, sometimes we forget our fundamental values on which Europe is built, and we must bear that in mind when we implement our social policy.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D). -
text: The EU is the largest economy in the world and yet poverty is still widespread. Many Europeans do not even make ends meet with their income even with a paid job. Poverty, including among workers, must be stopped as soon as possible.  And, Commissioner, three questions: 1. What actions are you going to take to ensure that the social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are on par with the fiscal objectives, so that Member States will step up their efforts to boost employment and reduce poverty? 2. The Juncker Commission's credo is jobs and growth, but how are you, as Commissioner for Social Affairs, going to ensure that they are also decent jobs with a living wage and good working conditions?  3. The Commission shares my view that in order to combat in-work poverty there are quickly and effectively ...  [The President deprives speaker of the floor].

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Madam President! Today we are talking about the 2020 strategy to combat unemployment, a ten-year plan. Our plan states that unemployment in the EU is 10%. What does this figure say? I ask them something else: how warm was it yesterday in Europe? In Vilnius, they will say: minus 3 degrees. And in Palma de Mallorca it was 23 degrees. But the EU measures 10 degrees. What does this have to do with unemployment? Well, a lot. Because just as little as a single temperature for Europe can be measured, a single interest rate for a single currency can be observed. Interest is nothing more than the temperature of an economy. If this temperature is measured incorrectly, the patient becomes ill, and the result is unemployment. We should rather talk about the causes so that our ten-year plans are more successful.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI). -
text: Madam President, from the liberalisation of regulated professions to the seconded workers directive, where is the social Europe that has been promised for so many years? In its communication on 5 March on the Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission is obliged to recognise that progress to date has been mixed. But then, instead of continuing to incriminate the 2008 crisis, what are our great strategists waiting for to finally question themselves?  As the European Union's unpaid bills pile up, you continue to announce huge budgets - EUR 960 billion - for the second tranche of this Europe 2020 strategy, which is not working. You won't be able to solve problems with billions that you don't have. It is high time to break with the dogma of the free movement of capital, goods and people. Indeed, how can we protect European workers when we refuse to protect European companies? Instead of creating a hypocritical Globalization Adjustment Fund to compensate victims of unfair competition, let's finally take the protectionist measures that are necessary! Let's cease to be the turkeys of farce! Let's be one step ahead rather than a late train and deal with the causes, not the consequences!

name: Sven Schulze (PPE). -
text: Madam President! Europe 2020 is the EU's growth strategy for the next decade. In a world that is evolving, we want a smart and sustainable economy for Europe. Social aspects must not, of course, be neglected. At European level, there is already a lot of sensible social policy legislation. This must first be applied correctly. However, social indicators such as child poverty, unemployment and employment rates should only be used as an early warning system. We should not make it binding on the Member States, because that would be a violation of the principle of subsidiarity. We do not need more harmonisation in European social policy. We need effective structural reforms in the labour market and in the social systems in some Member States. The sometimes high level of youth unemployment is a challenge, and the Youth Guarantee is a first correct answer. However, we must not forget one thing about all employment policies: in the long term, only healthy, sustainable economic growth helps, and investment against unemployment must not be financed with new debt. The implementation of the EU 2020 strategy by Member States must not be carried out through debt-financed recovery plans. That would only be a straw fire on the labour market.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to invite Mrs Thyssen to comment on point 35 of the draft motion, which calls on the Commission to open a public consultation procedure for the review of the European Semester in order to improve its effectiveness and legitimacy, because it is clear, Madam Commissioner, that we do not need partial and auxiliary measures but a basic redefinition of the policy paradigm. And I will only quote the conclusion of the Commission in its March Communication, which pointed out that for decades the EU has been a model of a mechanism which breeds cohesion and convergence, and this convergence process, says the report, has slowed and even gone into reverse.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE). -
text: We have been on the road for four years with the Europe 2020 strategy and, unfortunately, together with Commissioner Thyssen, we have seen that we have not come any closer to our objectives in those four years, but that we have moved even further away from it. In other words, this means that our objectives are ambitious, but our approach is lagging behind. I see this as a major threat to the credibility of the European Union as a whole. So there are two things we can do: we can make our goals less ambitious or we can make our approach more ambitious. I choose the second option. In particular, an ambitious approach means that member states must adopt this ambitious approach. This means that we should not be transferring large, one-off European project grants, but that we must work on structural reforms in the Member States and that we should guide and encourage these reforms from Europe. Secondly, let us not be blind to the number of indicators at European level. Indicators are important, measuring is known, but above all let us also look at which policy instruments lead to certain results at national level. And let us take those results to learn from each other and work together towards our goals.

name: Javi López (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the European Union's employment and social objectives have simply been a good intention sheet of the European Union, because, in some places, they cannot be further from reality. Let's look at Spain. One in five people is below the poverty line. Five million standing and 7.7 million people — nearly half of employees, almost half of them – with salaries below a thousand euros per month. No more good intentions! We need action from the European Union. And that certainly means changing our economic policy to accompany our social objectives, because so far it has proven to be absolutely counterproductive to our social objectives. It means placing our employment and social objectives at the same level as our binding macroeconomic objectives. And we must remember, no doubt, that losing the European social model — as is happening to us — is losing the soul of Europe.

name: La Présidente. -
text: Before I give the floor to the next speaker, I just want to point out that we still have 12 registrants, that we absolutely must have released this forum at eleven o'clock and that, unfortunately, we will not be able to organize interventions on demand.  I want to point out to members who were registered for these interventions on demand that they will have the opportunity to provide a statement of about 200 words that will be attached to the record. We will not be able to spill over into on-demand interventions.

name: Anne Sander (PPE). -
