Overall, the adoption of the CONVENTION by the EU will complement the achievement of the objectives underlying EU rules on the extension of competence by establishing a harmonised set of rules in the EU in relation to third countries that will become Contracting Parties to the Convention. It is part of the creation of a common judicial area based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — Since, in my view, the speedy ratification of the Council decision approving the Hague Convention would ensure greater legal certainty in international exclusive jurisdiction agreements and, inter alia, promote trade between the participating States, I voted in favour of the request.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The express objective of the Convention is to promote international trade and investment by strengthening judicial cooperation through the introduction of uniform rules on jurisdiction on the basis of exclusive court election agreements and on the recognition and enforcement of judgments given by the courts chosen by the Contracting Parties. According to the Council proposal, eu approval of the Convention will reduce legal uncertainty for European companies operating outside the EU by ensuring that the choice of judicial agreements included in their contracts is respected and that judgments handed down by the courts designated in those agreements will be eligible for recognition and enforcement by the other Contracting Parties to the Convention. Article 6 of the Convention imposes certain limits on Article 5, stating that the court of a Contracting State other than the elected court must suspend or declare itself incompetent to hear a case to which an exclusive agreement for the election of the forum applies. This report is a recommendation for the adoption of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005. The Convention was signed by the EU in 2009. The current step is the ratification process and we have not opposed it.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. -Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I am consistently voting against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed must be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán Javier Couso Permuy Paloma López Bermejo Y Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for 577 laid-off workers at STX Finland Oy, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 30 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing other transport material'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Finland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - The Finnish company STX Finland, which is active in the shipbuilding sector, has made a total of 577 redundancies. In the Finnish region of Rauma, the redundancies have led to an increase in the unemployment rate of more than two percent. Finland had justified the application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on the grounds that the global shipping industry had changed drastically in recent years and that the EU's market share in this sector had declined sharply. Shipbuilders from Asian countries in particular have an advantage over European shipbuilders due to the low labour costs. EUR 1,426,800 will be made available to the country from the Fund. The Fund will provide personalised services for reintegration into the labour market, including coaching, job placement, training, retraining and expert services.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people in Finland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Finland's needs in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by STX Finland Oy due to major structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalisation. The company was engaged in the shipping industry. The EU's share of the shipbuilding market was 5% in the first three quarters of 2013 and 13% in 2007. The corresponding combined market share for China, South Korea and Japan was 86% in the first three quarters of 2013 and 77 % in 2007. The package of services for redundant workers will include up-to-date training, employment and business services provided at the Service Centre, retraining, promoting entrepreneurship, etc.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. If I voted in favour of the release of this aid for employees who are victims of ultra-liberalism, I continue to denounce the inconsistency of this European Union, which is acting as an arsonist fireman.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - The shipbuilding sector in Finland is a national job creation hub. Unfortunately, the shipbuilding sector is facing increased competition from countries in Asia where labour is cheap. The consequent drop in production volume was fatal to the Finnish company RAUMA.  Following this disaster for the local economy, a great solidarity with the 565 laid-off workers is needed.  That is why I am in favour of mobilising EUR 1,426,800 from the EGF to enable the reintegration of former RAUMA workers into work.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the Globalisation Fund for the Finnish company engaged in the manufacture of other transport material which has suffered the consequences of reducing the European shipbuilding quota , which fell dramatically, from 13% in 2007 to 5% in the early years of 2013. There were a total of 577 fired in four months. The number of beneficiaries will be 565 people, of whom 87.78% are men and 12.21%, women. 41.42% of dismissed persons are between the ages of 55 and 64, and face greater risks in terms of reintegration into the world of work. The Fund will allow people who want to set up a company to do so after internships at existing companies.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. - This report aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the amount of EUR 1,426,800 to help 565 people out of the 634 workers laid off in the Rauma region of Finland. This request is intended to support sacked employees of STX Finland Oy, which is active in the shipbuilding sector.  In the face of unfair competition from low-cost countries, particularly in Asia, and the European Union's refusal to protect these borders, this sector can only bear the brunt of forced globalisation.  According to statistics, the EU's share of shipbuilding now stands at 5% of world volume compared to 13% in 2007 (2013 figures) even though China, South Korea and Japan together total 86% market share compared to 77% in 2007. Europe has thus largely lost ground to Asian countries even though it is the cradle of maritime conquest and major shipyards such as in France in Saint-Nazaire or Le Havres.  I have therefore voted in favour of this report in order to support these laid-off workers, especially those aged 55 to 64, who represent a high proportion.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, for 634 redundancies in the Finnish shipbuilding sector. At a time of crisis such as this, the EGF is emerging as a valuable instrument of support which cannot and must not replace the reforms that Europe must have the courage to carry out.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - (SV) I have voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 426 800 of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 565 workers who have lost their jobs at STX shipyards in Finland as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the naval sector in the face of the plummeting of EU market share and the expansion of Asia, they do provide good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected. The EU must show greater commitment to the future of the european naval sector as a whole from Finland to my home region, Galicia, which is also facing serious difficulties.  The customized services to be financed from the FEAG include training, vocational guidance and recycling activities and incentives for the creation of companies. We do not want to have to approve more aid funds for redundancies, this should be the last resort for the sector.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which deals with finland's STX Rauma application to the European Globalisation Fund. As a result of major structural changes in the world trade system resulting from globalisation, the Commission adopted on 14 October 2014 a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF for Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from NACE (Production of Other Transport Equipment). The aid is necessary as the Finnish authorities argue that the global shipping industry has changed significantly in recent years and that, in this global context, the EU's share of the shipbuilding market has decreased. In many Asian countries, shipbuilding has become an industry that creates jobs and receives foreign currency. Due to the global nature of the shipbuilding industry and the impact on employment, this industry is supported in Asian countries. As a result, Europe, where the modern shipbuilding industry is created, has transferred a significant part of the market to Asian countries with lower labour costs. The Finnish authorities say that the unemployment rate in the Rauma region will increase by more than 2 percentage points from 11.1% to 13.1% following the closure of STX. In addition, low education and relatively older age are likely to increase the risk of prolonged unemployment.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising resources on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I believe it is necessary to keep our European productive tool in a viable situation and also to maintain employment in Europe as long as possible.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of saving 634 redundancies in the shipbuilding sector.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — Parliament has approved Finland's request for intervention by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the shipbuilding company STX Rauma. The company was forced to lay off a large number of its employees as a result of strong competition from third countries. More than 500 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 577 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation by STX Finland Oy, a shipbuilding company.  The global maritime industry has changed dramatically in recent years and, as part of this trend, the EU's market share has fallen from 13% in 2007 to 5% in the first three quarters of 2013, while the corresponding share of China, South Korea and Japan combined has increased from 77% in 2007 to 86% in the first three quarters of 2013. As a result of this considerable expansion of Asia into the shipbuilding market, to which is added a reduction in orders due to the economic crisis, the European sector is characterized by global overcapacity which has led to strong competition. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit from this fund because of the lack of support from local institutions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report emphasises the need for support for workers whose income has been diminished due to major changes in trade patterns due to globalisation. I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund with somewhat mixed feelings: on the one hand, I am pleased that this fund is being used and that we are succeeding in buffering the industrial situations that have degenerated as a result of globalisation, while on the other hand I regret to note that workers and companies are being hit so hard. I hope that these funds will also serve to create development alternatives, which are needed today more than ever.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 1 426 800 for Finland with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at STX Finland Oy.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the report on the mobilisation of the EGF in relation to Finland's application to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundancies in STX Finland Oy. Due to Asia's significant expansion in the shipbuilding market, countries such as China, South Korea and Japan have seen their market share increase from 77% in 2007 to 86% in 2013, while the EU's market share has plummeted from 13% in 2007 to 5% in 2013. Europe, the heart of the modern shipbuilding industry, has lost ground to low-wage Asian countries. EGF aid provides personalised services for redundant workers such as: help to find work, help start up a business of their own and training. In particular, a measure called the Enterprise Survey will aim to obtain up-to-date information on the staffing needs of enterprises in the Rauma region. I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market and will help the entrepreneurs affected by the crisis.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to support the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report confirms that 565 workers previously operating in the manufacture of transport equipment in Finland will be targeted by the EGF co-funded measures. Personalised services for the redundant workers will include coaching and other preparatory measures, training and entrepreneurship promotion and training. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will provide additional opportunities and support to the workers (and their families) affected by these redundancies.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) This is the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland. It calls for the mobilisation of around EUR 1.4 million to assist 565 beneficiaries working in the maritime construction sector. I am in favour of mobilising this fund as a general rule. I am aware that it is certainly not the instrument that can best help workers, but in the absence of alternatives it must be supported nonetheless.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 14 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in STX Finland Oy, operating in shipbuilding, due to major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. It refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 426 800 from the EGF for Finland. It concerns a total of 565 beneficiaries. The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF, and the EP’s Budgetary Committee has already supported the decision with strong majority. Hence I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With the release of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), 577 workers laid off by STX Finland Oy will see their support towards a substantially improved return to employment. They will rightly benefit from personalised training and advice to help them reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I supported the proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland because it proposes the re-employment of 565 workers made redundant in stx Finland Oy, who have lost their jobs as a result of the major changes in world trade due to globalisation.

name: Deutsch Tamás (PPE)
text: Writing. - On 14 October 2014, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from STX Finland Oy in sector 30 (Manufacture of Other Vehicles) of the major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. A total of 565 beneficiaries are affected by the application. The Finnish authorities argue that the global maritime sector has changed dramatically in recent years and that, in such a global environment, the EU's market share in shipbuilding has fallen sharply. Asian countries have acquired a significant share of Europe, the cradle of modern shipbuilding, where labour costs are low. The Finnish authorities argue that, following the closure of the STX, the unemployment rate in the Rauma region is expected to rise by more than 2 percentage points from 11.1% to 13.1%.  A coordinated package of personalised services for redundant workers includes the following actions: advice and other preparatory measures, employment and business services at a service point, training and retraining, business promotion, training and expert services, company survey, payment allowances, travel, accommodation and removal expenses. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting in favour, although we disagree with the economic policy of re-entry into employment, under which funds are allocated to education, advice and guidance companies instead of those who are made redundant in urgent need.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - FEAG was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. In 2014-2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. In this mobilisation of the EGF, the Finnish authorities submitted on 27/05/2014 the EGF/2014/008 FI/STX Rauma application to a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 577 employees at STX Finland Oy, which operated in the economic sector classified in DIVISION 30 of NACE Rev. 2 Manufacture of other transport equipment, on the grounds that the global maritime industry has undergone dramatic changes in recent years and that, in this global context, the EU market share in the shipbuilding sector fell from 13% in 2007 to 5% in the first 3 quarters of 2013, while the equivalent share of the pool formed by China, South Korea and Japan increased from 77% in 2007 to 86% in the same period. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In view of the dismissal of 577 employees of STX Finland Oy, a transport equipment producer, the Finnish authorities have submitted an application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 426 800. The application is justified on the basis of the dramatic changes that the global maritime industry has undergone in recent years, affecting the company's market share in the shipbuilding sector, which has fallen from 13 % (2007) to 5 % (in the first 3 quarters of 2013), with an expansion of the Asian shipbuilding market, and the decline in orders resulting from the economic crisis has led to a weakening of the sector. We understand the immediate need to contribute to improving the situation of these workers, in particular by mobilising the proposed amounts. However, as we have said on several occasions, the mobilisation of this fund cannot be used to enable redundancy policies promoting the worsening of the exploitation of cheap and non-rights labour.  In this case, it is appropriate to denounce the deregulation and liberalisation of the shipbuilding and repair sector on a global scale, which is intensely promoted by the EU, that these consequences are inseparable.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - The European Commission received the application in question in favour of mobilising the EGF in May this year after 577 workers lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns, namely in the global maritime industry, where the European Union's share of the global context in the construction of new ships has fallen. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region will increase and the old age and low education of the redundant workers make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 1 426 800.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — Vote in favour of this application for the 634 workers in the rauma shipbuilding sector.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the report although I disagree with the economic policy of re-entry into employment, under which funds are allocated to education, advice and guidance companies, rather than to those made redundant who need them immediately.  In addition, in this case, grants to new potential entrepreneurs are provided first and secondly, salary subsidies to employers who will hire unemployed people.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is an example of EU policy leading to the destruction of European industries, and then the EU using taxpayers’ money to effectively give ‘EU Dole’ to those people affected. Surely it is the responsibility of the Finnish Government, in this case, to help their people in this instance, and not British taxpayers.  This is a national competency and for this reason I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2014/008 FI/STX Rauma. I believe that the EU should protect and support its citizens from any crisis. We should provide financial support for people in need and give them a chance to reintegrate themselves into the labour market after they were dismissed because of force majeure.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Companies and the Member States themselves should come up with appropriate aid measures. The European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation is just a wipe for the bleeding and in practice means pumping out member states' financial resources.  Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly disapprove of these degrading practices. But with the funds from the European Fund, we are at least making sure that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I fully support this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund which has come about as a result of the downturn in European shipbuilding. Like Finland, Scotland has a long history of shipbuilding – and the devastation caused by shipyard closures is only too well known to Scottish communities. We hear that certain naval contracts awarded to Scottish shipbuilders are now under threat; the Tory-led ʽNoʼ campaign in the recent referendum was guilty of a huge deceit.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for a motion for a resolution to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event of the redundancies of 577 STX Finland Oy workers, as the funding allocated to it is a dynamic and effective way to mitigate the consequences of redundancies in southwest Finland. Most workers have lower qualifications and are aged between 55 and 64, leading to a more prominent possibility of long-term unemployment and exclusion from the labour market.  Therefore, it is important to launch urgent assistance to workers to help find an alternative solution to the emerging situation, which is further under pressure due to globalisation trends in the maritime industry and the sharp decline in the European Union's market share in the shipbuilding sector.  I also welcome the fact that the Finnish authorities initially initiated the implementation of needs-friendly services for affected workers, followed by a request to mobilise the fund.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is another perfect instance of the EU policy putting a business out of commercial viability and of the EU then using its funds, sourced from the UK amongst other Member States, to deal with the impact – effectively to pay dole payments! UKIP MEPs voted against since we do not agree that UK taxpayers should fund or support incoherent EU policies and by implication subsidise scenarios that fellow Member States should manage.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Petri Sarvamaa's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of STX in Finland. A grant of 1.4 million euros will be provided for the workers who have been made redundant from this company to help them reintegrate into the labour market, including through training. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on Finland's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies at the maritime construction company STX Finland Oy. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I am the the fore, the most pleased, for the adoption of this financial aid, amounting to more than EUR 1,420,000.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported Mr Sarvamaa's report, which contains the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundancies in the Finnish company STX Finland Oy, which operates in the field of the manufacture of means of transport. In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. By using the most appropriate destination criteria, Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping the people most affected by a devastating economic crisis.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the Sarvamaa report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 634 sacked employees of STX Finland Oy (Rauma site). The EGF will finance 60% (1,426,800 euros at a total cost of 2,378,000 euros) projects consisting mainly of the distribution of financial aid and the establishment of support in finding a new job, setting up a business or starting training.  In the face of mass unemployment and the excesses of globalisation, the WEF is once again proving to be an effective and sustainable tool to support the victims of the successive crises that have hit the European Union countries.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - This is the mobilization of feAG on behalf of Finland to support the return to the labour market of laid-off workers at STX shipyards in Rauma (FI). The total amount of the financial contribution amounts to EUR 1 426 800 from the EGF with a total of 565 beneficiaries. In the face of Europe's economic and financial crisis and the competitiveness crisis in our industry, it is necessary to support the mobilization of funds like this under the above conditions.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - As a result of significant structural changes in world trade flows, I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers who lost their jobs at STX Finland Oy, as significant structural changes in world trade flows have significantly affected business downsizing and significant redundancies.  The European Globalisation Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation. This report aims to provide a sum of 1.5 million euros to assist redundanized workers through training measures, promotions of entrepreneurship and payments related to travel costs and other expenses.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am abstaining because, from the total budget of this measure, which amounts to EUR 2,378,000, only EUR 113 000 is earmarked for the implementation of this measure.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 14 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in STX Finland Oy operating in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 30 (‘Manufacturing of other transport equipment’) due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I supported this proposal.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported the proposal to mobilise the EGF concerning redundancies in the Finnish shipbuilding sector in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 577 workers made redundant by STX Finland Oy, a shipbuilding company.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up as a legislative and budgetary instrument to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market in sustainable economic sectors.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The European Union has a duty to prepare legislative and budgetary instruments providing additional support to workers affected by market changes due to globalisation.  In Finland, the closure of STX Rauma could seriously undermine the well-being of many workers in the region, as the shipbuilding and metallurgical sectors are vital economic activities for the country. That is why I thought it appropriate to support the Sarvamaa report, which supports the mobilisation of the EGF for the benefit of a large number of Finnish workers in difficulty.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for STX Finland OY should be supported, as the company concerned fulfils all the criteria for support. It is also very commendable that the Finnish Government has already started to provide assistance to the workers concerned before the EU applies for assistance. This willingness to act will allow us to be sure that the funds provided by the Union will be used in a meaningful way and will only benefit the workers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is playing its destructive role. Instead of helping workers it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. The case of this Finnish company specializing in the shipbuilding industry is exemplary. The report's figures reveal the effects of free trade on an industry far ahead of its global competitors: "the EU's market share in shipbuilding was 5% in the first three quarters of 2013, down 13% since 2007" when "the equivalent share of China, South Korea and Japan combined was 86%" over the same period. , up sharply. The report finds that our direct competitors support the shipbuilding industry because of its global and employment impacts, but without proposing to do the same in Europe by introducing solidarity protectionism. This aid only brings a band-aid to a policy that has been defeated. However, I abstain in order not to object to the means that will be distributed to the 500 Finnish workers through this fund.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used by other EU countries in the past, and it is now appropriate to give this aid to Finland which submitted the EGF/2014/008 FI/STX Rauma application on 27 May 2014, following the dismissal of 577 workers at STX Finland Oy, which operated in the economic sector classified in DIVISION 30 of NACE Rev. 2 Manufacture of other transport equipment.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - Finland aims to use these funds to provide 634 workers affected by difficulties in the shipbuilding sector which are related to globalisation with personalised services and to promote entrepreneurship. These workers are at risk of prolonged unemployment, since most of them have a relatively poor standard of education and are in an advanced age group. I have therefore voted in favour of this report in order to reintegrate these persons affected back into the labour market.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Finland, which was submitted following the dismissal of 577 workers in Rauma from an enterprise operating in the shipyard industry. The EGF funding will contribute to personalised services for the redundant workers, which shall include help transferring to a new job, starting their own business, as well as providing training and/or education.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. STX Finland Oy (Division 30 "Manufacturing Other Transport Equipment") applied for a grant of 1,426,800 euros under the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help retrain 634 people who have been made redundant. The employees of the Rauma shipyard were the most affected by these layoffs, and those at the Turku shipyard were not spared either. The reclassification of these employees will be difficult since many of them are already elderly. STX Finland Oy saw a drop in the number of orders, even as competition from Asia continued to increase pressure on the European market. Faced with China, South Korea and Japan, the European maritime industry is laminated. While shipbuilding, which is booming and job-creating in these countries, is largely supported by states, in the European Union ultra-liberal dogma and free and undistorted competition have finally led to this sector. Without protectionist measures, the shipbuilding industry, like other industries for that matter, will not be able to compete with Asian countries and their low-cost labour. I voted for this grant.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which mobilises EUR 1,426,800 for the laid-off workers of the Finnish naval company Rauma. This company, which has been hard hit by international competition, has laid off 634 employees, 566 of whom will benefit from this assistance. The shipbuilding sector boomed in the pre-crisis period and many shipyards were established, mainly in Asia. With the crisis and increasing competition, the EU's market share in the sector has fallen to 5% of the world market this year, down from 13% in 2007.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted two reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of its two reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 1,426,800 from this fund to 565 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of a shipyard in Finland.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I believe that the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be supported for STX Finland OY, as the company concerned meets all the criteria for support. It is also very commendable that the Finnish Government has already started to provide assistance to the workers concerned before the EU applies for assistance. This willingness to act will allow us to be sure that the funds provided by the Union will be used in a meaningful way and will only benefit the workers. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This proposal follows the dismissal of 634 employees of a company in a region of Finland due in particular to competition from the port sector in Asia. This European aid will come to support these employees in the search for a new job or a career reorientation.  So I decided to vote in favour of mobilizing this fund.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 1 426 800 to Finland from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), as it will allow us to help 634 people who became unemployed in the Finnish shipbuilding sector.  Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can re-engage these people in the labour market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The EU must help Member States to address the short-term negative effects of globalisation in an expeditious and effective way. In this way, while expressing solidarity with the redundant workers.  It should be noted that financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a vital instrument that increases the chances of finding work in sometimes rather difficult circumstances. Therefore, financial support for redundant workers from STX Finland is necessary. It will provide opportunities for reintegration in future-oriented and sustainable economic sectors. It should be noted that support should, in particular, be paid to the implementation of social assistance measures for the most vulnerable and low-skilled workers. On the other hand, given the number of applications submitted in the shipbuilding industry, I believe that the shipbuilding industry in different Member States could be supported by european guidelines.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - In view of the fact that the Finnish authorities have submitted a specific application for financial assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 577 workers from STX Finland Oy operating in the manufacture and transport of equipment, given that the maritime industry has fallen dramatically by 7% since 2005, given that the Commission considered that the criteria for the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund were met. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Marit Paulsen (ALDE)
text: Written. - (C) Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We can possibly accept that the Fund is being used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis – especially given people's sense of hopelessness and exclusion that follows in the wake of the crisis, and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, we believe that the worst crisis is now over, and that the fund therefore lacks justification in the not too distant future. To mark this, we chose to abstain in today's vote. Marit Paulsen, Cecilia Wikström and Fredrick Federley

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — Once again, the European Union is trying to partially compensate for the damage it is causing by its blind ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to bother anyone. I am voting for this aid to employees who are victims of European ultra-liberalism.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported my colleague Petri Sarvamaae's report. Globalisation has also had an impact on the shipbuilding market. Due to the significant expansion of Asian producers into the shipbuilding market and the reduced number of orders due to the economic crisis, there is currently oversupply, causing fierce competition.  I welcome a proposal by the European Parliament and the Council to grant funding to help 577 redundancy workers of STX Finland Oy amount to EUR 1 426 800, which would provide redundancy workers with assistance in moving to a new job, helping to start their own business and providing training and education. I would point out that in recent years there have been major changes in the global maritime industry, and that as part of the global trend, the EU's market share in shipbuilding has fallen from 13% in 2007 to 5% in early 2013, while the common share of China, South Korea and Japan increased from 77% in 2007 to 86% at the beginning of 2013.  It is important to note, in addition to the fact that the redundancies of these 577 workers will further exacerbate unemployment in southwest Finland, that they are low-education workers and that they are of a more mature age, which increases the risk of long-term unemployment.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) As has already been said in the past, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument providing additional aid to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade, also due to the general crisis. Finland's request to mobilise the fund for the reintegration into the labour market of redundancies by STX Finland Oy (a company in the "Manufacture of other means of transport" sector, in this case shipbuilding) fulfils the conditions for a financial contribution in accordance with the EGF Regulation. I hope that the personalised services enjoyed by redundant workers in Finnish companies (including coaching, training and retraining, promotion and training for entrepreneurship and counselling services, travel, overnight and removal allowances) will serve their reintegration into the labour market despite the risk of prolonged unemployment that may persist due to the relatively old age of many workers in the company.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — (DE) With the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the EU all too easily gives the impression that globalisation is something negative to protect citizens from. In so doing, it is fuelling fears and resentment scares towards a process that in many respects benefits citizens in many respects. Although it is not an effect of globalisation that these Finnish workers are unfortunately losing their jobs, I nevertheless voted in favour of mobilising the Fund. In this way, the Finnish State receives the financial resources that it would actually use from its national budget to fulfil its social obligations. However, under the current situation in the EU, I believe it is justified to give back to Finland, by voting, some of its membership fees, which are overdue in this case.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Following the economic crisis, the supply of shipbuilding was subject to intense competition, causing great difficulties for STX Rauma. Such a situation in this sector is similarly repeated throughout the European Union, and dismissed workers should be supported in job search, retraining and business creation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 634 redundancies at STX Finland Oy, which operated in division 30 of NACE Rev. 2 (Manufacture of other transport equipment), during the period from 7 October 2013 to 7 March 2014. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is found, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as the EU market share in the shipbuilding sector fell from 13 % in 2007 to 5 % in the first three quarters of 2013 , due to the expansion of the Asian shipbuilding market and the decline in orders resulting from the economic and financial crisis, and, on the other hand, that such redundancies will further aggravate the unemployment situation in the Rauma region, with a high risk of prolonged unemployment, given the low educational level and advanced age of the workers affected. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — In order to mitigate the effects of the closure of STX Finland Oy a Rauma, I voted in favour of the grant of EUR 1 426 800 through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This shipbuilding company, which is highly ranked worldwide, suffered a dramatic reduction in orders between 2007 and 2013. By endorsing these funds, we confirm that the European Union is committed to the Member States and citizens to deal with the economic crisis and the restructuring that results from it. Finally, it should be noted that this financial assistance is accompanied by several concrete measures to help laid-off workers in their plans to reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 426 800 of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 565 workers who have lost their jobs at STX shipyards in Finland, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the naval sector in the face of the plummeting of EU market share and the expansion of Asia, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland: the Finnish authorities had made this request following the dismissal last May of 577 workers from STX Finland Oy, which is active in the naval sector. And for good reason: the global maritime industry has changed dramatically in recent years: the European Union's market share in shipbuilding has reached only 5% in the first three quarters of 2013 globally, compared to 13% in 2007, while the combined market share of China, South Korea and Japan has increased from 77% in 2007 to ... 86% in the first three quarters of 2013. The considerable expansion of Asia in the shipbuilding market, the decline in orders due to the economic crisis has led to a global overcapacity of the European sector, causing increased competition at the expense of workers. We have to help them.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), with a maximum annual budget of EUR 150 million for the period 2014-2020, demonstrates the European Union's concern for workers who have lost their jobs following major structural changes in international trade patterns due to globalisation and the global economic and financial crisis. The EGF provides additional support to these workers, materialised in individual counselling and monitoring activities, translated into vocational guidance, job search support, education, training and retraining or for the creation of new businesses. Finland submitted an application to the EGF following the dismissal of 634 workers from STX Finland Oy in Rauma. Having found that the application meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour of this report, sincerely hoping that the measures it has supported will enable these workers to have a stable and future working life.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance for the 565 employees of STX Finland Oy, who were made redundant in September 2013 when the Rauma shipyard closed.  Once again, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund proves its full usefulness, which explains my willingness to support this resolution in order to continue our commitments to a fairer And closer Europe to the citizens.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of 613 redundancies in the shipbuilding sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources for 577 laid-off workers at STX Finland Oy, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 30 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing other transport material'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Finland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome that today the European Parliament approved EU aid to help workers made redundant in STX Finland. The EUR 1 426 800 in EGF aid approved by Parliament will support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in STX in the Rauma region. It concerns a total of 565 beneficiaries. The Finnish authorities argue that the global maritime industry changed dramatically in recent years and that in this global context the EU market share has plummeted. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers who lost their jobs at STX Finland Oy. The dismissals at the company followed various structural changes that have occurred amid a major economic crisis that is being tackled by the whole of Europe.  Finland submitted this application on 27 May 2014. The purpose of this report is to provide additional resources to help those workers who have lost their jobs and to support them through various measures. This report aims to provide a total amount of EUR 1 426 800 for assisting redundantist workers through various measures such as upskilling, promotions of entrepreneurship and other costs related to the upskilling of workers and for assistance with their employment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - As Finland applied on 27 May 2014 to launch a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, concerning the redundancies of 565 workers at STX Finland Oy in Raumi. As the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) dictates, it was set up to support redundant and self-employed workers whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, as a result of the continuing global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Furthermore, since the EGF must not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million (2011 price), as laid down in Article 12 of the EEA, it is not possible to exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million (2011 price). Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2020/2013 1311/2013, I therefore support the mobilisation decision to ensure a financial contribution of EUR 1 426 800 for Finland.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. - The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore the ECR will vote against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — We vote against because we disagree with the economic policy of re-entry into employment, under which funds are allocated to education, advice and guidance companies instead of those made redundant who need them immediately.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken out in favour of this aid. As a reminder, on 14 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the WEF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers dismissed at STX Finland Oy in May 2014 and supplemented by additional information, the latest of which was received on 22 July 2014. The Commission concluded, in light of all the applicable provisions of the WEF Regulation, that the application met the conditions for granting the WEF's financial contributions.  The Finnish authorities argue that the global maritime industry has changed dramatically in recent years and that, in this global context, the European Union's market share has fallen. Calculated on the basis of production volume, the EU's market share in shipbuilding reached 5% in the first three quarters of 2013, up from 13% in 2007. By comparison, the combined market share of China, South Korea and Japan was 86% in the first three quarters of 2013, up from 77% in 2007.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on Finland's request for a financial contribution of EUR 2.3 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to the redundancies of a total of 634 workers from STX Finsland OY.  I believe that such packages of measures represent only short-term solutions for laid-off workers and further aggravate the poor economic situation, which is particularly reflected in the sectors affected by the crisis. Namely, it is the Member States that should provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitive on the global market, which presupposes tax relief and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - STX Finland Oy, a transport equipment producer, intends to lay off 577 workers and the Finnish authorities have submitted an application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 426 800. The application is justified on the basis of changes that the global maritime industry has undergone in recent years, affecting the EU's market share in the shipbuilding sector, which fell from 13% (2007) to 5 % (in the first 3 quarters of 2013), as a result of the economic crisis and global competition. We follow the immediate need to contribute to improving the situation of these workers, in particular by mobilising the proposed amounts. However, the mobilisation of this fund cannot be used to enable redundancy policies, promoting the worsening of the exploitation of cheap and non-rights labour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — I support the request for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for STX Finland OY, as all the criteria have been met by the company concerned. It is also important to emphasise that the Finnish Government has already launched aid measures prior to the application for the EU Fund. I voted in favour without hesitation on the conviction that the funds are being used wisely here, as the Member State itself is also contributing a great deal.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In view of the dismissal of 577 employees of STX Finland Oy, which produces transport equipment, the Finnish authorities submitted an application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 426 800. The application is justified on the basis of the dramatic changes that the global maritime industry has undergone in recent years, affecting the EU's market share in the shipbuilding sector which has fallen from 13% (2007) to 5% (in the first 3 quarters of 2013), with an expansion of the Asian shipbuilding market. They also argue that the decline in orders resulting from the economic crisis has led to a weakening of the sector. We understand the immediate need to contribute to improving the situation of these workers, in particular by mobilising the proposed amounts. However, as we have said on several occasions, the mobilisation of this fund cannot be used to enable redundancy policies, promoting the worsening of the exploitation of cheap and unentitled labour, without accountability for the right-wing policies that are at its origin.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. -Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I am consistently voting against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed must be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán Javier Couso Permuy Paloma López Bermejo Lidia Senra Rodríguez Y Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for 744 laid-off workers from GAD société anonyme simplifiée, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 10 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Food Industry'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for French purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by GAD société anonyme simplifiée due to major structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalisation. The company was engaged in the production of food products. The financial and economic crisis in Europe has led to a fall in pig consumption, which in turn has reduced the production of pork and the productivity of slaughterhouses such as GAD. In 2007, one resident consumed 43 kg of pork per year and 39 kg in 2013. Gross revenue shrank from EUR 495,1 million in 2004 to EUR 495,1 million in 2004. In 2008, eur 445,8 million was allocated to the european economy. In 2009, the company no longer recovered. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers are the only action: the advisory and guidance service provided by the expert team of consultants. I agree with France's eur 918 000 for the EGF in order to speed up the reintegration of 760 redundant workers into the labour market.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the release of this aid, which, however critical in principle, will help the employees of the GAD company. It seems that the difficulties faced by the pork industry are not unrelated to other phenomena that the European Union, like the French officials, refuse to consider...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In a region where the agri-food sector is highly employment-generating, the situation of a company such as GAD is of crucial importance because of the serious consequences it can generate. It is therefore essential to pay particular attention to the situation of the 760 workers made redundant as a result of the increase in the prices of pork, caused by the global financial and economic crisis.  That is why, the mobilization of EUR 918,000 by the EGF to help reintegrate these 760 people into the labour market seems to me to be totally justified.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported the authorization of the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund in favour of GAD, which was engaged in the food industry, slaughterhouses and meat processing and which could not withstand price pressure, as a result of the increase in the price of feed and lower-income consumers. 76% of dismissed persons will benefit from the Fund.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report is to mobilise a grant of EUR 918,000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by France in order to support the retraining of sacked employees of GAD, slaughterhouses specialising in the cutting and processing of pork and located in France, in the Brittany and Loire regions. Nearly 760 laid-off workers are affected by these retraining measures. The opening of all our borders to unfair competition from foreign countries, wanted and imposed by Europe from Brussels, explains this social disaster. It is becoming urgent to challenge the ultra-liberal and technocratic Europe of Brussels by re-establishing customs barriers to save our businesses from competition from countries with low labour costs. In addition, it is essential to restore French pork everywhere in school canteens, which has often disappeared under pressure from communitarian associations. Nevertheless, in order to support employees who are victims of globalist policies, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF to help 760 French workers working in the pigmeat slaughter and processing sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the most important instruments by which the EU can take concrete action to help all those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis or the perverse effects of the internal market. In this regard, I would like to point out that the European Parliament's Own Committee on Budgets, which is called upon to assess this case, said: 'considers that there have been other factors which have had a significant impact on the difficulties of society, such as unfair competition in the internal market by competitors who have abused the Posting of Workers Directive ...'.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - (SV) I have voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 918 000 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 760 workers who have lost their jobs in gaD, slaughterhouse and meat processing company, located in the Brittany region of France, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include measures to advise and guide workers dismissed by a team of expert advisers (reclassification cell), whose mission is to support laid-off workers and help them find solutions that allow them to continue in the labour market and get another job. These aids constitute good assistance for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the decision to mobilise the EGF for French purposes in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. The French authorities argue that the global financial and economic crisis in Europe has led to a fall in pig consumption, which in turn has reduced the production of pigmeat and the productivity of slaughterhouses such as GAD. The decline in consumption caused by the global financial and economic crisis is also typical of other types of meat, but pork producers have been most affected, as the price of pigmeat has grown faster than other meat, especially beef. In addition, the costs of pig feed are reimbursed, thereby increasing the final price of pigs, which is ultimately borne by the consumer. As the EU was still affected by the crisis, consumers did not want or could not buy as much pork as they had before. The slaughterhouse and the meat processing company GAD are in a price pressure zone, with farmers grapping with the challenges of rising feed prices and consumers facing reduced income problems. This pressure lasted five years or more, putting the company in a particularly difficult financial situation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the resources of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I believe it is necessary to keep our European productive tool in a viable situation and also to maintain employment in Europe as long as possible.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of saving 760 redundancies in the meat slaughter and processing sector.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help employees who were made redundant following the closure of the GAD slaughterhouse in Lampaul-Guimiliau, Brittany. The pig industry is experiencing very serious hours in Brittany. Businesses are failing to cope with ever-increasing global competition. The economic and financial crisis has reduced pork consumption in Europe, which has a direct impact on producers and slaughterhouses. The European funds granted to the company GAD will help more than 700 sacked employees to return to the world of work. This is a victory for European solidarity.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 744 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation by GAD, a company operating in the meat slaughter and processing sector. The GAD has been caught in the grip of a double pressure on prices: that of farmers, who are struggling to cope with the rise in feed prices, and that of consumers, who are struggling with a reduced income. In fact, the fall in meat consumption is due to rising prices and a deterioration in consumer purchasing power linked to the global financial and economic crisis. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying actions, such as assistance in finding employment, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promoting self-employment and entrepreneurship. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit from this fund because of the lack of support from local institutions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report emphasises the need for support for workers whose income has been diminished due to major changes in trade patterns due to globalisation. I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — The applications for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund always deserve a vote in favour: these are companies and workers in difficulty because of events greater than themselves, with which politics has to contest. Alternatives must be created, or at least they must be favoured, but it is also necessary to give oxygen to the territories that are hard hit by a crisis that is in addition to the international economic situation and the historical moment.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 918 000 for France with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by gad societé anonyme simplifiée.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the report on the mobilisation of the EGF in relation to the request made by France to support the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant at gad, société anonyme simplifiée, operating in the field of slaughter and meat processing. The GAD has faced a double pressure on prices: that of farmers, who are struggling to cope with the rise in feed prices, which are largely imported from countries outside the EU, such as the United States, Australia and South America, regions affected by drought and which have consequently seen a significant increase in the price of feed , and that of consumers, struggling with a reduction in income linked to the financial and economic crisis. As this situation lasted for more than 5 years, the company was in serious financial difficulties. This greatly aggravates the problem of unemployment in Brittany, since this region is more dependent on the agro-industrial sector than the average French. I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market and will help the entrepreneurs affected by the crisis.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The redundancies of 760 workers in GAD, an enterprise operating in the manufacture of food products, are linked to the global and financial economic crisis. Redundant workers will be given advice and guidance by a team of expert consultants aiming for the reintegration of redundant workers in the labour market. I have therefore voted in favour of this report since the measure not only addresses loss of jobs but also reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. The call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France is aimed at mobilising around EUR 900 000 to assist 760 workers in a company operating in the meat slaughter and processing sector. We also welcome the fact that the figure requested appears to be rather small in relation to the number of beneficiaries.
