Aware that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not an exhaustive means of safeguarding workers' rights and trusting in a more appropriate instrument, I believe that we should support this request.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 24 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in GAD société anonyme simplifiée operating in the manufacturing of food products due to the global financial and economic crisis. It refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 918 000 from the EGF for France. It concerns a total of 760 beneficiaries.  The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF, and the European Parliament’s Committee on Budgets has already supported the decision with strong majority. Hence I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Faced with declining consumption of pork and the parallel decline in its profit margins, GAD, based mainly in Morbihan and Finistère, has been forced into significant redundancies. I welcome, as was the case with PSA recently, that the European Union can take concrete action in France through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Thanks to the budgetary resources disbursed, nearly 744 French workers made redundant from the company GAD will be able to benefit from personalized services thus promoting their return to the labour market.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France because it supports the reintegration into employment of the 565 workers made redundant at GAD, a company hard hit by the global economic and financial crisis. The EGF is an additional instrument that supports all those workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The global economic and financial crisis has hit many sectors of European industry hard, including the food sector. The French pork industry, particularly in Brittany, has been hit hard by the economic crisis, coupled with the effects of the Russian embargo on pork. In 2014, the Breton slaughterhouses GAD had to lay off 760 employees due to the decline in the consumption of pork in France.  In this context, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, set up to provide rapid assistance to workers affected by the crisis, finds its usefulness. It is thereby justified that the European Union should release EUR 918,000 for those made redundant, an amount equivalent on average to 1,200 euros per sacked employee. This decision should help Gad's former workers find a job by providing them with appropriate support and advice. France should ensure that measures taken at national level complement European funds so that people who have lost their jobs can actually be reinted into the labour market.

name: Deutsch Tamás (PPE)
text: Writing. - On 24 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from the simplified company GAD in economic sector 10 (food production) under NACE Rev. 2 as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. Gad's gross margin was EUR 123 million in 2010 and EUR 107 million in 2012-13. While the company made a profit of EUR 16 million in 2008, it was loss-making in 2009 and ultimately made losses of EUR 20 million in both 2012 and 2013. The company's gross revenue fell from EUR 495.1 million in 2008 to EUR 445.8 million in 2009 and this decline proved irreversible. On 27 February 2013, the company went into receivership after its losses in the period 2010-2013 amounted to EUR 65 million. Personalised services for redundant workers include the following — a single measure: advice and guidance (Cellule de reclassement) provided by a team of experts to redundant workers. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting in favour, although we disagree with the economic policy of re-entry into employment, under which funds are allocated to education, advice and guidance companies instead of those who are made redundant in urgent need.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. In this mobilisation of the EGF, the French authorities submitted the Application EGF/2014/005 FR/GAD on 6 June 2014, following the dismissal of 744 employees at GAD société anonyme simplifiée, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 10 (Food Industries) of NACE Rev. 2. In this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of this region of Brittany, EUR 918 000 was granted for aid in the reintegration into the labour market of workers. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The capitalist crisis affects millions of families, through unemployment, falling wages and the withdrawal of rights. The French company GAD, which slaughters and processes meat, has fired 760 workers, presenting as an argument the pressure on prices, both by farmers, who are struggling with the increase in the price of rations, and by consumers, who see their income swell and the impossibility of buying their meat. It is unacceptable that the process leading to these redundancies has not had any negotiations with workers' representatives and trade unions, and that it intends to channel funding to private employment firms into the so-called process of integrating the workers affected, rather than applying this money to more direct aid to the injured. France submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 918,000. Although it can bring some momentary relief to workers, this fund is nothing more than a crutch created by the capital to enable redundancies, giving a handout to reassure conscience and public opinion. In practice, this fund does not reset the hundreds of thousands of jobs extinct across the EU. There is an urgent need to change policies promoting unemployment.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - This request concerns the release of EUR 918 000 of funds for staff who have worked in slaughterhouses in France, which have had to reduce production and capacity as a result of the economic and financial crisis. Since 2007, the consumption of pork per inhabitant has decreased by up to 4 kilograms. Such a company is also GAD, which has recorded losses of EUR 65 million over the last four years. The funds in question from the European Globalisation Fund should be used to cover personalised services for redundant workers.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of this request for the 760 workers in the pigmeat slaughter and processing sector.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2014/005 FR/GAD, from France) although I disagree with the economic policy of re-entry into employment, under which funds are allocated to education, consultancy and guidance companies but not to those who are in urgent need.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is an example of EU policy leading to the destruction of European industries, and then the EU using taxpayers’ money to effectively give ‘EU Dole’ to those people affected. Surely it is the responsibility of the French Government, in this case, to help their people in this instance, and not British taxpayers. This is a national competency and for this reason I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2014/005 FR/GAD. As I was elected by the nation, marked by longstanding agricultural traditions, I felt the need to vote in favour of supporting the French abattoirs. The issue, which French authorities encountered, is very close to the situation that Lithuania experiences at the moment due to the Russian embargo.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Companies and the Member States themselves should come up with appropriate aid measures. The European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation is just a wipe for the bleeding and in practice means pumping out member states' financial resources.  Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly disapprove of these degrading practices. But with the funds from the European Fund, we are at least making sure that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and hope that it can contribute to those French workers who have lost their jobs.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for a motion for a resolution to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the laid-off 744 workers of the French company GAD, because these redundancies will have a major impact on the unemployment situation in Britain, where the agricultural sector, relative to the French average, has a major impact on the employment of the region.  The decrease in pigmeat consumption, closely linked to the global financial crisis and the trend of globalisation, has further exacerbated the situation in the GAD. In addition, the slaughterhouse and meat processing company GAD have found it difficult to wither price pressures and lower consumer purchasing power, but also external factors such as unfair competition in the internal market.  Furthermore, the age of most workers represents the possibility of exclusion from the labour market thereof, and insufficient engagement of local political bodies and trade unions has been established. Therefore, I believe that the EGF's financial contribution will be a concrete assistance to GAD workers affected by global structural changes.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is another perfect instance of the EU policy putting a business out of commercial viability and of the EU then using its funds, sourced from the UK amongst other Member States, to deal with the impact – effectively to pay dole payments! UKIP MEPs voted against since we do not agree that UK taxpayers should fund or support incoherent EU policies and by implication subsidise scenarios that fellow Member States should manage.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Anneli Jaatteenmaki's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Gad's sacked employees in Brittany. EUR 918,000 will be provided for 744 laid-off workers from this company to help them reintegrate into the labour market, including through training. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by France concerning redundancies in the meat processing company, GAD. This fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I am the the fore, the most pleased, for the adoption of this financial aid, amounting to more than EUR 910,000.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy. Anneli Jäätteenmäki. As in the previous case, it is a question of allocating resources to ensure the reintegration into the labour market of some redundant workers. In this particular case, these are the workers of GAD société anonyme simplifiée, an economic company classified in Division 10 of NACE Rev. 2 ("Food Industries"), who lost their jobs in France as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. In this respect, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be able to make a positive and concrete contribution.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the JAATTEENMAKI report aimed at mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 744 sacked employees of the French company GAD. The EGF will finance 60% (EUR 918,000 At a total cost of EUR 1,530,000) the establishment of a reclassification unit for these employees made redundant following the crisis in the European agri-food sector, which is very marked in the Brittany and Loire regions.  Faced with the difficulties posed by mass unemployment, the EGF is once again proving to be an effective tool by offering sustainable prospects to sacked employees.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. — On 25Th of November, the European Parliament voted on a grant of EUR 918,000 to promote the reclassification of the 760 workers laid off by GAD. I voted for it, out of solidarity with these workers. This sum will in fact finance a "reclassification cell" which we hope will not be a decoy and that it will increase their chances, thanks to personalized training, of finding jobs. That said, the European Union is largely responsible for this human tragedy that has hit Britain hard. Indeed, the "detachment" directive and the ultra-liberal rules of the European market have allowed the German competitors of this company, which specialises in the slaughter of pigs and the processing of their meat, to compete unfairly by massively recruiting underpaid Romanians to break prices.  I therefore denounce the cynicism with which the European Union claims to calm the just anger of our sacked workers with alms. Ironically, this aid is taken from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, whose name proves that the European monster intends to continue to sacrifice French companies on the altar of its ultra-liberal globalisation.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - This is the mobilization of the EGF for France to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off at GAD s.a.s in Brittany (F) due to the economic crisis. The company operates in the food manufacturing sector. The amount of the financial contribution amounts to EUR 918 000 and affects a total of 760 beneficiaries. In the face of Europe's economic and financial crisis and the competitiveness crisis in our industry, it is necessary to support the mobilization of funds like this under the above conditions.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help France, as the global economic and financial crisis has resulted in a significant redundancy of workers to be helped to re-enter the labour market.  The European Globalisation Fund has been created to provide additional support to workers made redundant as a result of the effects of the global financial and economic crisis to help re-enter the labour market. This report aims to mobilise around €1 million for consultations and guidance, all for the purpose of restoring laid-off food industry workers in France to the labour market.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting against the Jäätteenmäki report because paragraph 18 of the report distributes a very low level of resources per worker, which amounts to only EUR 1200.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported this proposal. The French authorities argue that the global financial and economic crisis led to reduced pig meat consumption in Europe, which in turn caused a decline in the production of pig meat and throughput of abattoirs such as GAD. While pig meat consumption in 2007 was still 43 kg per annum per head of population, it had dropped to 39 kg per annum in 2013. This decline in consumption, caused by the global financial and economic crisis, affected other types of meat as well, but hit pork particularly hard, as its price had been increasing faster than that of other meats, particularly beef.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France to support the reintegration into employment of the 565 workers made redundant at GAD, a pigmeat slaughter and processing company. The EGF is one of the most important instruments by which the EU can actually intervene in support of redundant workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - The aim of the EGF is to support, through training and reintegration programmes, those who lose their jobs as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. My agreement with the Jäätteenmäki report, which supports the mobilisation of this financial instrument, for the benefit of 744 workers made redundant in a Breton company operating in the slaughter sector, stems from the conviction that it really contributes to generating new employment opportunities.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for STX Finland OY should be supported, as the company concerned fulfils all the criteria for support. It is also very commendable that the Finnish Government has already started to provide assistance to the workers concerned before the EU applies for assistance. This willingness to act will allow us to be sure that the funds provided by the Union will be used in a meaningful way and will only benefit the workers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Aid Fund is playing its destructive role. Instead of helping workers it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. The case of the pig slaughterhouses of the Gad company in Brittany, is a typical example of the consequences of the directive "detachment" of workers which institutionalizes social dumping in the Union. While the sites concerned closed, Gad, through a foreign temporary company, hired about 100 Romanian workers at his other site in Morbihan, paid 600 euros a month. The company therefore saves money on social security contributions that are paid, as stipulated in the European directive, in the country of origin. In addition, the report notes the lack of consultation with local authorities and trade unions in this FEAM. The Commission's analysis even states that "the dismissed workers had not been informed of the FEAM's request for intervention". In these conditions I vote AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to France to give this aid to France, which submitted the EGF/2014/005 FR/GAD application on 6 June 2014, following the dismissal of 744 workers at GAD société anonyme simplifiée, a company operating in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 division 10 (Food Industries).

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on 760 persons affected by difficulties such as unfair competition within the internal market and the absence of a decent minimum wage in the agro-agricultural industry. These funds will contribute to the implementation of personalised services for these workers, to the reconversion programmes and processes of the local economic system. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report in order to aid these affected workers in finding employment.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the decision adopted by the European Parliament to help the 760 sacked employees of the French company GAD through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, up to EUR 918,000. GAD, a company active in meat slaughter and processing, has been hit hard by the global economic and financial crisis on the one hand and the decline in meat consumption on the other. Gad's financial difficulties are thus directly linked to a major change in the structure of global trade. That is why we felt it was essential to help the workers of this company through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the Report for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in France, which relates to 760 redundancies in France and will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package providing assistance for the reintegration of those redundant workers into employment.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. GAD (Division 10 "Food Industries"), based in Brittany and the Loire Region (France), has applied for a grant of 918,000 euros under the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF), in order to contribute to the conversion of 760 sacked employees. The Breton SLAUGHTERHOUSEs GAD, which specialise in the cutting and processing of pork, have suffered the full consequences of the ultraliberal model and the free and undistorted competition imposed by Brussels. Although consumption of pork in France has been declining steadily since 2007, from 43 kg per year per capita to 39 kg in 2013, no direct link can be made with the economic crisis (swine meat remains the most affordable). On the other hand, it should be noted that, in order to stem this significant decline, the authorities are doing nothing, preferring, for example, to remove pork from school canteen menus and thus bending to the communitarian demands. GAD and its employees are victims of unfair competition and social dumping in the European market. I still voted for this grant so as not to further penalize the 760 people made redundant from GAD.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will unlock EUR 918,000 for 760 licensees of the French company GAD. This vote recognizes that GAD is a victim of the crisis as well as of globalization. This support from Europe will enable a personalised service to be set up so that employees can find a job. I hope that this aid can compensate for the French government's inaction on this issue.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted two reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these two reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 918,000 euros from this fund to 760 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of the COMPANY GAD in Brittany.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I welcome this vote, which is providing almost EUR 1 million for GAD employees. Britain sees this as proof that, in the turmoil, it can count on the European Union. I strongly support the European Parliament's request to the French government to propose a more ambitious plan given the scale of the needs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for GAD in France should be supported, since the company concerned meets all the criteria for support. Particular attention must be paid to the fact that almost one fifth of those who have been made redundant so far are between 55 and 64 years old. Those affected are particularly at risk of falling into long-term unemployment. This is to be prevented by the assistance offered by the French Government. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the fund.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This proposal follows the dismissal of 760 employees of GAD in France, mainly due to the decrease in pork consumption since the beginning of the economic crisis in Europe. This European aid will come to support these employees in the search for a new job or a career reorientation.  So I decided to vote in favour of mobilizing this fund.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 918 000 to France from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which will allow 744 people who became unemployed in the food industry as a result of redundancies.  Unemployment in the European Union increased dramatically as a result of the economic crisis. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can re-engage these people in the labour market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — It is essential that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund continues to demonstrate the European Union's solidarity with workers during this new programming period. Urgent and effective assistance will help to avoid disastrous consequences for people's lives and economies. In this context, I support this resolution, which proposes to mobilise the EGF for workers made redundant from a French slaughterhouse and meat processing plant in order to support their return to the labour market.  It is essential that the measures envisaged respect the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination and are directly linked to the provision of personalised services. It should be noted that the EGF improves the economic situation of the regions by helping workers retrain and acquire a new profession, renewing and improving job search skills. In addition, it enhances self-esteem and self-confidence. The measures are therefore well implemented with a long-term positive impact.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, given that the French authorities submitted the FR/GAD EGF/2014/005 application on 6 June 2014 following the dismissal of 744 workers of GAD société anonyme simplifiée, a company operating in the food industry, Given that, according to the French authorities, the GAD has been caught in the grip of double pressure on prices, namely that of farmers, who are struggling to cope with the rise in feed prices and that of consumers on low incomes, given that workers are already supported through various measures that help them find new jobs, and given that the Commission considered that the criteria for applying the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund were met, I therefore voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — Once again, the European Union is trying to partially compensate for the damage it is causing by its blind ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to bother anyone. I am voting for this aid to employees who are victims of European ultra-liberalism.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported rapporteur Anneli Jäätteenmäki's report. In the world of market economy and globalisation, many companies and their workers are affected by structural reforms aimed at eliminating unprofitableness and poor resource allocation. In the case of the French FAD, there has been double pressure, on the one hand from farmers struggling with rising food prices and on the other from consumers struggling with reduced incomes.  I supported a proposal by the European Commission and the Council to provide financial assistance to GAD, a food production of EUR 918 000. The process of quick assistance to people who have been dismissed in the form of creating personalized services tailored to each individual is very useful, but I think it would be useful for the French Government to present a more complex programme with a broader aspect of the measures.  The data showing the level of severity is the fact that the Brittany region is more dependent on the agricultural sector than the rest of France, 11% brittany, and on average 5% France, so this redundancy of workers in the region is reflected in the entire French economy. In the face of a difficult economic situation and a large increase in unemployment, we need to shift our focus to mitigating the crisis.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The mobilisation of the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) is this time in favour of France for the occupational reintegration of workers made redundant by GAD, a food industry company, in accordance with a proposal for a decision adopted by the Commission. The French authorities have stated that the world economic crisis has led to a fall in pigmeat consumption in Europe, which has been higher than the consumption of other types of meat because its price has increased more exponentially due to the increase in the cost of pig feed (such as maize, wheat, barley and soya) which in turn has suffered a reduction in production due to the drought that has affected pigmeat areas. Production. I hope that the tailored services for workers funded by the fund will help them retrain. In this particular case, it is a counselling and guidance service that a group of experts will give to workers.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — I have rejected this request. The French side argues that the great depression has led to a reduction in meat consumption. In addition, prices for pig feed have risen sharply in recent years. As a result of the closure of a slaughterhouse, France is applying for funds from the Fund. It is incomprehensible why the EU has to claim competence here. It is also necessary to ask to what extent these events are linked to the issue of globalisation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Conditions in the pork market have worsened significantly in recent years leading companies, such as GAD, to close. I therefore vote in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is aimed at helping workers who are made redundant in such a situation to help them retrain and start a business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — France has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 760 redundancies at GAD, which operates in division 10 of NACE Rev. 2 (Food Industries), in the Regions of Brittany and the Pays de la Loire, during the period from 29 November 2013 to 28 March 2014. According to the Commission, that application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are linked to the economic and financial crisis, which caused a reduction in pork consumption, related to the decrease in consumer incomes and the increase in pig feed prices , and, on the other hand, that such redundancies have a significant adverse impact on the Brittany region, whose employment depends more on the agricultural sector than the French national average. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of France.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of providing 900,000 euros in aid to people formerly employed by the French slaughtering and processing company GAD. Affected by the fall in pork consumption, it has recorded losses of 65 million euros over the last 3 years. This aid comes from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is dedicated to workers in the sectors most affected by the crisis. It will be intended to co-finance measures to support job search, training, or initiation to entrepreneurship for the former employees concerned.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 918 000, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 760 workers who have lost their JOBS GAD, abattoir and meat processing company, located in the Brittany region of France, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include measures to advise and guide workers dismissed by a team of expert advisers (reclassification cell), whose mission is to support laid-off workers and help them find solutions that allow them to continue in the labour market and get another job. These aids constitute good assistance for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the vote of this report, which aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 744 workers of the French agri-food company GAD who were dismissed in June 2014. As the company has suffered serious difficulties, including unfair competition within the internal market from companies that have misused the Detachment of Workers Directive, I reiterate my request here to see this directive revised as soon as possible.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — As in the Finnish case discussed above (A8-0043/2014), I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) proposed by the French authorities following the dismissal of 760 GAD Société Anonyme Simplifiée workers, which was the second application voted at the Strasbourg Plenary session. In addition to what I said earlier in the French case, I would just like to point out that I believe that the EGF is, alongside cohesion policies and the structural funds, a clear example of what intra-European solidarity should be.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report to provide financial and professional assistance to the 760 employees of the GAD company, at a time when the pork industry is facing major difficulties in Brittany. This will be an aid of 918,000 euros for the sacked employees of this company, in order to support them in their reintegration into the job market in an efficient and sustainable way.  Having always defended the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of this text because Europe must be close to its citizens, especially in times of crisis.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of intervention in favour of 760 redundancies in the pigmeat slaughter and processing sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this Fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue their social rights.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. - Thanks to todayʼs vote France was granted EGF aid to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at GAD. GAD société anonyme simplifiée operates in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 10 (ʽManufacturing of food productsʼ).  The French authorities argue that the global financial and economic crisis led to reduced pig meat consumption in Europe, which in turn caused a decline in the production of pig meat and throughput of abattoirs such as GAD. The EUR 918 000 in aid will pay for personalised services consisting of advice and guidance to the 760 redundant workers, provided by a team of expert consultants.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the area of cooperation on budgetary matters and sound financial management in France. Following the dismissal of GAD société anonyme simplifiée workers, the French authorities applied for a financial contribution from the EGF and the Commission concluded after its assessment that the conditions for granting financial support from the EGF had been met.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation. Closing large companies or moving production outside the EU, which may be the result of the global economic and financial crisis, puts EU nationals who are out of work at a disadvantage. This report aims to mobilise €918,000 to help redundate workers look for a new job through counselling and professional orientation, in order to return to the labour market as soon as possible.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Given that on June 6, 2014, France has applied for the launch of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, due to the redundancies of 744 workers at GAD société anonyme simplifiée in France, and taking into account Council Regulation No 1001/2013. 1311/2013 as of 2 December 2013, setting out the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, the application meets all the criteria necessary to mobilise the fund. As the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) dictates, it was set up to support redundant and self-employed workers whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, as a result of the continuing global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. I support the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, tabled by France, to provide a financial contribution of EUR 918 000.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. - The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore the ECR will vote against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The money from the adjustment fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration companies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - I have spoken in favour of this aid. As a reminder, on 24 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favour of France in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at GAD, a simplified limited company active in the economic sector classified in Division 10 ("Food Industries") of NACE Rév. 2, due to the global financial and economic crisis.  The French authorities argue that the global financial and economic crisis has led to a decline in pork consumption in Europe which, in turn, has led to a decrease in the production of pork and that of slaughterhouses such as GAD. While pork consumption in 2007 was still 43 kg per year per capita, it was only 39 kg per year in 2013. This decline in consumption, due to the global financial and economic crisis, affected other types of meat, but hit pig meat particularly hard, whose price had risen faster than that of other meats, especially beef.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is based on France's request for a financial contribution of EUR 918 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, due to the redundancies of a total of 760 workers from .  I believe that such packages of measures represent only short-term solutions for laid-off workers and further aggravate the poor economic situation, which is particularly reflected in the sectors affected by the crisis. Namely, it is the Member States that should provide their companies with a healthy business framework that will enable them to be competitive on the global market, which presupposes tax relief and the removal of bureaucratic barriers holding back investment and business.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The French company GAD, for the slaughter and processing of meat, has fired 760 workers presenting as an argument the pressure on prices. On the other hand, it is unacceptable that the process leading to these redundancies did not have any negotiations with workers' representatives and trade unions, and that it intends to channel funding to private employment firms into the said process of integrating the workers affected, rather than applying this money to more direct aid to the injured. France submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 918,000. Although it can bring some momentary relief to workers, this fund is nothing more than a crutch created by the capital to enable redundancies, giving a handout to reassure conscience and public opinion. What is in practice is that this fund does not re-place the hundreds of thousands of jobs extinguished throughout the EU, but it is urgent to profoundly change the policies that extinguish them.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — I support the request for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for gad société anonyme simplifiée in France, as all the criteria were met by the company concerned. It should also be noted that there is a risk that around 17 per cent of those made redundant will become long-term unemployed, as they are already over 55 years of age. That is the basis of this, i voted in favour of the motion.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The economic and social crisis, a consequence of the exploitative nature with the aim of maximum profit of the capitalist system, affects thousands of families through measures to reduce incomes and increase taxes, with a drop in associated consumption and the increase in prices of consumer products. This is a snowball whose results affect workers every day, aggravating the exploitation of a cheap and devoid of rights workforce. The French company GAD, which slaughters and processes meat, has fired 760 workers, presenting as an argument the pressure on prices, both by farmers, who are struggling with the increase in the price of rations, and by consumers, who see their income swell and the impossibility of buying their meat increase. It is unacceptable that the process leading to these redundancies did not count on any negotiations with the representatives of the workers and trade unions. It also wants to channel funding to private employment firms into the so-called process of integrating affected workers, rather than applying this money to more direct aid to the injured. France has submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 918,000, which we voted in favour of, although we consider this solution to be wrong.

name: John Stuart Agnew Jonathan Arnott James Carver William (The Earl of) Dartmouth Bill Etheridge and Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. - UKIP does not recognise the authority of any EU court, including the one which this report called on an opinion from. We would usually vote against any report that recognises EU court authority. However, given the possible concerns about personal data security, we decided to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán Javier Couso Permuy Paloma López Bermejo Y Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - On 19 November 2013, the European Data Protection Supervisor delivered his opinion on the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on the processing and transfer of passenger name registration data. In that opinion, it questioned the necessity and proportionality of PNR schemes and large transfers of PNR data to third countries, as well as the choice of legal basis.  I voted in favour of this report as it asks the Court for an opinion on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties, as there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the draft agreement with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52 , paragraph (1) as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data. Further, it calls into question the choice of legal basis, namely Article 82(1)(d) and Article 87(2)(a) TFEU (police and judicial cooperation), rather than Article 16 TFEU (data protection).

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - On 2 December 2010, the Council adopted a decision and a negotiating directive authorising the Commission, on behalf of the EU, to open negotiations on an agreement with Canada on the transfer and processing of PNR data in the context of counter-terrorism. Legal uncertainty has arisen since the Court annulled the Data Retention Directive in its judgment in related cases C-293/12 and C-594/12 on 8 April 2014. The purpose of the agreement is to define the conditions under which PNR data may be transferred and used and how data should be protected. In my view, it is not appropriate to obtain an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the agreement with the Treaties before the issue is discussed in the relevant committees. That is why I rejected this motion for a resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compliance of the EU-Canada Agreement on the processing and transfer of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data by air carriers to EU legislation. In 2005, the EU concluded an agreement with Canada on the processing of Passenger Name Record data. Following the expiry of the relevant Commission decision on 22 September 2009, the European legal basis for the transfer of PNR data to the Canadian Border Guard ceased to exist. As there is legal uncertainty today as to whether the draft new agreement complies with the provisions of the EU Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights relating to individuals' rights to the protection of personal data, I support the decision to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the agreement with the EU Treaties.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. As part of the negotiations on the AECG agreements (CETA), the European Parliament is seeking the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of eu treaties with the proposed transfer of data from air carriers. Although I doubted in advance the reliability of the opinion that will be given, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Council sought the approval of the European Parliament on the PNR Data Processing Agreement signed with Canada on June 25, 2014.  On 30 September 2013, the European Data Protection Supervisor issued its opinion on the agreement questioning the need and proportionality of PNR systems and mass data transfers to third countries, as well as the choice of the legal basis.  On 8 April 2014, the Court of Justice declared the Data Retention Directive invalid. It was therefore appropriate to refer the matter to the Court of Justice as to whether the draft agreement with Canada is consistent with the provisions of the treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights with respect to the right of individuals to the protection of personal data.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution because, since it is the objective of the Agreement to lay down conditions under which passenger name registration (PNR) data can be transferred and used to CBSA and to establish how to protect data, there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility with certain articles of the EU Treaty and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. That is why I think it is appropriate to ask the Court for an opinion on the compatibility of the Treaty Agreement.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the exchange of information on air crossings following the agreement between the European Union and Canada on 25 June must enable a more effective fight against terrorism.  Recognizing the length of the procedure by requesting an opinion from the ECJ, I nevertheless believe that legally requesting treaty compatibility with the Canada-EU agreement on the transfer and processing of passenger data (PNR) is necessary from the point of view of the protection and use of this data in order to avoid any uncertainty regarding the rights of individuals to the protection of personal data. I therefore voted in favour of that opinion.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Court of Justice to rule on the compatibility of the PNR agreement between the EU and Canada with the European Treaties.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Resolution to urge the Court of Justice of the European Union to rule on the compatibility with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on the processing and transfer of passenger name registration data. The Court's judgment of 8 April 2014 declaring the Data Retention Directive invalid raises legal uncertainties as to the compatibility of the draft Agreement with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7 and 8 and Article 52(1)), so it is relevant to seek an opinion from the CJER in this regard to ensure respect for the right of persons to the protection of their personal data.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained from voting on this text because I believe that the European Union must be at the forefront of data protection and that an exchange of data like this can clearly harm European citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union is preparing to conclude a PNR agreement with Canada to facilitate the transfer of the personal data of air transport users to combat jihadist terrorism. In practical terms, this agreement will allow Canadian authorities to access data collected by air carriers during booking and check-in procedures and store it for a period of five years. This data relates, for example, to information relating to the name, address, telephone number but also the credit card number or information relating to the passenger's luggage.  These measures, in addition to participating in the widespread registration of European citizens, will not be able to effectively combat jihadist networks, which are likely to carry out attacks in Europe or Canada.  Indeed, the fight against jihadist terrorism involves firstly the restoration of border controls of the Member States, the cessation of wild immigration, and the dissolution of fundamentalist associations with proven close links with the supporters of the Islamic State. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution submitting the PNR agreement to the opinion of the European Court of Justice.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour: asking for greater guarantees for the right to privacy is necessary in view of the abuses and violations that are committed in violation of fundamental personal freedoms.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the request for the European Court of Justice to give its opinion on the EU-Canada agreement signed on 25 June on aspects of passenger data transfer (PNR). It is essential that legal uncertainty is disbanded as to the compatibility of the draft EU-Canada agreement with the provisions of the TREATIES and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights with regard to the right of individuals to the protection of personal data. There are obvious privacy implications that deserve all attention. I note that PNR has proved to be a useful tool for combating serious crime and, specifically, the current agreement with Canada has allowed the seizure of large quantities of cocaine and the significant reduction in cases of child abduction and trafficking in child pornography. The adoption of the motion does not stop the transfer of PNR data to Canada, which continues within the framework of the current understanding.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - The right to respect for private and family life and the right to the protection of personal data are enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights; Article 52 of the Charter makes the legality of restrictions subject to those rights subject to respect for the principle of proportionality, thus making only the restrictions actually necessary for purposes of general interest recognised by the Union or to protect the rights and freedoms of others admissible. The Court of Justice, in its judgment of 8 April, provided some clarifications which, however, do not provide an answer to the problem of the validity of the agreement between Canada and the Union on PNR, but which in many respects support the doubts, which are also highlighted by the European Data Protection Supervisor. Precisely because of the complexity and sensitivity of this issue, I believe it is appropriate to allow the Court of Justice to express itself at this stage, so as to overcome any legal uncertainty and be sure to approve an agreement that is fully in line with the fundamental rights of citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution. I consider it populist and useless at this stage. The PNR system, which has already been rejected by this Parliament, is an instrument for combating international organised crime and, above all, terrorism, the greatest threat to public security these days. This resolution, if adopted, would have slowed down the achievement of a new agreement with Canada for a remodulation of data exchange, but it would not have stopped the current flow of information in ways that no one likes. I do not support initiatives that go against the interests of the people I represent.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Security is undoubtedly a key issue for the European Union and its citizens. Concern that has been growing since 2001, due to the rise of organized crime and terrorism. In the name of security, however, we cannot jeopardize the fundamental rights of citizens. Their restriction should be essential and proportionate only. These issues are all the more current when it is still unclear what the impact of the latest Judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union (C-293/12 and C-594/12) on the Data Retention Directive is still unclear. However, I cannot remain indifferent to the way in which this resolution was tabled, for disrespecting the practice of the European Parliament and, in particular, the members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. So I decided to abstain.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — In 2005, the EU adopted the agreement on the transfer of passenger data requested by the USA and Canada following the attacks of 11 September 2001. An amendment to this agreement was submitted to the European Union earlier this year, in respect of which a request for an opinion was raised to the Court of Justice of the European Union on compatibility with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. I voted against the request for an opinion from the Court of Justice because I believe that the new amended agreement on the transfer of passenger data is absolutely valid and therefore a court intervention is quite unnecessary. In today's situation in which the threat of terrorism has awakened in the form of new extremist groups, such as that of the Islamic State, the correct identification of each individual and the exchange of data on it are certainly necessary in favour of greater security and protection of the citizens of the countries that are part of the agreement. Furthermore, this agreement would ensure more effective management of border systems, guaranteeing citizens the right not to be subject to unnecessary suspicion or control, the result of a lack of information on the part of the authorities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have abstained from voting for or against this motion for a resolution as I would have expected the relevant Committees to be given adequate time to consider such an important issue. At the same time, in view of significant doubts in relation to data retention and data transfers, issues that are closely linked with privacy rights and fundamental rights, the Court’s decision would bring clarity and provide parameters within which a balance between rights and public interest is to be reached. While Parliament, Commission and Council have the necessary authority to transact such agreements, their work is subject to the review of the Court of Justice.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. In 2005, the European Union concluded an agreement with Canada on the processing of passenger data on the basis of a series of commitments by the Canadian Agency for Cross-Border Services in relation to the implementation of its reservation code programme by air carriers. I am in favour of adopting this resolution because this agreement does not provide sufficient guarantees for the protection of passengers' personal data. Compatibility with the Judgment of the Court of Justice, which declared the Data Retention Directive invalid, is being discussed. I support the rapporteur's request because the conclusion of an international agreement providing for lower standards of data protection than the protection afforded by current European legislation would be binding on any new provisions on the transfer of data to third countries.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. - Passenger Name Record (PNR) data is provided by passengers, collected by air carriers and used for their ticketing, reservation, and check-in systems. PNR data contains several kinds of information, including names, addresses, passport numbers, credit card information, information on whom one is travelling with, travel routes, seating preferences, check-in times and methods, meal preferences. The agreement with Canada in question involves the Canadian Border Services Agency (BSA) requesting passenger air carriers flying into and out of Canada to provide PNR data before passengers enter or leave Canadian territory. Whilst agreeing with the fight against terrorism and serious cross-border crime, here we are dealing with peopleʼs personal data and we need to make sure that this agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. That is why I support the decision to seek an opinion from the Court of Justice.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I regret that, by this vote, the European Parliament has failed to send a positive signal to European citizens and our international partners for better cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. The agreement between the European Union and Canada on the processing and transfer of passenger records (PNR) data by air carriers to the Canada Border Services Agency is now frozen pending an opinion from the European Court of Justice.  At a time when terrorist and jihadist threats are increasingly worrying, it is deplorable that politicians are voting by ideology at the expense of security. Under the pretext of seeking better protection of personal data, left-wing parties have delayed for months or even years the conclusion of this agreement, which they are opposed to. Contrary to what is claimed, this decision runs counter to better protection for European citizens. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. - Passenger Name Records (PNR) are personal data provided by passengers to airlines for commercial reasons. These figures are an important tool to help fight crime, because they are communicated by air carriers to accredited facilities with the aim of combating terrorism, drug trafficking and other serious crime. The current agreement with Canada has stopped cases of child abduction and allowed the seizure of large quantities of cocaine and child pornography. I voted against this motion for a resolution because the time taken for a ruling by the Court of Justice could vary from 2 to 4 years, which will lead to significant delays in finalising the agreement with Canada.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — By its opinion, the Court of Justice will finally provide a legal basis for the processing and transfer of passenger data under the so-called PNR (Passenger Name Record) agreements. This will establish a framework for future agreements between the European Union and Canada and with other countries in the future.  It should also improve and strengthen international cooperation in the fight against terrorism.  And why not pave the way for a European NRL.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting in favour, because there is indeed a legal ambiguity as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1)) concerning the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data. We also agree to consult the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — Relations between the European Union and Canada on the processing of passenger name record data are almost 10 years old. However, since 2009, the legal basis for the transfer of data from the European Union to Canada has ceased to exist, even though the Border Services of that country has unilaterally decided to ensure that the EU fulfils the obligations under that agreement. The Council itself has already endorsed the Commission for the start of negotiations for a new agreement. The truth is that the European Data Protection Supervisor has raised doubts about the necessity and proportionality of this agreement and the Court itself has declared the Data Retention Directive invalid. With so many legal uncertainties, clarification is urgently needed on this matter from the competent authorities, in particular the Court of Justice.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We supported the sending of the draft agreement with Canada on the transfer and processing of passenger name record (PNR) data to the European Court of Justice. This is a means of postponing the adoption and entry into force of measures which we believe violate the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens, both in Canada and in the EU Member States. The PNR agreement aims to transmit information held by airlines about the itineraries and personal data of each passenger. The purpose, use and retention of this information remains sour in great uncertainty. Concerns are healed by the known espionage scandals. The negotiation and future implementation of this agreement is also a counter to the sovereign right of each country to decide whether or not to conclude it, as well as whether to block it or terminate it. The dangers of this agreement are increasingly evident, especially in the context of the serious crisis we are experiencing which has justified the destruction of social rights and achievements, democratic freedoms and rights.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. - It is very important that the fundamental rights of every citizen of the European Union are protected. Fundamental rights include the right to data protection and, as with previous PNR proposals, the agreement between Canada and the European Union on the transfer and processing of passenger name record data, it is the responsibility of the European Parliament and each Member to represent the interests of the citizens of the Member States in the first place.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of the proposal because I think it is not at all wrong to demand greater guarantees of the right to privacy. On the contrary, it is right, given the abuses and violations that are sometimes committed in violation of fundamental personal freedoms.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transmission and processing of passenger record (PNR) data by air carriers to the Office for Border Services of Canada, because there is indeed a legal ambiguity as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7 , 8 and 52 (1) and in relation to the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data. We also agree with the Court of Justice being consulted on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transfer and processing of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data by air carriers to the Canadian Border Services Agency. I voted in favour, because I do agree that the Court of Justice should express an opinion on the compatibility of the agreement with the Treaties regarding PNR data usage. We should not forget that the transfer of PNR data amounts to a violation of EU data protection. I truly believe that all of us should respect the fundamental rights of citizens of the Union.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the court's opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on the transfer and processing of passenger name record data. I believe that this agreement is an essential tool in the fight against terrorism and international crime. In this regard, I appreciate the position of the PPE Group and call for an end to the application of the legal framework for data transfer, in the absence of which the concern for the security of citizens is just a slogan.  The tense geopolitical context, in particular the presence of more than 3,000 European combatants among terrorist movements in the Middle East, is forcing much closer transatlantic cooperation. Similar attention to the other political groups, if they are still so concerned about respecting the rights of European citizens, would be desirable for the abolition of visas imposed on citizens of some EU Member States by Canada and the US. Romanian and other new citizens are still deprived of the fundamental right to free movement and are discriminated against in relation to the citizens of most Member States.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — When utopianism and ideology take over on lucidity and realism, we lead to the adoption of a resolution that sacrifices the security of citizens and makes our traditional partners the purveyors of our freedoms. In referring the agreement on the transfer of passenger data between the European Union and Canada for consideration before the Court of Justice, we have just demonstrated that: - the European Parliament, failing to know how to weigh in with the Council and the Commission, is unable to discern the security requirement claimed by its own citizens and to assume its responsibilities as a legislator; - the left-wing coalition and the National Front, never short of discourse on the protection of citizens, have just assumed the danger of travellers and the risk that their data will be transferred outside a legal framework by ignoring the agreement and rejecting any form of Americanism;  - these same groups, which did not fail to send messages of support to Canada at the time of the attack on Parliament, immediately designate this essential partner in the fight against terrorism as abhorrent manipulator and enemy of democracy. A great lesson in diplomacy and a real vision for Europe!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for a motion for a resolution on seeking the Court's opinion on the transfer and processing of passenger name list data (Canada - European Union), as this further ensures and protects the right of individuals to the protection of personal data, and it has been established that this right is often violated and abused. I also believe that the opinion of a European body such as the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Treaties can further contribute to a general sense of security and correctness.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – As a UKIP MEP and as a member of the EFDD Group, I do not recognise the authority of any EU Court, including the one from which this report called for an opinion. UKIP MEPs would usually vote against any report that recognises EU Court authority. However, given the possible concerns about personal data security, I and fellow UKIP MEPs decided to abstain.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I support the request from the Parliament for a legal opinion from the Court of Justice on the Passenger Name Record agreement between the EU and Canada. It is critical that we strike the correct balance between ensuring security and personal liberty, within the legal framework. We need to be sure that the agreement does not go too far at the expense of personal freedom and data protection.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against this resolution calling for the case to be referred to the Court of Justice on the compatibility between the treaties and the agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transfer and processing of passenger record data (PNR). The text aims to delay the entry into force of the agreement signed on 25 June 2014 after two-year negotiations. This new agreement strengthens the protection of travellers by bringing an administrative or judicial remedy before The Canadian courts. The text was adopted by a majority of 383 votes in person, 271 against and 47 abstentions, which I regret.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against the resolution calling for the European Court of Justice to be referred for advice on the treaty compatibility of the agreement signed on 25 June 2014 between Canada and the European Union on the transfer and processing of passenger name data (PNR). The transfer of PNR data aims to enable better prevention and detection of terrorist offences or serious forms of transnational crime. It is therefore an essential tool to combat organised crime and ensure the safety of European citizens. The European Union already has an agreement on the transfer and use of PNR data with the Canadian authorities. The main objective of this new agreement is to strengthen the legal framework for the use, protection and access of PNR data, in order to provide better guarantees for air passengers. Thus, this resolution will cause a significant delay in the implementation of the agreement and deprive many European air passengers of a substantial legal framework regarding the processing of their data.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – There are several legal questions with the agreement. I have therefore supported a request for a legal opinion from the European Court of Justice before voting on it. We should not rush into an agreement that has potentially far-reaching consequences for the civil liberties of EU citizens and might undermine ongoing work on the data protection package. We need to have legal certainty that the agreement is fully in line with EU fundamental rights before consenting to this international agreement.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. — With regard to the referral of the PNR security agreement with Canada to the ECJ, I was in favour of this issue being discussed first in the relevant committee. The decisive factor is that a review by the ECJ will take a long time. In the meantime, there is uncertainty about the scope. When passing on passenger data, it is necessary to decide whether the need for security is above the right to data sensitivity. The scheme helps in particular in the fight against terrorism by recording suspicious movements. This is legitimate in view of the increasing number of returning terrorism suspects worldwide. Unfortunately, we have recently seen canadians in particular being exposed to terrorist attacks when terrorists invaded the Canadian Parliament a few weeks ago and took people hostage there for hours. Canada is a reliable partner for the EU.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) My vote against the motion for a resolution on the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaty of the Agreement between Canada and the EU on the transfer and processing of PNR data is not to be interpreted as a lack of attention to the protection of citizens' data.  Instead, it is a form of further protection for European citizens. It is undeniable that PNR has proved to be a useful tool for combating terrorism, drug trafficking and other serious forms of crime. We cannot afford any further delays in finalising the agreement with Canada, which would under no circumstances stop the transfer of PNR data to canada, which would continue within the framework of the current agreement. Furthermore, we cannot prejudge the European Commission's work on a PNR directive which aims to harmonise the rules and procedures by which Member States oblige air carriers operating to and from their territory to communicate PNR data for security purposes. It is a question of having the safety of our citizens at heart and not of prejudicing the protection of their personal data.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have decided to vote against this report, because I believe it is inappropriate to extend the time taken to ratify the agreement that is the subject of this report, given also the excellent relations between the EU and Canada. I understand the request to take the matter to the Court of Justice, but I think that having already ratified these agreements, which had previously been examined and considered compatible with the Treaties, insisting on the request could conceal a mere delaying tactic.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The Passanger Name Record in EU-Canada relations focuses on air transport. It is aviation (airports, airlines) that are important partners in the implementation of the provisions of reasonable protection of personal data and fundamental rights in the agreement with ensuring anti-terrorist security.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. - The N-VA is committed to privacy and the protection of personal data. At the same time, we recognise that international Passenger Name Records (PNR) agreements are important for the protection of the rights and security of EU citizens, in particular in the fight against trafficking in human beings, child exploitation, organised crime, drug smuggling, terrorism, increasing radicalisation and in the current challenge of foreign fighters. We therefore want to explicitly justify our support for the speedy implementation of the new PNR agreement between the EU and Canada.  Firstly, data from European citizens is currently being exchanged under the old framework agreement with Canada (2006), which is considerably less stringent. The new agreement includes more rights for citizens, better data retention rules and increases independent oversight. Additional advice to the Court would lead to a significant delay, which would allow the less stringent rules to remain in force for longer and reduce the protection of EU citizens.
