Secondly, it is important for the EU to work on clear European rules for the exchange of data with third countries, resulting in better protection of EU citizens.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - It seems appropriate that the CJEO should be encouraged to rule on the compatibility of the EU-Canada PNR Agreement, given the questions raised about the compatibility of this Agreement with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. These concerns have been expressed by the EP Legal Service as well as the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS). It is very important for the S&D Group to maintain a guaranteeing position on fundamental rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting against the motion for a resolution because I consider, on the one hand, that the draft agreement to be adopted is incompatible with the provisions of the SLEE (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1)) as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data and, on the other hand, because it wrongly selects Articles 82(1)(d) and 87(2)(a) of the SEE (police and judicial cooperation) as the legal basis; , instead of the rectum, i.e. Article 16 of the SLEE (data protection).

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. — We voted in favour of this draft resolution which will allow the European Parliament to refer the accounting of the Passanger Name Records agreements with the treaties to the European Parliament because it supports the rights of European citizens and, by extension, the French.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported seeking an opinion from the Court of Justice on this agreement with Canada as I take the view that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1)) and as regards the right of individuals to protection of personal data.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Court of Justice to rule on the compatibility of the PASSENGER NAME Record (PNR) agreement between the EU and Canada with the European Treaties. This is a form of guarantee for the protection and security of European citizens and for the protection of their personal data.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have decided not to support the report, as I do not think it is unnecessary for the Court of Justice to be called upon to give its opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the agreement between Canada and the European Union on the transfer and processing of reservation code data by air carriers to the Canadian Border Services Agency.  The existence of similar agreements with other countries suggests that the Court will accept the legality of the text.   In short, I believe that this request is nothing more than a political decoy to delay the ratification of the agreement.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) I am opposed to comprehensive data storage, which is, above all, unfounded and indiscriminate. I therefore welcome this motion for a resolution, which aims to have the admissibility of this data retention of passenger data examined by the European Court of Justice.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The European Union reached an agreement with Canada on the processing of passenger records (PNR) data in 2005. A new agreement was signed in July 2014. Before its ratification, Parliament considers it necessary to verify its compliance with the provisions of the treaties and asks to refer the matter to the Court of Justice for advice. The issues at issue include the right of individuals to the protection of personal data. In order to preserve this right, I support this request from Parliament and I vote for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — I share the rapporteur's position of non-objecting to the Commission's delegated Regulation on the provisional system of advances in contributions to cover the administrative expenditure of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the name of the fight against terrorism an agreement has been reached between the European Union and Canada on the use of PNR (Passenger Name Record) data. This data containing various information such as name, address, passport and credit card number, itineraries and travel agency is provided by passengers and collected by airlines. However, in order for this agreement to enter into force it requires the approval of the European Parliament beforehand. By voting for the Court of Justice's request for advice, we place as a precondition the compatibility of the agreement with the treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights and thus reiterate the importance of ensuring a balanced approach between the need to ensure the safety of our citizens and to guarantee them the right to privacy and the protection of their data. As a Liberal, I am committed to finding the right balance between these two values.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I backed the request for asking the European Court of Justice for a legal opinion before voting on a planned agreement between the EU and Canada on the exchange of air passenger data (PNR) in the fight against serious crime and terrorism. The Agreement seriously interferes with the fundamental right to privacy and the protection of personal data; therefore, before endorsing it, I would like to ensure that the agreement will by no means increase the risk for EU citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. The European Parliament wishes to refer the matter to the European Court of Justice to legally verify the compatibility of the processing and transfer of PNRs (passenger records data) by air carriers to the Canada Border Services Agency, as part of the agreement between the European Union and Canada. It should be noted that the EPP tried to have this proposal removed from the agenda on the grounds that the procedure might be too long.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted against this resolution. Under the pretext of defending freedoms that are in no way threatened or protecting personal data that is not more threatened, seeking the opinion of the Court of Justice on this agreement would have set a very serious precedent likely to undermine the credibility and effectiveness of the fight against terrorism in Europe as well as in Canada. The PNR agreement is about strengthening the security of people travelling between Canada and the European Union, which is vital in a world where terrorism threatens us every day.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the result of today's vote, which saw my party, the Socialists and Democrats, the main progressive force in the European Parliament, support the request for a legal opinion by the Court of Justice of the European Union before the vote on the agreement between the EU and Canada on the exchange of air passenger data (PNR) in the context of the fight against crime and terrorism.  In my view, this is an obligatory step to avoid making the same mistakes as in the past. I refer in particular to the judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU, which last April declared the Data Retention Directive illegal because it would violate the fundamental right to privacy and the protection of personal data.  It is therefore essential to ensure that this agreement does not end in the same way. As legislators, we need to make sure that the decisions we take are in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights and current EU legislation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against the referral to the Court of Justice on the transfer of passenger data between the European Union and Canada. The current situation, after the terrorist attack in Ottawa in October and the proven returns of jihadists from Syria, the security of citizens requires that we share this type of data.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — This report is about whether or not the European Court of Justice should review the transfer of passenger data to Canada. Passengers' data is stored for up to five years. A total of up to 60 individual information (e.g. food requests, credit card details) are stored per person. I welcome this report and am opposed to comprehensive data collection and to legal certainty for EU citizens. It makes perfect sense to put the data retention of travel data to the legal test.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which raises a fundamental question to the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the treaties of the agreement between Canada and the European Union on the transfer and processing of passenger file data. In no way does the prospect of signing a transatlantic agreement justify a lowering of the level of protection of the personal data of European citizens, and the adoption of procedures that go against fundamental rights.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — Given the importance of this agreement, it is essential that legal uncertainty is removed. In order to ensure adequate protection of personal data, all doubts as to the compliance of this agreement with the EU Treaties must be allayed. The transfer of passenger data must strictly respect the principles of necessity and proportionality.  In particular, sensitive data must be unfiled through the automatic detection and erasure procedure for sensitive data. It is also important that the categories of PNR data to be processed be limited and the specific Canadian authorities to which PNR data may be transmitted are identified. In order to reduce access to personal data to the lowest level, a targeted mechanism for the assessment of PNR data against risk criteria should be established. There must be regular impartial supervision of compliance with the agreement. The agreement should therefore be mandatory so that no other Canadian authority has direct access to and access to PNR data on request. This will prevent abuses in order to circumvent the provisions of the agreement and ensure adequate protection of personal data.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης και Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece has been white on the resolution, because this does not condemn the EU's PNR agreement with Canada, which is an overt file of those travelling between EU Member States and Canada under the pretext of 'counter-terrorism' and 'security'. The JRC is in favour of rejecting and annulling this agreement because it concerns a matter of policy which cannot be referred to the courts and much more to the Court of Justice of the EU, which always operates on the basis and criterion of defending the interests of capital.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - Considering that in 2005 the European Union concluded an agreement with Canada on the processing of passenger name record (PNR) data, given that, with the expiry of the relevant Commission decision in September 2009, the European legal basis for the transmission of PNR data to the CBSA failed, given that the CBSA continued to provide the above data, considering that it was not necessary to sign a further agreement and considering that, following the entry into force of the In view of the fact that, in order to conclude new PNR agreements, the European Parliament must give its approval before they are adopted by the Council, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — For once, Parliament seems to be concerned about the coherence of the various EU regulations and wants to check whether the EU-Canada agreements are compatible with the treaties. Let us praise this concern, unfortunately, rare on so many other subjects. I therefore vote for this resolution.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I did not support the proposal for a resolution to seek the Opinion of the European Court of Justice on compliance with the treaties of the Agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transfer of passenger name data to the Canadian Border Services Agency and their processing, as it would slow down the entry into force of this useful agreement. We must continuously work for the safety of European Union citizens, and more recently we have been attracted to foreign warriors, European citizens and third-country citizens who go through EU territories to wars in Iraq and Syria and join ISIS. I am of the opinion that the measure of transmission and processing of airline passenger data is a step forward in increasing safety.  The data must only be used for the purpose of countering terrorism and criminal activity. Any misuse of data would lead to a serious demolition of the credibility of all agreements signed with third countries that must guarantee high security when keeping such data.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - There are a number of legal question marks surrounding the draft Agreement between the European Union and Canada. Although both the European Council and the Commission are instiling the European Parliament to approve the agreement expeditedly, I consider the European Parliament to be the safety insurance policy when it comes to protecting the rights of EU citizens. Fundamental rights undoubtedly include the right to the protection of personal data and the prevention of its misuse. Although ensuring security and counter-terrorism protection are among the fundamental tasks of any state, this must not be at the expense of automatically restricting citizens' rights. If we restrict these rights, we must have not only serious reasons for this, but also a legal basis, so that there are no doubts about the correctness of such actions in the future. I therefore consider the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the draft agreement to be a necessary basis for making any further political decisions.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The new PNR agreement negotiated with Canada is a very balanced text and also strengthens the guarantees regarding the processing of personal data. In addition, Canada, as agreed, has agreed to make a number of unilateral commitments. The 2010 resolution, where the EU opened PNR negotiations with Canada, set out minimum requirements that Canada fully complied with.  Thanks to this agreement, we have seen that PNR has been successful in terms of combating serious forms of crime, such as, for example, the seizure of large quantities of cocaine and the fight against child abduction and trafficking in child pornography. Accepting the Court of Justice's request to examine compatibility with the Treaties – and that is why I voted against – would lead to a major delay in finalising the agreement with Canada, even if there would be no consequences with regard to the transfer of PNR data to Canada. I hope that, in view of the excellent results achieved, we will soon be able to arrive at a harmonised EU PNR system.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. - I did not support today's draft decision for the European Parliament to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the Agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transfer and use of passenger name record (PNR) data by air carriers to the Canadian Border Services Agency with the Treaties. We asked for a more detailed discussion of the proposal in committees, but this was rejected by a majority of Parliament. I support this AGREEMENT between the EU and Canada, together with my faction in the EP, because it is an appropriate and effective tool to protect the security of citizens and to counter terrorist threats. I am, of course, aware of the sensitivity of the handling of personal data, but I believe that this problem is adequately regulated in the agreement.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — A situation of legal imbalance between the European Union and Canada is indeed detrimental to travellers and airlines. For the time being, legal security requires the adoption of such an agreement, which is why I am voting against a motion for a resolution that could render any decision inoperative because it is too late.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the rejection of the motion to postpone this vote, I voted against this request for an opinion to the Court of Justice, because I consider that the effects that the delay of the entry into force of the Agreement between the European Union and Canada on the transfer and processing of passenger name record (PNR) data may have been properly considered from the point of view of risks to international security , especially if we take into account that drawing up an opinion may, in some cases, take about 30 months.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. - European citizens expect the European Union to respond to the urgency posed by European fighters and the terrorist threat on its territory.  Measures to combat terrorism such as the NRL must, of course, respect the balance between the protection of fundamental freedoms and security.  However, I have decided to abstain on this vote because I do not think that the referral of the ECJ's opinion on this agreement is the right one. It is indeed the responsibility of the elected representatives in the European Parliament to take the most delicate political decisions, knowing that the Court will always ensure the proper application of the treaties. Without an agreement, PNR data will continue to be transferred, but without legal guidance, which will weaken the level of protection for passenger data in Canada. In the immediate future, it is the discussions on the European NRL that are likely to be blocked, while the European Union would benefit from its own rules more protective of personal data. In the meantime, Member States have already adopted their own PNR systems, giving rise to heterogeneous and uncoordinated measures, which only weaken the European Union's response against terrorism.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. - The exchange of information on air passengers is an essential element in the fight against terrorism. Signed on June 25, the agreement between the EU and Canada on the processing of this data is moving in the right direction and that is why I support it.  I also believe that this agreement should enter into force as soon as possible to ensure that the transfer and exploitation of our information guarantees the protection of the personal data of European citizens. Indeed, the 2005 agreement, which expired in 2009, has so far not found a successor. However, if we ask the Court of Justice for an opinion now, we are effectively postponing the adoption of this agreement by several months, as this opinion is suspensive. Given the experience with such agreements, I do not believe that this request is timely, so I did not wish to support it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution to urge the Court of Justice of the European Union to rule on the compatibility with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on the processing and transfer of passenger name registration data. The Court's judgment of 8 April 2014 declaring the Data Retention Directive invalid raises legal uncertainties as to the compatibility of the draft agreement with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1),) and it is therefore relevant to seek an opinion of the CJEO in this regard to ensure respect for the right of persons to the protection of your personal data.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this vote, Parliament decided to refer the agreement on the transfer of European air passenger data to Canada to the European Court of Justice (PNR agreement). Doubts have indeed been raised about: 1) the legal basis of this agreement and its necessity, as the European Commission has not demonstrated the need for mass data collection and storage; 2) proportionality (to the extent that the five-year retention period appears to be haphazard and not based on specific evidence); 3) limiting the purpose (the possibility that PNR data may be processed for the purpose of complying with a subpoena, warrant or order, even if it is limited to these issues or carried out by a court, potentially expands the purpose for which PNR data can be processed). The European Parliament will therefore question the Court on the legality of mass data transfers to third countries and its compliance with European law before voting on this agreement signed last June between the European Union and Ottawa.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider legal certainty and certainty with regard to the conclusion of International Agreements of the European Union with other Member States to be very important. As regards the Agreement concluded in 2005 between the European Union and Canada on the processing of passenger name record data which, in the meantime, ceased its effects due to lack of european legal basis for this purpose, there are well-founded legal doubts as to the choice of legal basis and, on the other hand, the compatibility of the draft of a new agreement with the provisions of the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the european union on the right of persons to the protection of personal data. For that reason, I see it essential to clarify the question of the compatibility of this Agreement with the Treaties before the Court of Justice, which is why I voted in favour of the submission of this opinion to that European judicial body.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against this request for a referral to the Court for advice on the PNR agreement with Canada. In the current security environment, this new arrangement, which has been negotiated for almost two years, will strengthen the protection of travellers who can now file an administrative or judicial appeal before Canadian courts.  The request and vote of this referral to the Court is a bad signal sent by the European Union to Canada, when it has just been the victim of an attack on its soil and has always been an essential partner in both the fight against terrorism and our trade relations.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe it is absolutely right to call for greater guarantees for the right to privacy in view of the abuses and violations that are sometimes committed in violation of fundamental personal freedoms.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favour of the request for a legal opinion from the European Court of Justice before voting on a planned agreement between the EU and Canada on the exchange of air passenger data (PNR) in the fight against serious crime and terrorism. The purpose of the agreement is to lay down conditions in accordance with which PNR data may be transferred and used, and to stipulate how data will be protected. There is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1)) as regards the right of individuals to protection of personal data.  I support the decision to obtain an opinion from the European Court of Justice because as legislators, we need to be sure that the decisions we take comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the already existing EU legislation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — I supported the proposed opinion because I believe that the european court of justice's evaluation of the Agreement is essential. The European Court of Justice should give its opinion as the collection and storage of air passenger data can compromise their right to privacy, the fundamental right of every European citizen, the right we are obliged to protect.  In addition to the fact that this agreement constitutes an incitement to the privacy of individuals, it is also questionable to justify insight into personal data for the purpose of combating terrorism and Canada's right to retain the same data for up to two years after its collection.  The acquis commulicity of the European Union highlights the principle of proportionality as one of the fundamental principles that this agreement may undermine.  On the basis of all of the above, I consider that the Court's opinion is necessary and may prevent in a timely timely way the potential violation of the right to protect the personal data of citizens and citizens of the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — I believe that better protection of passenger personal data should be defined in the EU-Canada PNR Agreement. In particular, it is necessary to limit the purpose of use, access rights, storage timeout and the amount of data. It is necessary to define very strict rules and restrictions on the transmission of this information to third parties, as well as to allow independent review and legal control of the data. There are serious doubts about the legality of such an agreement. The mass collection and storage of air passenger data without any reason to suspect them violates basic human rights. Furthermore, we have no evidence that this kind of data collection helps to prevent terrorism, as some argue. The EU legal services of the institutions, the EU Agency for Fundamental Human Rights and also the Data Protection Supervisor have warned of a problem and possible human rights violations. The European Parliament should not agree to an agreement that is not in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. For the reasons set out above, I supported the procedure to refer this agreement to the European Court of Justice for review before the European Parliament proceeds with any decision on whether or not to give its consent to that agreement.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. "I did not support this resolution. We must first and for all care about the general security of european union citizens and that decisions such as passenger data transfers do not encroach on their fundamental human rights. I find that, while the purpose of the Agreement, as set out in Article 1 therein, is to establish the conditions under which data can be transmitted and used and to determine how data is protected, and since the Agreement was signed on 25 June 2014 and that on 8 July 2014 the Council asked Parliament for consent to a new data transfer agreement with Canada, we must ensure that all citizens and interests of the European Union are fully protected before concluding the contract.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - We must be sure that citizens of the European Union feel safe and that decisions such as passenger data transfers do not harm them as citizens of the European Union.  Therefore, I do not support the resolution because I consider that while the purpose of the Agreement, as set out in Article 1 therein, is to establish the conditions under which the data can be transmitted and used and to determine how data is protected, and since the Agreement was signed on 25 June 2014 and that on 8 July 2014 the Council asked Parliament for consent for a new data transfer agreement with Canada , we must ensure that all citizens and interests of the European Union are fully protected before concluding the treaty. I welcome any positive cooperation, if the interests of the European Union are satisfied and if the citizens of the European Union are protected.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — There is a legal ambiguity as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1)) as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data. Finally, we agree with the proposal to consult the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. — As draftsman for the Foreign Affairs Committee opinion of this file I am well acquainted with the arguments in favour and against referring this matter to the European Court of Justice (ECJ). It seems clear to me that such a referral will take many years and is primarily motivated by delaying tactics rather than securing the safety and privacy of EU citizens. In referring the matter to the ECJ, the result will be that the existing 2006 agreement will continue to operate, an agreement that offers lower levels of data protection and access rights than the one now proposed. This agreement is about preventing terrorism against our Member States and their citizens, not about snooping on the private lives of travellers. Limited storage periods of data form the cornerstone of the agreement, as do strict purpose limitation clauses and significant degrees of access rights and rectification processes. This agreement ensures vital co-operation between the EU and Canada, a NATO country that shares our democratic values and is an ally in the fight against global terrorism and trans-national crime. It is for these reasons that I will be voting against the resolution today.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We believe that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7 and 8 and Article 52, paragraph 1) with regard to the right of individuals to the protection of personal data. In addition, I question the choice of the legal basis, namely Article 82, paragraph 1, point (d), and Article 87, paragraph 2, paragraph a), the FUE Treaty (police and judicial cooperation), and not Article 16 of the FUE Treaty (data protection); I am therefore in favour of the decision to refer the agreement to the Court of Justice for advice on the compatibility of the agreement with the treaties.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a request from the Parliament for a legal opinion from the Court of Justice on the Passenger Name Record agreement between the EU and Canada. PNR data contains a large amount of private information and we need more clarity on the legal safeguards to ensure proper legal protection for EU citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I consider illogical and unfounded proposal by the ALDE Group to ask the European Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the Treaty between the European Union and Canada with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, since the Canadian Border Services Agency has decided on its own initiative to ensure to the Union that the old data transfer obligations will remain in force until the new agreement is applied, which has also been notified to all Member States of the Union and their data protection authorities.  Instead, I think it logical, rather than seeking a compatibility opinion from the European Court of Justice, the smooth adoption of a new EU-Canada PIP deal, as this move by the ALDE Group could lead to a significant setback in the adoption of the new agreement.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – This alde group proposal is to be welcomed. Asking the European Court of Justice for an opinion on this issue is a wise decision. This topic is sensitive and its legal basis is confusing. Since this agreement with Canada is likely to become a model for similar agreements, it is essential that all possible inconsistencies with the Treaties of the European Union are resolved before Parliament takes a decision. I believe that the wrong legal basis chosen is based on Articles 82(1)(d) and 87(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (police and judicial cooperation) and should be based on Article 16 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (data protection). We must ensure that any transfer and processing of personal data is carried out in accordance with the fundamental rights of our citizens, which are enshrined in the Treaties of the European Union and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — On 19 November 2013, the European Data Protection Supervisor delivered his opinion on the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on the processing and transfer of passenger name registration data. In that opinion, it questioned the necessity and proportionality of PNR schemes and large transfers of PNR data to third countries, as well as the choice of legal basis.  I voted in favour of this report as it asks the Court for an opinion on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties, as there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the draft agreement with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52 , paragraph (1) as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data. Further, it calls into question the choice of legal basis, namely Article 82(1)(d) and Article 87(2)(a) TFEU (police and judicial cooperation), rather than Article 16 TFEU (data protection).

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the ‘Opinion of the Court of Justice – EU/Canada agreement on the transfer and processing of Passenger Name Record (PNR)’. This new agreement will help regulate the flow of data concerning passenger details in line with the 2013 EU Court of Justice ruling. The agreement will ensure that any data collected will not interfere with individual’s fundamental right to privacy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We agree to send the draft PNR agreement with Canada to the Court of Justice. This is an expedient to delay the adoption and entry into force of measures that grossly violate the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens in both Canada and the EU Member States. A PNR agreement aims at the transmission of information held by airlines about the itineraries and personal data of each passenger and whose purpose, use and retention remain soured by great uncertainty. We must recall the scandals that denounce the use of mass espionage.  At the same time, these agreements constitute the withdrawal of sovereign power from each country, and the dangers of their use against the rights and interests of citizens are increasingly evident.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — In my opinion, data protection is one of the most important assets to be safeguarded and protected. I fully support the report that the European Court of Justice should review the transfer of passenger data to Canada. In my opinion, data retention must go through a legal review, which is guaranteed here by the European Court of Justice. I am also opposed to comprehensive collection of data without cause, as it puts the utmost compromise on the legal certainty of EU citizens.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — Passenger data retention raises the question in principle of whether police and judicial cooperation is more important than individual data protection for citizens. Citizens should not be placed under general suspicion when booking a flight. The request was tabled at the last minute, the group coordinators were not informed, and there was no consultation in the specialist committees. As a member of the AfD, I stand by our political programme: the Alternative for Germany is strongly calling for a comprehensive right of the citizen to determine his or her own personal data. The indiscriminate, uncontrollable or proportionate surveillance measures shall be discontinued. This includes the retention of data required by the EU. The effectiveness of government surveillance measures to prevent or combat serious crime must be demonstrated in a transparent and quantitative lyant manner. The mass transfer of data from European citizens to the security authorities of the United States and other non-European countries must be stopped. This applies in particular to the transfer of data from international transfers under the SWIFT Agreement and to the transfer of passenger data.

name: Axel Voss (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted against the motion for a resolution. Passenger data agreements are an important building block in the fight against global terrorism. The threat situation is becoming increasingly complex. This data is needed to better combat terrorist acts and other criminal threats posed by organised crime, trafficking in human beings, children and drugs. The growing threat of foreign fighters reinforces this need. In addition to greater security, PNR agreements bring clear err and better rights in data protection to citizens. And for airlines, they mean more legal certainty. I also voted against the motion for a resolution because we, as the European Parliament and the legislator, should take political responsibility and retain our powers and not give them to the ECJ. The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and carefully examines the legislative proposals for compatibility with the Treaties. The European Parliament is an equal legislator in the institutional framework with the Council and the Commission, and the ECJ is responsible for the case law! It is our responsibility to maintain the EU's institutional system and that is why I voted against the motion for a resolution. In addition, I am convinced that the ECJ's opinion will not go beyond the requirements of the judgment on data retention.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. - This resolution calls for an opinion from the Court of Justice regarding the legality of an agreement between the EU and Canada to transfer the Passenger Name Record (PNR) of air passengers to Canadian border forces. PNR is data collected by air carriers for ticketing and check-in systems; it can include information like passengers’ names, addresses, passport details and credit card information. This resolution has been prompted by suggestions by the European Data Protection Supervisor that collecting PNR for counter-terrorism purposes may not be proportionate, and by the decision of the Court of Justice to annul the Data Retention Directive earlier this year, which makes the legality of other methods of mass data collection unclear. Labour MEPs have never been against sharing PNR as such, but we have always demanded appropriate safeguards and that counterterrorism measures be compatible with fundamental rights. We have supported this resolution so that we can have a clear judgement on the legality of the PNR agreement.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. - The resolution tabled by the Liberal Group on the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the agreement between the EU and Canada on the processing and transfer of passenger name record (PNR) to the Canadian Border Service Agency is not to be welcomed, as the opinion of the Court of Justice requested there will take several years and will effectively stop the possibility of regulating the exchange of PNR data with third countries at EU level. The processing and analysis of passenger data, while respecting strict data protection principles, is an essential mechanism for combating and preventing organised crime and terrorism. Threats both within and internationally demonstrate the need for an effective tool to mitigate and address these threats.     At present, several third countries wish to start processing PNR data for flights to and from the EU. However, if it is not possible to conclude a single EU-level framework for the transfer of PNR data to third countries in the near future, there is a risk that this processing of passenger data will be very chaotic, as airlines will have to do so under 28 different, different and mutually difficult national frameworks, and a chaotic and fragmented system will reduce the level of protection of personal data.  It should be noted that the EU-Canada PNR Agreement is not new, it was concluded in 2005 and is currently under review. The necessary guarantees for the protection of personal data in the EU-Canada PNR Agreement will be provided in the judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU, to which the resolution refers.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have supported the sending of this draft agreement with Canada to the Court of Justice, in particular with the aim of postponing the adoption and entry into force of measures which, as we have been denouncing, grossly violate the freedoms and guarantees rights of citizens, both in Canada and of the EU Member States. It is reputed that a PNR agreement aims at the transmission of information held by airlines on the itineraries and personal data of each passenger and whose purpose, use and retention remain soured by great uncertainty, a situation that is deepened by the scandals that denounce the use of mass espionage. Its negotiation and future implementation also constitutes the withdrawal of the sovereign power of each country to decide whether or not to conclude such an agreement, as well as to be able to block or terminate when it so wishes. The dangers of its use against the rights and interests of citizens are evident, especially in the context of a serious crisis of capitalism with no end in the view that affects the major world powers and in the face of measures to address it that impose the permanent destruction of social rights and achievements, democratic freedoms and rights and its unchallenged acceptance by peoples.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the Stier report on the EU and the global development framework after 2015 first and foremost because it stands up for the poorest and the most vulnerable in our society. The report’s increased focus on sexual and reproductive health, tackling inequality and bringing an end to corruption and tax evasion are crucial in gaining my support. It is simply awful that companies are withholding a hundred billion from the poorest countries through tax dodging each year – money which they so desperately need to develop education, health care and infrastructure. We now need to combine our forces in the run-up to next year’s UN Summit to make sure that the European Year of Development lives up to its name. Only if the EU speaks with a strong and unified voice will we make an actual change and deliver results that far exceed what the EU Member States can do individually.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I strongly supported this report because it was a strong and comprehensive agreement on the key topics that we need to address in the post-2015 global framework. I also voted for this report because the core issue of climate change has been recognised as one of the main underlying structural factors that lead to poverty and inequality in the world today. Due to climate change the world will have to face the consequences of struggles over scarce resources – conflict, violence and hunger. Rising sea levels endanger entire areas of the planet. If we do not act now, there will be an increase in natural disasters, which will continue to cause the death and suffering of hundreds of thousands of people, often those in developing countries who, let us be clear, are the least responsible for climate change. Therefore I really welcome the fact that the framework will be universal and the burden will, hopefully, be shared. In order to achieve our post-2015 development goals, we must make sure that our development – not only that of the developing countries but of the European countries as well – will continue and will be long-lasting and sustainable.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I am impressed by the content of this particular report and yet I find myself struggling actually to accept all its parts. There are two parts in particular which I think run counter to what the ethos of the report itself was for, namely those which touch upon a minimum wage and those which touch upon a financial transaction tax. These are things which we do not have here in our own continent; we have been careful and cautious as we have discussed them, recognising sovereignty and Member Statesʼ rights, and yet for reasons that remain unclear we have felt the need, in almost a neo-colonialist approach, to include these particular provisions within this important piece of work. For that reason, I think it is troubled, and those parts in particular are the worst reflection of what we could be doing in this particular chamber.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eradicating poverty, putting an end to hunger in the world and combating inequalities and social exclusion are ethical and moral imperatives before they are even binding objectives set by the United Nations in the Millennium Declaration.  The European Union, as the world's largest provider and donor of development aid, has a great responsibility. It can and must play a crucial role at international level in the review of the new post-2015 Millennium Development Goals scheduled for next year. These objectives must, of course, be identified with due regard for the competences of the Member States in order to guarantee equal dignity for every human person. A dignified existence means supporting and fighting for respect for human rights, creating the conditions for truly sustainable development, ensuring fair and universal access to health and food safety and, above all, ensuring access to quality education, an essential tool for the real long-term development of self-sufficient societies.  As Pope Francis told us just an hour ago, Europe must return to being fully itself, and it has done so with a great message of hope and trust. So we have to pick it up.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Mr. Vice President, respected colleagues and colleagues, today I supported the report of my colleague Davor Stier from the Croatian delegation on global development goals for the post-2015 period. I believe that it is complete, that it fits perfectly into the year of European development, the year of development in 2015. It is a continuation of the work to meet the Millennium Global Goals we have been working on for the past fifteen years in the wider framework of the international community.  I think the approach is to eradicate poverty, to assist underdeveloped countries, an essential aspect of the emphasis on human rights, openness to civil society, openness to the private sector to be implemented in development objectives in agreement and dialogue with the Commission, on whose portfolio Croatian Commissioner Mimica works, a very good and very good effort for Member States to meet their targets of giving 0.7 gross social product to development assistance as one of the main objectives of the European Union.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, when we were at school, we would see on the wall maps of the world which would show Europe in the middle. They are slightly adjusted – the equator is moved to emphasise the centrality of this continent – but that is how we think of geopolitics. We still assume that the world is centred in Europe, and increasingly it is not. Just as we saw a huge economic and commercial shift from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic some 400 years ago, now we have seen a similar shift to the Pacific. This is the only continent on the planet that is not experiencing any economic growth. In the circumstances there is pathos, as well as futility, in the constant – almost rather plaintive – demands of the EU authorities for more growth. Remember how the Lisbon Agenda was going to give us the most competitive economy in the world by 2020. Remember how the euro was going to add one per cent of growth to the GDP of all participants in perpetuity. The truth is that we cannot will growth. We cannot legislate for it. We cannot make it happen by bureaucratic decree. The only thing we can do is step back and allow the people who actually create jobs to get on with it.

name: John Stuart Agnew Jonathan Arnott William (The Earl of) Dartmouth and Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. - UKIP believes the EU is one of the primary causes of poverty in the world, due to its vindictive trade policy and its rapacious behaviour in the world’s poorest countries. We note that non-EU development actors have been infinitely better at dealing with poverty, notably India and Brazil, which have both made positive contributions to fighting poverty in the world’s poorest nations. We invite the public to contact our offices for a more detailed explanation of how the EU harms the world’s poor.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán Javier Couso Permuy Paloma López Bermejo Y Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report as it contained key aspects such as the fight against inequality, the establishment of binding rules on corporate social responsibility for enterprises, an EU trade strategy with the aim of maintaining and protecting social and environmental standards, while rejecting any form of social or environmental dumping. The report recalls the commitments made in terms of development aid and also calls for the creation of gender equality objectives. The text similarly recognizes health as a human right and the importance of access to public health services, such as family planning among others. That's why I voted for it.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against the report on the European Union and the global development framework after 2015 because despite good intentions, there are significant lacks, namely the management of migration flows and corruption.  There is no paragraph on the management of immigration when the migration issue is linked to our development effort, in order to loosen the noose on Europe.  The issue of corruption is not dealt with with the importance it should be given. Yet it is an important factor in the maintenance of conflicts and the plundering of resources in some countries through multinationals and transnational mafia networks. I therefore consider that the means that will be put in place to control and spend the money should be shown in such a report.  We need to know to whom this money is being distributed. I therefore believe that by failing to deal with these issues with due importance, we will continue to deal with the consequences without dwindling on the real causes of poverty and all human disorders. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution and the mention of access to sexual and reproductive rights, which covers a wide range of sexual health measures as well as maternal, post-natal, menopausal, reproductive cancers and fertility treatments. This report did not mention access to abortion. Sinn Féin believes that the option of a termination should be available where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of a pregnant woman, including where she is suicidal, that would only be averted by an abortion, and in the case of rape or incest. We voted against the extension of the 1967 Act to the North of Ireland when it was proposed in the Assembly. We support the introduction of legislation in the 26 Counties in line with the X Case and we have called for the immediate introduction of guidance for medical professionals in the Six Counties.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - As the 2000 United Nations Millennium Declaration, which aims to significantly reduce poverty in the world, expires next year, a new declaration on post-2015 global development goals is being prepared. A systematic approach is still needed to successfully combat poverty. In this context, in this resolution, the European Parliament urges Member States, inter alia, to fulfil their commitment to spend at least 0.7% of their GNI – including at least 0.2% of their GNI on the least developed and other most vulnerable countries – on official development assistance. It is also necessary for the EU to present a confident and coherent position on the establishment of clear guidelines for development aid.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set priorities for post-2015 development policy. In 2000, the UN adopted the Millennium Declaration and set specific targets to be met by 2015. Although there are positive results: halving extreme poverty, good results in the fight against malaria and tuberculosis, but it is still necessary to reduce poverty, increase food security, education, promote gender equality, sustainable energy, sustainable growth, etc. I support the stated proposal for development policy to focus on poverty reduction, the fight against inequality, the protection of human rights and the sustainability of health systems. 2015 is a symbolic year as it ends with the implementation of the Millennium Development Goals agreed in 2000 at the United Nations.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report, which accumulates declarations of good intentions without proposing relevant solutions. With a well-ordered charity starting with itself, I hope that the European Union will focus on the problems of the citizens of its Member States, problems that are getting worse every year.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - In 2000, the United Nations adopted the Millennium Declaration. The objectives set out in this declaration have led to some improvements, including halving extreme poverty. Unfortunately, however, most of the objectives have not been achieved. I voted in favour of a post-2015 agenda so that we can continue our fight for development. This programme focuses on 11 priority areas in order to take concrete action on the challenges of tomorrow.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because some economies are still experiencing high and increasing levels of inequality, and we need another global approach that responds to poverty and hunger. Also because a renewed global partnership with a strong and cohesive position is needed. Priority areas for poverty eradication, the fight against inequalities and sustainable development, the defence of human rights, conflict prevention efforts, post-conflict recovery and peacebuilding and the promotion of lasting peace must be defined. The role of civil society and local and regional authorities, and the mobilization of financial resources in innovative tools, must be taken into account.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report, which is merely a list of wishful thinking, will not, as usual, resolve all the priorities contained in it. The European Union and the United Nations want to halve the populations that suffer from hunger and also multiply the major challenges on many issues such as human rights violations, unemployment, climate change, corruption, economic and financial crises, poverty and many others ... Of course, this will only remain at the stage of dering good intentions. The European Union, unable to deal with the same ills that affect it, nevertheless intends to support this Millennium Declaration. On page 23, the explanatory statement states, for example, that "the Union has recognised that there is no sustainable development without peace and security, and vice versa: without development and eradication of poverty, peace cannot be sustainable."  This is a laudable goal, but we should start applying the advice given to ourselves, since 24% of the total population of the Union (more than 120 million people) is at risk of poverty or social exclusion and this figure is only increasing. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I did not vote in favour of this text, which seeks to include among the priorities of the poorest communities an approach to environmental policies and the issue of climate change that I do not agree with. I do not believe that the issues raised in the report take priority over issues such as development and the eradication of poverty.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - The aim of this report is to help shape the EU's position at the next UNITED Nations Conference in September 2015. It is the latest in a series of analyses prepared annually by the EP on how the Millennium Goals worked, how to improve them and how to make them more viable In September 2000, the United Nations adopted the Millennium Declaration, which would continue to set targets to be achieved in 2015. In these years, the world has halved extreme poverty, and the fight against malaria and tuberculosis yields spectacular results. But with the aim of a new post-2015 agreement, the international community is conducting an extensive analysis process for a policy framework for the sake of global development. Among our main contributions I would like to highlight the objective of eradicating extreme poverty, linking development and humanitarian aid, ensuring actions in failed states, combating tax evasion and corruption, ensuring the specific needs of people with disabilities and showing greater force on sexual and reproductive health and rights, minority and vulnerable rights.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to adopt a new development programme for the post-2015 period. Secondly, it is essential to ensure human rights and conflict prevention, peace-building and the long-term promotion of peace. The EU has recognised that sustainable development can only be ensured in peace and security and vice versa, in the absence of development and poverty, peace will not be lasting long-term. It is also important to ensure health care and education. In the new development programme, the EU should focus on promoting fair and universal health protection, ensuring quality costs and access to quality healthcare. It is particularly important that health and education services are received by the most vulnerable groups in society. It is also important to give priority to eliminating all forms of violence against women and girls.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it to be a good part of the main issues facing the European Union after 2015.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The global development framework practically implements the principles underlying the European Union, namely freedom, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the rule of law. EU Member States are obliged to instill in their citizens compliance with these principles, thus contributing significantly to the eradication of European problems. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that this global development framework has the beneficial aim of raising public awareness of the current problems facing the European area, of assessing them and countering the problems in the years to come.  Key issues such as human rights violations, armed conflicts and terrorism, climate change, food insecurity, migration, corruption, tax fraud and evasion, unemployment, as well as financial and economic crises, are still challenges of EU Member States. That is why I believe that the common aim of the 28 states is to partner with its citizens, as well as with the European institutions, to instill in a unified manner the respect and application of the EU's pillar principles.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - I voted against. The report seeks to commit Parliament on too many fronts to the detriment of concreteness, and there is an excessive emphasis on the role of the Eu ropean Union in conducting these policies at the expense of the Member States.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - In 2000, the United Nations adopted the Millennium Declaration, with 2015 targets that have halved extreme poverty in the world or combating malaria and tuberculosis in a very important way. It is now necessary to promote and support a new post-2015 framework that captures the goals on sustainability and growth of the United Nations-led international community. The EP discusses how to contribute to the EU's position to be defended in New York in the September 2015 meeting. Our main contributions include: - the identified goals and objectives should continue to revolve around the same main objective: eradicating poverty and inequality; - strong language on sexual and reproductive health and rights, on the rights of minorities and vulnerable persons;  - the fight against tax evasion and corruption. Innovative sources of financing, such as tax on financial transactions; - the objective of ensuring the specific needs of persons with disabilities.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — Fifteen years ago, the United Nations adopted a Millennium Development Declaration that sets targets and deadlines for 2015. With these deadlines coming to an end, it was time to take stock of the various advances made since 2000 and the efforts that still need to be made after 2015.  Overall, extreme poverty has been halved. In addition, much progress has been made in health care, particularly in the fight against malaria and tuberculosis. However, great strides still need to be made in terms of human rights, poverty eradication, sustainable development, prevention and conflict resolution, to name a few. I voted in favour of this report, which allows European development targets to be set again.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this report today.  In many countries, the goal of the Millennium Development Goals has not been achieved in the slightest. Moreover, even where progress has been considerable, it has not led to the elimination of very high levels of inequality. Some groups, such as the inhabitants of slums or peripheral regions, religious minorities and disabled people continue to be excluded from achieving these objectives.  I believe that understanding the reason for this exclusion is essential to ensure that, in future, the commitment to development is more effective and inclusive. The feelings of exclusion and alienation that come from this situation can undermine social cohesion.  I therefore believe that the global development framework should reflect a greater awareness of the fundamental importance of inclusion: no person, regardless of ethnicity, geography, disability or race, can be denied universal human rights and basic economic opportunities.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report focuses on global development after 2015 and has many positive elements such as the fight against poverty and the protection of LGBT rights. Nevertheless I could not support this report as within it there are references to the Financial Transaction Tax and the universal access to abortion as a human right.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I support this report because I firmly believe that the EU must take a strong, clear and cohesive position with regard to the post-2015 global development framework. Poverty eradication must continue to be the main priority of the post-2015 development agenda, together with economic, ecological and social sustainability.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) New great challenges await humanity. After the Millennium Development Goals, which are based on the first fifteen years of the twenty-first century, we need to start looking further. I voted in favour of this negotiating mandate so that the EU can make its voice heard in the United Nations by taking care of the sustainability of development, so that the views of all countries, including industrialised countries, are taken into account and we stop thinking rationally about accountants. What matters is the well-being that can be generated, not the parameters.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — Twenty five years ago, world leaders made a promise: to protect and fulfil the rights of all children. Rights to grow up safe and healthy, to express their views, and fulfil their potential. But the reality is that, 25 years on, that promise remains unfulfilled for millions of children throughout the world. Today, 18 000 children under the age of five still die every day from preventable causes; as many as 1.5 billion children are at risk of violence annually; and 1 in 3 children in developing countries are malnourished. These are just some of the statistics which prove that, while much progress has indeed been made, much remains to be done. The EU has a key role to play in changing this picture and fulfilling the rights of all children – both within the EU and beyond.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Following the latest UN reports on the Millennium Goals and the post-2015 agenda, we must now look at the new negotiating frameworks in a coherent and appropriate manner to the new global challenges, such as poverty, human rights, armed conflict and terrorism, climate change and financial and economic crises. I believe, in this regard, as I have argued in the past, that the EU's response to these problems must be made with one voice, strong, clear and cohesive, while allocating means of financing to sustainable development based on good governance. However, a new approach should be initiated that affects the structural factors underlying poverty and inequality and which are linked to new extremely complex challenges that will be on the agenda for decades to come, from terrorism to gender inequalities, food security, unemployment, etc. I agree that this new development framework must have a universal but fair nature, appropriate to the realities and capacities of each State, based on criteria of transparency and ambitious objectives for the years to come.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the EU and the post-2015 global development framework. I am in favour of creating a renewed global partnership, characterised by full coverage and capable of recognising the contribution of all types of instruments and including technologies and innovation, capacity building and trade.  Global challenges are set to increase due to serious situations such as poverty, human rights violations, armed conflicts and terrorism, climate change, unemployment, demographic change, corruption, unsustainable growth and financial and economic crises. These are just some of the challenges facing the EU and we must certainly have as a polar star the will to finally reach a definitive development process.  The post-2015 framework needs a human rights-based approach in addition to promoting peaceful societies, attempting to drastically reduce poverty, promoting, as highlighted by the Rio +20 commitments, a fight against soil and soil degradation, and also recognising that water is at the heart of sustainable development. In order to do this, therefore, new development models must be defined that guarantee inclusive and sustainable development.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. - I fully support the objective of this report and stress the need for a new development framework to achieve a strong, cohesive EU position, but in voting against this report I have considered the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. According to the division of competences between the EU and the Member States as stated in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union, the EU can act in different policy areas if the content and form of the action does not exceed what is necessary to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties. The report seeks to introduce issues related to sexual health and reproductive rights as well as issues of tax when both these competences fall within the discretion of the Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In September 2000, the United Nations adopted the Millennium Declaration, which led to the creation of concrete development goals to be achieved by 2015. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the priorities of the post-2015 development framework must be articulated around key points such as the eradication of poverty through the fight against inequalities and sustainable development, conflict prevention, post-conflict reconstruction, peace building and the promotion of peace. I can only vote in favour of this resolution in order to ensure that the post-2015 framework guarantees an approach based on human rights and justice, equality and equity, good governance, democracy and the rule of law and finally peaceful societies without violence.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - The world landscape has changed profoundly, economic and political balances have clearly shifted to some emerging economies, which, however, still find themselves living with high levels of inequality. The European Union has a duty to play an active role in the processes of redefining the balance in those areas and countries, interacting with all interested parties, including the private sector, civil society organisations, local authorities and national parliaments. In this sense, trade policy, for example, although aimed exclusively at economic objectives, must be aimed at promoting our fundamental values, helping to generate fair models capable of guaranteeing sustainable economic growth and jobs; to improve people's living and working conditions; to strengthen sustainable development, the promotion of social standards and environmental sustainability. Europe's role in the global paradigm must contribute to strengthening labour standards, human rights and fundamental freedoms and to creating economic growth, capable of promoting fair distribution of wealth, helping in the fight against poverty and improving the quality of development.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. - The key priorities within this report are clear: sustainable development, poverty eradication and the fight against inequality are all key factors which will help towards global development in order to work towards a more developed world – a world where everyone, regardless of their geographical location, has the same chance of survival, development and quality life as anyone else. For this reason, I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution with the reservation that I disagree and do not approve the references to sexual and reproductive health and rights due to abortion and the reference in Article 78 to the financial transaction tax.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. When it comes to foreign policy, the European Parliament has few powers. That is why the value of this report is all the greater. It allows it to affirm its uniqueness and priorities. Among the many interesting recommendations, I voted with interest those relating to the empowerment of women and the elimination of all forms of violence against them.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I also support the rapporteur's proposal to include on the post-2015 world agenda a clear message on women's participation in decision-making processes, as well as the importance of ensuring equal access to jobs for women and men, as well as equal pay for work. I also believe that the EU needs to be more active in supporting programmes to improve girls' access to all levels of education and to remove gender barriers to learning, because without adequate education, women cannot play a leading role in the new global development framework.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE)
text: in writing. - In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the GPPE, we would like to state, in relation to the EU Report and the global framework for post-2015 development, that while we supported this report today in the final vote, we do not agree and therefore voted against recital "0", and paragraphs 28 and 58 of that report , which refer to sexual and reproductive health and rights. These are ambiguous terms, which are often used to address sensitive issues pertaining to individual conscience and on which, moreover, the institutions of the European Union lack the competence

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. — I abstained from voting on § 37, because low-carbon emissions do not exclude the option of nuclear energy as an alternative. In my view, nuclear energy is not a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The UN Millennium Development Goals initiative launched in 2005 has halved extreme poverty and the number of people who do not have access to safe drinking water in 10 years. However, lessons must be learned from what has not been achieved by the MDGs to define the new post-2015 framework as eradicating poverty and reducing inequalities, particularly in access to health and education.  The future European development strategy must also be provided with sufficient financial resources. The aim is for Member States to meet their commitments to provide 0.7% of their GNI for development aid, but also to consider raising private funds through innovative mechanisms, following the examples of airfare taxes or the International Financial Facility for Immunization (IFFIm) which raises funds in financial markets and returns them to agencies fighting the spread of AIDS. Finally, the heads of state and government of the Member States must implement the draft financial transaction tax to help finance development aid.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. "Unfortunately, the report has two major flaws that motivated my unfavourable vote. On the one hand, the issue of migration flows is not addressed operationally and realistically. On the other hand, the systems of corruption and misappropriation of European aid funds are not treated with sufficient firmness and precision to put an end to these networks and the financial waste.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I agree with the text and voted in favour, during the negotiation period of the text, the GUE rapporteur for this individual has managed to include the following aspects which we consider key to the future development framework: appeal to the need for the framework to be universal; a strong emphasis on inequality; prioritization of tax justice and the mobilization of national resources; mention of the need to establish legally binding rules for corporate social responsibility for multinational companies; the need to meet aid commitments in both quality and quantity; universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights; and the call for an independent objective on gender equality, while ensuring the incorporation of the gender approach in a comprehensive and cross-cutting way to the rest of the development framework.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against because we disagree with almost the whole approach and because we do not believe that the EU should be the feeder of the planet or that it has the right to consider itself capable of imposing its views throughout the world. After all, we disagree with how many of these views are expressed.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The eradication of poverty in 2015 has always been assumed to be one of the main MDDs by all parties who signed the document for the implementation of this desideratum. The evaluations made in the meantime highlight the processes obtained in their implementation, reinforcing the need for a strong link between poverty eradication and the promotion of sustainable development. However, poverty reduction is unequal and inequalities between countries and at home, which have worsened in both developed and developing countries, pose a major challenge. Currently, 1.5 billion people live in poverty with health, education and living conditions shortages. It is therefore urgent and necessary to prioritise poverty eradication, reducing inequality, sustainable development, having a human rights-based approach, preventing conflicts, thinking about post-conflict recovery, consolidating and promoting lasting peace; mitigating climate change, protecting the environment and reducing disaster risks by combining food security, nutrition, sustainable agriculture, combating soil degradation, water and sanitation with health and education and taking a central role for women in the post-2015 global development framework, as well as inclusive and sustainable growth and creating decent jobs. MSs themselves must respect the commitment to allocate at least 0.7% of GNI to ODA.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report points out small steps taken in this or that area with regard to development objectives. However, assuming in some areas these small steps, much is what has remained to be done and are also notorious a few steps back in other areas. The resolution is weak in diagnosis and even weaker in the path point. It is significant that some of the more critical references in the report on the negative impacts of some EU sectoral policies – such as trade and agricultural policies – were withdrawn during the vote. Even the mere consideration that the impact of these policies should be examined was withdrawn. On the other hand, it is visible the attempt – which is not today, but long ago – to seek to impose on developing countries a neoliberal model, to the payment or menorization of the role of the State and of strong prevalence of the private sector. While some of the positive aspects included in the resolution, which we value, we did not vote for.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - The Millennium Goals were adopted in 2000, through which world leaders wanted to contribute to poverty reduction in developing countries by 2015 through concrete objectives. However, we can now see that society is still a long way from achieving the objectives set and the international community needs to focus on defining a new framework in this specific area. It is very important that society learns from the past and establishes a new global framework for the development of developing countries that is politically acceptable but at the same time decisive in the fight against poverty.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I do not support the report because I do not see a clear commitment and many points are detrimental to the national sovereignty of the individual Member States. It seems like a wish list without the necessary concreteness to achieve them.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report on the EU and the global development framework for the period after 2015, because I disagree with almost the whole approach. We do not believe that the EU should be the feeder of the planet, nor that it has the right to consider itself capable of imposing its views on the whole world. After all, I also disagree with how many of these views are expressed.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing.
