I voted in favour of my colleague Davo Stier's report because it is a very good report, the preparation of which was carried out with the aim of strengthening the position of the European Parliament and the European Union in setting the post-2015 development targets. The report highlights the need to put human rights at the heart of global development policy. In particular, access to education, including secondary education and for girls, is highlighted as an essential goal for development. There is also a call for a strengthening of the partnership with civil society and private actors, which is absolutely necessary, especially because SMEs are a key element for development in all countries. The report has the merit of reflecting on a more meaningful role of emerging countries in global development policy. Finally, the report has given a central place to the role of women in development: the new goals and development cannot be achieved without an improvement in women's rights around the world.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the EU report and the post-2015 global development framework as it provides a basis for bringing the Millennium Development Goals back into a framework that has changed significantly since its adoption. In this sense, the actions from an approach based on human rights, peace and the eradication of poverty in a framework of sustainable and responsible growth point us to a path certainly humanistic, with a return to recognition of the person as the center in decision-making that guides public policies. That is also why Member States must become aware and mobilisation of the financial resources needed to carry out the objectives set for after 2015.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - The MDGs should be achieved in 2015; however, near the end of the year we are still far from fulfilling them, with the consequences that come with it for developing countries. We need to learn our lesson and do the right tests if we really want to eradicate poverty and inequalities in the world. I supported this report because it has contained key development issues, such as combating human rights violations and all forms of inequality, defending sexual and reproductive health rights, the rights of minorities and the most vulnerable, combating tax evasion and tax evasion , as well as new forms of financing, such as tax on financial transactions. I hope that this report will make a strong contribution to the establishment of the European position and that these red lines will be respected for the United Nations Summit in September 2015.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report as it supports the work carried out by Spanish civil society by asking for a framework that not only fights for those most in need in third countries, but also addresses the situation we have in Spain. I therefore support a universal development framework that, in both developed and developing countries, combats violations of human rights, inequalities, including gender inequality and persons with disabilities, armed conflict and terrorism, climate change, food insecurity, lack of property rights , lack of land rights, limited access to health services, including sexual and reproductive health services, education, resource scarcity, biodiversity loss, corruption, tax evasion and tax evasion, unemployment and crises. I hope that in September, in New York, the ambitions of our governments will live up to the needs of our citizens.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the EU and the global development framework after 2015. MDGs adopted in 2000 have reached a lot of successful goals and made a huge impact on people’s lives. I agree with the Human Development Report 2014 that stresses increasing global challenges due to poverty, human rights violations, corruption, etc. Therefore, we need a strong and cohesive EU position as well as all stakeholders united to be able to resist these challenges.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on ‘the EU and the global development framework after 2015’ because I believe it is important that we acknowledge what has been achieved with the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), but also that we develop a strong development framework after 2015 to address what has not achieved with the MDGs. The EU needs to take a strong leadership role in this global development framework as the world’s biggest development aid donor.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Party for the Animals is in favour of green, renewable, carbon-free energy. By not including the words ‘green’ or ‘renewable’, the ‘carbon-free strategies’ proposed in paragraph 37 could also include nuclear energy. Nuclear energy is no sustainable alternative because it depends on limited resources. Furthermore nuclear power plants produce extremely hazardous waste and pose a potential high environmental risk. Therefore I voted against these carbon-free strategies.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - In recent years, much has been done to achieve the Millennium Development Goals set in 2000. Unfortunately, in the face of global challenges such as armed conflicts, poverty, climate change and natural disasters, the economic crisis and many others, there is still a great deal of room for further effort. The number of challenges currently facing development policy is best illustrated by the new SDGs, of which there are as many as 17. Their implementation will require the European Union and other donors to work hard together, while respecting the principles of aid effectiveness. It is also important, in my opinion, to use a wide range of aid instruments, including the combination of loans and grants, which can contribute to increased development funding. I also agree with the rapporteur that additional efforts should be made to eradicate hunger, especially among children. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I welcome this report which lays down some important principles for post-2015 global development. Despite our own ongoing economic problems, the EU remains one of the worldʼs economic powerhouses and it is vital that international development objectives are not sidelined. The EUʼs efforts compliment smaller initiatives such as the Scottish Governmentʼs International Development Fund and the issues detailed in this report will help ensure these efforts remain effective.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I agree with the text and voted in favour, during the negotiation period of the text, the GUE rapporteur for this individual has managed to include the following aspects which we consider key to the future development framework: appeal to the need for the framework to be universal; a strong emphasis on inequality; prioritization of tax justice and the mobilization of national resources; mention of the need to establish legally binding rules for corporate social responsibility for multinational companies; the need to meet aid commitments in both quality and quantity; universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights; and the call for an independent objective on gender equality, while ensuring the incorporation of the gender approach in a comprehensive and cross-cutting way to the rest of the development framework.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the proposal for a resolution on the EU and the global development framework for the post-2015 period, as it clearly sets out the necessary guidelines towards achieving a balanced and sustainable system of comprehensive stability. It is extremely important that special attention was paid to respect for fundamental human rights, and to their indivisibility and universality, as well as to building a space of peace and coexistence. This added great importance to the role of women in the new global context, and provided strong support for combating and condemning violence against women and girls.  Large-scale inequality is also known; economic, social, political... therefore, the global development framework after 2015 focuses heavily on eradicating poverty, sustainable development and environmental protection, ensuring basic services, rights and health conditions, and promoting dynamic employment and quality education. As mentioned in the proposal itself, I believe that the implementation of these measures will be a key contribution and role that local, regional and national authorities, and civil society will know, and be able to take.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP believes the EU is one of the primary causes of poverty in the world, due to its vindictive trade policy and its rapacious behaviour in the world’s poorest countries. I am of the opinion that non-EU development actors have been infinitely better at dealing with poverty, notably India and Brazil, which have both made positive contributions to fighting poverty in the world’s poorest nations. I invite the UK public and particularly SE region constituents to contact my office for a more detailed explanation of how the EU harms the world’s poor.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Davor Ivo Stier's report on the European Union and the post-2015 global development framework. The text stresses the importance of maintaining the European level of development aid, the largest in the world, while addressing more the causes of poverty by encouraging the principles of good governance, democracy and the rule of law. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I welcome the vote on this resolution to define a universal and ambitious post-2015 agenda to go beyond the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) set out in the United Nations in 2000. A series of sub-goals, quantified, are to achieve, by 2015, the following eight objectives: reducing extreme poverty and hunger, ensuring primary education for all, promoting gender equality and women's empowerment, reducing child mortality, improving maternal health, combating HIV, malaria and other diseases, preserving the environment, and establishing a global partnership for development. A new generation of MDGs must be promoted, placing greater emphasis on environmental issues as development factors, given the changing global challenges and the link between environmental protection, improved health, prosperity (green growth) and peace.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The beginning of the ep's new term of office is the right time to set global, uniform priorities for development and the direction in which EU policy should follow. Looking at the Millennium Development Goals set by the United Nations in 2000, we can see that this makes the most sense: progress in the fight against certain diseases, strengthening interstate and interinstitutional cooperation are clear examples of the effectiveness of such declarations. Discussions on the way forward have been intensified within the Framework of the Open Working Group on the Sustainable Development Goals as well as the UN Intergovernmental Committee of Experts on Sustainable Development Funding, and the position of the European Commission, the Council of the EU and the European Parliament on post-2015 projects is set out in a communication entitled 'A Decent Life for All'. On the other hand, our colleague's report from the Committee on Development is the European Parliament's contribution to creating a coherent, unified framework for future action.  Undoubtedly, these include important issues such as sustainable development, the elimination of social dissees, conflict prevention, adequate education or access to healthcare. However, sustainable agriculture and food security must not be forgotten, because these issues should underpin any effort to exclude poverty and improve the quality of life among the inhabitants of our planet.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the report as a step forward and a strong message to the world that Europe is serious about development and committed to tackling poverty. The EU needs to play a leading role in helping to define the future global development goals and targets. These must be ambitious and universally binding in order to tackle the root causes of global poverty effectively. Tackling inequality, combating tax dodging, and protecting the environment are key pillars in this battle and must be at the heart of these new goals.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The aim of the report on the EU and the post-2015 Global Development Framework – for which I voted – is to set a coherent EU development policy strategy for the post-2015 period. The report is a step towards an ambitious development agenda based on a broad international partnership in dealing with issues of global importance, such as m.in poverty, access to education and healthcare and gender equality. The Union's development policy is strongly focused on protecting human rights and promoting an inclusive model of diversity-based economic development that is effective and fair at the same time. As a member of the FEMM Committee, I particularly support the call for women to be empowered and recognised as a priority development policy area. The elimination of violence against women and harmful practices such as forced marriages, honour killings and female genital mutilation is a prerequisite for promoting gender equality. The report says that nothing – including elements of religion, culture or tradition – can justify violence, thus building on the spirit of universality of human rights, on which the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women is also based. The development framework proposed by the EP also promotes the demand for equal opportunities in education and the labour market as part of a fair and economically beneficial development strategy.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. - In a few months' time, we will be entering into the heart of the negotiations aimed at defining a new post-2015 global agenda. The world is preparing to discuss a new global approach to development that is broader and more universal in scope and not just aimed at poor countries. While acknowledging the important achievements of the Millennium Declaration in 2000, there are still many efforts that we must make in the face of the growing global challenges we face. Our response must be through full respect for the dignity of every human being: a fundamental requirement for dealing with the root causes of poverty, social exclusion and inequality. Parliament stresses that gender equality and women's rights are a necessary condition for the success of the post-2015 global development framework. In particular, we have recognised the important contribution of women to conflict prevention and peace-building and democracy efforts.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Stier in that it highlights how poverty eradication and the fight against inequalities are the fundamental principles of the post-2015 global development framework. I believe that the European Union must adopt an approach that guarantees justice, equality and fairness. I certainly agree with the rapporteur on the need to eliminate all forms of violence against women, and this must be a priority for the new framework.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — Poverty, health, education and living standards are affected by some EUR 1.5 billion. and 162 million people. children still suffer from malnutrition. Poverty eradication at international level must therefore be a priority issue by which the EU should express a unified position.  It should be stressed that the eradication of poverty, the fight against inequality and sustainable development should become the priority themes of the post-2015 development programme and that human rights should be the cornerstone of the programme. In order to implement this programme, attention must be paid to areas such as sustainable economic growth, job creation and resource efficiency. I supported the European Parliament resolution on the EU and the global development programme after 2015, because the aim of reducing the number of people living outside or close to the poverty line is important, and the choice of appropriate and reliable data-based measures is likely and feasible.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - In September 2000, the United Nations adopted the one known as the Millennium Declaration, followed by the establishment of specific and narrow targets in the time to be achieved by 2015. Since then, the world has halved extreme poverty, and the fight against malaria and tuberculosis yields significant results. Building on what has been achieved and with the aim of reaching a new post-2015 agreement, the United Nations-led international community is conducting an extensive analysis process to achieve a coherent and ambitious regulatory framework. In addition, agreements were reached during the negotiations on all the amendments tabled by the S&D Group, inter alia, on: the universality of the EU's leadership structure and role; strong language about sexual and reproductive health and rights; the rights of minorities and vulnerable persons; the fight against tax evasion and corruption. That is why my vote on the report has been favourable.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is crucial for the European Union to adopt a strong, cohesive and unified policy for global development in the post-2015 period. The interdependence of progress in the main priority areas laid out in the report makes it vital that they be tackled in unison. Article 208 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union establishes eradication of poverty as one of the primary objectives of the EU development policy. However, poverty and inequality cannot be combated without improving education. Conversely, education cannot be efficiently improved without combating poverty and inequality. As such, policy coherence for development is imperative. I support this initiative and believe that the EU must provide the necessary legislative framework and mobilise the necessary financial resources to effectively address all the priorities laid out. Besides providing the appropriate legislative and institutional framework, the new global framework needs to include the necessary tools for monitoring, assessing and enforcing these mechanisms.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this report, because I believe that the fight against poverty and inequality, sustainable development and a human rights-based approach, including the principle of good governance, are necessary components of a new long-term global framework that requires global engagement and joint action. The programme so far has been extremely successful in the areas of extreme poverty reduction, the fight against malaria and tuberculosis.  He also showed significant improvements in access to drinking water and a reduction in differences in primary school enrolments. However, despite all these successes, additional efforts are needed to identify shortcomings and continue the fight against inequality globally. The Millennium Development Goals were set in 2000 with a view to meeting by 2015.  This programme has achieved a global partnership and demonstrated its agreement in prioritising all actors of society, including governments, the international community, civil society, but also the private sector in order to achieve these objectives, and it is imperative that this type of connectivity between all relevant actors continues both in the global development framework and after 2015.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Stier report because the eradication of poverty and the fight against inequalities, together with sustainable development, should be the main direction of the global development framework after 2015 and because the elimination of inequalities in access to health and education should be the primary Millennium Development Goals for the period after 2015 , priorities set out in this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report identifying the priorities of the post-2015 development framework. The aforementioned measure aims to contribute to the definition of a coherent position, establishing principles and guidelines of the new European Union negotiating strategy

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is necessary for the European Union to adopt a rights-based approach, which guarantees justice, equality, equity and good governance. And it is equally important that the post-2015 agenda has a deeply renewed global partnership, capable of addressing the growing challenges of poverty, inequality, education and health. It is for these reasons that I have expressed my agreement with the Stier report, which highlights how the eradication of poverty and the fight against inequalities are the fundamental principles of the post-2015 global development framework. I particularly agree with the rapporteur that the elimination of all forms of violence against women must be a priority for the new framework.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — Although the MDGs have achieved a great deal of success, I voted against this motion. New development paths for sustainable and inclusive development in the post-2015 period are necessary, but not sufficiently thought out under prevailing conditions. Better monitoring of the implementation of future objectives is essential to ensure their success. Introducing measurable standards would be the first step towards better monitoring the enforcement of THE MDGs.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - In September 2000, the United Nations adopted a Millennium Declaration setting concrete targets to be achieved by 2015. The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) have made significant improvements in some human situations. With less than a year to go before the deadline for their implementation, extreme poverty has been halved worldwide and the fight against malaria and tuberculosis has led to impressive progress.  The European Parliament continues its work towards the adoption of an ambitious post-2015 development agenda. The report aims to clarify its objectives: eradication of poverty, human rights, health, education, the fight against global warming, etc. Even if all this is largely wishful thinking given the union's devastating free trade policy, I am voting in for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) have had a huge impact on people's lives. Less than a year before the deadline for achieving the MDDs, extreme poverty in the world has been halved and efforts to fight malaria and tuberculosis have shown impressive results. However, much has yet to be done with regard to the realisation of the MDDs.  I therefore believe that the post-2015 agenda needs a genuinely renewed global partnership, comprehensive in its coverage, which recognises the contribution of all types of instruments and is able to deal with technology and innovation, as well as capacity building and trade. It is in this sense that we all have to work to eradicate hunger and extreme poverty in the world at last.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – This report covers the various aspects to drive global development forward after 2015. However, I could not support a number of specific aspects of this report, namely the points dealing with the Financial Transaction Tax and the inclusion of sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. We are only a few months away from the deadline for the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2000. Despite progress in the eight priority areas of action, there is still a long way to go and the challenges are very numerous: human rights violations, violence against women, conflict, terrorism, climate change, food insecurity, lack of access to safe drinking water, etc. Launching a deep reflection on the post-2015 development framework is therefore unavoidable. As the largest donor of official development assistance, the European Union must take the lead in pushing for an ambitious post-2015 development agenda. By voting in favour of this report, we are laying the groundwork for the main thrusts of the European Union's strategy in the ongoing negotiations for the definition of the post-2015 framework.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – In 2000, the UN adopted the Millennium Declaration, setting out the so-called Millennium Development Goals to be achieved by 2015. Since the adoption of the development objectives, the parties have made considerable efforts to reduce, in particular, poverty, hunger and violations of fundamental human rights, but this is only a step in the right direction compared to the scale of extreme poverty and humanitarian problems in the world, which must continue to be deepened. Negotiations on a new framework after 2015 should therefore result in the resumption of a global partnership to ensure an effective solution to the remaining global challenges. Like many other colleagues in the European Parliament, I support an ambitious approach that would prioritise the protection of human rights, the eradication of poverty and sustainable development. On the contrary, I do not agree that development policy promotes abortion as sexual or reproductive rights or methods of modern family planning, because the European Union has a duty to protect the right to life and human dignity, and this obligation under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights must be respected in all areas of EU policy.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. — I abstained from voting on § 37, because low-carbon emissions do not exclude the option of nuclear energy as an alternative. In my view, nuclear energy is not a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the report ‘The EU and the global development framework after 2015’, which I believe stands for the poorest and most vulnerable people in our society. The report calls for the adoption of a new global development framework which will help eradicate poverty and fight against all form of inequalities. The human-rights-based approach to the framework is at the heart of the report and it is a key priority for the S&D Group. Nevertheless, I did not support the very strong language on sexual and reproductive health and rights and on innovative sources of financing such as the financial transaction tax, therefore I voted against those parts in paragraphs 28, 58, 78 and recital O.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is in fact merely a list of wishful thinking and empty formulas. The first recital of the motion for a resolution is thus written: "Considering that in the year 2000, all relevant stakeholders met to define the MDGs with a view to achieving concrete results in terms of development and poverty eradication by 2015." It should be noted that the goal of eradicating poverty by 2015 will be very difficult to achieve on time, including in the European Union! Except to believe the miracle of course! Point III includes priorities: poverty eradication, inequality reduction and sustainable development, human rights-based approach, conflict prevention, post-conflict recovery, peace building and promoting sustainable peace, climate change mitigation, environmental protection and disaster risk reduction, food security, nutrition, sustainable agriculture, the fight against soil degradation , water and sanitation, health and education, the central role of women in global development after 2015, inclusive and sustainable growth, employment and decent job creation... In short, a list of good intentions to give good conscience, endorsed by the United Nations and the Union. As for the right of peoples to self-determination and the non-interference of the great world powers, the report says nothing...

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the post-2015 global development framework. 2015 is the deadline for the international community to achieve the eight Millennium Development Goals, which have been endorsed by all countries around the world.  As this date approaches, it was necessary to take stock of the actions aimed at achieving these objectives in order to learn from them. Since 2000 (the date of the signing of the Millennium Declaration), global crises have followed and the economic situation has deteriorated considerably. Yet we must continue on the path to achieving the Millennium Goals, especially to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger in the world.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has always worked to achieve an ambitious post-2015 global development agenda. We therefore also welcome this report because it seeks to contribute to the definition of a coherent position by establishing principles and guidelines for the European Union's new negotiating strategy. Indeed, we call for global issues such as poverty, health, food security, education, gender equality, water supply and sanitation, sustainable energy, decent work, inclusive and sustainable growth, inequalities, sustainable consumption and production, biodiversity, to be addressed. In particular, we want to call on the United Nations to make gender equality, women's rights, women's empowerment and the human rights of women and girls an independent objective and an essential requirement for fair and inclusive sustainable development. Indeed, we believe that the time has come to provide for a specific action plan on gender equality, accompanied by the necessary financing mechanism that includes specific budgetary instruments in order to combat cross-cutting and structural factors that generate inequalities and multiple forms of discrimination both in the European Union and in the rest of the world.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report in particular in that it supports the establishment of a more private sector-oriented policy: it is indeed a question of promoting, in the countries where the European Union intervenes, the emergence of a local private sector. This policy will enable recipient countries to develop their own jobs internally through the emergence of SMEs/TPEs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I firmly believe that new development pathways are necessary for a sustainable development policy after 2015 – but I do not think that the concrete measures proposed are ill-conceived. Better monitoring of the implementation of future objectives is essential to ensure their long-term success. The introduction of objective and verifiable standards would be a first step in this direction. I have therefore voted against this motion.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported the vote on the report on European priorities for global development after the expiration of the Millennium Development Goals in 2015. This compromise text has very positive elements, such as the universality of the global development framework, the development of binding rules for multinationals, a European trade strategy to maintain high social and environmental standards, the fight against social and environmental dumping, a commitment to quality European aid, a clean goal for gender equality, and a goal of universal access to health.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the European Union and the global development framework for 2015. Human rights, poverty, inequality, terrorism, health, discrimination, armed conflicts, climate change, etc. remain a major problem in developing countries. A global and coherent approach to these challenges is needed, so that benefits reach more people in need and that national development is more balanced. The new framework must create a more transparent system with greater responsibility, and so must the European Union. Specific objectives and activities must be reflected in the EU's internal and external policies.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. Given that the challenges of poverty eradication and sustainable development are of general concern and are of common concern to all countries and to all people, they must be tackled globally. In order to ensure decent living conditions throughout the world, a strong political commitment must be established and decisive action taken. In particular, the EU and the global development programme after 2015 must be based on the principles of human dignity, impartiality, equality and sustainability. It must promote new developments, help to establish a new global partnership and be able to respond to the ever-changing situation in the world. It should be noted that the programme should provide for the responsibility of the parties, taking into account the different situations, capacities and levels of development of the parties. I support the proposal that greater attention be paid to strategies that promote the non-emissions of coal compounds. It is essential that national minimum social protection is established in all developing countries and universal access to comprehensive health and education services is ensured. The least developed and other vulnerable countries cannot be left behind. Close cooperation with other donors is needed to develop and implement innovative financial mechanisms.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - Considering that the Millennium Goals to be achieved by 2015 have strongly contributed to improving people's lives, reducing poverty and considering that the post-2015 agenda needs a deeply renewed global partnership, which will strengthen the international community's commitment to addressing the main global challenges, and considering that the establishment of a coherent EU position would make it possible to establish the guidelines for a negotiating strategy , I voted in favour.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report identifying the priorities of the post-2015 development framework. In particular, I believe that the eradication of poverty, the fight against inequalities and sustainable development cannot be achieved without a commitment on the issues of climate change, food safety, without a real commitment to combat the use of fossil materials that degrade soil, water and the environment by denying future generations the future they deserve.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution entitled 'Post-2015 Development Framework: Eradicating poverty and protecting human rights'. Poverty eradication, the fight against inequality, the protection of human rights and sustainable health systems are some of the key objectives set out in the resolution on the post-2015 development framework. Poverty eradication and the protection of human rights should be the main guide to the post-2015 development framework, states a resolution proposed by the Committee on Development. 2015 will be the European Year of Development and, at the same time, the year when the Millennium Development Goals set by the United Nations in 2000 are expected to inherit a new post-2015 global framework.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE)
text: Written. - I was pleased to vote in favour of the report on global development work after 2015. In particular, I welcome the elements of the report that safeguard women's sexual and reproductive health while strengthening the principle that everyone should have the right to control their own bodies.  I chose to vote blank on the reference to "legally binding requirements" concerning CSR and corporate social responsibility. It is, of course, important that the EU's development and trade policy is based on companies in third countries edating in a fair and transparent way. However, it is important to understand that all cases are different and it is therefore difficult to find a "one size fits all" solution. At the same time, it is also important not to confuse fair trading conditions with the democratic right of developing countries to develop the model of society they want. That is why we must be very careful about pressuring companies into a particular behaviour which, in some cases, does not create better development. Of course, our development policy, through sustainable growth and without harming the environment or reducing social security, must ensure that both developing and donor countries benefit from cooperation.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. "Have a development policy, of course, but it would still have to be sensible. This resolution proposes absolutely insufficient measures to combat corruption and embezzlement of European funds (while so many scandals have shown that there is an urgent need to better control the actual destination of the funds granted). The text is very unsatisfactory on another point, migration policy. With these two major negligences, the resolution is unacceptable. So I'm voting against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Unfortunately, the fight against poverty is still a current battle. Despite the tangible positive effects of achieving some of the Millennium Development Goals, there is still much to be done. By, and beyond, 2015. The EU and its Member States are the main donors of development aid. However, building a development agenda beyond 2015 requires a new, more structural and less 'occasional' approach: aid policies must be implemented within a unified and coherent framework of universal development that takes account of natural needs and diversity. To this end, Europe must have a strong and cohesive position. In its role as guarantor of human rights, it must work to ensure the rights of women, children and minorities, to guarantee education, access to sanitation, drinking water and employment, within a framework of promoting sustainable development that involves all actors: from international, European, national and local institutions to civil society. Because combating inequalities is the duty of all of us.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - An analysis of the impact of the UN Millennium Declaration has shown significant improvements in the living conditions of the people of developing countries, but at the same time it has shown that it needs to be updated and adapted to the new challenges and possibilities offered by today's world. In particular, I consider the success of the implementation of the Millennium Development Goals to date to be a commitment to further deepen and better target our efforts. The European Parliament resolution clearly defines the basic and develops the sub-areas that need to be addressed in addressing the problem of global inclusive and sustainable growth. I am convinced of the need to create a strong, binding document that represents the EU's strong and united position, the basis of which should be the communication 'A dignified life for all'.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am pleased that the Council and Parliament have given their support to the general EU position defined by the Commission on the post-2015 agenda.  I believe that the title chosen for communication is effective and expresses the will of what it aims to achieve as a goal in terms of global development "A dignified existence for all". With some major global issues such as poverty, fair work for all, the elimination of inequalities, health, sustainable production and environmental protection. Of course, all this can only be achieved with a clear and ambitious agenda, based on the rights and protection of the human being, where strategic priorities and objectives are as clearly highlighted as parliament has done.   I hope that the Council conclusions will clearly set out the principles and lines of the EU strategy for the years to come. In addition, third countries that share EU priorities should be more systematically involved and, in doing so, the EU must lead the way.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the Union and the post-2015 global development framework. The 8 Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) set in 2000 for developing countries expire in 2015. But today in 2014, not all of these goals have been achieved. That is why the UN has been thinking about a new post-2015 development framework using Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and a global agenda. It was important for the European Union and in particular for the European Parliament to take a position on the post-2015 development framework and the SDGs. I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has been able to set its main priorities by recalling the need for an approach based on respect for human rights.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted against this report because it contains mismanagementin the issues of gender and climate in many ways, of which the EP has already adopted enough to the detriment of the citizens.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — In the run-up to intergovernmental negotiations following commitments to the United Nations on the Millennium Development Goals, it is necessary for the European Union to weigh its weight by agreeing on priority positions. I therefore vote in favour of the report on the Union and the global development framework in order to encourage the international community to persevere in the face of the challenges of the 21st century, including the eradication of poverty through education and the place of women in society, as well as sustainable development and peacekeeping.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the definition of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in 2000, visible progress has been made, notably in reducing extreme poverty, combating malaria and tuberculosis and improving access to drinking water. Despite the positive results achieved, key issues such as poverty, human rights violations, inequality, armed conflicts and terrorism, climate change and environmental protection, food insecurity, migration, limited access to health services and education, unemployment, demographic change, corruption and unsustainable growth will continue to place , in the coming decades, complex challenges, which cannot fail to be addressed in the definition of the global development framework post-2015. The present report rightly stresses the need for the EU, in the framework of future intergovernmental negotiations to define the new framework, to make every effort to ensure that these priorities are dealt with properly and to focus on a human rights-based approach that gives due emphasis to issues such as good governance, democracy , the rule of law and access to justice. In agreeing to this approach, I voted in favour.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. - As Pope Francis pointed out in his speech today, 21 November 2014, we must put European citizens, people and their primary needs at the centre of the public. I believe that the first step to be taken is to combat inequalities of any kind. Reducing inequalities between Member States and, by implication, between the inhabitants of the Union is the basis for sustainable development, which can lead to the eradication of poverty. In my view, poverty eradication can be achieved through three key conditions: the absence of armed conflict, the prevention of climate disasters and the improvement of productivity in the agricultural and fisheries sectors. The new global development framework, the 'EU and the post-2015 global development framework', voted on today, is the key to creating these necessary conditions. Good governance for sustainable and balanced global development in the post-2015 period is directly intertwined with one of the main objectives of the millennium: halving the number of people suffering from hunger and poverty.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this initiative report calling on the international community to set a universal and ambitious post-2015 agenda with sustainable development goals that engage countries around the world. For this new agenda, priority themes have been chosen, some of which are particularly close to my heart: access to primary and secondary education for girls, universal provision of health services and access to sexual and reproductive rights, and the fight against violence against women. In this regard, let us remember the awarding of the 2014 Sakharov Prize to Dr. Mukwege, who has worked so hard to repair the harm suffered by women who have been victims of rape and genital mutilation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which aims to help shape the EU's position at the next UN Conference in September 2015. It is the latest in a series of analyses produced annually by the Eurochamber on how the Millennium Goals have worked, how to improve them and how to make them more viable. In September 2000, the UN adopted the Millennium Declaration, which would continue to set targets to be achieved in 2015. Fourteen years later, the world has halved extreme poverty and the fight against malaria and tuberculosis yields spectacular results. But, with the aim of a new post-2015 agreement, the international community is conducting an extensive analysis process for a regulatory framework for the sake of global development. Among the main contributions of my group I would like to highlight the objective of eradicating extreme poverty, linking development and humanitarian aid, ensuring actions in failed States, combating tax evasion and corruption, ensuring the specific needs of persons with disabilities and acting more forcefully on sexual and reproductive health and rights, as well as in relation to the rights of minorities and vulnerable persons.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this resolution (541 votes in, 96 against and 29 abstentions) which clearly expresses the wishes of the European Parliament for the position that the European Union will defend in the new international negotiations on the Millennium Development Goals which will take place next year.  The voted text argues that the eradication of poverty and the fight against inequality should be the guiding principle of the future global development framework and that the Union should work to ensure that the approach based on human rights and the right to development become founding concepts. The resolution also calls on the European Commission to make the elimination of inequalities in access to health and education a priority and calls on the EU to support its autonomous goal of gender equality. Finally, it also calls on Member States to respect their commitment to allocate at least 0.7% of their GNI to official development assistance.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour because this document encourages all EU countries to review the millennium targets set above and to make even more ambitious ones. It is of particular importance that the document covers three aspects of sustainable development, both social, economic and environmental. Without sustainable measures, we will not be able to overcome the root causes of so many poor people in the world, who are subjected to violence and discrimination. We cannot remain indifferent when EUR 1.5 billion is invested in the eu-25. people are experiencing poverty and multiple deprivation of health care, education and living standards. Today we are talking about poverty not only somewhere far away, but also here in Europe. Therefore, more than ever, a new development programme must be global in nature and applied in all countries. I would like to welcome the fact that this document calls on the EU to work to indicate what commitments the Community is prepared to make and propose internationally. I think it is time to realise that we will not be able to change anything if each country does not contribute to this process if we do not ensure permanent funding and consistent policies and clear criteria for assessing progress.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Millennium Development Goals that were defined in 2000 are coming to an end and will soon be redefined. Future negotiations for the post-2015 development agenda will result in a new set of goals and replace the Millennium Goals.  I supported this text because there is an urgent need to define sustainable and comprehensive solutions to combat inequality, eradicate poverty and defend human rights around the world. The European Union will be a central player in these future negotiations and it is important that it continue its central role on the international development policy stage.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have decided to vote negatively for these two reasons: excessive emphasis on a prominent role in the conduct of EU and UN policies on post-2015 development by the Eu ropean Union to the detriment of the Member States and support for environmental and climate change policies that I do not entirely agree with and which do not take priority over issues such as development and the eradication of poverty.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I agree with the text and voted in favour, because over the negotiation period of the text — as the GUE rapporteur for this particular — I have managed to include the following aspects which I consider key to the future development framework: appeal to the need for the framework to be universal; great emphasis on inequality; prioritization of fiscal justice and mobilization of national resources; mention of the need to establish legally binding rules for corporate social responsibility for multinational companies; need to meet aid commitments in both quality and quantity; universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights; and calls for an independent objective on gender equality, while ensuring the incorporation of the gender approach in a comprehensive and cross-cutting way to the rest of the development framework.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this resolution with the reservation that I disagree and do not approve the reference at Article 78 to the financial transaction tax. In my view, given current circumstances, this reference is inappropriate and unnecessary.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in support of the global development framework after 2015. The communication ‘Decent Life for All’ lays the foundation of the EU position on the post-2015 agenda. This communication calls for tackling issues of global concern such as poverty, health, food security, education, gender equality, water and sanitation, sustainable energy, decent work, inclusive and sustainable growth, inequality, sustainable consumption and production, biodiversity, land degradation and sea and oceans.  I support the recommendation that a human rights-based approach and good governance should be the underlying concept of the new framework.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I have abstained for the vote on the Stier report as in general it calls for good issues (protecting of people and minorities), but it has some bad points in it as well, as for example point 28 which asks for ‘the promotion of universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights’. I do not agree with this and therefore abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. — As global problems such as poverty, hunger, lack of access to quality healthcare, lack of education, high unemployment, in particular youth unemployment, gender inequality, environmental degradation persist, it is essential to find new solutions for development. I advocate that the European Union be actively involved in edging these problems and encourage the involvement of other countries in activities to ensure sustainable development on Earth.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. - With the adoption of the POST-2015 RESOLUTION on the EU and the global development framework, the European Parliament has asked the Council to adopt a single EU position ahead of the Negotiations under the auspices of the United Nations. It is important to point out that the resolution emphasizes respect for the dignity of every human being, which relies on Article 2 of the EEA. charters on fundamental rights on the right to life of every human being.  This resolution must also be seen in the context of earlier decisions taken by the European Parliament, not least the Resolution on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights of 10 December 2013, which underlines the principle of subsidiarity and the right of each Member State to define those rights itself. Therefore, the reference to sexual and reproductive rights in the EU Resolution and the global development framework after 2015 cannot and must not be interpreted as a formulation that automatically includes abortion, but it is left to countries to regulate it through national legislation.   The resolution on the EU and the global development framework after 2015 makes no mention of abortion at all, nor does it in any way encourage, much less force, EU member states or developing countries to legitimise abortion.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I welcome the fact that the Millennium Development Goals set in 2000 have had great success in middle-income countries and developing countries, but the report also points out that progress within these same countries is uneven, and before designing the Development Goals after 2015, it is necessary to analyse the results correctly so far, as they are the clearest indicator of the results of the work to date, which must be further worked on. I agree that the "Global Sustainable Development Framework for the Post-2015 Period" should be transformational in a way that addresses the root causes of poverty and inequality, the way to continue and fulfil the unfinished business of the current Millennium Development Goals. Furthermore, key issues such as inequalities, human rights violations, climate change, limited access to education, demographic change and other problems we face today are key factors that must be addressed and must be of importance when drawing up new targets. As a member of the environment committee, I would particularly address environmental sustainability as one of the main challenges, and I agree that failure to achieve it would likely jeopardise all aspects of human development and the realisation of sustainable development.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — We disagree with almost the whole approach. We do not believe that the EU should be the feeder of the planet, nor that it has the right to consider itself capable of imposing its views throughout the world. After all, we also disagree with how many of these views are expressed.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We are continuing our work towards an ambitious post-2015 development agenda. With this report, we wish to contribute to the definition of a coherent and firm position of the Union, which the Council will adopt in December 2014. The Council's conclusions should set out the principles and set out the main directions of the Union's negotiating strategy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I strongly support efforts to take into account the different circumstances, capacities, policies and priorities of individual countries in the new development framework, and I consider it extremely positive to recognise the issue of poverty eradication and sustainable development as crucial themes of the new development framework.  I also agree with the view that achieving the new development goals requires continued close cooperation between the EU and developing countries, with a view to increasing countries' domestic revenues, as well as transparent and reliable mobilisation of funding. So I voted in favor.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. I objected to this report because the following two points are mentioned far too briefly: - the management of migration flows; and - reference to corruption networks and the establishment of systems that would allow the control of the recipients of European aid funds.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. - Although it offers reasons for reserved optimism, global poverty figures show that one and a half billion people still live in absolute poverty, deprived of food, easy access to water, healthcare, education and security. I believe that there is a need for joint measures, whereby the European Union is openly and unequivocally able to assume its role as a global exporter of know-how in all areas with an impact on the standard of living - education, good governance, legislation, public health.  Absolute poverty also exists in the EU, even though it looks perhaps different from poverty exacerbated by civil wars and conflicts in other parts of the world.  I believe that poverty within the borders of the European Union and that of the rest of the world must be addressed in parallel. While the national governments of the 28 EU states, but especially of eastern European countries, have a great responsibility in promoting national policies and using the resources made available by the EU to eradicate poverty, the European Union must act together to accelerate the reduction of poverty in the rest of the world.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this document, but I would like to highlight a number of key points which I believe are key to achieving the objectives set. First of all, it is the fight against corruption, which, like cancer, destroys all the good work done. Secondly, we need to act by setting an example for other countries – especially in the area of nature protection, we need to show that development is based on clean energy, which comes along a sustainable path, is possible.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as it contained key aspects such as the fight against inequality, the establishment of binding rules on corporate social responsibility for enterprises, and an EU trade strategy with the aim of maintaining and protecting social and environmental standards, while rejecting any form of social or environmental dumping. The report recalls the commitments made in terms of development aid and also calls for the setting of gender equality objectives. The text also recognizes health as a human right and the importance of access to public health services, such as family planning, among others. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We can boast about the small steps taken in this or that domain in the quality of life of the populations of our planet. However, if progress is certain to be made in some areas, we find a profound degradation in the quality of life of people in many places on the planet and, in particular, here in Europe, where hunger and misery gain ground every day. This report, being accurate in the complaint, fails to diagnose and does not prescribe substantial for the cure of the patient. In fact, nothing is said about the heavy responsibilities of neoliberal policies implemented around the world from the 1980s on.  It says nothing about the absolute need for public programmes to develop education and health and plan the economy. The idea that the whole strategy is based on an outsourcing logic is still fashionable, with the use of companies and NGOs.  We agree on all these goals. We believe, however, that it is not possible to devise a clear strategy for its fulfilment, without changing our model of society, in which the interests of large capital overlap with the well-being of peoples and where political power is in the hands of economic power.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — While new development pathways are needed for sustainable and inclusive development in the post-2015 period, I believe that the approaches in this motion cannot be sufficiently implemented or have not been sufficiently thought through. There have certainly been some successes from the MDGs set, but it should be possible to implement this success in a chidon way by better monitoring and by introducing measurable standards to better control the MDGs. I voted against this motion in this respect.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — All women have the fundamental right of access to public health systems, in particular basic health care, gynaecology and obstetrics services, as defined by the World Health Organisation.  However, the EP is narrowing this approach and still sees abortion as a major contribution by Europe to the fight against poverty in the Third World: the children of the poorest are too much for the EU. The term "sexual and reproductive health and rights" is not defined in any treaty or convention that is binding under international law. The WHO dictionary uses "inclusive language" that refers to "sexual and reproductive health" in particular fertility control methods, referring in particular to abortion methods. There is no obligation under international law to grant abortion services.  In the Estrela report on 10 December 2013, this EU Parliament itself stated that the formulation and implementation of the policy on SRHR (as well as sex education in schools) falls within the competence of the Member States and is expressly not a competence of the EU. However, it is equally telling that, in its resolution on the future of development policy, the EP expressly does not mention the right of developing countries to self-determination and the recognition of their cultural diversity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report, being accurate in the complaint, fails to diagnose and prescribes nothing substantial to solve this humanitarian disaster. In fact, nothing is said about the heavy responsibilities of neoliberal policies implemented around the world from the 1980s on. Nothing is said about the responsibilities of large multinational companies, or the large military and industrial complex, that sow war and misery. It says nothing about the absolute need to have public programs to develop health education and plan the economy.  We agree on all these goals. We believe, however, that it is not possible to devise a clear strategy for its fulfilment without changing our model of society where the interests of large capital overlap with the well-being of peoples, and where political power is in fact the hands of great economic and financial power.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this resolution four years after the launch of the strategy and after the Commission specifically proposed its revision, pointing out that progress towards achieving the objectives has been completely uneven in terms of employment and poor in terms of poverty reduction. There were 122 million people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in 2013 and the target was 96 million. That is why an absolutely timely response is required. To this end, in an integrated area such as the eurozone, the coordination of all economic policy instruments will therefore be essential. Budgetary constraints, slow growth and the erosion of economic potential lead to the need to consider a European vision based on the promotion of investment. A genuine global investment policy is key to stimulating demand and growth. A greater effort will be needed both by the Member States in the more oriented use of the Structural Funds and by the Commission in strengthening gender and youth employment policies through greater information sharing.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the failings within the Europe 2020 strategy are clearly linked to the overriding austerity agenda of the European Semester. We have been calling on the Council and the Commission to end the policy of austerity and to stop putting pressure on salaries and labour. The Commission should instead launch new policies which would create jobs and promote training, research and innovation, education, reducing poverty, and the fight against climate change. We are asking the Council and the Commission to embed Europe 2020 targets in a new social and economic governance architecture which sits on an equal footing with the economic goals and is linked to an ambitious social agenda. We have tried to introduce such issues into the resolution but unfortunately they have not been incorporated meaningfully enough, and for these reasons we abstain in this vote.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I applaud the fact that the final text of this 2020 Strategy includes important references to the creation of quality jobs, policies focused on growth instead of austerity, the fight against precarious employment and the inclusion of national parliaments and social partners in decision-making, and stronger language on the eradication of child poverty. I believe it is crucial that the resolution calls for employment and social considerations to be assigned finally to their proper place, which is on a par with economic and fiscal governance. But words are not enough. In my region of the West Midlands, employment rates have improved, but they are still extremely high. Eight per cent of the people are still out of a job. Meanwhile, wages growth has dropped to just 0.7%, meaning that those with a job are not necessarily guaranteed to meet their basic needs. We will only be able to substantially reduce the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion if we make targets binding and ensure that they are closely monitored.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe 2020 strategy, as we are all aware, represents a great opportunity to use the EUR 960 billion budget provided for in the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework in a manner consistent with the real priorities. However, it is in danger of becoming a missed opportunity in the absence of a decisive change of direction in the allocation of resources and in the Union's activities. We all share the view that the benefits of growth should fall on society as a whole, but the reduction of inequalities should be seen not only as a possible result of growth or as a side objective but above all as a means of promoting growth. The more exploitation and speculation are combated, the more resources can go to current and potential workers, reducing unemployment and precariousness and increasing production and consumption. The resolution moves in this direction, also calling for concrete measures to facilitate peripheral regions and which are having greater difficulty in developing investment programmes within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Mr Vice-President, the Strategy on Employment and Social Aspects of Europe 2020 is one of the key issues in the upcoming Multiannual Financial Framework for the European Union, in the forthcoming work of the European Commission. About our efforts to work towards inclusive growth and fulfilment of all those objectives related to both increasing employment to 75% for people between 20 and 64, making 20 million less in poverty in the European Union than it is today, and reducing the number of school leavers before their time.  In any case, with other measures within the European Semester, with measures concerning the fulfilment of programmes under the European budget, the Role of the European Parliament in highlighting the social aspects of the 2020 strategy is extremely significant and I therefore supported today the adoption of this report, which we have prepared in the context of the 2020 strategy.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. - (C) Today we voted on a resolution on the Europe 2020 strategy. I voted against the resolution as a whole because it partly puts an increased strain on the EU budget by calling for increased appropriations for various labour market policies. In addition, there are wordings on the European Youth Guarantee, minimum wages and flexibility in the labour market. These wordings are contrary to the principle of subsidiarity and contribute to greater detailed management of Member States' policies in the social and labour market policy areas. This is not a desirable development. It is up to the Member States themselves to decide on social and labour market policy issues.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are subordinate to the macroeconomic objectives of the European Semester, which are contradictory to the former. In order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, it would be necessary to put an end to austerity policies, which are putting pressure on wages and employment, and new binding, figure-backed initiatives should be put in place to create jobs and protect and promote training, research and innovation, education, poverty reduction and the fight against climate change.  We call for the challenge of the Europe 2020 Strategy and replaced by a pact of progress and social justice that strengthens and leverages budgetary resources in order to increase production in deficit countries, support SMEs, combat unemployment and precariousness, create jobs with rights and ensure the protection and improvement of public services. All this is not included in the resolution, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - Four years ago, the European Union adopted the Europe 2020 strategy. The aim of this strategy is, among other things, to improve the EU's competitiveness and to strengthen social and employment policies. Concrete targets related to education, employment and poverty reduction were on the agenda. The study, which has now been carried out after four years, revealed a number of negative results. In terms of employment and poverty, Member States are moving away from the EU 2020 targets rather than approaching them. That is why we, as a Parliament, are suggesting that these objectives be bindingand enshrineed and reviewed in the context of the European Semester. In future, the European Commission and the Member States must insist much more strongly on the employment and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to review the employment and social aspects of the EU 2020 strategy. Since the launch of the Europe 2020 strategy, unemployment has continued to rise in 2010, with the EU totalling 24.6 million people. Unemployed. Since 2008, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased by 10 million. – up to more than 122.6 million, i.e. every fourth population. I agree that the role of social protection systems as a key instrument for improving economic and societal stability and poverty reduction is not sufficiently taken into account. I support the proposals set out to call on Member States to go beyond what is more ambitious when they move the EU's objectives to their national objectives. I believe it is necessary to call on the Commission and the Member States to ensure that the employment rate only increases by creating new quality jobs in the European economy, and it is also important to create a platform for social partners that combines the interests of employers and workers.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. From the liberalisation of regulated professions to the seconded workers directive, where is the social Europe that has been promised for so many years? In its communication on 5 March on the Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission is obliged to acknowledge that "progress to date has been mixed." But then, instead of continuing to incriminate the 2008 crisis, what are our great strategists waiting for to finally question themselves? As the European Union's unpaid bills pile up, the Commission still promises to spend billions of euros that it does not have... for projects that don't work. Instead of playing on announcement effects, it is high time that the European Union changed its paradigm and broke with the dogma of the "free movement of capital, goods and people".

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The latest Eurostat statistics are relentless: nearly 125 million Europeans are or are at risk of falling into poverty at any time. The Luxleaks case is just as relentless: fiscal injustice is unbearable. As for the unemployment rate, it remains far too high. The European project cannot be built on such social, human and fiscal injustices. There is no other way than to take this into account in the Europe 2020 strategy. Poverty and unemployment must be reduced by imposing large capital. The too-timid stimulus package presented by Jean-Claude Juncker must be amplified, in particular by developing public investment. But it is also necessary to preserve social gains firmly. The recovery must not be at the expense of workers. In this regard, I will be extremely vigilant about the application of the REFIT programme and its respect for the rights to health and safety of workers enshrined in the European Charter of Fundamental Rights

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I abstained due to the absence of the term "security" in the paragraph. We defend a labour market with a single contract, which reduces fragmentation and precariousness, simplifies administrative burdens and gives companies greater flexibility, while ensuring the safety of workers.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution because current policies focus only on economic growth without recognising the need for an inclusive and sustainable approach. This requires a more ambitious approach to States with clear objectives for re-industrialization; with the introduction of an industrial plan that increases competitiveness; dual education and the creation of an effective employment service; with a new framework between political and social priorities; with a youth guarantee booster; with the requirement that Member States look at the 'green sector' and the 'white sector' for the creation of new jobs. The objective, as proposed by the proposal, is for all these measures to be carried out with the participation of local and regional authorities.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution for which I voted against is just another text that is supposed to solve all the jobs problems in Europe. The resolution's findings are damning: unemployment at 10.1%, plus 10 million people since 2008 for a total of 123 million Europeans at risk of poverty, a considerable increase in income inequality and so on. It is clear, however, that the Liberal and austerity policies of the European Union, which impose free and undistorted competition, the total opening of uncompared borders and the profusion of standards and regulations, have not helped in any way the employment situation in Europe. Worse, it is clear that this technocratic Union has rather promoted the ruin of the peoples and the emergence of mass unemployment. We will not solve the situation with fine speeches, it is high time to radically change European policy and the results of last May have clearly shown this aspiration of citizens for a renewal.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained from voting on this report because I do not agree with the modus operandi of this Europe of empty slogans and strategies that fail on time. The truth is that the fantmatic European strategies always conceal an asymmetry of interest between what is thought and wanted for adults and what is only announced for the little ones.  We should therefore not be surprised if what is in the interests of capital, banks and multinationals proceeds quietly but is achieved, while what is in the interests of ordinary citizens or small entrepreneurs is praised but remains inexorably on paper. The truth is that, today, this Europe is an ideological and financial construct, allergic to democracy and aimed at expanding market forces beyond all limits. Conceived in this way, this Europe can only oppose all forms of self-government and self-determination, instead favouring processes of globalisation, privatisation and deregulation. Processes that, in addition to reducing the differences between peoples, also take away from them every area of freedom: including that of mutual aid, which is the foundation of every welfare. What is needed, therefore, is not to define another European strategy or to adjust the current one. What is needed today is an exit strategy from this Europe.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The EU is living in an unprecedented social emergency. Since 2010, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased by 10 million to more than 120 million people. There are also almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU28 and many of those who do have a job fail to make it to the end of the month. That is why I voted in favour of establishing a minimum insertion income at European level: because I believe that the EU has a legal and moral obligation to ensure that Europeans have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs. I also voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there must be a change in the policies of the European Semester to align them with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, putting macroeconomic and employment and social priorities at the same level and ensuring that the employment created in Europe is of quality and with job guarantees. I believe that we must increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in order to return Europe to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because much further progress is needed in the Member States to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. It remains regrettable that in some Member States the growth surveys and country-specific recommendations are not sufficiently aligned with the Europe 2020 objectives for employment, poverty reduction and education. The role of social protection systems as key tools for improving economic and societal stability and poverty reduction is not sufficiently taken into account. Unemployment remains high, so people often choose zero-hours contracts, bogus self-employment or socially insecurity as a way out. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Member States to respond as actively as possible to labour market needs, in particular by ensuring strong links between education and work.
