Calls also on the Commission to strictly align the activities of the European Social Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds with the policy priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy in order to strengthen the role of these funds in terms of financial support for the implementation of the strategy.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. — We are looking at the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy. Unemployment, precariousness, etc. More than getting closer to your goals, you move away from it. According to this strategy, employment is an absolute right. However, the employment rate has not increased. Another structural failure of the European Union. Its bureaucracy and regulations are stifling our SMEs. As the resolution notes, "the European Union is far from achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 employment and poverty reduction strategy." Unemployment "reached an alarming 10.1% in 2014, with 24.6 million people unemployed in the EU and the number of working poor also on the rise". It should come as no surprise that this strategy, like the previous ones, is not working. The predicted precariousness and flexibility can only exacerbate poverty and precariousness. This European Union keeps promising us a bright future. I can only doubt that after so many strategies. I therefore voted against the motion for a resolution entitled 'Employment and social aspects in the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy'.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union must create the conditions for linking its investments in cooperation to the issue of combating adaptation and climate change if it is to be credible and effective.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I abstained. The text is not convincing in terms of practicality and results.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - On 19 March 2014, the EC published a Communication entitled 'Balance of the Europe 2020 Strategy' as the basis for the revision of that Strategy to be presented next year.  This Communication reveals that we are further from achieving social and employment objectives. Since 2010, the number of citizens without employment or at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased across the EU, and 120 million Europeans live in poverty or at risk of poverty. 16 million citizens must be added to employment in order to comply with the Europe 2020 Strategy (employment rate of 75%).  The Commission is therefore asked whether it intends to increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion, whether it intends to set more ambitious targets for these issues in national reform programmes, or whether it will increase the contribution of the EU budget to the achievement of national objectives.  The Council is mainly asked about the possibility of adding indicators to the Social and Employment Scoreboard, what such indicators should be raised and what consequences making them binding.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Europe 2020 strategy was put in place to restore political, economic and social momentum to a Europe in crisis. It is based on five objectives: employment, education, poverty reduction, the fight against climate change and research and development. The goal is to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I voted in favour of the resolution on employment and social aspects in the Europe 2020 strategy.  It was time, halfway through, to take stock of the progress made in employment and to determine the efforts to be mobilized. The crisis we are experiencing is not only economic but also social. We must fight to redress the unemployment curve and especially youth unemployment by adopting appropriate structural reforms as proposed in the country-by-country recommendations from the European Commission.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted today in favour of the resolution on the employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy, which set a target of achieving, by 2020, a population share of 75%, employed between the age of 20 and 64.  I believe that, in addition to achieving a higher employment rate, it is a top priority to move towards a higher quality of employment. It is therefore necessary for the indicators on the subject to focus not only on the number of people finding work but also on the quality of the work itself and for the objectives of creating quality employment and quality jobs, as well as ensuring the efficiency of resources, to be made more effective and visible within the framework of the light initiatives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Finally, financial and economic priorities must be balanced in relation to social priorities, strengthening them, in order to ensure that social policies can be implemented.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution in its core focuses on combating unemployment, and highlights the problems youths face in entering the workforce. I have voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for integrated guidelines to tackle youth unemployment.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. — (1) We believe that all people should have proper social security, especially the weakest in society. We believe that the European Union can usefully work to make all governments aware of the many positive aspects, including social convergence between Member States, which is promoting adequate social security for the most vulnerable members of society. However, we firmly believe that the Commission should neither propose nor set a minimum basis for social security, as this issue is best dealt with at national level. We do not want to help set a precedent for the Commission to legislate on the Danish welfare state, its benefits and rates. It must remain a purely national matter.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the high rate of poverty and unemployment, especially among young people, which Europe is facing, I believe that the Member States are called upon to focus actively on employment policies, paying particular attention to the outermost regions affected by natural handicaps, isolation, geographical discontinuity and economic fragility. All this accentuates inequalities in access to employment, traineeship and training opportunities for the population. I stress that these regions require specific strengthened investment mechanisms in order to implement programmes aimed at achieving the Europe 2020 objectives and exploiting their potential in terms of economic and social development. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — One of the things the EU needs to change is how it handles the major issues of our time, in particular the work emergency. I believe that the mid-term review of the targets set for 2020 is a good opportunity to take stock of the situation and to bring about the change that we all expect. With this hope in mind, I voted in favour, and I will continue to ensure that, as the Pope said, technocrats do not win but that technology is at the service of the great political objectives.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The employment and social dimension of European integration is a key element of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims at ensuring ‘inclusive growth’. Four years after its launch, the European Commission has begun a review of this strategy. The European Parliament, for its part, is preparing a resolution on the employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy. The crisis has highlighted the importance of labour markets, welfare systems and social inclusion in strengthening socio-economic policies, and made the need for reinforcement of the social dimension of the new EU ‘economic governance’ evident. In October 2013, the European Commission (EC) proposed a new early-warning tool – the scoreboard of key employment and social indicators – to ensure better integration of employment and social policies into the European Semester, and this has been implemented as from the 2014 cycle.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The integrated approach of the Europe 2020 strategy underlines the principle that smart, sustainable and inclusive growth cannot be achieved if all five major objectives are not achieved. On the other hand, the high unemployment rates of the European Union are intrinsically related to the decline of the industrial and manufacturing production base. I believe that meeting the targets of reindustrialisation is fundamental to the EU's competitiveness and that the relaunch of a genuine European industrial policy will contribute to growth and job creation. At the same time, the Commission and the Member States should promote and improve mobility mechanisms, such as the European Job Mobility Portal (EUTRES) and public employment services, in order to increase employment, particularly among young people. A dual education system and the implementation of true lifelong learning should also be introduced with a view to a significant improvement in the qualifications of older workers.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Poverty is an EU problem that needs effective, strong and direct action to be taken at EU level. Such action must be capable of ensuring that causes and consequences of poverty are addressed also at Member State level. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Since 2010, the number of citizens unemployed or at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the European Union has increased on average and today there are 120 million Europeans living in poverty or at risk of poverty. According to the Commission's forecasts, in order to achieve the target of an employment rate of 75% set by the Europe 2020 strategy, it is necessary to guarantee a job for another 16 million citizens. In addition, disparities between the employment rates of the various Member States and regions are increasing, with the consequent risk that greater social imbalances will be created in the long term. I am also voting in favour of this resolution in order to support the minimum wage guaranteed at European level.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are subordinate to the macroeconomic objectives of the European Semester, which are contradictory to the former. In order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, it would be necessary to put an end to austerity policies, which are putting pressure on wages and employment, and new binding, figure-backed initiatives should be put in place to create jobs and protect and promote training, research and innovation, education, poverty reduction and the fight against climate change.  We call for the challenge of the Europe 2020 Strategy and replaced by a pact of progress and social justice that strengthens and leverages budgetary resources in order to increase production in deficit countries, support SMEs, combat unemployment and precariousness, create jobs with rights and ensure the protection and improvement of public services. All this is not included in the resolution, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) It is depressing to note that, even in spite of the many words and documents that are produced, the Union is still a long way from achieving the employment and poverty reduction objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. On the other hand, also because of the crises we are experiencing, but not only because of that, the rates of unemployment - particularly among young people - and poverty rates - concentrated in certain specific areas of the continent - have increased, in some cases out of all proportion. There is one thing that strikes me particularly and that is the increase in families at risk of poverty. It is an indicator that hides and has worrying implications. For example, it is directly linked to the increase in the school drop-out rate, which has soared rapidly in some European regions. The resources of the European Social Fund will have to be used and concentrated to finance programmes and recovery courses for the training courses of many young people who have left too soon. Europe absolutely cannot afford to lose the challenge of education and, as a result, that thousands of its citizens should remain excluded from the global circuits of knowledge and progress.

name: Csáky Pál (PPE)
text: Writing. - In order to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, we need a more ambitious approach, particularly in the area of unemployment and poverty. I agree with the European Commission's proposal to review the strategy. Economic growth alone does not guarantee better jobs, poverty reduction or reduction of social inequalities, and appropriate policy decisions are needed to achieve these objectives. In addition to macroeconomic aspects, employment and social considerations should be taken into account to the same extent. Administrative and bureaucratic burdens still make it difficult for the self-employed, micro-enterprises and SMEs to make ends meet, and it is therefore necessary to reduce the burden. Start-ups also expect better conditions.  Member States are responsible for achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, thus complying with the principle of subsidiarity, but mutual review and the exchange of best practices can also be the secret to success. This will help to increase the flexibility of the labour market and create conditions for businesses to create jobs. It is regrettable, however, that the multiannual financial framework adopted for the period 2014-2020 is the first EU budget with a net budget allocation of EUR 960 billion. It may be useful for the objectives if, following a review of the strategy, the proposals formulated and the subsequent decision are reviewed together by Parliament and the Commission. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – In order to ensure that our social systems are sustainable and in order to ensure that we work towards the Europe 2020 targets we must ensure that our employment and social policy targets are in line and on par with our governmental economic and fiscal policies. The Motion for Resolution has highlighted the main issues at hand to do this – the creation of not just job growth but quality employment, the need for access to social services in order to reduce poverty, the need to fully address the issue of inequality to be able to engage and re-innovate the European work force, the direct implementation of measures to tackle poverty – especially child poverty – and the need to implement the Youth Guarantee, amongst others. I voted in favour of the Employment Committee’s resolution as I believe that these are all concrete measures that will help millions of people currently facing the reality of poverty.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support the rapporteur's proposal to set a secondary target for reducing child poverty in the interim evaluation of the Europe 2020 strategy, but also the use of objective 'poverty' indicators for assessments aimed at measuring poverty rates in the Member States, precisely to help identify those who are at risk of exclusion.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. - As the unemployment rate in the European Union reached alarming levels in 2014 and the risk of poverty increases, it is necessary for Member States to adopt a mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy to meet these challenges. They must also agree on the establishment of mechanisms to coordinate and monitor progress in employment, education and poverty alled, and on the financing of these measures.  The European Parliament, through this resolution, is contributing to the debates on the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy. In particular, I support the provisions stressing the need to ensure an employment rate of 75% by 2020 in the European Union, the reduction of the school drop-out rate to less than 10%, and the exit of 20 million people from poverty and exclusion.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By voting on this resolution, the European Parliament is emphasizing the need to properly include job recovery and social aspects as part of the Europe 2020 strategy. The creation of quality jobs, not just precarious jobs, is a priority for the European Union in this new Parliament. This requires the re-industrialisation of Europe, the revival of competitiveness, and quality lifelong learning. I am also particularly in favour of this desire expressed by the European Parliament to remove the excessive administrative burdens on SMEs, the backbone of our economies.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — While it is true that the content of most of the points of the Resolution is clearly critical — in reflecting the gender perspective in employment material, to consider that social aspects must be as important as macroeconomics or that improving the economy will not necessarily lead to higher quality jobs, but that improving the quality of employment must come from policies that bet on it— , we have had to vote ABSTENTION, since other points in the Resolution underline things, in our view, intolerable. They stress that the problem of youth unemployment is because young people are not sufficiently trained, have no leadership capacity, or do not undertake; that worker mobility needs to be encouraged and the labour market further loosened. These measures only throw balls out, blaming young people for not having jobs, forcing workers into exile to find work and encouraging the precariousness of employment with more and more flexibility than, in countries like Spain, we know leads to further worsening of the labour market.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against because there are reports of continued 'necessary reforms and structural changes' (monumental policy).

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. - If we are to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy and eliminate situations of dependence on persons with disabilities, it is crucial that equality be ensured in all areas of influence of Community policies and, in particular, in access to the labour market for persons with disabilities. In this regard, the measures established by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the reports implementing it should be taken.  As reflected in the case-law of the COURT of Justice of the EU, the Convention is the first legally binding international human rights instrument to which the European Union has become a party. The European Union is therefore bound by the Convention within the limits of its competences, and the Equal Employment Directive, as far as possible, should be interpreted in a manner consistent with the Convention.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — Unemployment levels have continued to grow in some MS since the entry into force of the Europe 2020 strategy and in the EU-28 reached an alarming level of 10.1% in 2014, with 24.6 million unemployed, with an increase in the number of workers in poverty. The most worrying figures are those in the outermost regions, where the average unemployment rate is 24% and the youth unemployment rate reaches 51%. The number of people at risk of poverty has also been increasing, currently reaching more than 122.6 million people and the risk rate of the poor in the EU amounts to, on average, 24.8%, 28% for children (up to 18 years old). The poverty rate of people with disabilities is 70%, higher than the average, partly due to limitations in access to employment. The high unemployment rates in the EU are intrinsically related to the decrease in the base of industrial and manufacturing production, however, by 2020 it will take more than 16 million citizens to reach the employment rate target of 75% by 2020, so it is necessary to improve young people's skills in leadership, management and entrepreneurship, so that businesses , new and start-up scans, can take advantage of new markets and realise their growth potential. It should also be noted that the Commission will have to address the issue of funding because the EUR 6 million is not enough to address the problem of youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU is living in an unprecedented social emergency. Since 2010, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased by 10 million to more than 120 million people. There are also almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU28 and many of those who do have a job fail to make it to the end of the month. That is why I voted in favour of the establishment of a minimum insertion income at European level; because I believe that the EU has a legal and moral obligation to ensure that Europeans have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs.  I also voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there must be a change in the policies of the European Semester to align them with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, putting macroeconomic priorities at the same level as employment and social priorities and ensuring that employment created in Europe is of quality and has job guarantees. I believe that we must increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in order to return Europe to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament is concerned that the annual growth analyses and country-specific recommendations adopted so far, as part of the annual cycles of the European Semester, have not been aligned with the social and employment objectives of the EU2020 strategy.  They were not and can not be, but in the rhetoric with which they seek to deceive the people. The neoliberal measures that have been implemented as an integral part of the EU2020 strategy, through the National Reform Plans, economic governance and the European semester, contribute to the worsening social and economic crisis, making the lives of workers and their families increasingly difficult, imposing a model of low wages and widespread precariousness, increasing unemployment and poverty , destroying essential public services. We call for the repeal of the EU 2020 strategy and its replacement by a strategy of progress and social justice by strengthening and mobilising budgetary resources, with a view to increasing production in countries in deficit countries, supporting SMEs, combating unemployment and precariousness, creating jobs with rights, safeguarding and valuing public services.  We regret that the amendments we have made to that effect have been rejected by the majority of Parliament.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - It is very important that Member States start transferring the European Union's objectives more ambitiously and specifically to their own national policies, particularly in the area of unemployment and poverty, as well as in the field of education. The European Union must become competitive and can only achieve this objective by improving education systems, which will lead to the creation of new high-quality workers who will meet the demanding conditions of a modern labour market. The multiannual financial framework that has been adopted is unlikely to be sufficient to meet the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, particularly in the area of employment and social programmes and objectives.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I shall abstain because the report contains aspects which we fully support and others which are not at all. Reviving employment must be the priority we must tackle now, as a matter of urgency.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against the proposal on employment and social aspects of the EU 2020 strategy, because there are references to the continuation of "necessary reforms and structural changes" (memorandum policy).

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution on Employment and the Social Aspects of the Europe 2020 Strategy in view of the need to refocus European policies on achieving inclusive, sustainable and inclusive economic growth for the whole of European society. The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are still far from being achieved, so concrete and determined measures should be introduced to help narrow the existing gap. Policies aimed at reducing high rates of poverty, exclusion and social inequality need to be promoted in line with the Commission's job creation objectives, with a focus on reducing unemployment rates, especially among young people. EU funding needs to be increased to meet the 75% employment target included in the Europe 2020 Strategy. Achieving the EU's re-industrialization objectives, innovation, research and development are vital for Europe's competitiveness and for promoting growth and creating new quality jobs.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The EU has still not met the Europe 2020 targets for employment and poverty reduction, with unemployment rates of 24% in some regions and up to 51% among young people, and the problem becoming more serious. Since 2008, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased by 10 million and among the disabled the poverty rate has increased by up to 70%. Disparities between regions and Member States in employment levels continue to increase. We continue to see significant inequalities in the employment rules between men and women. There is a lack of effective means of stimulating investment, especially in SMEs, that drive economic growth. At the same time, we must bear in mind that investment growth alone will not guarantee better quality employment. Therefore, one of the most important objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy should be the sensible reindustrialisation of the EU, which is essential for Europe's global competitiveness. Financial and economic priorities should be balanced by social priorities. The world of education must be linked to the labour market. The unnecessary administrative burden on self-employed persons must also be eliminated. All this, however, plus the most important tool, which is funding, is not enough. A number of regulations need to be prepared not only to reduce the risk of investing in SMEs and innovation, but also to ensure a safe start and functioning in the market, without the threat of conflicts in cases of various types of infringements. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — Less than one month after European Safety Week, it is crucial that we have concrete legislative proposals regarding better health and safety for our citizens across the European Union.  Every single employee should have the same high level of protection, regardless of who their employer is.  If an employer cannot operate without risking the lives and health of their workers, they should not be in business.  As Unite the Union has made clear, it is only unscrupulous and incompetent employers who fear consistent and fair regulation of health and safety. We need increased and better health and safety legislation from the European Union, not just strategic frameworks.  UCATT, the Construction Union, North West Branch has been focusing on stress at work and I call upon the Commission to legislate on this area.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. - On Tuesday, I voted in favour of a resolution to promote better social conditions in Europe, as part of the Europe 2020 strategy. Inequality is widening in the distribution of wealth and income and disparities are growing between Member States, particularly in relation to youth employment.  The European Union must therefore take a more ambitious approach to combating unemployment and returning to work to ensure that every European citizen has a dignified life. For this to happen, the Union must give equal consideration to social and employment policies and macroeconomic policies in order to finally emerge from the crisis.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Member States, and mainly the Spanish State, have refused in the last three years to give an effective response to the social aspects of the crisis, as the Socialists have long claimed. The European Parliament again intends to record our disagreement with this policy. The number of citizens without employment or at risk of poverty and social exclusion has doubled, particularly affecting young people, women and over-45s. There are 120 million Europeans living in poverty or at risk of poverty and so far we have not seen a clear strategy to solve it.  What is the current Spanish Government doing to achieve the goals set for 2020 in education, innovation, employment, etc.? Otherwise to what the EU aspires to, and even by legislating counterproductively. I am voting in favour of the basic principles advocated by the Socialists to take the necessary steps towards Europe which we want to be soon, six years from now: a Europe without precarious contracts, without false self-employed persons, with quality employment, with a strengthened welfare state, and not dismantled as in the current situation.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. With an employment rate of 68.4% in 2013 (the target was 75%) and 122.6 million people at risk of poverty or social exclusion (the target was 96.4 million), it is the credibility of the Europe 2020 strategy that is at stake today, as we are so far from the count. That is why I have given my full support to this resolution to recall the need to fully integrate the social and employment objectives into the European semester, by strengthening social indicators and finally making them binding, as well as the economic and budgetary policy objectives within the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact.  It is no longer possible to have social policy coordination on the one hand and macroeconomic governance on the other, which do not meet the same rules of the game. On the other hand, I voted against the reference to "easing the labour market" because I believe that this is not the way we will help create quality jobs.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on employment and social aspects of the EU2020 strategy. I strongly support the expressed regrets that current EU policies focus solely on economic growth, which does not necessarily lead to sustainable society. I see an urgent need for Member States’ active role implementing EU2020 strategy goals, especially by helping to create quality jobs within the European economy.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — The EU is living in an unprecedented social emergency. Since 2010, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased by 10 million to more than 120 million people. There are also almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU28 and many of those who do have a job fail to make it to the end of the month.  That is why I voted in favour of establishing a minimum insertion income at European level: because I believe that the EU has a legal and moral obligation to ensure that Europeans have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs.  I also voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there must be a change in the policies of the European Semester to align them with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, putting macroeconomic priorities at the same level as employment and social priorities and ensuring that the employment created in Europe is of quality and with job guarantees. I believe that we must increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in order to return Europe to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - There is no doubt that, at the threshold of 2015, we are still extremely far from achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. The economic crisis, after which Europe is still regenerating, has increased unemployment, especially among young people, and worsened the economic situation of many citizens. I believe that if we want to find a solution to this situation and bring us closer to achieving our objectives, we must act in a multi-pronged way. Measures aimed at economic growth and new investment must go hand in hand with an in-depth analysis of labour markets and the necessary reforms. Science and business cooperation should be strengthened and the vocational training system consistently developed. Preparing graduates well for work is just as important as creating incentives for entrepreneurs.   We must not forget that the situation on the labour market varies greatly between Member States. They must therefore adapt the EU-wide objectives of the strategy to the specificities of their country. In addition, an effective system for monitoring progress, evaluation and recommendations should be put in place.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. - (C) We cannot support a resolution which very much calls for the policy that led Europe into the economic crisis that Europe is now coming out of. What Europe needs is not more political governance and increased public spending. The same policy has in recent years led France to weaken competitiveness, growing unemployment and increased deficits. There is no contradiction between jobs and growth, quite the contrary. In order to create the conditions for jobs and growth, the EU must continue ambitious structural reforms that facilitate entrepreneurship, stimulate research and development and make it profitable to work. Labour market policy is a Member State competence. The EU has an important role to play, not least through market reforms that facilitate freedom of movement under socially good conditions and contribute to trade and growth. Labour market policy should not be steered from Brussels. Nor can we support the calls for a larger EU budget. It is not EU subsidies that create the conditions for jobs and growth in the Member States, but increased investment in entrepreneurship and job creation.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - This resolution rightly notes that economic growth alone cannot bring true benefits to the whole of society. Social justice must also be at the heart of policy-making and Europeʼs citizens must be fully involved. At present Scotland must endure a Tory Westminster government for whom social justice is anathema. This state of affairs was fully supported by their friends in the Labour party during the recent referendum. It is essential that Scotland gains real powers in future UK constitutional reforms so that a Scottish Government can implement social and economic policies aimed at the people of Scotland.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — While it is true that the content of most of the points of the Resolution is clearly critical — in reflecting the gender perspective in employment material, to consider that social aspects must be as important as macroeconomics or that improving the economy will not necessarily lead to higher quality jobs, but that improving the quality of employment must come from policies that bet on it— , we have had to vote ABSTENTION, since other points in the Resolution underline things, in our view, intolerable. These measures only throw balls out, blaming young people for not having jobs, forcing workers into exile to find work and encouraging the precariousness of employment with more and more flexibility than, in countries like Spain, we know leads to further worsening of the labour market.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy, as I believe that this resolution would contribute to strengthening the Single Market of the European Union and improve economic development and social work, which can strengthen the European Union. Investments in SMEs should be launched as soon as possible to put an end to unemployment and poverty and to put the wind in the back for positive growth. The Europe 2020 strategy, based on the principle of subsidiarity, could become a major factor for the political future of the European Union, thus strengthening the complementarity between inequality and growth.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Marita Ulvskog's resolution on employment and social aspects as part of the Europe 2020 strategy. This text takes place in the context of the mid-term revision of this 10-year strategy aimed at reviving the European economy. It reiterates the importance of continuing to implement the 2020 strategy, with a more ambitious approach to tackling unemployment and returning to work, particularly among young people. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on employment and the social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy. This strategy launched in 2010 by the EU aims to revive the European economy through smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Through this strategy, the European Union has set five main targets to be achieved by 2020 in terms of employment, research, environment and energy, education, social inclusion and poverty reduction. The resolution calls on Member States to continue their efforts and to adopt, among other things, a more ambitious approach to combating unemployment and returning to work, particularly among young people.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. — Things are going from bad to worse, especially with regard to the social objectives proclaimed four years ago, and this has to do not only with the economic crisis, but also with something even more important: the absence of mechanisms for achieving the objectives. The scoreboard of the five social and labour indicators records the dramatic economic reality of the Union but there are no tools to deal with the problems. The supposed tool of the European Semester is proving insufficient to bring results, and things are even worse when even country specific recommendations do not exist. For example, the Commission's five indicators for Greece record 30% unemployment and 60% youth unemployment, the fastest declining average family income in the Union, while 20% of residents already below the poverty line risk adding a 34% who are threatened to fall below the threshold. At the same time, inequality is widening dramatically and the top 20% of the income pyramid in the country earns 6 times more than 20% of the lowest rate. What country specific recommendation was made for Greece by the Commission to deal with this situation? The countries in a memorandum are excluded from any version of European Economic Governance. In what ways will this exclusion be lifted by the Commission?

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The difficult situation on the labour market forces us to act hard. The situation is very severe, especially for young people, women and people living outside cities. We cannot just focus on creating economic growth. In addition to development, it is important to place emphasis on the quality of jobs and respect for workers' rights. It is social groups such as young graduates and women who are most at risk of discrimination and exploitation at work. We should provide them with a range of rights so that they can carry out their activities with dignity. For the development of the labour market and the implementation of the strategy, a flexible education system that responds efficiently to the needs of the economy is essential. A system that will mobilize to learn throughout life and continuously improve qualifications. At the same time, it is important that the youngest are included in a good education. Therefore, measures must be taken to prevent discrimination in this respect of children from poor families or living in peripheral areas or simply outside large cities, as they are exposed to poorer quality of education and therefore a more difficult start in adulthood.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the resolution as it calls for a rebalancing within the strategy of financial and economic priorities with strong social priorities to ensure social policies are enabled. It is important that employment and social considerations are put on a par with macroeconomic ones. It also focuses on the creation of quality employment, the shift from austerity to growth-inducing policies, and an increased focus on tackling child poverty.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. — (1) We believe that all people should have proper social security, especially the weakest in society. We believe that the European Union can usefully work to make all governments aware of the many positive aspects, including social convergence between Member States, which is promoting adequate social security for the most vulnerable members of society. However, we firmly believe that the Commission should neither propose nor set a minimum basis for social security, as this issue is best dealt with at national level. We do not want to help set a precedent for the Commission to legislate on the Danish welfare state, its benefits and rates. It must remain a purely national matter.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. - This resolution clearly identifies the order of priority over the serious economic and social conditions of the moment and at the same time acknowledges the serious delay in implementing the Europe 2020 Strategy. We must recover the essence of the Europe 2020 strategy, in order to increase social cohesion in Europe, at risk of disintegration. The tragedy is the exponential increase in poverty and therefore in inequalities in Europe. The first problem, the biggest, what generates the increase in poverty and inequality, is the rise in unemployment. If we do not want to fail the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, we must attack all the structural factors that are prolonging the crisis. In my opinion, the main road is, on the one hand, to reform the labour market in order to promote good employment – and the resolution rightly proposes to pool the most positive and fruitful experiences developed at national and regional levels. The other pillar is training, and the resolution gives impetus to the so-called dual school-work system, which is by far the most useful way of increasing people's employability. Finally, support for job creators, existing businesses that need to be encouraged and rewarded in their work support initiatives. All these aspects are well addressed in the resolution.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of the report proposed by Mr De Clercq. Marita Ulvskog because I am convinced that she can bring great benefits to the European Union by ensuring sustainable growth based on the defence of rights. In addition, Mrs Ulvskog's report pay particular attention to the situation of women and the protection of their fundamental rights, which are unfortunately not always guaranteed.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The FDP has voted in favour of the report because we support the comments on strengthening dual training. It is particularly important to promote dual training in the context of high youth unemployment, as long-term studies show that people with dual training are more successful on the labour market than people who have only learned their profession in a vocational school. At the same time, the report shows clear weaknesses in other areas. Social indicators should not become part of the country-specific recommendations or the European Semester, as there are no social and employment problems during the emergence of macroeconomic imbalances. It is only when a macroeconomic imbalance has become apparent that the real social and employment problems of the country concerned become apparent. The FDP also opposes an increase in the Youth Guarantee.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — It must be acknowledged that the EU has not achieved its Europe 2020 targets for employment and poverty reduction. The unemployment rate in some Member States has continued to rise and in 2014 the EU-28 average reached an alarming level of 10.1%, of which high youth unemployment is particularly worrying. Measures such as occupational mobility, the EURES programme in the Member States must be easily accessible to all, and a broad information campaign to reach even socially sensitive EU citizens. The introduction and application of new measures can be linked to a mid-strategy review, integrating and integrating the specific youth employment target, as can the public consultation, consultation with civil society on the proper and effective implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, and can draw attention to the main employment and social aspects.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - Until the first quarter of 2010 Europe does not renew its roadmap for economic growth with the current Europe 2020 Strategy. At the equator, practically, on the time horizon of this Strategy, the results seem rather poor and the challenges, on the other hand, far superior compared to the beginning of the journey, especially in terms of employability, but also in terms of well-being. In these years there has been a total shift in our economic policies towards austerity for no more reason than the "moral" of moral hazard, departing from the Keynesianism and interventionism that have brought so good results to the US and the UNITED Kingdom. Beyond the improvements and good intentions highlighted by the resolution for which we will vote in favour, it is necessary to call on the Commission and the Council to really provide a turning point in economic policies and the design of European economic governance, and to bet decisively on productive investment and quality job creation in order to grow back and be able to cope with our financial debts , but also to the social deficits that we have created in so few years.

All this is not included in the resolution, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I supported the report on employment and the social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy. Europe 2020 is a key plan for growth and greater economic efficiency. Its priority objectives include increased employment and greater social cohesion. Unfortunately, the assessment of the achievement of these objectives is not satisfactory. In the area of employment, we continue to face high unemployment, particularly among young people. Increasing social inequalities are an obstacle to achieving social cohesion. In this context, particular attention should be paid to the educational aspect as an instrument for bridging inequalities, increasing opportunities in the labour market and tackling social exclusion. I therefore hope that the new investment package will include education and training, as only through them can it contribute effectively to achieving the objectives of the strategy.  Another issue is to support entrepreneurship, especially SMEs. SMEs are the main source of employment in the EU, without their support it will not be possible to increase employment and thus achieve the strategy's target of an employment rate of 75%. In order to effectively implement the demands of the strategy, we must also constantly monitor and coordinate our actions more effectively. We need results, new jobs and a more confident future for Europeans, which is why I call on the Member States to engage in the europe 2020 objectives and to openly cooperate and financially support EU initiatives in this area.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Europe 2020 strategy has set specific employment, education and social targets that the EU must strive to achieve. It is encouraging to see that progress has been significant on some areas, such as tertiary educational attainment, which currently stands at 36.9% with a 40% target, or early leavers from education, which currently stands at 12.0% with a 10% goal. It is, however, alarming that in other areas progress has been slow or non-existent. The major economic and social problems of the EU, unemployment and poverty, do not appear to react sufficiently to the European Union's initiatives, and in some Member States they are even increasing. The 68.4% employment rate in 2013 and the 122.6 million people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in 2013 put us very far from the targets of 75% and 96.4 million, respectively. I strongly believe that we need renewed efforts in these areas and that, without more cooperation between the EU and the Member States and without sufficient spending, we may not reach the Europe 2020 goals. If we do not act now, we may be faced with worsening situations instead of the improvements that each EU citizen is looking forward to.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - Since the Europe 2020 strategy came into force in 2010, no significant progress has been observed in terms of reducing EU member states' unemployment, poverty levels, and a long-term sustainable development plan in general. On the contrary, the figures and statistics point to further rises in unemployment, the risk of poverty increases and income inequalities increase.  From all of the above, it can be concluded that it is insufficiently emphasised that the benefits of economic growth must be incorporated into the whole society, so that long-term results can actually be seen. I support this resolution because I believe that Member States should be more prepared to respond to labour market needs while ensuring connectivity with the education system.  I call on Member States to work to reduce red tape that unnecessarily burdens the entire Union system. Easier access to the labour market for all self-employed, micro-entrepreneurs, and all SMEs in general is important.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - That's one of the basic documents for the Social Democrats! Promoting employment is key now after a severe crisis. The €300 billion promised by Juncker's new Commission will do nothing if there is no employment promotion and a finely thought-out social policy at EU level. I voted in favour with my group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because the employment and social protection measures launched by this resolution are particularly important objectives in the current economic climate, a situation characterised by great inequalities in Europe and by social disintegration in Greece, where, as a result of the memorial measures, 3.9 million Greeks live below the poverty line (i.e. 35.7% compared to 27.6% in 2009).

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for this Report which stresses that job quality is important for bringing more people into employment and making it possible for them to work longer, and is therefore a crucial factor for reaching the employment target of the Europe 2020 strategy; considers, therefore, that employment indicators should focus not only on the number of people finding employment, but also on the quality of work, in order to provide a thorough picture of national labour markets

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. — We voted against this motion for a resolution which goes against our expectations: the aim of the Europe 2020 strategy is to strengthen coordination between national economic policies, while this motion for resolution calls for a European approach to the problems of employment and social affairs. We are against this motion.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - The resolution of the employment and social aspects of the EU 2020 strategy is a great opportunity to use the 960 billion budget provided for in the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. It also promotes concrete measures to facilitate regions in greatest difficulty in the development of investment programmes under the Europe 2020 strategy. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — This Europe 2020 programme sets out important objectives (employment of 75% of all 20-64 year olds; investment in research and development, which accounts for 3% of GDP generated in the EU Member States). However, I did not speak in favour of or against the resolution, as this programme, despite its merits, very restricts the economic autonomy of the sovereign Member States. The solution to growth, which at best stagnates and low employment, must be at its root and must not be imposed from above.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have decided to offer my support to the Ulvskog report, as I believe that the Europe 2020 Strategy can help to fuel sustainable and inclusive growth within the European Union.  In particular, I welcomed the reference made to the need to safeguard women's rights in the context of the implementation of the strategy.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - This resolution strongly criticises the Europe 2020 strategy and its employment performance.  The text thus blames the declines in public spending even though "the rise in unemployment led to an increased need for social protection. He also denounces "the numerous job destructions and wage cuts" that jeopardize "the European social model". It deplores the fact that current policies remain "focused exclusively on economic growth without taking into account the need for an inclusive, sustainable and rights-based approach" and the consequence calls for "a rebalancing within the strategy between financial and economic priorities and strong social priorities". The report even notes that the 'widening inequalities observed in the Union pose significant risks to democracy'. Nevertheless, the proposed solutions take up old, inefficient liberal rengains: the elimination of unnecessary administrative burdens and bureaucracy for the self-employed, micro-enterprises and SMEs, a reduction in labour taxation, improved labour mobility, etc. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Europe 2020 strategy underlines the principle that smart, sustainable and inclusive growth cannot be achieved unless all five major objectives are achieved.  More and better employment needs to be done. We have to find ways to encourage sustainable job creation. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - This resolution makes repeated references to rising youth unemployment and the need to address this crucial matter. The call for a specific integrated guideline on youth employment across the Member States is a point I believe is very much needed in the current climate. I have thus voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the face of the economic and financial crisis, we must ensure a balanced approach, where economic reforms, fiscal responsibility and solidarity converge. Despite the economic and financial obstacles, it is essential that we maintain the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, particularly in the areas of employment, poverty reduction and education. Reforms to ensure the sustainability of our systems are basic but must be offset by other measures to strengthen solidarity. I therefore welcome the desire to include more social criteria in the analysis of the economic situations of the member countries. We need to move beyond the automatism of certain decisions so that we can develop a real framework for smart, sustainable, inclusive and job-creating growth. The new investment plan will play a key role.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Work brings dignity. However, the European Union has been unable to put in place policies that are sufficiently dynamic and effective to revive economic activity. She even acted in the opposite direction. It has thus imposed on all Member States ultraliberal dogma and free and undistorted competition, which has led to deindustrialization, relocation and the explosion of unemployment in Europe. The austerity measures it wanted, meanwhile, have finished rolling down the purchasing power of our compatriots. The employment rate has not increased in Europe in ten years. In France, growth is now zero and will soon fall into deflation. All this to save a single currency that will have ruined the peoples of Europe. The European Union is, in fact, experiencing a structural failure of its policies. As far as SMEs, PMI and TPE are concerned, they are literally falling under ever heavier and more restrictive European standards and administrative regulations. By suffocating companies in this way, the European Union has contributed to the bankruptcy of many of them and thus to the resulting redundancies. Last point, the Union did not want to build a social Europe, preferring in reality to support the camp of the wildest capitalism. I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution. This text, which is a compromise reached between the various political groups in Parliament, raises the question of the consideration of social aspects and employment in European Union policy until 2020 (Europe 2020 strategy). This resolution rightly underlines that job creation requires the re-industrialisation of our continent and entrepreneurship, as part of a long-term strategy. This vision is in contrast to that of the current French government, which prefers to subsidize precarious jobs by widening the public deficit, without succeeding in reducing unemployment.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has today tabled a resolution to accompany two oral questions to the Commission and the Council on the employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy, which was voted on in plenary by a large majority, with the aim of rekindleding the debate on the social and employment dimension of European integration. The resolution highlights the need and importance of keeping the debate open on these important issues as the credibility of the EU2020 strategy is now at serious risk as most of its objectives have so far remained, partly due to the economic crisis, only on paper. We need only think of the fact that since 2010 people at risk of poverty have increased by around 7 million, rather than, as we would like, to fall by twenty million. It is therefore more necessary than ever for all Member States to commit themselves to integrating social and employment objectives into the European Semester by broadening social indicators and making them binding. I am particularly pleased that, for the first time, thanks to the mediation work of the Group of the European People's Party (S&D), a fundamental principle has passed, so that from now on considerations relating to employment and social aspects must be equated with macroeconomic considerations within the European Semester.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) With the adoption of this resolution, we believe it is essential to call on the Member States to take a more ambitious and concrete approach in translating the EU's objectives into their commitments at national level. We certainly take note of the work in progress on the theme 'Beyond growth', thanks to the efforts of the Italian Presidency, and we believe that this should contribute to the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. We call for a mandatory principle of comparative learning to be included in the Europe 2020 strategy in Member States' policies, especially with regard to the European labour market; this would allow the implementation of effective monitoring and registration of best practices with regard to models and methods in Europe. Finally, we recommend, in the context of a new investment programme to combat unemployment, that attention be focused on combating youth unemployment, which is now one of the most serious problems in the European Union. In this regard, we believe it is necessary to allocate new funds to the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs, in order to better support entrepreneurship and youth mobility as an effective means of combating youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text because I am convinced that the training of the population, and in particular that of the unemployed and young people, must be a fundamental part of our growth strategy. Our economies need people who are properly trained and focused on growth-leading industries and services.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Resolution on Social Issues and Jobs in the EU 2020 Strategy. It is a priority that the elements set out in the European strategy are implemented in order to ensure that its beneficial results are visible as soon as possible. There is a need for the European Union to act quickly to combat the social problems arising from the economic crisis. The resolution draws attention to the fact that social issues must become high on the European agenda.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — The Europe 2020 programme contains very important objectives, such as the employment of 75% of all citizens aged 20-64. An investment of at least 3% of EU GDP for research and development is also a move in the right direction. However, the Europe 2020 programme restricts The political autonomy of The Member States too far. It would be another step towards a central state controlled from Brussels. Growth and economic prosperity cannot simply be prescribed. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report deplores the fact that the EU's efforts focus mainly on economic growth and often little on rights, and calls for ambitious and binding measures for Member States to effectively combat unemployment and offer quality jobs, especially for young people and people in highly affected regions such as the RUP. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the Europe 2020 strategy on employment and social aspects, because in addition to achieving economic growth, the European Union also has to address other burning problems. Inequality and exclusion must be reduced. It is important that Member States take more account of the needs of the labour market, in particular by ensuring stronger links between the world of education and work. The investment plan proposed by the European Commission must be implemented effectively. Policy-making efforts must be targeted and results measurable.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. It should be noted that the Europe 2020 objectives have not yet been achieved and stronger measures must therefore be implemented to bridge the current gap. Social systems are key instruments for increasing economic and societal stability and poverty reduction. It is therefore essential that employment and social issues be considered equivalent to macroeconomic issues. In particular, in order to achieve the Europe 2020 poverty reduction target, the Commission should present as soon as possible a proposal for the establishment of a minimum level of social protection, with particular attention to minimum income schemes. This would improve living standards and further boost competitiveness, help to ensure greater economic, social and territorial cohesion and help mitigate the social consequences of the crisis and protect fundamental human rights. It is an emergency stabilisation mechanism that guarantees a balance between economic and social objectives and reduces social exclusion among the population of the Community. As unemployment rates continue to rise in some Member States, and disparities between Member States are increasing, Member States need help in carrying out the necessary structural reforms, increasing labour market flexibility and removing administrative and bureaucratic barriers. In addition, a special role must be played in the multiannual financial framework, which currently provides for underfunding in order to achieve the employment and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - Considering that in 2005 the European Union concluded an agreement with Canada on the processing of passenger name record (PNR) data, given that, with the expiry of the relevant Commission decision in September 2009, the European legal basis for the transmission of PNR data to the CBSA failed, given that the CBSA continued to provide the above data, considering that it was not necessary to sign a further agreement and considering that, following the entry into force of the The european Parliament must give its approval before they are adopted by the Council for the conclusion of new PNR agreements, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — Once again, a resolution proposes to combat the effects of the European Union's economic policy by strengthening its causes. No, destroying national laws under the pretext of harmonising them to make "more Europe" will not solve the crisis, restore growth and fight unemployment. The facts show us every day. I therefore speak out against this resolution.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - The increase in unemployment, especially among people from at-risk social groups, and the increase in the number of people at the border, or even below the poverty line, is alarming. It is clear that the social impact of economic measures has not been sufficiently reflected, GDP is not an all-powerful indicator, and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy have moved away in the area of social and employment instead of getting closer. The European Parliament resolution offers a comprehensive overview of the proposals for measures that can lead to the correction of the situation. As a member of the ITRE Committee, I particularly support the points concerning the promotion of reindustrialisation and the interconnection of the world of education and work. Only strong social priorities can lead to strong social policies, and in this respect there is a need to work better with the European Social Fund and with other cohesion policy funds.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission has started the process of reviewing the Europe 2020 strategy, with the aim of presenting the new proposals in a few months' time. It is clear that, following the global economic crisis, the main objectives of the strategy formulated in 2010 (employment, education, social inclusion, innovation and climate/energy) must, in my opinion, be completely reformulated. That is why I find, and I voted in favour of the motion, that the overall analysis of the new strategy lacks at various points greater attention to the current problems that are evident to everyone. At the moment there is a very worrying employment situation in Europe, with social groups in serious difficulty and groups most affected. That is why the strategy must be stronger in addressing the social problems of poverty reduction and increased employment, with a more sectoral and sustainable approach, with a more oriented use of the Structural Funds and more policies for young people, avoiding focusing solely on macroeconomic growth.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — The design of this strategy shows how little understanding has been given to the causes of the current crisis. What the countries in need need first and foremost are reforms. Many European states, both north and south, still do not understand what promotes employment. We could already do much better today if lean and reliable legislation finally became the hallmark of Europe! Unfortunately, the report does not provide sufficient evidence for this.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — I am voting in favour of this resolution, which is part of the revision of the objectives of the Europe 2020 policy, which should be encouraged to be achieved. Only the perseverance and the guarantee of joint action by the European institutions and its Member States will overcome the challenges of the European Union. However, in the context of the revision of the strategy, it is clear that the inclusion of the fight against youth unemployment and support for training are part of this perspective.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — High levels of unemployment in the EU (24.6 million people, representing 10.1 % of the general population; 23.3 % for youth unemployment) and the number of people at risk of poverty (more than 122.6 million) seriously put the European social model at risk, further demonstrating that the EU is far from achieving the europe 2020's major employment and poverty reduction targets. Effective measures should therefore be taken to promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and create jobs, in particular in the context of public investments in innovation, research and development and professional qualifications and skills, as well as in meeting the EU's reindustrialisation targets, encouraging entrepreneurship and eliminating administrative burdens. In this regard, it is also important to highlight the importance of the investment programme to combat unemployment recently announced by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.  Therefore, because I believe that the proposals put forward in this resolution are appropriate for the pursuit of the social and employment objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU is living in an unprecedented social emergency. Since 2010, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased by 10 million to more than 120 million people. There are also almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU28 and many of those who do have a job fail to make it to the end of the month.  That is why I voted in favour of establishing a minimum insertion income at European level: because I believe that the EU has a legal and moral obligation to ensure that Europeans have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs.  I also voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there must be a change in the policies of the European Semester to align them with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, putting macroeconomic priorities at the same level as employment and social priorities and ensuring that the employment created in Europe is of quality and with job guarantees. I believe that we must increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in order to return Europe to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. - The Europe 2020 strategy has two social objectives: to ensure employment for 75% of the working population in the EU and to ensure that the number of people affected or threatened by poverty and social exclusion is reduced by 20 million units by 2020. But given the current bleak socio-economic record (rising poverty, rising inequality, record unemployment), these two goals will not be achieved. So it is the credibility of the strategy that is at stake here. And the European Parliament had to discuss new avenues.  That is why I voted and supported a rebalancing of the strategy between financial and economic priorities and strong social priorities in order to promote social measures. That is why I have also called for joint meetings between the EPSCO and ECOFIN councils and voted in favour of the establishment of a social protection base which provides for an adequate minimum income system at European level in order to strengthen the social convergence of member states. Finally, I voted to make social targets binding, as well as economic and fiscal policy objectives under the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour because I fully agree that current policies remain focused solely on economic growth, regardless of whether this growth benefits all sections of society. The economic crisis, the constant aspirations of certain groups to profit at the expense of ordinary people, has led us to the fact that more than 6 million people live in poverty. It is clear that poverty has included not only those who are unemployed, but also part of the workforce. The huge workload, the requirement to work after-hours free of charge, and the exceptionally low wages are just a few aspects that a significant proportion of workers experience every day. I fully support the idea in the document of the need to remove the tax burden from the workers and to apply other forms of sustainable taxation in order to promote growth and jobs. At the same time, we must review the system for setting poverty indicators and constantly monitor how the poverty rate is changing in order to identify and help those at risk of exclusion.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. " I supported this resolution, which is part of the general context of the revision, halfway through the Europe2020 strategy. The strategy was launched in 2010 and outlined five priority objectives: employment, education, poverty reduction, climate change and research and development.  I supported this resolution in order to underline the importance of continuing the implementation of this strategy, but insisted on a more ambitious approach to combating unemployment and returning to work, particularly among young people.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — While it is true that the content of most of the points of the Resolution is clearly critical — in reflecting the gender perspective in employment material, to consider that social aspects must be as important as macroeconomics or that improving the economy will not necessarily lead to higher quality jobs, but that improving the quality of employment must come from policies that bet on it— , we have had to vote ABSTENTION, since other points in the Resolution underline things, in our view, intolerable. They stress that the problem of youth unemployment is because young people are not sufficiently trained, have no leadership capacity, or do not undertake; that worker mobility needs to be encouraged and the labour market further loosened. These measures only throw balls out, blaming young people for not having jobs, forcing workers into exile to find work and encouraging the precariousness of employment with more and more flexibility than, in countries like Spain, we know leads to further worsening of the labour market.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are subordinate to the macroeconomic objectives of the European Semester, which are contradictory to the former. In order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, it would be necessary to put an end to austerity policies, which are putting pressure on wages and employment, and new binding, figure-backed initiatives should be put in place to create jobs and protect and promote training, research and innovation, education, poverty reduction and the fight against climate change.  We call for the challenge of the Europe 2020 Strategy and replaced by a pact of progress and social justice that strengthens and leverages budgetary resources in order to increase production in deficit countries, support SMEs, combat unemployment and precariousness, create jobs with rights and ensure the protection and improvement of public services. All this is not included in the resolution, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. - Four years after the launch of the Europe 2020 strategy, we are far from achieving the employment and social objectives we set ourselves. There is talk of an average unemployment rate of more than 10% across the European Union in 2014 and a risk of poverty or social exclusion for one in four European citizens.  The answer to these alarming figures cannot be found in the imposition of new binding targets for employment and poverty reduction, nor in the possible introduction of additional social indicators.   It is time for the European dialogue to take on a more concrete dimension, focusing on the analysis of effective solutions to create new jobs and thus relaunch europe's economic and social growth.  I hope that the resolution adopted today will move in this direction, stimulating the development of a more constructive strategy, based on the exchange of best practices between Member States, innovation and targeted economic interventions that guarantee, for example, better access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, greater stability in the financial sector and the promotion of new public and private partnerships.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favour of Parliamentʼs resolution on employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 Strategy.  Currently the EU is far from having achieved the employment and poverty reduction headline targets of the Europe 2020 Strategy. The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased by 10 million since 2008 to over 122.6 million, with one in four citizens affected.  In addition, since the implementation of the Europe 2020 Strategy, unemployment levels have continued to rise in some Member States and the unemployment rate for the EU-28 has reached the alarming level of 10.1 % in 2014. It is understood that an increase in economic growth does not, in itself, guarantee decent jobs, a reduction in poverty or a reduction in social inequality. This requires appropriate policy choices for meeting such goals, specifically the Europe 2020 targets.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on employment and social aspects of the 2020 strategy, because I consider it essential that employment in the EU should already take on growth curves. The resolution clearly states all the causes of high unemployment, especially for young people. The biggest cause is the lack of conformity of the education system with the working environment and with the requirements of the labour market. Individual Member States must therefore restructure their teaching and study fields very quickly and also support, through the social fund, those sectors where young people can also be realistically applied to the labour market after leaving education. Action needs to be taken very quickly and effectively, because we are already in the fourth year of implementation of the 2020 strategy, and an additional 16 million citizens need to be employed to meet the measurable target of achieving the 75% employment rate.
