The work programme of the new Commission, led by Mr Juncker, makes it a prerequisite for meeting the employment target of the 2020 strategy, but the Commission will need to appeal more to the Member States to also incorporate this strategic objective into their national programmes.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — Since 2010, the number of unemployed persons who are at risk of poverty or at risk of social exclusion has been steadily increasing. The situation on the labour market is particularly critical for young people, regardless of level of education, as they often find themselves in precarious employment relationships and unpaid internships. Targeted social investment should play a major role in resolving the crisis in the Member States. These are crucial for achieving the europe 2020 objectives in the field of employment and education and social. Member States should focus on sectors that are growing and creating new jobs, such as the green sector. The most deprived must be given access to jobs and adequate social security. Effective monitoring of good practices, models and methods in Europe is needed. Member States need to take a more ambitious and concrete approach in implementing the European Union's objectives in their national. This is particularly the case for employment, poverty reduction and education. In addition, cooperation with the social partners, which can coordinate the interests of employees and employees, is very welcome. As unemployment is also a very pressing topic in Slovenia, I supported the resolution and I hope that the Member States and the other institutions or organisations involved will take it into account with a view to improving the situation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. — Social aspects are becoming increasingly important in the European Union. Ensuring inclusive growth with a high level of employment and reducing the number of people living in poverty or at risk of social exclusion should be a top priority for the Europe 2020 strategy. It is also crucial to support the young generation at the beginning of their professional careers and therefore to combat youth unemployment, as the youth unemployment rate is up to twice as high as for adults (22% vs. 10.2%).

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the employment and social dimension report on European integration, which is a key element of the Europe 2020 strategy. Since 2010, the number of unemployed citizens or those living at risk of poverty and social exclusion has risen to 120 million in the EU, with an increasing number of people living in poverty or at risk of poverty.  The Europe 2020 Strategy sets a target that plans to raise the employment rate of women and men aged 20-64 to 75 through greater participation of young people, older workers and low-skilled labour, and better integration of migrants. EU Member States differ from each other, so the unemployment rate varies between Member States, which can lead to increased social inequalities.  We also have negative experiences with poverty risk and high unemployment rates in Croatia.  According to Eurostat studies, Croatia is among the countries with the highest unemployment rate, but also among the member states with the most poor in the EU and the highest poverty risk rate, and this is influenced by the education rate. Employment and education should be encouraged due to the progress of society, the state and the European Union, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — Abstained on Paragraph 46 (Part 1) as I supported the final MMF deal and believe it was a balanced compromise.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Commission proposal "Strategy Europe 2020"  which would launch a strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, contains the issues we still face in the European Union, namely unemployment and youth unemployment. Unfortunately, there is still a crisis of unemployment, especially for young people, and I personally believe that this should be one of the priorities that must be actively and thoroughly worked on to help young people in Croatia and the European Union in terms of unemployment.  The 51% figure for the average unemployment rate is a sign that this issue really needs to be worked on, so that the objectives of the 2020 Strategy are achievable. Also according to the report, women's employment has increased over the past few years, but these same women work part-time rather than full-time, and we need to work on this issue as well, as figures show that 32.9% of women work part-time compared to 8.4% of men working part-time. Furthermore, the 2020 Strategy must implement a decisive policy to support growth, combat poverty, and respect fundamental rights such as respecting and promoting the principles of gender equality and non-discrimination.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — There are clear references to the continuation of the "necessary reforms and structural changes" (memorandum policy).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this motion because, in my opinion, the member states' employment and poverty reporting is not perfect. Unfortunately, this will remain the case until there is a single, mandatory and effective reporting system. In some countries, e.g. Hungary, 4-6 hours of part-time work, public workers working for EUR 160 per month or nationals working abroad are also considered to be full-time employees. With such tricks, we will only achieve the Europe 2020 target in statistics. The resolution addresses, inter alia, the civil control that I consider important (asking the Commission to involve these organisations throughout the consultation process), eradicating child poverty, alleviating youth unemployment and adopting an environmentally friendly approach.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - I draw your attention to the fact that this important allocation of powers for the transmission of confidential information to several authorities must be balanced by the obligation of the receiving authorities to take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of the confidential statistical information concerned. A similar obligation was introduced in 2009 in the basic act for SEBC members receiving confidential statistical information from the authorities of the European statistical system.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Austerity policies are a failure that is generating more misery, poverty and inequalities in Europe.   With the Europe 2020 Strategy, European leaders pledged to reduce poverty by 20 million people between 2010 and 2020. However, poverty, rather than declining, has risen from 118 million people in 2010 to 123 million in 2013. This is totally inadmissible and States must implement policies to create jobs, growth and competitiveness, but with an inclusive, sustainable and respectful approach to people's rights.    On the other hand, the unemployment rate among young Europeans is alarming and concrete measures should be sought to tackle this problem directly. To begin with, the Youth Employment Initiative budget should be increased. It is also necessary to incorporate a gender-specific pillar into the Europe 2020 Strategy that will help to reduce the gender gap still in Europe.  It is urgent to avoid the collapse of the European social model and the destruction of the welfare state, already at risk in many European countries.  That is why I voted in favour of the Resolution on Employment and the Social Aspects of the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Writing. The FDP has voted in favour of the report because we support the comments on strengthening dual training. It is particularly important to promote dual training in the context of high youth unemployment, as long-term studies show that people with dual training are more successful on the labour market than people who have only learned their profession in a vocational school. At the same time, the report shows clear weaknesses in other areas. Social indicators should not become part of the country-specific recommendations or the European Semester, as there are no social and employment problems during the emergence of macroeconomic imbalances. It is only when a macroeconomic imbalance has become apparent that the real social and employment problems of the country concerned become apparent. The FDP also opposes an increase in the Youth Guarantee.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I agree with the notion that achieving the goals of employment and poverty reduction must indeed be a priority for us, but I do not believe that we will come to this by increasing the regulatory burden that is suffocating small and medium-sized enterprises that are the carrier of economic growth and whose stability and good business are the main impulse for employment.  A good part of colleagues advocate higher social benefits to combat poverty, while demanding a rejection of fiscal consolidation. The Croatian example proves that without fiscal consolidation and tax relief for companies, any effect is absent, because the closure of private companies leads to a budget deficit that would only deepen unrealistically high social benefits. So I voted no.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. I oppose this report because the aim of the Europe 2020 strategy is to integrate the different national economic policies and to centralise their control. The strategy's slogan is more Europe in social and labour matters. Of course, it takes less.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Europe 2020 strategy risks remaining only a document full of good intentions and objectives, in the absence of clear and decisive measures first at European level and then, equally and even more importantly, at the level of the 28 Member States. Less than six years away from the 2020 deadline, the employment figures situation in Europe is far from what the EU has set out to do. At this rate, the gaps between the more developed EU countries and the poorest ones, such as Romania, are at risk of getting worse. I would particularly draw attention to how the Member States have agreed to achieve their Objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The lack of prompt action, concrete measures to stimulate economic, investment encouragement and reduce and combat unemployment can have serious consequences, leading to a sharp increase in inequality within the Union. I am convinced that, in the near future, Member States will make every effort and take a much more ambitious and concrete approach in translating the objectives of the 2020 Strategy into national objectives.

name: Elena Valenciano Martínez-Orozco (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU is living in an unprecedented social emergency. Since 2010, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased by 10 million to more than 120 million people. There are also almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU28 and many of those who do have a job fail to make it to the end of the month.  That is why I voted in favour of establishing a minimum insertion income at European level: because I believe that the EU has a legal and moral obligation to ensure that Europeans have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs.  I also voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there must be a change in the policies of the European Semester to align them with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, putting macroeconomic priorities at the same level as employment and social priorities and ensuring that the employment created in Europe is of quality and with job guarantees. I believe that we must increase investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion in order to return Europe to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are subordinate to the macroeconomic objectives of the European Semester, which are contradictory to the former. In order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, it would be necessary to put an end to austerity policies, which are putting pressure on wages and employment, and new binding, figure-backed initiatives should be put in place to create jobs and protect and promote training, research and innovation, education, poverty reduction and the fight against climate change.  We call for the challenge of the Europe 2020 Strategy and replaced by a pact of progress and social justice that strengthens and leverages budgetary resources in order to increase production in deficit countries, support SMEs, combat unemployment and precariousness, create jobs with rights and ensure the protection and improvement of public services. All this is not included in the resolution, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of ‘Employment and social aspects of the EU2020 strategy’ because in order to achieve the objectives of EU2020, stronger measures need to be initiated to effectively combat the growing unemployment levels and other concerning social issues in many Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I'm going to talk about health and safety at work. The European Commission has set out an objective, at least questionable, and I quote: Preventing workers from being victims of serious accidents or occupational diseases and promoting the health of workers throughout their working lives is essential for them to work until later. Beautiful words, but so empty of action and commitment. The right to safety, hygiene and health in the performance of professional activity is a social right of workers, conquered by decades of struggles, which imposes respect for the right to physical integrity, the prevention of accidents, occupational diseases, occupational-related diseases and health promotion in the workplace.  There are several health and safety problems at work in Portugal that result, in large part, from the lack of supervision of the laws that are already enshrined, which means complacency with the employer. There is no inspection because state services, which must monitor business infringements in this area, are simply being dismantled in the name of meeting the deficit target. This is the reality that makes the reality so distant and hypocritical, resulting from EU guidelines, and a speech supposedly concerned with workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — The Europe 2020 programme must be subject to double standards. On the one hand, it contains important and noble objectives, mainly relating to employment policy, and also investments of 3% of the EU's research and development GDP are to be guaranteed by this programme. On the other hand, it is increasingly restricting the economic autonomy of the Member States and is basically prescribed by the upper echelons. That is why I abstained.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. — The free movement of citizens within the European Union is one of the EU's most important fundamental rights, and there is also strong public support for it. The possibility of moving across borders in search of work is an opportunity that we should make much greater use of in the European Union. At the same time as we are suffering from high unemployment, there are two million job vacancies in the EU. In addition, a large number of companies report problems finding skills that meet their needs. We should therefore encourage people to seek work boldly across Europe. In the USA, for example, the annual mobility of citizens is ten times higher than in the EU, and it also makes economic growth in the USA strong. The free movement of labour increases everyone's own employment opportunities, helps companies to find labour that meets their needs, then strengthens economic growth throughout Europe.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. - This resolution calls for the Europe 2020 Strategy to be rebalanced and to include social, as well as economic, priorities. It expresses disappointment in the economic focus of the strategy, and calls for policies to aim for economic growth with sustainable benefits that are spread throughout society. The resolution also has an emphasis on youth unemployment, as the resolution praises the youth unemployment initiatives of some Member States. Labour MEPs supported this resolution because we feel strongly that economic recovery must benefit the many, not the few, and that rising inequality is a threat to long-term economic growth. Labour MEPs also support measures to reduce youth unemployment, which is unacceptably high in the EU.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — On Tuesday 25 November, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on employment and the social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy. The Europe 2020 strategy is an EU initiative for sustainable, sustainable and inclusive growth. The resolution prepared by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs aims to help achieve the overarching objectives of the EU 2020 strategy. A number of objectives of the strategy, to be achieved by 2020 includes: an increase in the employment rate among citizens aged 20-64, at least 75%, a 10% reduction in the share of early school leave rs, an increase in the share of people aged 30-34 with tertiary education, a 25% reduction in the number of people living below the poverty line and an increase in R20-34 investment expenditure at 3% of GDP. It is in poland's interest to achieve the objectives and objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy. The Commission resolution calls for specific tasks to be taken to help Member States achieve the EU 2020 targets. The content of the resolution is well balanced, and I voted in favour of it.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — It is hypocritical that the European Parliament is now very concerned that the Annual Growth Analyses and country-specific recommendations adopted so far as part of the annual cycles of the European Semester have not been aligned with the social and employment objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.  How could that happen? If it is neoliberal policies that have been implemented as the matrix of the EU 2020 Strategy, through the National Reform Plans, economic governance and the European semester, which contribute to the worsening social and economic crisis, making the lives of workers and their families increasingly difficult, imposing a model of low wages and widespread precariousness , increasing unemployment and poverty, destroying essential public services. We call for the repeal of the EU 2020 strategy and its replacement by a strategy of progress and social justice by strengthening and mobilising budgetary resources with a view to increasing production in countries in deficit countries, we advocate support for SMEs, combating unemployment and precariousness, creating jobs with rights, safeguarding and valuing public services.  We regret that the amendments we have tabled to that effect have been rejected by the majority of Parliament.

name: Presidente. -
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Elnök asszony -
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to inform you that our meeting continues. First, allow me to make findings on the minutes of yesterday's meeting. The minutes of the meeting have been allocated. I ask my fellow Members if anyone has any comments on the minutes. I see you don't, so I declare that the protocol will be accepted. We will then move on to our next item on the agenda, which is item 1 in the afternoon session: "Budget 2015: Outcome of the Conciliation Committee" is the title of the debate. As my fellow Members know very well, we are after fruitless negotiations. The European Parliament and the Council were unable to reach an agreement, standing up from the negotiating table without agreement, either on the additional resources for 2014 or on the necessary and sufficient items for 2015. First, I give the floor to the chairman of the committee, and I have three minutes at the president's disposal.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: President BUDG. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you said, Madam President, the conciliation committee has not been able to succeed. So it's a big disappointment but it's also a real hope.  It is a great disappointment because the conclusion was a finding of failure and because it was not until Monday 17 November, the last day of conciliation, that the Council's proposal was obtained at 1 p.m. For almost 21 days, our conciliation was hemiplegic, only one of the two branches of the budgetary authority worked. It is also a disappointment because the ministers were very absent during all these discussions. Mr Zanetti has done everything he could, and I want to praise his efforts, but the other people present did not really have a mandate, who were, no doubt, busy to deal with the problems of amending the regulation with regard to Member States' participation in the European Union budget. Finally, it is also a disappointment because the proposal that came to us at 1 p.m. on Monday, November 17 was unacceptable.  So I also said that this committee finally gave us real hope. It gives the Council hope that Europe cannot remain in such a situation that unpaid debts are piling up on the Commission's desk: 5 billion in 2010, probably 30 billion at the end of 2014. However, when there are unforeseen revenues - and this is what happened in 2014, almost 5 billion unanticipated revenues - they must be used to pay the oldest bills. We are hopeful that, in the coming days, we will be able to share this principle with the Council because allowing unpaid invoices to accumulate on the Commission's desk is to damage the credit of the European Union, which thus creates counterfeit money.  There are resources, the question is simple: should these unforeseen resources of five billion go into the accounts of the Member States or should they be used as a priority to pay unpaid bills? We told you what our belief was. I hope that in the coming days we will find the right answer through trilogues and new conciliation meetings in close contact with the Commission and the Council. It is a question of the credibility of the European Union, which must pay its debts.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, after what the chairman of our committee has said, I could be more synthetic, but I would like to say to the representative of the Council, Mr Zanetti, that despite all his efforts, I am, both as a member of Parliament and as rapporteur, disappointed and frankly dissatisfied. Firstly, I am disappointed because my conviction is established - and it is not only mine but that of many parliamentarians - that the Council has spent much more time trying to resolve problems among its members, as a result of the 'rant' - forgive me the expression - which mr Cameron has given, with regard to the rebalancing of the contributions of the various Member States. , to try to agree on a common position on the 2014 and 2015 amending budgets. I am well aware that for some States it is difficult to get out of the car a large sum, but we cannot understand, and we are deeply disappointed, that the Council has taken so long to deal with its own problems rather than the European Union budget for 2014 and 2015. I am also disappointed and dissatisfied, Mr President, to have heard - I think you said it - that, in the sort of match between Parliament and the Council, when someone gets satisfaction on something, the other side must also get satisfaction on something else. We're not playing a game. There is no match between Parliament and the Council! We have an obligation to agree on the best amending budgets for 2014 and the quality of the 2015 budget. Therefore, I want to make it very clear what we need to do. Firstly, we support the 2014 amending budgets proposed by the Commission because we believe that this is an essential step to ensure the credibility of the 2015 budget which, without it, will otherwise start totally burdened by previous debts. Mr President, we want a 2015 budget that is realistic. You have reduced the commitment appropriations, you have further reduced the payment appropriations by $2 billion, whereas this budget has the lowest payment appropriations we have seen in recent years. We have also told you, and we confirm this, that we want Parliament and the Council to agree on a procedure, mechanism or plan to phase out unpaid debts in order to avoid the asphyxiation of the Commission's budget in the future, either by strangling commitments or by the fact that delays in payments will become unbearable. Therefore, Mr President, we confirm our willingness to put ourselves around the table but, with grace, in a different spirit and with a different will than those who have ruled the Council so far.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Mr Zanetti, the truth is that I have been thinking for several days what I am going to say here today. I have been reviewing all the meetings we have had with the Council, with the Italian Presidency, with the Commission... and compiling all the arguments we have put on the table to defend the European Parliament's proposal. Because I think it's a proposal that's very easy to understand: we have to pay what we owe. The European Union cannot have debts. The European Union cannot be delinquent to its citizens, its organisations, its municipalities, or its students. And, in order to defend this proposal, which is so easy, we have given them legal arguments, because Article 310 TFEU says that the European Union budget has to be balanced. We have given them economic reasons, because it is not understandable that we ask our states to pay their debts and we increase ours. We have given them grounds for justice, because it is unacceptable that we should have more than EUR 25 billion in cohesion funds to the countries that are having the worst time and who need it most. Reasons for solidarity, and Commissioner Georgieva knows this very well: we cannot accept that our NGOs in the field of humanitarian aid do not have the money to carry out their programmes. And even reasons for opportunity, because we have an extra 5 billion euros of income, which can help alleviate the situation. But it's clear that all these motives haven't worked. Thomas Paine once said that 'time produces more converts than reason', and I think it is a perfect description of what has happened at the European Council. Because over time they are advancing in positions, over time they understand that we have a problem of defaults, and over time they understand that the multiannual financial framework, even partially, has parts of flexibility. We had twenty-one days to reach an agreement and it was not possible; so we give them extra time to see if we have any more converts within the Council. He said earlier that, in preparing this intervention, he collected all the arguments, but he also tried to think if I could come up with any new ideas, some magic phrase, some key word that manages to get the Council out of that hypnosis that doesn't seem to let them see what the reality is. And the magic word was said to me today by Mr Renzi at a meeting we had: politics. That is what we need, because it is politics that will allow us to get out of this rigidity that we have in the Council today. Because it is politics that will allow us to move forward with agreements and get out of this blocking situation. The European Parliament is prepared to put all policies and proposals on the table, but we need receptiveness from the Council. And, if the Council wants to make proposals to solve the problem of defaults, we will accept them, because all we want is to be able to pay people, be able to pay for the projects and move the European project forward.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has I am far from happy that the Member States have not been able to reach a compromise. The image we are giving to the outside world is actually relatively confused, even in a difficult time of crisis. At a time of crisis, we are expected to boldly focus on what has been on everyone's agenda for months – I would almost have said in Sunday speeches – and that is called growth, that is called jobs, it is called social stabilisation, it is called innovation, that is called research and so on and so forth. In this context, it is, of course, particularly incomprehensible to expect five billion in fines or other payments to be returned in the European Union, to have old invoices of 6.3 billion and for the Commission to make a proposal of 4.7 billion that one would have liked to have paid. Now we enter the typical technocratic debate, which is not understood by any public. What is in contingency, what is outside the ceilings, what is inside the ceilings? It takes me an hour to explain to anyone what we are debating here technocratically. There is simply no one outside who understands that we have open invoices, that we have money in our accounts, but that we are unable to pay the bills because the Member States would like to have it returned to their budgets, but do not want to pay the old invoices. I say this so aggressively here: the old bills should be as little discussed as possible. They must be paid. We once had the consensus here that old bills should be paid and not a debt to take into the next year. That was actually a fundamental principle of this European Union, which we are currently breaking with. The second is that if we transfer too much of old bills to the budget, we will put Commissioner Georgieva in an almost impossible state. The new programmes will be launched, including important programmes. I am now deliberately mentioning one that the whole of the European Parliament has been hanging on to and which has got off to a brilliant start and is fulfilling exactly the purpose that we have set ourselves: namely, the new Horizon 2020 programme, which has been designed to support innovation and research for small and medium-sized enterprises. Which companies are the most involved? They are Italian and Spanish small and medium-sized enterprises, small and medium-sized enterprises from countries that are not doing so well economically at the moment. Now that 95% of these companies are rejected or even unable to apply for the programme, we are frustrated by those who really use all their skills to be there for science and research. In this context, I therefore ask that old invoices be paid and that the new programmes should not be deleted too much, because otherwise we will no longer be able to fulfil what is necessary in the essential areas.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Georgieva, I too, of course, open my speech by expressing regret that it has not been possible to reach agreement on the budget between our institutions within 21 days of the conciliation period.  There is no doubt that a number of elements, some of a more technical nature and others of a political nature, have undoubtedly contributed to the failure of the negotiations. Conciliation was not a vain exercise, however: important progress has been made on the most controversial issues in relation to the starting positions, and I am thinking in particular of the use of the contingency margin on amending budget No 3. In this regard, the Council accepted the use for 2014 of this budgetary flexibility instrument precisely to address the exceptional situation of unpaid invoices and other previous commitments pending liquidation. I believe that this is objectively a good thing, the result of a debate that is not taken for granted and which should not be underestimated, all the more so given the Council's initial position of clear closure on this point. It is clear that the agreement on the level of use of the contingency margin has not been reached, but work can be done on this during the negotiations that will open immediately after the presentation by the European Commission of the new 2015 budget proposal.  Further progress has been made by the Council on the position on the 2015 budget compared with the position adopted last September with the availability of a reduction in cuts in payment appropriations compared to the budget proposal presented by the European Commission. This progress, too, was not considered adequate with a view to an agreement, and even the Commission's subsequent compromise proposal, formulated at the final stage of conciliation, failed to bring positions closer together while containing elements in this direction. It is clear, however, that at this point we must start from the positive elements of the negotiations carried out so far and find the basis for reaching an overall agreement in the coming days. We must therefore first await the Commission's new budget proposal, which will have to take account of the discussions held with the Council and the European Parliament. We hope that this proposal will provide an optimal starting point for the timely establishment of a common position enabling the 2015 budget to be adopted by next December. The Italian Presidency will clearly work in this direction, as it has worked in recent months, hoping for and urging the active contribution of all the institutions involved. I believe that it is a common objective for all of us to ensure that Europe and its citizens have an adequate budget, functional to achieving the Union's priorities and at the same time functional to ensure the credibility of all its institutions.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, my apologies to Mr Arthuis for running in while he was speaking. We were with President Schulz and it took us a while to reach the Chamber. I am here reflecting on what we heard earlier today from Pope Francis. He spoke to us about the risk that we get so caught up in technicalities – in our case it would be margins and ceilings and payment credits and commitments – that we lose sight of why we are here and what we have to do. What we have to do is bring resources to help our people, our small businesses, our municipalities, our farmers, our teachers, the elderly that rely on social programmes that we fund, and this is what it is so important for us to keep focused on. Like Parliament, like the Council, we regret very much that agreement was not reached in conciliation on Monday night and that we started negotiations in earnest late and could not complete them, but we are working very hard to make it possible for us to facilitate, in our position of honest broker, the next stage of trialogue so that the Council and Parliament can agree on amending budgets for 2014 that would write off income from fines already collected to shrink the Union’s unpaid bills, so that we are able to agree on a sound budget for 2015 that can underpin investments in competitiveness, growth and jobs and would underpin a strong Europe in the world, and so that we can agree on the next steps in the coming months – that the Commission would come up with a payment plan that shows how we can further shrink the bills that we are not supposed to have. We are not supposed to have unpaid bills in the Union, and of course we count very much on the Member States as well because, to come with a credible payment plan, we have to work with our Member States as well as with Parliament. I will finish with three points. My commitment here is that first we will put forward on Friday for approval in the Commission a revised draft budget for 2015 as required by the Treaty. Second, we will participate actively in the trialogue in the following days with a view to reaching an agreement, and third, we are also working on a budget in case we do not have an agreement. I pray we will not put our citizens at risk of the so-called provisional twelfths, which would mean less money and a much more difficult time in delivering resources where they are needed.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress that Parliament, despite the diversity that is salutary and also underlined, has been united. It is also a finding that the Council is disunited in this matter. It is important that, in this space that we now have, we take it as an opportunity, an opportunity for a new draft budget, an opportunity also to reach an agreement within the Council.  What Parliament wants should be what the Council should also want. We don't want more money, we want to help pay off debts, our ambition is no longer even to pay what we owe, is to stabilize the debt. We want credibility, we also want to, and I would like to welcome the payment plan for the future, Commissioner, but it is important that this payment plan is not made at the expense of delays in programmes that should already be in place, because when we are saying that at the end of this year we run the risk of having 30 billion euros of unpaid invoices , this means that we are harming growth and jobs, penalising small and medium-sized enterprises, also contributing to difficulties for national and local authorities, harming farmers. And those who want growth and jobs, as I assume the Council also wants, in addition to paying what it owes, should use the instruments at its disposal for growth, the budget is one of them, respect for the Multiannual Financial Framework should also be something that was common to all of us. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – (2) Dear colleague, I have listened carefully to your speech and I am concerned, as a Member and as a citizen, of the bad example that the Executive Bodies of the Union are making. So I would like you to answer the following question: these accumulated debts of more than EUR 25 billion are due to what? Mismanagement by executive bodies? Spend in addition to the recipes you have? What is the end of this debt, since the States are obliged by the Commission and the executive bodies to strict austerity policies, strict compliance with budget deficits, to which this immense debt of the European Union is therefore due?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – It is due to a very simple reason: there is a majority in the Council to approve commitments for the implementation of projects, for the advancement of new programmes and then the result of these commitments are invoices, they are payments and the incredible and difficult to explain is that the same majority in the Council, which authorises programmes and projects, then fails to have the same majority , does not authorise payments.  There is no irregularity here, it is not mismanagement, it is a political issue and it is something unacceptable that our citizens do not understand. How can you not pay what you authorize and often ask for.

name: Jens Geier
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Vice-President Georgieva, Secretary of State Zanetti, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has When do we see an end to this annual ritual? The net contributors regard their payments to the EU budget as lost grants and not as means of achieving jointly agreed policy objectives. The net recipient countries, of course, see it quite differently, but they do not prevail in the Council. As a result, the EU budget is stocked according to national discretion and not according to political needs. Within the framework of the commitments, the EU Commission pledges to finance projects that are not paid for by the Council. The victims are students, cities and municipalities that cannot pay for their urban development projects are small and medium-sized enterprises. If there is still evidence that the EU needs real own resources, here it is! In the short term, however, even that would not be a solution and, at the moment, the Council is failing to adopt a dogmatic attitude. In doing so, a concession from the Council might not solve a serious problem, but at least would contribute to a short-term stabilisation. The Commission needs EUR 4.7 billion to ensure that the situation on unpaid bills does not get any worse. On the other hand, we have EUR 5 billion in fines collected. Here too, however, we will not be able to get there, because here too there is a dogma of the Council standing in the way, namely the dogma of not having revenue in the EU budget used for the EU. At this point, I urge the Presidency of the Council to free us from these dogmas. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – In your speech you mention that the net contributors see the budget as one thing, and that those who take out see it as another. Have you not just really hit the nail on the head – that the problem is that this is not one state? Sovereign states have different requirements, different needs for different countries, and it will never work. This cannot work, because there are so many different requirements in so many different individual sovereign states. That is the whole reason this does not work.

name: Jens Geier (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Etheridge, whether you like it or not, this EU has rules, and we comply with those rules. I understand that these are complicated in the budgetary procedure.  I understand that the british electorate does not know about this properly. When I read British newspapers, I think I can also see that these newspapers obviously perceive a different EU from the one I perceive. The British situation is particularly complicated at the moment due to the need for additional payments. My point is this: let us create own resources for the European Union, a separate revenue base for the budget, and all your problems have been resolved.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – Indeed, dear colleague, I would like to ask whether it does not seem that there is somehow everything standing on the head, but on the head. That the work is first negotiated, then huge bills are presented, then we all suffer and then decide how to resolve that issue. Should everything be built in our seats and initially agreed on funding, before we discuss how we will implement those projects.

name: Jens Geier (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. You could not be more right, honourable Member. However, the events in the European Union are quite different. The Member States that agree on policy objectives under the legislation for the seven-year programmes are the same Member States which are then unwilling to adequately finance these objectives. This is one of the illogicalities of this event in the European Union. A great bitterness that I have felt here for five years as a housekeeper is that in the capitals you can still get away with such logic. When a German government representative stands in front of the camera in Berlin and says that the EU must save, he gets applause because it is not said that he is actually not keeping his own promises when financing the budget.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The EU budget has not only failed this year, it has failed several times in recent years. Against this background, we must ask ourselves: do we have the right system at all to draw up a budget if, in a few years' time, it is not possible to draw up a budget within the time limits set? When I see that we have an annual battle for the budget here, I wonder: who is actually fighting whom here? Should we not all pull together, we, the European institutions and the Member States? And if we pull together, it will also go in the same direction. This is far too little in our country. As has already been said, we also have a budget that is far too complicated, far too many adjusting screws. We can no longer make it clear to anyone outside this Parliament, to the citizens in particular, how this budget works. We should therefore pay attention to greater transparency here and simplify this budget. When I see the figures we had here in total: an original draft of the Commission with EUR 142 billion, then reduced by the Council to 140, raised by the European Parliament again to 146, and in the Conciliation Committee we end up again at EUR 142 billion, but we do not agree. The problems of debt have not been addressed at all. In other words, we do not yet have a solution to this problem. From our point of view, the problem can only be solved by reducing commitment appropriations, but in no case simply using the watering can to increase the means of payment. We want a lean and economical budget!

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for One could actually start this speech with a reference to today's high guest. In the Latin Mass there is a clause that sounds like this: Libera nos a malo – Save us from evil – and the following question is therefore about: What is the evil here? I believe that the evil we saw when the Commission came in two minutes before 24 noon last Monday, I believe that the evil in this context is the Council's inability to reach agreement within itself. It is a serious institutional problem in which I would urge the current President-in-Office of the Council to actually think seriously about how the Council is improving its decision-making process, because the decision-making process that we were subjected to during the conciliation negotiations is an impossibility: we come to a meeting room and we will have to wait there for two hours. You can't, as it's called in a little vulgar language, the stern of the chaise. And when you don't get the stern out of the chaise in a European context, things go bad. Then I will turn to another participant in this long discussion: Georgieva Kristalina Ivanova. I think that is how it is pronounced in Bulgarian. You made a very strong impression on us, but you have a big problem ahead of you. While we are trying to decide on this year's supplementary budgets and next year's budget, you have the perhaps thankless task of finding money for President Juncker's 300 billion budget. I would like to say that the democratic rules of the game presuppose that we are also involved in deciding on it. It cannot be done in the way that the Commission secretly saves money from a budget that we have approved and uses it, so to speak, for Juncker's 300 billion.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, tá sé aitheanta ag beagnach gach Feisire sa Pharlaimint seo go bhfuil sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go bhfuil fiachais bhuiséad na hEorpa slán. Mura n-íoctar iad tá na himpleachtaí do-ghlactha. Anuraidh, mar gheall ar an staid seo, níor éirigh leis an Aontas Eorpach aon pholasaithe nó cláir a chur i bhfeidhm, go háirithe iad siúd a bheadh ábalta fostaíocht agus fás a chruthú. Tá sé seo go léir ag tarlú in am nuair atá Ballstáit na hEorpa ag streachailt; in am ina bhfuil an tAontas Eorpach ag dul i dtreo géarchéime don tríú bliain, agus in am a bhfuilimid cóngarach do dhíbhoilsciú. Ní féidir linn ligint don rud céanna tarlú arís i 2015. Tá tuilleadh acmhainní ag teastáil do phoist agus fás. Sin é an gealltanas a thug an Chomhairle dúinn. Tá tionchar ag an staid seo ar thús chlár 2014-2020 agus mar aon leis sin, tá torthaí diúltacha eile ar inbhuanaitheacht airgeadais do pháirtithe leasmhara na sochaí sóisialta. Caithfear aisíocaíocht a dhéanamh agus a thabhairt do Bhallstáit, gnóthaí beaga agus meánmhéide, ionaid taighde agus ollscoileanna. Tá daoine ag fanacht ar an méid a bhí geallta dóibh, agus níl siad ábalta fanacht ar an gComhairle ach oiread atá ag glacadh i bhfad an iomarca ama. Tá straitéis nua ag teastáil agus tá sé ag teastáil go luath. Mura dtabharfaimid aire do bhuiséad 2014 anois, conas a bheimid ábalta aire a thabhairt do bhuiséad 2015? Is é seo atá ag déanamh damáiste do chreidiúnacht an Aontais Eorpaigh agus tá géarghá ann go bhfuil sé ar chumas an Aontais Eorpaigh na fiacha seo a íoc agus aghaidh a thabhairt ar an bhfadhb seo. Tá sé díreach uafásach; ní féidir linn leanúint ar aghaidh mar seo.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I wonder whether we can seriously avoid the term ‘irresponsibility’ while talking about the Council, which is unable to adopt a common position before the last day – not to say the last hour – of the three-week long conciliation period? The Council, which is unable to adopt a common position on DAB 3 after almost five months? Can we seriously avoid the term ‘irresponsibility’ while talking about the Council, which is consistently cutting payments which are a legal obligation and a logical consequence of the commitments made jointly by us? The Council, which wants to impose upon this very Parliament a fast-track procedure on own resources, although it has been unable for years to fix the most important issue – the reform of own resources? Can we really avoid the term ‘irresponsibility’ under those circumstances? No, we cannot. Let me ask the Italian Presidency to convey this message to the Member States: just pull yourselves together! Look at the efforts of the Commission and this very Parliament, which I would go so far as to describe as impressive, and try to forget your members’ selfish interest. Just focus on the fate of Europe. More responsibility.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if I am to be honest, I was very impressed by what happened with conciliation. I expected the European institutions to cooperate seriously in order to achieve an objective that everyone was claiming in words. Unfortunately, however, the reality is quite different. The Council was completely uninterested in the whole matter until the last few hours, forcing Parliament to reject its last-minute proposal. I have heard of tactics and strategies, and here too I am very perplexed. What is the purpose of all this? Is it to win an institutional tug-of-war or really to do the interests of european citizens? We have been clear: if there are any previous problems to be solved, we are available, but we would like to see a completely change of direction in the future.  The Commission should also be clear about what its real intentions and needs are, while maintaining a clear and well-defined position. Finally, I regret to note the total inadequacy and complete failure of the Italian Presidency in this matter. Mr Zanetti, please tell Renzi to engage less in slogans and to deal with people's real problems instead.

name: Sophie Montel (NI). -
text: Madam President, the European Commission should amend the 2015 EU budget to allow some Member States to defer their payments, following the revision of their GNI.  The UK will therefore have to pay an additional contribution of EUR 2 billion by 1 December 2014. Prime Minister Cameron has said he will not pay. Since 1984, during Mrs Thatcher's era, the UK has received a rebate on the famous principle: I want my money back. This rebate granted to the United Kingdom, which, let us acknowledge, has perfectly defended its own interests, is of course supported, in the name of solidarity dear to the European Union, by the other Member States, including my own France. However, with zero growth, 8.4 million poor and more than 5 million unemployed, France is now laminated economically and socially. As a reminder, France is already paying 21 billion and only has 13 billion; Obviously, the account is not there. Why the $21 billion?  The level of unpaid debts has soared from 5 billion in 2010 to almost 30 billion at the end of 2014. And for what result? No growth and an ever-growing unemployment rate. The European Union is really in debt, against the very spirit of the European treaties. The European Union imposes budgetary rigour on Member States, even though it has stashed bills in drawers.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We all know this principle that the budget is a policy translated into numbers. In fact, what is going on between Parliament, the Council and the Commission today is a serious discussion not of a technical nature, not just about finance, but about the future nature of the European Union: what the Union is supposed to do, how it is supposed to function, how the European budget is supposed to work, how it is supposed to function, how it is a balanced budget, how to approach investment. Therefore, this discussion, which may seem purely retail and technical from the outside, is, in fact, a very serious and political discussion. When there is a concination, the question arises: the concocation between who and who? It seemed to us that this was a conciration between Parliament and the Council. It seems increasingly that there is a concocation between the members of the Council. It is a concocation before our eyes, when we sit and look at what is happening, the Member States find it difficult to agree on a position among themselves. This is a very serious signal for the functioning of the entire European Union. I would therefore like to make it clear: our discussion of the budget is really a discussion about the functioning of the European Union.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, here we are. The payments crisis has become an institutional crisis. On the one hand, we have the Council, which is approaching schizophrenia with Member States which have committed themselves to expenditure but refuse to find the means to pay for them. We'd just like to know how they plan to break this deadlock. On the other hand, we have a European Commission which seems to want to please everyone but forgets its primary mission, which is to protect Community interests. And we European parliamentarians want only one thing: that everyone respects their word and their commitments. I tell you as I think: I do not like what I see in the press and frighten me greatly. The Council cannot seriously suggest that Parliament is blocking the EU budget. Let everyone take responsibility, because this blockage comes at the worst time and it is not trivial. It is the financial crisis that has led to an economic and social crisis and it is the inability of the Member States to offer a response other than austerity that has aggravated this crisis. Now, as I said, it is an institutional and political crisis that is undermining our common project. Commissioner, Minister, our Europe is hungry for investment and all the experts, all the economists, the Commission and the Member States say it, everyone is saying the same thing: we need investment, between 1,500 and 2 trillion by 2020, and today we are here to butt for 4 billion. The budgetary deadlock, which we are debating today, echoes the investment plan, which may not even reach the 300 billion announced, as it echoes the delay in the implementation of the Structural Funds. Member States must move away from their austere obsession, ordoliberalism and the selfishness of just return. All this is not up to the challenges of the European Union.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR). -
text: Madam President, to the Council and Commission, I have to say that I could not agree the budget, which has such high levels of unpaid bills and unfunded liabilities; that is not acceptable. But I did fully agree with the Commissioner – she was exactly right when she said earlier that we need to devote resources to meeting citizens’ needs. That means investing in jobs and growth. But I would make two observations here. First to the Parliament and Commission, to say that this must not be confused with a call for a bigger budget. Now is not the time for increasing the size of the budget. But secondly I want to appeal to the Council: success or failure of this budget will not be determined by this house or by the Commission, it will be determined by the Member States and their willingness – or not – to show collective commitment to addressing citizens’ needs that will determine whether we succeed or we fail.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the Union's budgets are ercan and uns social, but they are redistributive, things as they are. Richer countries contribute more and troubled countries receive proportionally more investment. This solidarity between peoples, even if it is small, means much more than trade union. It makes us friends and brothers, not just partners. But it also makes us stronger. An unequal Europe is undoubtedly an unjust and sad Europe, but it is also a poor and fragile Europe. That is why the northern governments are now trying to widen the social divide, along with the Union's debt, by 4 billion is not only selfish and insolidary, it is also short-term and irresponsible. Don't let the southern countries later accuse you of wanting to leave Europe. Eurosceptics are them.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, three impressions arising from the conciliation procedure. First, the Council confirms its growing tendency to act as a club of states and not as a European Union. Second, it neglects the Commission, which it considers to be a technical-administrative delegation. And, thirdly, it mistreats the European Parliament in form and substance. In the meanwhile, the Commission buys time for its President to present to us tomorrow its brand new investment plan, now through financial multipliers from a minimum public contribution. Will the interpretation that the entire negotiation process be defaulted for its conclusion without agreement will be true? This Parliament, in any event, will not be able to vote in favour of any new proposal which does not meet the minimums it adopted at the time. First, apply the available funds—5 billion—to the goal of stabilizing the level of unpaid bills in 2014. Second, to consolidate the nature of an additional resource for so-called special instruments. And, third, formulate a concrete and committed programme of payments for the effective reduction of debt stock. There is a need for a profound reform of the concept of own resources, which now sounds like sarcasm. The resources, for the time being, are all of the Member States and none of the European Union.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, according to Mark Twain, patriotism is supporting your country all the time and your government when it deserves it. The European Union in all of this does not deserve it. It should be no surprise that I am passionately English, passionately British, passionately European, but not passionately pro-European Union. How can even the most ardent of pro-Europeans support this almighty mess? Our Parliament repeatedly voted down measures that would have saved taxpayersʼ money and helped the books to balance. In the EU budget, Parliament, the Council and the Commission are treating the issue as a political football. Yes, we talk about the victims of unpaid bills, but there is one group which is forgotten in all of this: the taxpayers, the people across Europe who have to pay for this bloated European Union.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I am really glad Mr Arnott spoke just before me so that I can repeat his words and say that I am utmost Finnish and I am really pro-European, but I have to say that this whole thing started to go in the wrong direction from the very beginning. This is not a cookie jar we are talking about. You cannot put a cookie in this jar and then just take it away and say, no, I do not want to put it there, or that you want to put in a cookie and then you want to take something out which does not belong to you. You always want to take precisely the cookie from the jar that you think that you deserve. As a matter of fact I remember my fifth birthday. I had modest little presents, and there was this one red plastic fire truck. When it was time for the parents to pick up the kids and the party was over, the kid who gave it to me took the fire truck from me and she said, ʽI don’t want to give this to you after all. I want to take it homeʼ, and she took it home. This is not a five year old’s birthday party we are talking about. For crying out loud! The Member States could not get their act together. The next time round the Commission will probably have a proposal not much different from the one they had just a few days or weeks ago. They will have pretty much the same thing, and we have to get our act together because, as a matter of fact, the Member States were there when these commitments were agreed upon.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, the budget conciliation procedure has effectively failed both on the 2014 amending budget and on the 2015 budget. All this because the Council refuses to understand that the interest of States is to deal collectively with the threat of recession.  It seems to me that it is now necessary for the Council to take the necessary political height and assume its responsibilities. It cannot be accepted, first, that the invoices remain unpaid and, secondly, that the Council reduces its commitments. We have to find some leeway. The payment of fines to the EU budget, 5 billion in 2014, is a first possibility.  However, new perspectives need to be examined, notably the resources related to the financial transaction tax but also, no doubt, the exclusion of state contributions to the European budget from the so-called convergence criteria which would make the system much more virtuous. I also want to tell you that we must not forget the huge revenue that would result from a thorough fight against tax evasion.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Unfortunately, the failure of the conciliation procedure on the draft budget for 2015 and the council's simultaneous request to Parliament for an urgent procedure on the reimbursement of appropriations to national budgets show that the Council's priority is not to settle outstanding bills. Payment arrears have been rapidly increasing in recent years, amounting to close to EUR 30 billion at the end of 2014, which means that they are already at a level that threatens the liquidity of the EU budget.  In this situation, Parliament should firmly maintain its position towards the Council and the Commission with the simultaneous resolution of six amending budgets for 2014 and the 2015 budget. It is of particular importance that nearly EUR 5 billion of the penalties and fines that have entered the Union budget this year should not be returned to member states' budgets and be used to pay the most urgent payments. It is also necessary to increase the level of payments in the 2015 budget by at least several billion euros compared to the Council's proposal.  Finally, I would like to express my hope that the European Commission, in the absence of funds to pay late payments, will not pursue a policy of rejecting payment applications against Member States under any pretext, which is particularly important in 2015, the last year of the 2007-2013 perspective. Thank you very much.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation is so risky, as Commissioner Georgieva described it, that we can only get out of it by trying to have a Europe that really does relaunch itself, precisely from the situation in which we find ourselves.  Of course we must have strong courage – and I say this fortunately, Commissioner – starting with the proposal that the Commission will make next Friday. We must also have courage on the part of the Council in the work that will be carried out in the various trialogues that will follow. Because we must give these answers, all of which have been said on this day, to the citizens. We have to pay the bills of our universities, our schools, our municipalities and our companies.  This is not the time for tactics and prejudice, it is time to put our cards on the table. It is also time to avoid a risk, which is to breathe new life into anti-European voices. We must avoid this, and this is a strong political work. We must have courage; Parliament is there and it has shown it. Let us wait for the initiative and work together. I believe that this is an opportunity to relaunch and to have a strong proposal also with regard to the prospects.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D). -
text: We have an accurate vision of a budget that will boost growth and jobs in the European Union. This is not enough for a good result, when the Council cannot even say today when it will pay the old debts.  If the path to our common objectives looked like budgetary conciliation, a joint project called the European Union would indeed be seriously threatened. That is also why, Commissioner, we must build the Budgets of the European Union on other principles and on independence from the economic or political situation in the Member States. From a national level, everything we can do together more effectively needs to be transferred to a European one. For example, only the common security and defence policy can save Europe EUR 26 billion a year, so much the Council owes on unpaid invoices. The question is: what to do to agree on the 2015 budget? We will have to ask the heads of European governments to enter this with full seriousness. Even in times of problems, the European Union must be a credible partner.

name: Lara Comi (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the failure of the negotiations that have taken place shows once again that there is a need for change, especially within the Council. We have often seen the latter in so many circumstances, in so many directives and in so many negotiations, thinking more about the interests of the Member States than about its community.  We cannot penalise those who do not pay, produce and adopt directives that require the payment of debts on time, when the European Union is the first not to do so. All the more so with the crisis, I believe that the European Union must set a good example and therefore pay its debts, otherwise only the weakest classes, namely the citizens, will put it back. We have made a directive on late payments - this was also one of the great successes - we enforce it, those who do not comply with it have infringements and then we are the first not to pay.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D). -
text: The way in which the conciliation procedure was conducted shows a rare lack of respect on the part of the Council. The fact that the Member States could not reach a clear agreement is worrying, but this is the result of the fact that the States were not represented at a decision-making level.  The situation is all the more difficult, as debts accumulate at European level. The bills have to be paid. There are financial resources to pay these bills. The credibility of the European Union depends on this and on the seriousness towards the beneficiaries. The Council needs to understand that these beneficiaries are from their own countries, regions, cities, companies or NGOs from their own countries. I don't understand, honestly, where the problem is. We, as MEPs, are accountable to the citizens we represent. The Council seems to have forgotten that he is also responsible to them. We need political will in the Council and in the Member States, if not for the European Parliament, if not for citizens, at least for him and his political ambitions, which, without a budget, cannot be achieved.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, the EU is spending more than its taxpayers are willing to give. The EU wants to spend on all manner of things that, if asked, I would suggest many of the taxpayers would not support. Equality, in its general terms, seems to be one of the targets of this spending. Well, the society that puts equality before freedom ends up with neither, and the society or the organisation that puts spending on fantastic schemes and goals above economic soundness ends up with debts burdened upon people, late payments, complete sterility of ideas and failure. I put it to you that this organisation needs to think again. Someone mentioned a complete restart. I certainly think a complete halt and some rational thought to realise that you cannot spend more than you bring in. The people do not want to give you any more. That is the truth.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: I would like to say that I very much welcomed the Commissioner's statement on how she wants to tackle the problem, or what she wants to propose a solution to. We can all see that the problem is in the Council, not in the Commission. Debt repayment is a question of the credibility of the European Union as a whole. How could the Union subsequently be credible when it is causing difficulties for businesses, citizens and, of course, for specific municipalities, municipalities?  Should the budgetary procedure not change so that we do not get into this situation again in a few months? How can projects be approved by the Council at all and payments subsequently not approved? I can't understand that. Can there be a catastrophic scenario that problems could be carried over to the new budget period 2014-2020?

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council We have heard many important words today, and I would like to start with the word consensus. Consensus has been found in the creation of the programme, consensus has been found in the support of the project. However, the Council seems to have forgotten from then on that this consensus also entails costs. The promoters, whether they were municipalities, whether they were Erasmus students, whether they were social institutions, whether they were simply Europeans, they trusted that this consensus would lead to projects, programmes and payments. They can presuppose this reliability of the European Union if they are prepared to participate actively in cohesion policy, in integration policy. This credibility of the European Union is at stake today if the Council continues to refuse. My hope now is that you, Commissioner, together with the Council and Parliament, will show common sense and foresight so that we can continue to be credible and reliable in the future.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to make a somewhat broader comment on the issue of the European budget. I believe that we are in danger of moving forward every year with this procedure, with Parliament having a position that it wants to move forward by doing more things and the Council which is constantly reducing the budget.  I think that the question of own resources can no longer be avoided, because otherwise Parliament's power as co-decision-making body in budgetary matters is in fact being undermined, because Parliament has no power over the Council, which continues to have the resources. I would therefore ask you to address the issue of own resources as a matter of urgency, so that the Union's budget is a real budget and, above all, so that Parliament's power – and we are, of course, speaking here from Parliament – is not totally frustrated by this situation, in which the purse strings in the end are always the members of the Council.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, many thanks to all the speakers for the comments that have been made on the immediate problems in hand to bring the budget negotiations to a successful closure, as well as on the future of the EU budget. In terms of the immediate task facing us, we are prepared to work very actively with Parliament and the Council to make sure that there is full clarity on the proposal we will be making concerning 2015, and that, in terms of a longer-term stability of our budget, we have an agreement in support of the payment plan I outlined at the beginning. It is our duty as the Commission to provide a credible underpinning to the decisions of the two sides of the budget authority, and we will do our duty. There are, however, fundamental questions on the future of the European Union budget in terms of its sourcing, the question of own resources, as well as in terms of the quality of spending and how we make every euro work to the fullest for the European people. I want to assure you that we will look at these two issues – the immediate budget, forming the budget for Europe, as well as the longer-term sustainability of our budget – equally seriously. As it happens, this will be in the first week of December, when we will have two critical discussions: one a trilogue on the 2014-2015 package, and the other, the Monti Group on own resources. The Commission will be participating very seriously in this meeting – myself, First Vice-President Timmermans and Commissioner Moscovici. I think we do indeed have to keep an eye on making sure that we create a budgetary decision-making environment that unites us and does not divide us.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened to all the speeches, as I have heard the speeches of Members of the European Parliament at previous meetings, both here in plenary and in committee. This is not the time, I believe, to fossilise ourselves on recriminations, on why conciliation did not give the desired result. We have a second half which must be properly exploited.  Of course, as a contribution to the debate, I would like to underline what Mr Mc8/80 has said. Bresso on the importance of own resources. I say this precisely from the point of view of experience gained during participation in this work on the budget. There is no doubt that the Council must be the Council and not a multilateral table of 28. There is also no doubt, however, that on the specific issue of the allocation of resources from the European budget, each individual country also has a role as a contributor which, as such, inevitably and understandably leads it to make assessments linked also to its budgetary problems, which sometimes also often result from the need to comply with obligations of European derivation. This interweaving which, year after year, is in danger of becoming inextricable and which, in order to have a real solution, implies not only that there are own resources but, I would add, that there are own resources that are recognisable and directly identifiable as such by the citizens.  Citizens need to know how much they pay for each level of government: at local level ( I am thinking of town halls), at regional level, at national level and also at European level. This is the best way for everyone to have real full responsibility, and where I really mean all the players in the process for everyone, because at a time when there is a European tax that is directly perceived as such, it is clear that the European institutions other than the Council of Contributors themselves will also need to respond more directly to the fiscal burdens that the increased budgetary allocations may determine. So that step is definitely important. This is a contribution I make to the positive debate we have had today; For the rest, the Presidency is doing its utmost to ensure that this second half ends with the result that objectively it would have been better to have already had a few days ago, but which, once it arrives, will leave us all certainly satisfied.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the Budgets Committee. Madam President, it is true that parliaments have been set up for consent to tax, and on the day when the European Parliament can vote on the tax, we will have taken a decisive step. But let it be clear that the European tax will have to be compensated by a reduction in taxes levied at the national level. Having said that, our conciliation has failed. She has given us some lessons, and I hope that will be taken into account. Conciliation has just begun, and I am pleased that our Committee on Budgets has been able to decide its position unanimously on the basis of method and principles. No doubt, Mr Zanetti, have you suffered during these twenty-one days of conciliation. You may have suffered because there was a clear dysfunction of the Council. I plead that this should never happen again.  Tomorrow, like every Member of Parliament, I want to be able to explain very simply to my fellow citizens what we are doing here. I would like to explain to them that we cannot continue to accumulate debts because the first political decision is commitment, and the commitment is made by the budgetary authority, that is, the Council and Parliament. Payment is only the fulfillment of this first commitment. So let's get out of the dysfunctions of public governance! This is true at the national level as well as at the European Union level.  I wish that conciliation, which has just begun, can be achieved, that it will be completed before Christmas and that we will give the Commission the means it needs to carry out a policy which is pro-growth and employment but which is immune to tricks such as the one we deplore, that is, the accumulation of debts. We need to find a structural and sustainable solution.

name: Elnök. -
text: The debate is over.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The European Commission is asking us here to amend the 2015 budget in order to help certain states, as a result of the revision of their GNI (Gross National Income), to defer their payment. Nine states are particularly affected, including the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Italy. The United Kingdom will thus have to pay an additional contribution of 2.1 billion euros, even though it already benefits from a rebate supported by other states such as my own, France, whose economic and social situation no longer allows to continue to pay 21 billion euros per year to the European budget to recover only 13. To quote Margaret Thatcher, we also mean "I want my money back"! More worrying is the level of unpaid bills this year. They were 5 billion euros in 2010 and reach the staggering sum of 30 billion in 2014.
