We can clearly see here the difficulty of the European Union, which is a bad payer, which requires the Member States subjected by the budgetary treaty to manage their exemplary budgets and to return to financial balance, while the gendarme himself hides the bills in a drawer and is thus clearly incapable of applying the fine theories which he would like to pass on to the whole Union.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing – The European Parliament wanted all budgetary amendments for 2014 to be fully adopted in the conciliation negotiations. This would have raised the 2014 payment levels by EUR 4.7 billion to ensure that the unpaid accounts already submitted by the Member States in cohesion policy are covered. If this is not provided, up to €26 billion in unpaid bills could be accumulated by the end of 2014. By 2015, we would have given EUR 6 billion more than the Council, totalling EUR 146.4 billion, to provide, inter alia, enough resources to fully pay for the cohesion programmes that will close in 2015. In the EP's reading, our amendments, confirmed by the People's Party and then by the reporter, increased the support for the convergence areas by EUR 4 billion. The lack of liquidity on the payment side also threatens the implementation of other programmes: horizon 2020 applications may reduce the pre-financing rate, postpone tenders and cause liquidity problems for universities and research centres that have won tenders. In the case of ERASMUS, it could mean reduced pre-financing, thereby narrowing the number of people who can "afford" to go abroad to study with this scholarship, as they have to advance a significant part of their costs. Raising the EP would also have been a solution to these problems. If the EU budget for 2015 is not adopted by 31 December 2014, 1/12 of this year could start next year. With tight deadlines and a responsible willingness to compromise, next year's European budget can be drawn up in time.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. The stalemate we reached during the conciliation on the budget is somewhat paradoxical. Paradoxical because, despite the solution to the serious economic and political crisis that the EU is going through, some governments persist in not wanting to act without understanding that the recovery of the economy also passes through the Eu ropean Union budget. One tool that, I will never tire of saying, is genuine investment in SME innovation, research, students, the environment, food safety and so on. Although the budget seems to be made up only of numbers, this debate is probably the most political and fundamental debate we can have to restore a soul to Europe. A Europe that looks not only at accounts and debts but that cares about the well-being of its citizens and linking their interests and ambitions together. We are now waiting, after the Commission's proposal, for a proactive attitude on the part of the Council, which is taking a serious look at a solution to save the EU. Parliament, representing 500 million citizens, is playing its part. We hope that the governments will also do theirs.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – After 18 days of coordination and months after the Commission prepared the draft amending budget for 2014, the Council was unable to submit a coordinated negotiating platform for the rebalancing of the 2014 budget, enabling the Commission to make payments for european projects already made. This means that the contractors of these projects, farmers, researchers and other groups will continue to wait for funds to be paid for services already provided. The Council has also failed to present negotiating positions for the 2015 budget adoption process, which must be completed by the end of this year if we are to avoid implementing the future budget after twelfths or a very limited amount of available funds. The fact is that, among other things, as much as 80% of agricultural subsidies must be paid in February 2015, and there is a high risk that even the commitments from the Structural Funds, which have been in place since October 2014, will not be paid at the beginning of next year. The matter is simple: we have to pay for what we owe. It is unacceptable that the Council has spent so much time resolving its problems, rather than taking its share of responsibility for the citizens of the European Union, the European Commission and, last but not least, the European Parliament, in a timely manner.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am personally very disappointed with the outcome of the conciliation committee's deliberations. Not only were the Member States unable to agree on a single position for a long time, but the Council's position was then not even worthy of negotiation. Like every EU citizen, every household, every European company has to pay its own unpaid invoices. As soon as possible. It's too late today. The current situation of the European budget casts a bad view of the entire EU and European integration as such. So let's deal with it.

name: Elnök. -
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on combating violence against women by Iratxe García Pérez on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O-000080/2014 — (2014/2916(RSP)) — B8-0039/2014)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner, seven women a day are killed in Europe, victims of gender-based violence. Karen, Samantha, Margaret, Susan, Tania, Emma, Ana are not figures. They are truncated lives, the fruit of injustice, the fruit of an unequal society that has allowed one part of the population to consider themselves owners of the other side: women. The study by the European Union's Agency for Fundamental Rights kept public this year yields shocking data. More than nine million women in Europe have been victims of some form of violence. Let's remember we're not talking about a fringe group. Let's remember we're talking about half the population. Older and young women, who live in cities and in the rural environment, who study, who work, with or without a good economic situation. We're talking about women. Of all the women. The European Union must be a space free of violence. We will not accept the excuse of lack of competence so as not to implement all necessary initiatives. Citizens will not understand that in Europe we have agreed to save the banks and do not agree to save women's lives. That is why today, 25 November, we are expressing our demand to launch a directive against gender-based violence. The last legislature, most of this House, supported this proposal. We believe that it is important that legislation is put in place, as has already been done in some Member States. The European Union cannot look the other way when the fundamental rights of such a large percentage of the population are being violated so heartbreakingly: millions of women who are being violent just because they are women. A comprehensive policy is needed to act in all areas: in prevention, in treatment; that includes police, legal, economic, social measures, not to mention educational ones. Because women have to know that the state is ampara. It's not your problems, it's our problems. Putting a face, face, on the violence faced by women will help many of those who hide behind shame and guilt today know that it is time to end silence. And part of our work and commitment lies in making visible a reality that was long ago in the realm of the private, without being considered a social problem. We want 2016 to be declared the European Year against Gender-Based Violence. Because decision-making, citizenship awareness is essential, but so is the awareness of community institutions, which must achieve greater commitment to the society they represent. Today a large number of social organizations and women are working on the support and treatment of victims. From here I express my sense of appreciation for your work and the requirement that the Community budget in this area not be cut. We have already had to see how in some countries the policy of cuts and austerity has been a setback in the measures being pushed forward in the fight against gender-based violence. Please let's not forget that cutting in policies against gender-based violence is cutting back on lives. In addition, we must keep in mind that many of the women who do not have financial resources at the moment do not report because they have no possibility of undertaking autonomous and free lives. Commissioner, it is difficult to see how, year after year, on 25 November we are having the same debate. We lament injustice. We're asking for more commitment. It's time to get down to business. We can't wait another minute. Don't let it be one more, because then, for many women, next year will be too late. (Applause)

name: Elnök asszony. -
text: Indeed, this is a problem that emerges in the most diverse places in our daily lives. There is a lot of work to be done and, in addition to talking about it every year on 25 November, it would be good to take action in this regard, because these women are looking for help from us. I will give Commissioner Jourová the opportunity to comment, and you, Commissioner, have several minutes. Let's hope we find a solution.

name: Vĕra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to thank the Members, and the members of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality in particular, for the opportunity to answer the questions relating to this very serious subject. It is an important symbol that the debate is taking place today on 25 November: the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. I hope that in one year’s time I will be allowed here to speak about better results and a better situation in the field we are going to speak about. Violence against women remains one of the most serious human rights violations of our time. It is deeply rooted in gender inequalities and reinforces them. It is an extreme form of discrimination. One in three women in the European Union has experienced physical or sexual violence since the age of fifteen. I was myself shocked by reading the latest figures given by the Fundamental Rights Agency in Vienna. I did not know myself that the situation is that bad in the European Union. I would like to stress in this place that for me, this problem is not a matter of statistics, because this concerns any individual. We had the Pope here today. He spoke about human dignity. This is what is at stake in this problem, in this field: not only human dignity but lives themselves, as you have said. Violence against women affects society as a whole and is also costly. Parliament’s European added-value assessment estimated the direct cost of violence against women in the European Union at EUR 69 billion per year. It suggests that if we reduce violence by just 10%, the direct economic costs would be reduced by approximately EUR 7 billion a year. Tackling violence against women therefore makes economic sense too, but again I want to stress that I understand this problem as more than an economic problem, for sure. This is just an illustration of economic figures. I can assure you that I share your commitment to eliminating violence against women. This will be reflected in the new Commission strategy for equality between women and men, in which there will be a chapter on gender-based violence. This strategy has been proposed by my services and by myself to be elaborated for the year 2015, and I am inviting a wide discussion on this topic under the preparatory work for this strategy. Violence against women is a complex phenomenon and there is no magic wand which makes it disappear at once. If we really want to make a lasting difference then I believe that we have to address it as part of our greater common struggle for equality. Our action must therefore be steady, coherent and based on several pillars. These are: legislation, awareness-raising and funding, as well as improving knowledge and data collection. Allow me now to go through these instruments we have in hand. As regards legislation: the EU has put in place a coherent legal framework to prevent all forms of violence against women and to support victims. This framework now includes the Equal Treatment Directive and its provisions on sexual harassment, the Directive on Trafficking in Human Beings, the Directive against Sexual Abuse and Sexual Exploitation of Children and Child Pornography, the Directive on the European Protection Order applicable in criminal matters, the regulation setting the European Protection Order (covering civil matters), and last but not least, the Directive on the rights of crime victims, which emphasises the need for tailored protection and support for victims of gender-based violence. The Commission is now guiding and monitoring Member States in the effective implementation of this legal framework. So this is the list of existing legislation, and the expression of the necessity to adopt new legislation may be one of the results of working on the new strategy on equality between men and women which we are going to prepare next year. Prevention measures and the cross-border dimension of gender-based violence that you have raised in your question are addressed by the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe. Insofar as the EU has competence to sign and ratify the Convention, I believe we should consider EU accession to it. It is equally important that Member States respect their commitments and ratify this Convention as soon as possible. To date, and over four years after the adoption of the Convention, 22 EU Member States have signed it, but only eight EU Member States have ratified it so far. So I ask all of those here who are from Member States which have not ratified the Convention to go to their governments, their national parliaments and their media and call for national ratifications of the first international legally binding instrument combating violence against women. The second pillar of what we can – and what we must – do is awareness-raising and funding. The second pillar of the Commission’s approach to combating violence against women involves supporting awareness-raising and grassroots actions by Member States, civil society organisations and European networks. For example, this year EUR 9.5 million were allocated to supporting European networks and grassroots projects to combat violence against women under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. Our objective is to make a real difference in women’s and girls’ lives, also by the good use of this supporting money. The Commission will monitor and evaluate the ongoing awareness-raising and prevention efforts before deciding on possible future awareness-raising activities such as a European Year to End Violence against Women. Improving our knowledge of the prevalence and causes of gender-based violence is essential, because it allows the situation to be monitored across the EU and holds governments and stakeholders accountable. It also helps us to formulate and implement better policies, beyond a mere benchmarking exercise. Comparable EU data shows us how to improve the prevention of violence and the protection of victims. We can learn from each other, from our successes and failures. My services are working with Eurostat and the European Institute for Gender Equality, two key actors in the area which I believe can help fill these gaps. As a follow-up to the Directive on the Rights of Crime Victims, Eurostat, in cooperation with national statistical offices, started in 2014 to collect more detailed crime data recorded by the police and justice systems. The results, disaggregated by sex, will be published in 2015 and will constitute a step forward in our efforts to better understand gender-based violence. However, to complement police records, comprehensive and in-depth surveys are necessary. The already-mentioned Fundamental Rights Agency survey paved the way in this field. It is now considered the gold standard, and we should be proud of this achievement. However, we cannot stop here and now. We need to repeat the Fundamental Rights Agency survey again, and we will make sure that such surveys are conducted at regular intervals to detect new trends and gaps. In my view we need to use existing tools more effectively rather than establishing new bodies like the European Observatory on Violence against Women. Instead, we need an orchestrated effort from all relevant bodies, making full use of the existing expertise. As you know, the Commission will adopt a new strategy on equality between women and men from 2015. Gender-based violence will be a priority of this strategy. I am committed to addressing new forms of violence emerging in an increasingly connected world, such as cyber violence and harassment. While new means of communication and technology offer great opportunities in combating violence against women, they can pose a new threat to the security of women as well. The most effective course of action will be determined and integrated in the new Commission strategy on equality between women and men. This strategy must also include actions to engage men in combating violence against women, raising their awareness of the issue but also engaging them as actors for change. Only by working together will our efforts be fully effective. Finally, I would like to engage with you and listen to you and other stakeholders when developing this new strategy.

name: President. -
text: We now continue with the debate on the question for oral answer O-000080/2014 – B8-0039/2014 – 2014/2916(RSP).

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, since I came to this Parliament, the defence of victims has been my priority and will remain so wherever I am. Today it is European women who are victims of violence who are asking us to speak with a unique and clear voice. They require us to join forces to raise awareness of the magnitude of a problem affecting not only Europe, but the whole world. Violence against women does not distinguish between rich and poor. It crosses all the barriers: home, school, work. There is no refuge for those fleeing from that aggressor, sometimes so close. More than a third of European women admit to having suffered some form of violence just because they are women, with consequent physical, moral and sexual harm. The countries of the Union need to laugh in the same direction towards the total elimination of violence against women, and that is why we need a common strategy. In this connection I worked as rapporteur on the European Order for the Protection of Victims, and today we have a legislative instrument capable of recognising a restraining order in any country of the Union. But I am not satisfied as long as the number of women and girls suffering abuse, rape, trafficking in whites, women who see their freedom and dignity trampled on continues to grow. As the Holy Father told us today, we have to put the person in the center; for today and every day we put women at the centre of our work and do so to achieve a safer, more dignified and fairer Europe. We owe it to all the murdered women, we owe it to their children, and we owe it to their families who still mourn them. (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation)).

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree with me that this awful subject is really about a lack of morals and honour in society, and that anyone harming a woman is not only no gentleman, but is no kind of man at all?

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Of course, I totally agree. I like that you to ask me that question because it is also an education problem that I, in a minute and a half, has not given me time to mention. Of course, it is a problem whose solution has to start also from men. And it's an education problem and it's the men we have to raise awareness of. It is men who would have to be more numerous in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and it is men who should be fighting this problem the same or more as we do.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of Women and President, it is european day to combat violence against women. It is true that if we look to our right or to our left, we are three people, at least one of whom has, has been or will be the victim of violence against it, but I would say more. I will have a hard time saying it today because, if I look to my right and to my left, I do not see many men. But, yes, if women are victims of violence, it is because there are perpetrators.  I thank the men who are among us. Today, we must send a message to the perpetrators of these violences, of course, but also to sanctions and support. One in three women is appalling. For years, as parliamentarians, we have been fighting this fight and yet, unfortunately, the numbers are rising, certainly because this violence is not decreasing but fortunately because some countries have put in place mechanisms that finally allow women to get out of the private sphere and to go and file a complaint, to be heard by a doctor, to be defended by a lawyer. , to succeed in the courts.  What we are asking for today is to be able to act, because the findings and the figures are there. There is therefore no question of setting up expert commissions or discussions. All the work has been done and today, Commissioner, we must act. We ask that, as soon as possible , and you have said this - this Istanbul Convention can be ratified by the European Commission, which could then set up a programme of actions because it is not enough to ratify, it must indeed be put into practice in each of the Member States.  There are no cultures, there are no differences, which justify the fact that in some countries we can better protect women than in others. We must guarantee a common European base which, at the same time, sensitizes, trains the actors, accompanies and protects, but which also allows the perpetrators to be properly punished.  We are asking for a legislative framework to do all this, we are finally calling for this European year to combat violence. Commissioner, I hope you will hear that message.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group. – Rough figures on how many women are victims of violence. We know from anonymous forms and savings how big a problem this is.  But let me draw your attention today to other numbers, the non-anonymous ones. Indeed, only 14% of victims of domestic violence will have the courage to turn to the authorities whose mission is to protect us. What does the fact that, while there have been 47 rapes per 100 000 inhabitants in Sweden, only two, three rapes per 100 000 inhabitants, in Greece, Hungary or Slovakia, for example, in Slovakia, mean by the fact that there are only two or three rapes per same number? No, it's not a fundamental difference between people, it's a difference in trust. In the confidence that if I turn to the police, I will not have another painful experience, but I will encounter a sensitive investigative approach that will be adapted to the needs of the victims, not record the perpetrators finding safety and not a reason to doubt whether the move to report the act was really correct, that the medical staff will recognize my problem and immediately advise me on how to protect myself, that investigators and judges are responding quickly , do not prolong suffering, but punish the act and protect the victim. The subject of violence against women is not only a problem for those women and their families, but for all of us. Each of us can only help by not being indifferent and judging. Please do not ask, therefore, whether the victims were wearing what they were wearing, whether they were where we believed they should not have been, but let us always ask first and foremost how we can help them.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, we are shocked to learn that one in three women in the world - and yes, European women too - will suffer sexual, physical or psychological violence at some point in her life just because she is a woman. However, the reality is much worse than the chilling data we know, because only a third of victims report it. The question is, again: what can we do? I am going to propose here and now, I too, that we do something immediate, radically concrete, revolutionaryly effective: ratify the Istanbul Convention. It is the first integrated and legally binding document that establishes that violence against women and domestic violence are a serious attack on human rights. The Istanbul Convention is a unique instrument, which commits each ratifying State to detect, prevent and eliminate violence against girls and women in all its manifestations, from domestic abuse to forced marriage, female genital mutilation or trafficking for exploitation purposes. There is already a comprehensive legal tool that requires the protection of victims, legislative and punitive action against perpetrators and the development of effective equality policies. It has been in force since August 1, it is ready and at our disposal. What are we waiting for to adopt him? To date, only eight Member States have ratified the Istanbul Convention: Spain, Portugal, Italy, France, Sweden, Denmark, Austria and Malta. Fourteen have already signed it and are in the process of ratification. But today is a good day to ask Bulgaria, Estonia, Ireland, the Czech Republic, Cyprus and Latvia why they haven't even signed it yet. Today is a good day for this Parliament to unequivocally implace the Commission to accept this mandate and the new Latvian Presidency to lead this indispensable process with determination from January on a determination. As a reference in the defence of democracy and human rights in the world, it is imperative that Europe has a unanimous voice; unanimously in the rejection, persecution and punishment of violence against women; unanimously in the quality public debate that expressly and decisively incorporates men, such as Dr. Mukwege, for example; and unanimously in the momentum and implementation of political and legislative measures that end the inequality that persists and shames us, the inequality that is at the basis of violence against women. (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation)).

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – The tragedy we are debating here today also has a cultural origin, derived from a culture that subordinates women. Today, here in Parliament, we had the leader of a Church that forbids the priesthood to women and that in many Catholic marriages we read a part of the Gospel in which the bride swears obedience to her husband. I wonder if these designs help to combat culturally the scourge we are dealing with today, namely the violence of men against women?

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response. – The Pope told us this morning about dignity, of transcendent dignity. I believe that dignity is above all things and talking about the dignity of people, of course, has to do with the majority of the population. The majority of the population is women and the Pope has expressly spoken that there is nothing above the dignity of people.

name: Malin Björk
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking all the women who have worked tirelessly before us to put this issue on the political agenda. I would particularly like to thank my predecessor Eva-Britt Svensson, former chairman of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, for her work in this area. It is with their work behind them that we are calling for action today. Commissioner Jourova, several colleagues have taken up statistics. It is a frightening read, but above all it is figures that show a reality, an unacceptable reality. A reality in which women are abused simply because they are women and where women and girls are de facto without rights because the judiciary does not judge the perpetrators. How can this continue?, we must ask ourselves. Well, the answer is that we have a culture and a power order that subordinates women compared to men. I agree that it is not something that the Pope has taken on, quite the contrary. A culture in which women's bodies do not belong to ourselves, where we constantly have to endure sexist comments. Groping and intimidation are everyday life for women and girls. Everyone knows a girl who's been raped, but no one knows a rapist. When women take their place in public, we are sexually harassed. It's a reality, but now there are no excuses anymore. Now we are calling for action and I am pleased, Commissioner Jourova, to hear that you intend to act, that you intend to produce legislation, because that is needed, and that you intend to press for the EU to ratify the Instanbul Convention as well as the Member States and to have a European year against violence against women.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, it is not often said, but I do want to say it. The inequality and society of inequality in which we are living is an obvious driver of the growth of violence. And the suppression of public services and cuts are now a problem that is generating this uptick in violence. I will not repeat the figures already given by many of my colleagues, but I do want to say that today, 25 November, it is also important to claim that we continue without a specific legislative instrument for combating violence at European level. You have spoken that, of course, in the gender equality strategy we will put references and instruments, but we do not have a specific legislative istrument and I hope we can have it. I also have to say that I didn't like him saying that the Observatory against Gender-Based Violence didn't seem like a good idea to him. I think it is very necessary in view of the situation we have to face. And on the Istanbul Convention — I share with you, Commissioner, the view that its ratification by all Member States is important — I have to say that the Convention does not replace, nor does its ratification replace the fact that we need a specific legislative instrument at European level. I would therefore like to instruct you and ask you, from the position you are now in, to promote the creation of this instrument, which we need at European level.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today is World Day against Violence against Women and we are here trying to persuade the Commission to legislate on the substance. Although some competences fall to the Member States, we would have expected a legislative initiative to be launched by the Commission at least as far as it is responsible, not least given that many States, including Italy, have already ratified the Istanbul Convention and legislated to that effect. Violence against women is not only physical, but is often also and above all psychological, frequently closed in the home and often consumed in the face of the helpless gaze of minors. There are often alarm bells that go unheeded because of objectively inadequate legislation, for which tragedies could have been avoided if action had been taken in good time. I am thinking of the case of Lucia Annibali, disfigured with acid by two assassins hired by her ex-boyfriend, up to the very recent case of Cisterna di Latina where a man already denounced several times for ill-treatment killed his wife and then committed suicide in front of the eyes of his children of six and seven years. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not forget that feminicides are constantly increasing. As can be seen from the latest Eures report for 2013, only in Italy there were one hundred and seventy-nine cases... (The President withdrew the speaker's floor.)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Madam President, who walks down the street in an elegant suit with an expensive wristwatch on his hands after dark, he'll take it upon himself to be attacked and robbed. Wouldn't it be weird if the police posted a crime prevention video like that? He publishes something similar when it comes to female victims and rape. Unfortunately, this is exactly the kind of thing that happened in my own country, a video like this. I suggest a more efficient and fairer video. He's a male police officer, he's a camera, and all he's saying is that whoever commits a rape is found, brought to justice and sent to prison because rape is a serious crime.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to note that the European Executive does not consider the time for shared legislation on the prevention and fight against gender-based violence to be ripe leaves me somewhat perplexed today. I would like to remind the Commission that it itself recognised gender-based violence as the main obstacle to achieving genuine gender equality. What, then, should we attribute the lack of transposition of the Parvanova report into legislation? The reluctance of the Member States or the economic difficulties? Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament has long insisted that a proposal for a directive should finally be presented which would put an end to the impunity of feminicide, promote the exchange of good practice, support the capacity of care at national level for the benefit of the victims and improve their access to justice.  Commissioner, at the beginning of your speech, you pitted a number of percentage figures: 33 % of women have been victims of sexual violence since the age of fifteen, 20-25 % of women are victims of physical abuse at least once in their lives, but do you believe that these existing means of intervention are sufficient to ensure adequate protection for victims? I am convinced that these numbers are sufficient to justify the implementation of a pan-European measure establishing shared references. Today, on this important day, we must talk about women and violence against women, because it is a question of civilisation and democracy as a whole.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D). -
text: Last week, a 20-year-old student was raped and brutally murdered in my home country in Lithuania, which, as her mother said, would not even dare hurt the beetle. And so one in three women in our developed, democratic Europe is subjected to violence based on their gender. Seven women die from violence every day in Europe. Can we still ignore this level of human rights violations? Is this acceptable to us? The answer is by no means no. That is why we In the European Parliament will never stop calling on the Commission to table a proposal for a European Union directive on combating violence against women. I am personally convinced that one individual measure will not help to eliminate violence against women. We need to take concerted action in all areas: law, courts, enforcement, infrastructure, culture, education, social. And only in this way can the result be achieved. I also call on the Commission to set up a European Observatory on Violence against Women and Girls. And this could be done by creating not new institutions, but by broading the possibilities for the European Institute for Gender Equality to fulfil this function.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR). -
text: Dear! Today, Pope Francis here in the European Parliament said that forgetting God breeds violence. Everyone has an inalienable right to dignity, and violence that affects human dignity is a very serious social problem. Every day, women all over the world experience physical, sexual, cyberbullying, psychological violence. A very high level of violence exists in developing countries: collective rape, trafficking in women, murder of Muslim women. Europe is also not free from violence. We must not accept this. We must target our actions to every form and form of violence where women need it most. However, putting pressure on the creation of further legislation at European level will not solve the problem of violence.  Given that the Member States of the Union have extensive legislation in this area in line with their needs, circumstances and culture, there is no justification for multiplying legal solutions at European level. Individual countries with legislation in this area should consistently comply with it. Thank you.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, this year a report was released by the EU Fundamental Rights Agency. It showed us the current extent of violent crimes against women and the chronic under-reporting that leads lawmakers and law enforcers to become complacent about the problem. In fact, one in ten women has experienced some form of sexual violence, one in twenty has been raped and one in five has experienced some sort of physical or sexual violence from a current or previous partner. These are terrifying statistics. So far the Commission has been less than forthcoming in response to the Parvanova Report. This called for a legislative proposal by the end of 2014. It asked for a European strategy and an action plan. And it is nearly December, and so far it has not been seen. Thankfully the Commission has picked up on the issue of female genital mutilation (FGM), important in taking European action on violence against women. But again we have yet to see the plan. We have to act now on FGM. It is taking place on European soil and it is European women that are being cut. Violence against women in all its forms – FGM, domestic violence and the exploitation and trafficking of vulnerable women – must be tackled with commitment by all of us. These issues cannot be seen in isolation but rather as part of a larger problem: society’s attitude to women. We need action plans at an EU level and at Member State level, and we need them now.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, you will allow me to sit in my seat and not stand up because of my situation. The figures on physical and psychological violence are overwhelming: some 13 million women report victims of physical violence, i.e. 7% of European women, aged 18 to 74. Violence against women has many faces, knows no borders and classes, is imposed in cruel and relentless ways, is experienced within the family, in society and in recent years very often at work. Personally, I have experienced cruel violence to stop claiming the rights of a class of people and not to make their voices heard. But now a new wave of economic violence is being revived in Greece. An employer has asked an advanced pregnancy worker to terminate the pregnancy if she wants to have a job. Phenomena such as these, workers of women who are afraid to declare their pregnancy because the employer does not wish to commit to not firing them for the eighteen months following childbirth, are daily in the countries to which the strict budgetary programmes have been imposed. We must tackle violence so unprovoked even against motherhood with legislation combined with the ratification of the Council of Europe Convention, the well-known Istanbul Convention. We must create an effective framework for legal protection.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 62 million women in Europe say they have been victims of sexual or physical violence at least once in their lives. I say: this figure is a scandal! This figure can no longer be ignored and you, Commissioner, you cannot just find out!  Now, what are the real questions? How is it possible that rape is still not recognised as a criminal offence by all Member States? Who can believe that in 2014, the Istanbul Convention, which provides a comprehensive framework to prevent violence, to protect victims, to prosecute perpetrators, will only be ratified by seven Member States? How is it that you, the Commission, always and again refuse to put forward a legislative proposal on preventive measures? We have to act here and now.  We want a European observer of violence against women. We want a binding legal framework to harmonize, particularly from the top, prevention measures, and you need to put pressure on the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention. In conclusion, I would say that we can no longer wait. It is time, ladies and gentlemen, to get women out of the law-free zone in which Europe has locked them up. (Applause)

name: Margot Parker (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, one thing I am sure none of you will mention is the complete free movement of people across the EU. Because of this open-door immigration policy, we cannot even check the criminal backgrounds of newcomers. People with convictions for abuse, violence, and often, of course, criminal gangs trafficking women across the EU have complete, free access to the UK with no questions asked. We cannot even do a background check, thanks to EU rules. It is, of course, completely mad. So before you start calling for more useless, bureaucratic, unaccountable and expensive EU quangos, let us stop giving criminals and people with convictions for abuse free access to our countries. What we need is proper border controls with checks, which will make it more difficult for criminal gangs trafficking people and those with a history of violence to enter the country. Then, and only then, can we have a better chance of dealing with the problems that we already have. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Arena (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, excuse me, but I am really exacerbated by what I have just heard.  On the assumption that the issue of rape is the issue of foreigners, I think, Madam, that on your part as a parliamentarian is unacceptable.

name: President. -
text: It was more a statement, but I will give you the floor to respond.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. –  I would simply draw your attention to quite a tragic murder in my country, two months ago, of a young woman who, sadly, lost her life. There was a conviction of, I believe, a Lithuanian guy who had already been convicted of murder. So, he came freely into that country. Maybe a life would have been saved if checks and balance had been in place. Do not underestimate the value of checking your borders with criminals, please. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I am intrigued that you think you can stop free movement. Can you tell me how you can check that Scottish criminals do not move to London or London criminals move to Northern Ireland?

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – It is not a question of checking that, it is a question of actually knowing where these people are when they have criminal records, and making sure that people, innocent victims – actually we need to know where these people are. It is vital that we protect our women, really it is. No, I am sorry, I do not accept that.

name: Georg Mayer (NI). -
text: Madam President! The other side will be shocked right now. Equality between men and women is unnatural. Now I have your attention. However, this does not come from me, as comes from the Turkish President, Mr Erdogan, who has said this in recent days. I commend this discussion that we can have here today, because that is an important issue. Violence against women is a serious issue that we should certainly address. Unfortunately, there are still tragic cases of violence and oppression of women in the 21st century. This is not just the case in countries such as Turkey, where 34% of women have been victims of violence before. This is also the case in Sweden, which, according to UN statistics, ranks third behind Botswana and Lesotho when it comes to registered rapes. But this is also the case in Belgium, france and the United Kingdom. I recall the case of Rotherham, where thousands of girls were tortured over decades. What do you think this increase is, ladies and gentlemen? You know very well, and I think it is necessary to put off the politically correct glasses in these matters. We know that, with unbridled immigration, we have attracted men who have a completely different image of women than we do.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE). -
text: Madam President, "No matter what effort you put into annihilating everything inside us. Inside me they couldn't annihilate anything. I won't give up. As long as I can keep walking, I'll hold out. I will find strength within me" (Enisa, survivor of a war violation in Bosnia). Indeed, gender-based violence is a global pandemic and a violation of human rights. It can take on multiple forms: economic, physical, psychic, material, sexual, white trafficking, forced marriage, child marriage... A third of women in the European Union accept and claim that they have been victims at some point in their lives of gender-based violence. Adolescent behaviors and new harassment with new technologies, cyberbullying, are particularly concerned. Teenagers are digital natives and often teens themselves are unaware of this cyberbullying. Two billion six hundred million women and girls live in countries where sexual rape is not expressly punished. And, no doubt, poverty increases the risk of violence. That is why a European strategy is so important that it can harmonise the systems of the 28 countries of the Union. The European Year against Violence against Women is also important, because it really shows that it is a problem in which the whole of society has to be involved. We call for prevention, policy, protection, persecution, benefits, partnership, in short, breaking the silence. My last words are for the most vulnerable groups: gay, lesbian, transgender, intersex, immigrant, disabled and girls.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D). -
text: I would like to talk about the Istanbul Convention which enshrines women's rights. Prevention, investigating and punishing underlies this document but doubts are also given to the implementation of these objectives.  We have already said that in Europe 62 million women have been victims of physical and/or sexual violence, but there are 500,000 women and girls who have been subjected to female genital mutilation. 180,000 are at risk from this cruel practice. What do we have in concrete to prevent these women from being mutilated and cut off in their dignity?  With the Istanbul Convention, it was certain that women would now be more protected. The truth is that the numbers of violence against women show what has not yet been done.  What legislative measures are being taken by the Member States that have ratified the Treaty of Istanbul? What preventive measures will be implemented? What monitoring mechanisms will be created? What sanctions will be imposed? What force is the Commission doing to ensure that the Convention is actually ratified by all Member States? It is only by mere chance, and I am already done, and some irony, that this Convention is called Istanbul, looking at the statements made by the President of Turkey, who considers that equality between men and women is against nature.

name: Julie Girling (ECR). -
text: Madam President, nobody here is in favour of violence against women, of course. But what we should be doing is uniting in coming forward with ways in which we think that in this place, from the European Parliament, we can actually help, actually do something. All 28 Member States have legislation in place making violence against women a criminal offence, but they do not always enforce it. Let us learn from each other. We have come a long way and we can go further. In London, thirty years ago, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, Sir Kenneth Newman, who was in charge of police for the whole of London, said: ‘stray dogs and domestic violence [are] rubbish work for police officers’. Now it is unthinkable that he would say that today, but still, on average, two women per week are killed by their partners in the United Kingdom. But what have we done? Well, we have criminalised FGM, we have criminalised forced marriage, we have passed something called Clare’s Law, which allows the police to disclose information on request about a partner’s previous history of violence, thus waiving that partner’s rights to protection under the Data Protection Act. So, ladies and gentlemen, please let us get together, let us find ways of working together to end this, rather than squabbling about how we attack the Commission.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Europe needs all its partners to share an ethical, legal and material assistance we offer to victims of violence against women and the one that often accompanies it, that directed against minors. There is no European legislation on this because we do not have the consensus that we have reached against other crimes such as terrorism. We miss the same unity in the face of sexist violence — a consequence of inequality — and ideas about possession and violence solidly installed in the subconscious of many Europeans.  We do want European legislation, comparable statistics and shared values. No European state can continue to see this issue as a private problem. Lacking active policies or not including the fight against sexist violence on a State's work agenda violates the Treaties.  Would you be prepared, Commissioner, to sanction the Governments for this?

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Violence is a global scourge and a global shame that spares no country or continent. It is the result of many years of ongoing discrimination against women, the fight against which is one of the European Union's priority values and responsibilities. I therefore strongly support the idea that the European Union should accede to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women, because this Convention is recognised as the gold standard for anti-violence policies by the international community and treats prevention properly, rightly tying anti-violence policy to gender equality policy. Dear! The efforts we are making in the Member States to combat violence require proper evaluation and monitoring, which in turn requires access to comparable data that means the same thing. Harmonisation and standardisation of data on violence, standardisation of methods for assessing violence is very important. I therefore ask the European Commission whether it is possible to make a recommendation and, ultimately, perhaps a directive that properly standardises and harmonises the methods of assessing anti-violence policies, because without this we will not be able to develop more effective methods of combating this cruel phenomenon.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D). -
text: Thank you, Madam President, "The Unmeathed Cry of Violence", which is what we called a few days ago the forum in Bulgaria dedicated to combating violence against women. These words do not contain only a sad finding, but a will to deal with this problem. The message of the victims, of the institutions, of civil society organisations, which I must today convey to you, colleagues, to the European Commission, to you, Commissioner, is: not new bodies and institutions, but a strategy and laws that must not just protect, but prevent those crimes that we are afraid to talk about, but we see more and more every day. We do not have enough tools at either European or national level. It is imperative that the Istanbul Convention be ratified and operational, not just a piece of paper. Because paradoxically, it is signed in Turkey, and today Erdogan declares that women should stay home. The Bulgarian Women's Lobby has launched an initiative to collect one million signatures. It leaves from the Bulgarian city of Yambol, but will reach all women in Europe in order to be able to develop the necessary directive and laws.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE). -
text: Sinjar President.
