name: Biljana Borzan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, we speak today for those who remain silent. They shut up because they're afraid, they keep quiet because they're ashamed, and there's a lot of them, too many of them. Last year alone, 3.7 million women were victims of sexual violence. As much as 80% of the violence has not been reported to the police at all. Particularly regrettable are cases of bullying on social media where children adopt behaviour that is intolerable. We must fight this problem with legislative measures uniform at Union level. No declarative measures are sufficient here. I must point out that the budget to combat violence is about a thousand times smaller than what the real needs are. We must end the culture of silence in which the victim of crime feels shame. Shame should be on the perpetrators, but also for the Commission, which has so far refused to address this problem. I hope, Madam Commissioner, you'll change that.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul I would remind Commissioner Jourova that last spring the European Parliament asked the Commission to present a legislative proposal by the end of 2014 setting out measures to promote and support Member States' efforts to prevent violence against women and girls. We're running out of time. Women and girls across Europe are still victims of violence and it would be embarrassing if the Commissioner did not act in every possible way to combat and prevent this violence. The EU must ratify the Instanbul Convention and actively call on the Member States to do the same.  I would also encourage the Commissioner to ensure that 2016 is established as a European Year against Violence against Women and Girls, to show that this violence is a major problem that affects everyone, and also to present a clear action plan that puts an end to this violence. The new Commission now has a golden opportunity to show that gender equality and stopping violence against women are a priority. I hope and expect you to take your chances now. Europe's women and girls are counting on it.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D). -
text: Madam President! I would like to use the framework of this discussion to talk not only about the Istanbul Convention, but also about the European protection order that you mentioned at the beginning, Commissioner. Although victim protection measures exist in all EU countries, they have so far only been enforced in the EU country in which they were obtained. The principle of mutual recognition now protects women, for example, from stalking men when they travel from one country to another and stay there longer. That is why I am now taking this opportunity to call on the Member States to implement by 11 January 2015 what we have decided on the European protection order, because it is so often sickened here in Europe. Wonderful things are decided, but they are not implemented. And, of course, that also applies to the Istanbul Convention. It is a disgrace not to implement them quickly.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D). -
text: Madam President, today the International Day against Gender-Based Violence is commemorated and I would like to begin by saying that I miss the opening of this session with a solemn act, an act on the part of the European Parliament, as perhaps I also miss the fact that precisely this part of the session was chaired by a president, in order to raise awareness among the other colleagues. This is a matter of the first magnitude, of murders, of attacks on dignity, against fundamental rights, against the human rights of women. And we have to be aware that we are all accomplices by action or by omission. Passivity also instills in us and neutrality with regard to gender-based violence is not possible in 21st-century Europe. Commissioner, throughout history Europe has set the way for the rest of the world to achieve a fairer society. We cannot give up leading this challenge and I would ask you to lead an effective commitment by all Member States to the implementation of a directive.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Commissioner, I would like to address you personally. You rightly point out that men must also become actors of action when it comes to stopping violence against women. I appeal to you in particular today: first of all, the Commission must, and first of all, you must become an actor in action when it comes to stopping violence against women. You have a responsibility, you must not hide behind the Member States! The Commission has been repeatedly called upon by the European Parliament to finally present a directive against violence against women. It is about dignity, it is about physical and mental health, and it is about the sexual self-determination of half the population in all the Member States. You say today: 'Everything should be worked out once'. I say to you: the background and the facts have been worked out a long time ago, and action must now finally be taken! Anyone who waits is guilty. Violence is not a cavalier offence, and to look away is not a cavalier offence!

name: Linda McAvan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, as Chair of the International Development Committee, I want to talk about something we have not talked about much, which is the issue of gender-based violence and combating it through our external policies. In particular, I would like to talk about the issue of gender-based violence during emergencies and how we can make our humanitarian aid and our development aid better able to tackle that problem, which – as we know – is a growing problem. Last week I met members of the International Rescue Committee, who work with women in such situations. They want all Member States to sign up to the call for action to end sexual violence in emergencies. Many of your Member States have not signed up. Please urge them to do so.  Tomorrow we will give the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has tackled gender-based violence and who provides care to women who have been victims. Next year you will be looking at the Gender Action Plan in the Commission. We need the Action Plan to be a real plan for real action. I hope that this will be a testimony to the work of Dr Mukwege and that it will be something we can come back to next year and say we have really achieved something.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on this day I too would like to ask the new Commissioner Jourová for a firm commitment to taking concrete and effective measures to tackle one of the social scourges involving hundreds of thousands of women around the world. Women who, even in the most advanced countries, suffer violence and harassment, which all too often take place within the safest place, which is that of the family.  Unfortunately, the current instruments are totally inadequate, as they are not binding, to deal with this problem, which is increasing in numbers and percentages by the day. The problem of gender-based violence cannot affect individual Member States; This is a global dramatic problem, which must remind us of a strong and collective responsibility, first moral and then political, which commits Europe to a pan-European initiative, which starts with an educational and cultural campaign aimed primarily at the new generations and which, however, leads immediately and quickly to the adoption of a new directive. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: question ("blue card"). Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have listened very carefully and I think it is terribly important that we bring this up. I think it is great that so many people have spoken, but precisely about this family violence, I have not heard hardly anything, or about honour-related violence, which is becoming a bigger and bigger problem in europe. We can see it in Sweden especially, where we see one balcony girl after another fall out. So I also think you should raise this.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I do not believe that this view belongs to me. Frankly, I note that the violence that is taking place against women is still a cultural, highly cultural problem. Gender discrimination that often takes place within the family, even in relations between partners, where, of course, women's emancipation still weighs, in some cases. But calling it violence out of honor, frankly, takes me back to a very distant time, which I hope is outdated.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I am the third man in this debate. It is true that it is too little, as you pointed out, and, indeed, many of us are displaying the white ribbon today, a symbol of this campaign against violence against women. The White Ribbon is a campaign decided by men in Canada twenty-five years ago, following a heinous crime on a technology campus where an unbalanced man murdered fourteen young girls. I want to go back to a fundamental issue, in this case, the possibility of declaring a year dedicated to the fight against violence against women. Commissioner, I am speaking to you because four years ago, with several colleagues, namely, Mrs Barbara Matera, who is still with us, but also Mrs Parkanov, from the ALDE group at the time, from Mrs' 'I propose to put back on the carpet a written statement ' I know that this is a symbolic work that can be done in this Parliament- , I hope, will collect a majority of signatures, so that you can consider the opportunity to devote a year to the fight against violence against women.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the fact that tomorrow we will declare Dr. Denis Mukwege laureate of the Sakharov Prize speaks volumes about the reasons why he will receive this award, which is the struggle for the dignity of a woman. Like Malala last year. That's one optimistic fact. Another is the fact that Ms. Věra Jourová has become our trustee and has explicit gender equality in her portfolio, i.e. caring for women. The third of the facts we all experienced here today was the address of The Holy Father Pope Francis, who told us and said that we must return man and dignity to the center. So those facts make me optimistic.  However, also every year here on 25 November, whether in this Parliament or in another, we symbolically remember the fight against violence against women and I don't think that should remain symbolic in any way. I agree that we must urgently ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE). -
text: The most important thing is to change social attitudes, both in Europe and around the world, as long as women are primarily engaged in and combating violence against women. It shows that, far from being right, things are far from right. In my previous office, I also encountered high-ranking leaders from many parts of the world, and some of them still told an absolutely unbelievable story about how systemic, such as sexual violence for security reasons, political control in their country is perfectly normal and that it is a tradition. Such justifications, which speak of tradition or culture, should not be accepted by anyone in today's world – this is not the 21st century. It is clear that the European Union must also do legally everything we can today to have zero tolerance for violence against women in societies. This concerns legislation, it concerns the much-talked about ratification of the Istanbul Convention, but also of Europe's own new legislation. I think that what we are discussing here today is basically the most important issue in this House today.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, we must deepen political and citizen agreement and commitment to walk towards common living spaces free from sexist violence. This must be present, as a matter of priority and permanently, on the political agenda of any institution, including, of course, this Parliament, although I do not know whether this image reflects this or that we are really aware of it. They are not isolated or exceptional acts. It's a major political problem. Sexist violence is an expression of the patriarchal system, its most serious consequence or representation. But this violence, which, of course, is also ideological and verbal, is embedded in the current social order, that is, it is structural. An entire system supports, protects, sustains and enables this type of violence. Clearly, it is a powerful means of maintaining power relations between men and women, so I would like to focus on the need for social transformation based on equal relations in all walks of life. It's absolutely urgent.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE). -
text: Madam President, may I say to the Commissioner that I welcome the proposal that we have an EU Year to End Violence against Women to acknowledge this issue. I also, Commissioner, welcome your strategy on equality between men and women to include a chapter on gender-based violence. I think that would be very important. We have all spoken here today about violence against women and asked how we can move forward in this area. One area where we can move forward is to ratify – for everybody to ratify – the Istanbul Convention. Commissioner, you said that only eight countries have ratified this Convention. My own country has not ratified the Convention. I have spoken to our Minister for Justice, and we intend to do it by this time next year, when everything is in place. We have had difficulties with constitutional rights and property rights under our Constitution when it comes to barring orders. But I think this is the single issue that is in front of us all: that only eight members have ratified the Istanbul Convention, while twenty have not. I think this is a question for us all here today. If we could do that, we would be one step forward in unifying our fight against violence across all sectors.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is taking place on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which makes us reflect even more on the seriousness of this phenomenon in all the countries of the Union. In Italy, for example, the annual report on voluntary murder prepared by an accredited study and research centre and published last week showed that 179 women were killed in 2013, or one victim every two days, and that compared to 2012 there was a 14% increase in these serious crimes. And alarming and unfortunately growing figures are recorded in many other Member States of the Union.  It is therefore clear that we now need cohesive action by the Member States in the field of prevention and support for women who are victims of violence and, in some cases, their children who, let us not forget, are themselves victims of assisted violence, with serious consequences for their serenity and for their mental development.  I would therefore specifically ask the Commission to take further legislative measures in addition to those that already exist, but which are clearly insufficient, and to call for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by all member countries and by the Union itself.

name: Vĕra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for this valuable, important discussion. I take a lot of inspiration and strength from it for what I am going to do in the Commission. You are calling for a new directive. I have experience. If I promise here a new directive, it will then be a good excuse to wait for the new directive. I do not want to wait, because this is the time for action. We have other instruments in the meantime, before we decide whether to adopt a new directive, to do many things using the instruments I spoke about before. I will push for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. That is clear. We will work on the action plan as the plan for real action. There will be solid, robust analyses, proposals for legislative and non-legislative steps, a time-frame, finance and responsibility. You can rely on me. This is something we can do and we will do over the next year. We need to have a permanent campaign concerning the media as well. We did not speak much – or indeed at all – about provocative advertisements and the abuse of women in this commercial sphere. This is something that is forming the idea that it is normal to abuse women. But this is not normal. I will finish with this last comment, because I know we have a shortage of time. It will be a little personal. We spoke about statistics and said that every third woman experiences violence. I will do my ‘coming out’ here. Many years ago, I had experience of violence being carried out against me, and many times in my life I was subjected to verbal harassment. I do not want you to experience the same, dear ladies here, but it would be interesting if we could express ourselves – we who are now influencing the situation and can help the situation with our own experiences. It was many years ago, and I remember feeling that it was sort of normal and it was my shame, but this is – and must be – the shame of those who commit violence, and not the shame of the victims. (Applause) Before we alert men to change their behaviour, we should impress this upon women: please do not accept this as a normal situation. Help us in our attempts. I will finish with this, and I look forward to cooperating with you, because this is a real, serious problem that we have to deal with.

name: President. -
text: Commissioner Jourová, thank you for your great humanity and your openness in terms of your own experience of violence. When we quote statistics we do need to personalise it, so I am sure it has been difficult for you to do that. But I think it has been appreciated by the House, and thank you for it. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – 25 November marks the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Violence against women is one of the most treacherous violations of human rights and exists on every continent, in every country and culture. It also exists in economically developed and developing countries. Rape, rape used as a weapon of war, forced marriages, marriages at young ages, crimes for dowry and crimes in the name of honour, trafficking in women and girls, female genital mutilation and selective abortion based on sex are all manifestations of violence against women. We currently have worrying statistics worldwide. UN estimates show that abuse against women is on the rise. The most common form of violence against them worldwide is physical violence. On average, at least one in three women is beaten, forced to have sexual relations or subjected to other types of abuse. It must be moved from words to deeds, by applying measures that prove to be the most effective in the fight against gender discrimination. States must devote more resources to making combating violence against women a priority, as promoting equal opportunities, non-violent behaviour and non-stigmatising victims is a necessity.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Written. – Even in the 21st century, we still encounter psychological and physical violence to which all women around the world are subjected. Violence against women is the most brutal form of gender inequality and violates fundamental human rights. One in five EU women were subjected to psychological violence and one in ten women were also subjected to sexual violence. The EC seeks legislation to prevent violence against women. Women need to be protected throughout the EU, and we must therefore ensure that recognised detention and protective ties that have been issued in one Member State and are automatically recognised in all Member States. This will allow women at risk of domestic violence to move freely throughout the EU. However, it should also be remembered that women who are subjected to physical violence rarely report an attack on their person to the competent authorities. Complaints should therefore be collected and recorded more thoroughly in the future and a database of rapists should be set up that can be compared across Member States. Violence against women is a very serious societal problem that must not be overlooked. I therefore very much welcome the activities of the European Commission through the DAPHNE III and PROGRESS programmes, which will continue in the future through the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme.

name: Gál Kinga (PPE)
text: Writing. – Violence against women is present in all societies, be it physical, psychological or sexual violence. A recent report by the Fundamental Rights Agency shows shocking data in this area. According to the survey, one in three women has experienced sexual and/or physical violence since the age of 15. It is important to be aware that this figure does not apply to third countries, but to EU Member States. Violence against women has a serious impact on both the individual and society. Still, for the most part, victims prefer to remain silent. Surveys in this area show that there are far more cases in reality than the statistics of the judiciary speak of. This urgent problem needs to be addressd at EU level, as violence against women violates the most fundamental rights.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing – Sexual violence and violence against women are still an emphatic social problem that persomes our daily lives, not only at home, behind closed walls, but also in workplaces, public places, the Internet and even schools, but despite the fact that cases are commonplace, they are often only revealed in the rarest or most extreme cases. The frequency of violent acts is confirmed by various research and police statistics, yet it is certain that countless cases will remain in obscurity, intimidated victims will not dare to go public, many may not even dare to admit to themselves that what they have experienced is not a natural part of everyday life and that it must be (should) be taken as harshly as possible. I believe that measures should be taken to a higher level, political will must be directed in order to take this problem seriously, both at social and EU level! A solution to this could be to delegate this issue to the EU level, in the form of legislation, in order to comply with the EP's previous request.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today is International Day Against Gender Violence. According to data from the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, one third of EU women have experienced physical or sexual violence at some point since the age of fifteen. Only six European countries have adequate legislation on this subject, according to the Council of Europe. This means that European women who are victims of sexist violence have different levels of protection depending on their country. We cannot allow it; women have the right to be covered and protected at the same level in all EU countries. And the European Commission, with its attitude in considering that there is no need to submit a legislative proposal on prevention measures at European level, is denying us this right and looking the other way at this social scourge. Just this year marks the tenth anniversary of the Spanish Comprehensive Law against Gender Violence, considered by experts to be one of the most advanced in the world. All Member States should move in this direction and, from the EP, we once again demand the imminent need for a European directive that protects all women and girls victims of sexist inequality equally.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – An estimated one in three women in the EU have suffered physical and/or sexual violence at least once since the age of 15. In Birmingham, one of the larger cities in my region, there will have been 1 400 victims of sexual assault in the last year. That is 1 400 persons who have seen their worst nightmare become reality.  These figures are staggering, and it is likely they are only the tip of the iceberg, as violence against women is notoriously under-reported. It therefore is surprising, to say the least, that the Commission has deemed inappropriate submitting a proposal for a legislative act establishing measures to promote the action of Member States for prevention of violence against women and girls (VAWG), and has not implemented an EU-wide strategy and action plan, as Parliament requested. The onus is now on the Commission to take action to ensure cohesive EU action, and make sure existing legislation and law enforcement mechanisms are geared towards fighting VAWG in the most effective way possible. Undermining women’s ability to participate as full citizens in society, VAWG is spreading its poison throughout entire communities. Failing to take effective action will therefore mean failing us all.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. Data on violence against women across Europe remain alarming. We need to act with a more systemic approach in order to tackle such a deep-rooted problem: the ratification of the Istanbul Convention should be only the first of many steps. We need more funds to strengthen the structures for welcoming and supporting women who are victims of abuse and violence, more effective sanctions against the perpetrators of these shortcomings, but, at the same time, we also need to identify an overall strategy that acts on the prevention side: we need measures, legislative and not, to support a profound change in the conception of the role of women in our society. This is a European problem and it is at European level that it needs to be addressed: violence against women is not a subject disconnected from problems such as the employment rate of women, the pay gap, the under-representation of women at the top of decision-making in society. They are all interdependent on each other and should be addressed as such. To this end, it would be extremely important to declare 2016 the 'European Year for the End of Violence against Women', in order to increase attention to this issue and awareness, especially in young people, boys and girls.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. Violence against women is a dramatic social scourge that is still on the increase in Italy, in the countries of the European Union and beyond. In addition to legislating on this issue, administrative, legal and procedural procedures must be standardised throughout Europe. The inequality that still persists in the approach to these issues in the various Member States is not a positive diversity, and therefore a resource, but weakens the action of procedures by not guaranteeing victims of such violence adequate equal access. Victims of violence, most often being confined to their homes, often find it difficult, mainly for economic reasons, to denounce such shameful acts. Legal aid must really be extended and guaranteed because the other party's lawyers often have more scope and powers than the victims, which results in a procedural imbalance between prosecution and defence. Changing procedures and culture and preventing such violence by teaching gender-based respect from schools is a priority and urgent one to combat this emergency.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – Violence against women is the most widespread violation of human rights in the world, affecting all strata of society, regardless of age, level of education, income, social position and country of origin or residence. We're not talking about a marginal group, we're talking about half the population. The European Union must be a space free of gender-based violence: one in three women has been the victim of some form of violence, physical, psychic or sexual, and seven women die every day from this cause. We cannot accept that the Commission makes an excuse for lack of competition. Citizens will not understand that European leaders have agreed to save banks and are unable to agree on life-saving measures for women. The last parliamentary term a large majority of this House agreed on the need to promote legislative action in this area as has already been done in some Member States. A comprehensive European strategy is needed, acting in all areas: prevention, treatment, protection and police, legal, economic and social measures, not to mention educational ones.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing.– Dear colleagues, on 25 November we commemorate the International Day Against Violence against Women. I find it alarming that even today, in the twenty-first century, a third of European women under the age of 15 have experienced some form of sexual violence. I therefore call for stronger measures to be taken across Europe to prevent violence against women, whether psychological or physical abuse. In this context, it is important that this year's Sakharov Prize was awarded to Denis Mukwege, a Congos doctor who dedicated his career mainly to helping victims of sex crimes. I therefore join the call for the European Union and its Member States, which have not yet done so, to sign and ratify the Istanbul Treaty. It is the first legally binding international instrument that creates a legal framework for protecting women against all forms of violence and prosecuting its perpetrators. There is also a need to raise general awareness of this issue, so it would be desirable for 2016 to be declared the European Year for Combating Violence against Women.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Every day, seven sexist men murder women. Every day, sexist men exercise multiple forms of violence against women Every day, governments and institutions, including in the European Union, develop and enforce violent laws against women, because they criminalize us, for example, laws that limit or prohibit the right to abortion. The multiple feminist struggles have slowly gotten laws against violence passed, for equality, but it is still not enough. Often these laws are passed because in our environment it would not be well seen to reject them, but then they do not advance because there is a lot of laxity when it comes to implementing them, they are not allocated sufficient funds, or they are simply forgotten. Some say that at this rate equality will not be possible for five hundred years to come. I think we have a responsibility to act to reduce these forecasts considerably. Ending patriarchy is essential to ending this situation. That is why I propose that the European Commission should assume the feminist agenda and perspective as the basis for the development of all its policies. Only in this way will we achieve equal rights between men and women and the end of sexist violence.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing.– Every day, violence manifests itself physically or in more lysious ways, on women of all ages, all over the world. Gender violence should not be tolerated in societies that will be modern. We must ensure firm principles in terms of protecting women, children and all those who find it difficult to defend themselves.  Violence against women knows no borders, it extends across Europe. It is a phenomenon that is a real-life phenomenon that we want to build. We cannot accept living in a European society where at least 45% of women have been subjected to some form of violence or discrimination during their lifetime. We cannot accept that more than a quarter of all European women are victims of violence and physical gender abuse without us doing anything. We invest in the principles set out in the Istanbul Convention on the Elimination of Violence against Women. Romania quickly acceded to the principles of the Convention and will soon ratify this document. I am convinced that, together, we can overcome violence of any kind against women. Only together!

name: Elena Valenciano Martínez-Orozco (S&D)
text: in writing. – Violence against women is the most widespread violation of human rights in the world, affecting all strata of society, regardless of age, level of education, income, social position and country of origin or residence. We're not talking about a marginal group, we're talking about half the population. The European Union must be a space free of gender-based violence: one in three women has been the victim of some form of violence, physical, psychic or sexual, and seven women die every day from this cause. We cannot accept that the Commission makes an excuse for lack of competition. Citizens will not understand that European leaders have agreed to save banks and are unable to agree on life-saving measures for women. The last parliamentary term a large majority of this House agreed on the need to promote legislative action in this area as has already been done in some Member States. A comprehensive European strategy is needed, acting in all areas: prevention, treatment, protection and police, legal, economic and social measures, not to mention educational ones.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is sad to have 2014 and still talk about violence against women. Unfortunately, the phenomenon exists and is growing, which leads us to the conclusion that there are not enough complaints, resolutions, condemnations but that a full legislative framework is needed to radically address these shameful violations of women's human rights. 25 November should not be a day of finding the problem, but of tackling and reducing it. Between the two approaches, prevention and repression, the EU must focus on the former. It is absolutely necessary for all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention and for new legislation to further protect the rights of abused women. However, repressive policies follow crime when it has already taken place. There are two think-making nurseries, especially among young people: family and school. Fortunately, the phenomenon of domestic violence is the exception to the rule. We must therefore systematically ensure that there is special treatment at all stages of education, analysing the causes of violence, the profile of perpetrators/victims and the circumstances in which violence takes place. This will create a culture against violence and a radical change of mindset.

name: President. -
text: The next item is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000078/2014 – (2014/2907(RSP)) – B8-0037/2014), and – the oral question to the Commission on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000079/2014 – (2017/2907(RSP)) – B8-0038/2014).

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. - Madam President, the context for this oral question could not be more powerful and more precipitous. We have, approaching the Chair, our new Commissioner, Commissioner Avramopoulos, for his first debate. He is just about to take the Chair. We have in the Council Mr Gozi, the Italian Presidency of Mare Nostrum, which will shortly move to Operation Triton. Unfortunately, the inadequate sticking plaster which sees good people trying to save migrants in the Mediterranean could not prevent three thousand migrants from drowning in 2014 alone. Earlier this day, we heard His Holiness saying to us, in an excellent speech, that we cannot allow the Mediterranean to become a vast cemetery. But he also said, in a very mature passage, that we need a united response to the question of migration based on a recognition of the human dignity of immigrants. It was a very mature response, which also talked about the causes and effects of migration. Colleagues, it is in that spirit that we talk about our oral question today in front of the Commissioner and in front of the Council. This is not the first time that we talk about this issue. It is after many, many oral questions. Colleagues, we have the tools to do the job – of course we do. In the final paragraph of our oral resolution we talk about the common European Asylum System. How many times have we talked about it? How many trilogues have we had? How many pieces of directives and laws have we put together? Of course we have the tools to do the job. The issue is one of solidarity, and the issue is one of political action. We have something to say to the Commission and to the Council today, and particularly, Mr Gozi, to the Council, not to the Presidency – because within the Presidency we have had Mare Nostrum, which has saved 150 000. It is the Council which is not implementing the common European Asylum System. So I direct this primarily to the Council: we do not have solidarity. And that is why we had that powerful moral message earlier today. In our search and rescue obligations – the first part of our oral question which I put to both of you – we have moved from Mare Nostrum to Triton the inadequacy of that programme. Secondly, when we talk about broadening the activities of Frontex and Triton, we have an inadequacy. First we have to ask that question. The European Commission does its best, but if we do not have the Member States working together, we do not have adequate burden sharing. Then we have development of safe and legal routes. What does that mean? It means what His Holiness was talking about: causes and effects, the push and pull factors, and a common resettlement policy. I attended the Justice and Home Affairs Council in Milan, and there was clearly no real resettlement policy with real burden sharing across the Member States, since it was not equal across the Member States. When we talk about the context – and we will hear many Members talk about the context – please remember that, despite the austerity that we have, the top ten countries receiving refugees today from Syria and elsewhere are all among the world’s developing countries. Not one country in the top ten countries receiving refugees today is a European Union country – they are all developing countries. So let us put that into context. Yes, we are generous, but we are not there amongst the developing countries of the world taking the biggest burden. So let us remember that President Juncker, in his opening statement, talked about adequate legal migration channels. So we have to be brave and courageous in actually saying what that will mean. Not perhaps today, but let us refresh our vision about what that will mean. So colleagues, yes, emergency funds, migration and asylum border control, fighting smuggling and trafficking, EU foreign and development policy, what we do about common standards for reception procedures and qualifications – all of that is vital. But the key point, and I put this both to the Commission and Council – and particularly to the Council – is that we do not have implementation of our Common Asylum System. The purpose of the oral question today is not that the Parliament has not done its job – we have done our job. Rather, the point is that we can do more. I address this to my colleagues in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and across Parliament. What I would propose is that we say to the Council: implement what we have and stop people dying in the Mediterranean. But we should also have our inquiry to ensure that pressure is put on the Council, that we have resources put into an inquiry or an investigation into what is happening, so that we can look citizens in the eye and ensure that they know that we as a Parliament are doing everything possible to ensure that Mediterranean deaths are not happening week in and week out, and that we have a managed migration system that is worthy of our Parliament. We have to show our moral compass and what we are doing about our refugee and asylum policy.

name: Sandro Gozi
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Moraes most sincerely for having put in place issues that are fundamental, that are priorities, that are part of the major priorities of our presidency. High priorities, I stress this as President-in-Office, also with satisfaction with the Commission's programme chaired by Juncker, which identified immigration as one of its immediate priorities, which it also included in the 2015 legislative programme. This is certainly a very important point for us. It is very important because if there is one issue where the European Union can and must demonstrate its added value, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that is exactly immigration.  By definition and by nature, immigration is a cross-border phenomenon. By definition and by nature, a cross-border phenomenon needs a more integrated, more common and bolder response from the European Union. We have worked very hard during our six months to give concrete meaning to that principle, to that article of the Treaty which speaks of solidarity in the field of immigration. For me, that article is a principle, it is a political principle, it is a legally binding commitment, it is a political programme for the European Union. A political agenda on which we must work much more. It is much more in cooperation between the Council of Ministers, the Commission and Parliament. In his question the author referred to the work of the Mediterranean task force. As you know, Mr Moraes, there have already been 37 concrete and operational interventions by the Task Force in the Mediterranean around five priority areas for action. I would remind you of them: cooperation with third countries, regional protection programmes together with resettlement and strengthening of legal access opportunities in Europe, the fight against trafficking, trafficking and organised crime, the strengthening of border surveillance to help protect and rescue migrants in the Mediterranean, and measures to assist Member States facing strong migratory pressures. These are the areas on which the task force has worked and the task force has regularly reported to the Council. I trust that this information has been given, as well as to the Council, to the European Parliament.  Having said that, are we satisfied with today's situation? No, we are not satisfied and we share the words to which you referred, which you recalled of the Pontiff. We too always say that the Mediterranean cannot be a graveyard. And I would add that it cannot and cannot continue to be a graveyard of indifference and selfishness on the part of Europeans. That is the concrete meaning of the word solidarity. That is why we must work much harder to implement quickly the operational programme adopted by the Council of Ministers at its meeting in Luxembourg on 10 October. One of the conclusions, entitled 'Working towards better management of migratory flows', concerns a strategic approach to give a concrete response to migratory pressure around three broad guidelines, three major sectors, which are, among other things, those that we identified as priorities during our six-month period, certainly enhanced management and external borders. After years of work and years of very serious responsibility on the part of Europe in rejecting this principle, the principle has finally passed that the European Union's external borders are not Italian or Polish or Greek or Spanish borders. The external borders of the European Union are common borders and, being common borders, they require a common approach, common initiatives, hence also the initiative of Operation Triton, which you mentioned.  Of course, this is not enough, and this must go hand in hand with much more operational and much more effective cooperation with third countries. The dialogue with the countries of origin and transit must first be extended geographically, according to the Presidency. It must certainly continue to include North Africa, but mobility partnerships must become much more effective, they must be linked much more to economic cooperation, they must be linked much more to trade cooperation. It must also be extended to sub-Saharan Africa, and it is necessary – and this has been one of the works on which we have put a great deal of effort during our six months – that it should also be extended to the Horn of Africa. These are the areas to extend that approach to, which only the European Union can do. Only the European Union can really make a difference in these areas. There is also much to be done because the first experiences and partnerships for mobility are not satisfactory. Let us face it in this plenary. There's so much more to do, we have to work much harder to to make operational sense and to convince the countries of origin and transit to make a real effort to cooperate in a concrete, effective and tangible way with us in the management of migratory flows. And then there is the third area that you mentioned, namely supporting and fully implementing our common European asylum system. As President-in-Office, I do not want to and cannot, Mr President- Mr Moraes, I would like to go into some of the comments that you have made, which would relate to possible infringement procedures that may exist against the Member States, the task of the European Commission, or to the presentation of new legislative proposals, which we hope will be presented, but which fall within the institutional prerogatives of the Commission. All I am telling you is that progress has been made in this common European asylum system in recent years and also during our six months. There are more common rules, there is a reduced possibility of derogations, there is progress. I am also thinking of the new regulations within the Dublin system, which we as presidency consider to be some of the inadequate. There is no agreement in the Council, but we consider it to be partly inadequate to meet all the challenges.  Internally, however, there is room for flexibility which must be used for much more effective management of an issue which is extremely serious, in the general gravity of the issue of immigration, which is the issue of unaccompanied minors, on which the rules allow us to do much more, just as we have a new early warning mechanism. It is clear that in the years to come the emphasis must be on consolidating the system, completing the system and also fully implementing the various legislative and administrative instruments that this system requires in order to achieve a genuine common European asylum system, which is the third absolutely necessary element. To do what? In order to rebuild mutual trust between the Member States. Because what has happened in recent years, namely the fact that we have left some States alone to deal with a massive phenomenon such as immigration, which affects us all as Europeans, has been the lack of mutual trust between the Member States. It is essential, and that is why we need to work on the issue of borders, on the issue of dialogue with third countries, but also on the issue of a better asylum system, which means that the individual Member States must also improve their national asylum systems, because that is the only way to restore that mutual trust that is the essential prerequisite for a genuine new immigration policy.  It is with this in mind that, as the Presidency, during our six months we have proposed the principle of mutual recognition, on which there is still no agreement but which is certainly one of the answers to create the system to which you referred, but which needs a premise: we must return to trust each other. As long as there is no full mutual trust, there can be no common immigration policy that Europe can and must absolutely develop.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, migration was always part of the home affairs portfolio but was never before in the title. Now it is – for symbolic, but also for pragmatic, reasons. I would like to express my thanks to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and its Chair, Mr Moraes, for having given me the opportunity to be present today at this very important event. I would also like to quote what Pope Francis said this morning. I fully agree with what he said and I can tell him, on behalf of everybody, that this strong signal that was sent to us was received with full respect for his remarks. I make no secret of the fact that I am honoured to be responsible for this portfolio. At the same time I know that there is no easy solution to address the important tasks ahead of us. But I can assure you that there is a strong political will. Your extensive questions show the complexity of the challenges the European Union faces on migration and asylum. We are confronted with the highest migratory pressure at our external borders since the Balkan crisis. This requires an integrated approach covering all areas, including foreign and security policy. It requires restoring and building more mutual trust to successfully face these challenges – trust between the Member States, and between the Member States and the European Union. The sharing of solidarity and responsibility remains the foundation on which the Commission and the Member States are building a common European migration and asylum system with common standards and rights for migrants. Many tools for solidarity have been developed to put this into practice, such as the financial solidarity and supported guidance provided by the relevant agencies – the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Frontex. Relocation has been developed by the Commission, and we will continue to work on this. We have the early warning mechanism and the possibilities offered by Article 33 of the Dublin III Regulation. Some of these tools have already proved their worth. We need to further develop and use all of them as appropriate. Solidarity goes hand in hand with responsibility. All Member States must take full ownership of the proper functioning of the system. The full and effective implementation of the Common European Asylum System is an absolute priority. The Commission will closely monitor implementation by the Member States and support their efforts. The Commission will support the Member States in practical cooperation, notably through EASO. We also count on the continued engagement of non-governmental organisations and international partners such as the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. The Qualification Directive and the Dublin III Regulation are already in force, but the other instruments will only be applied from next July. So I do not see an urgent need for major changes to the asylum system in the very near future, but this is not ruled out for the medium term after careful consideration. Smuggling and trafficking have elements in common, but they are two separate criminal offences which required tailored responses. The EU’s response to trafficking in human beings will remain victim-centred and human rights-based. We must ensure protection for all victims and a strong criminal response to the traffickers, working closely with all the justice and home affairs agencies which implement actions on anti-trafficking. Prevention is key, and the Member States are obliged to take legal action to reduce the demand that fosters all forms of exploitation, whether this is by criminalising employers who use victims, or by holding companies liable or individuals who knowingly use victims. Smuggling is steadily increasing. We need to increase our response capacity. We need to build a stronger criminal justice response to stop this crime, investigating and prosecuting those in charge more severely. The EU plan that we intend to develop to counter migrant smuggling will focus both on dismantling the criminal networks through reinforced intelligence sharing, investigation capacities and prosecution, and on prevention, through information campaigns about the dangers of being smuggled into the European Union and enhanced cooperation with third countries. The response to the migratory pressures at the borders and smuggling should include a strengthened role for Frontex. To broaden the activities of Frontex, Member States must uphold their commitments to work with the Agency. Only they have the border guards and equipment to carry out such activities. Regarding joint operation Triton: as you know, this began on 1 November of this year, and its duration will depend on how the situation evolves. The Commission is following it closely, but the decision will be made by the Agency and the Member States involved. The estimated cost is EUR 2.9 million per month. To launch and finance it in the short term, the Agency performed internal reallocations and the Commission provided EUR 3.9 million via a direct transfer from resources available under the Internal Security Fund. The Commission is aware that Parliament has proposed an amendment to add a reserve of EUR 20 million to the 2015 Frontex budget. We look forward to the final joint decision on this by Parliament and the Council. Resettlement is for the time being effectively the only route of legal entry for a person in need of protection. It is the most tangible expression of international solidarity with refugees in third countries but also a tool to relieve some of the burden on host countries. While the decision whether to resettle and, if so, how many people lies with Member States, the Commission will continue its efforts to encourage them to increase quotas or, of course, to start resettlement for those not doing it yet. But something is out of balance here. Member States that receive the highest numbers of spontaneous asylum requests are also the ones that resettle the most refugees. The Commission intends to address the situation. Yesterday my services had a first orientation discussion with the Member States on a possible allocation or division mechanism. The Commission is already committed to exploring new avenues, in particular the possibility of developing a common approach to issuing humanitarian visas to allow those in need to come to Europe and apply for protection. This was also discussed during the meeting yesterday. I do realise that it remains a very sensitive issue. On legal migration: for obvious demographic and economic reasons, Europe needs to address labour and skill shortages and address the challenges of an ageing continent. We will work closely on this with business and social partners. Our first step will be to look at policies currently in place, such as the EU blue card, and see what can be done to increase their attractiveness and effectiveness. The answer to many of the challenges in the area of home affairs lies in our relations with third countries. We need to improve the link between the European Union’s internal and external policies, putting an emphasis on the need to adopt a long-term approach which addresses the root causes of migration. In this vein we should try not only to respond to immediate emergency situations but also to work on a comprehensive and structured approach to address the increasing migratory pressures. More specifically, the European Union approach should aim at integrating political and economic stability, development and security aspects, as well as both operational and political instruments. Issues such as migration, asylum, crisis management, humanitarian aid, development, trade, democratisation and human rights should be addressed in a comprehensive and coherent way. We must make sure that migration is embedded in all fields of EU external relations, including development cooperation and security policy, but we also need to be supportive and credible. We must support partner countries, therefore, to ensure better migration and border management as well as improved protection and reception capacity with a view to helping these countries fulfil their international obligations. Mobility partnerships have been put in place to enable deeper and tailor-made policy dialogues and operational cooperation with partner countries, so far with Morocco, Tunisia and Jordan. For the long term, tackling irregular immigration at its source is the best investment we can make. I intend to coordinate with High Representative Federica Mogherini and work closely with my colleagues, the Commissioners responsible for neighbourhood policy, development and humanitarian aid, as was set out in our mandate by the Commission President. Finally, I turn to funding. Under the Development and Cooperation Instrument the Commission is currently implementing initiatives for around EUR 53 million focused on migration and international protection. Around EUR 14 million of this fund supports the fight against trafficking and smuggling and tackles irregular migration, while EUR 17 million is dedicated to actions focusing on regional development and the protection programme for refugees and host communities in the Middle East, the Horn of Africa and North African countries. The European Neighbourhood Instrument mobilises around EUR 60 million for migration and international protection-related interventions in the Mediterranean countries. In addition, around EUR 200 million was allocated in 2014 to respond to the Syrian refugee crisis. Under the 2014 to 2020 financial framework, Member States and Schengen-associated countries will receive more than EUR 4.4 billion under the two funds combined: the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, and the Internal Security Fund – Borders and Visa. The frontline Mediterranean Member States – Italy, Greece, Malta and Spain – will receive a large share of these funds: in total, together, around EUR 1.4 billion over the whole financial cycle. For emergency situations we have set aside for 2014, for all Member States together, EUR 25 million under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, and EUR 6.8 million under the Internal Security Fund – Borders and Visa. I am looking forward to working closely with you to tackle these challenges using all the means that are at our disposal.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We have just lost more than 12 minutes on the scheduled timetable. I therefore regret having to tell you that I have to be very strict with speaking time and that I cannot give the floor to more than five speakers in the catch-the-eye procedure.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I warmly welcome the Italian Presidency, ladies and gentlemen. Of course, on the scale of the issue, it is not possible to go into everything. That is why I want to focus on one priority, in addition to the issue of rescuing refugees. First of all, Mr Commissioner, a warm congratulations on what you have said. I believe that your speech shows how much work we have ahead of us to find a solution at all. That is why I have a specific question about cooperation in the fight against trafficking in human beings. Some 42,000 people crossed the Mediterranean in 2013, and 108,000 in 2014. The number of deaths is estimated by the Migration Agency at 3 000. We do not even know how many people die, are killed or tortured, abducted or are subjected to forced prostitution, forced labour, enslavement, organ trafficking, the sexual abuse of children, torture and multiple murders, because we cannot see them and can only guess the extent. In the meantime, it seems that fewer women are victims of human trafficking, but more and more children are falling into the clutches of criminals. In this context, it is particularly important to me that law enforcement authorities also cooperate in a coordinated manner, that we develop cooperation with third countries that is capable of displacing traffickers, and, at the same time, that cooperation in humanitarian aid is stepped up – although this is not one of the tasks of our committee – and that the legal possibilities are developed towards humanitarian visas so that we can put a stop to traffickers. To what extent can you develop law enforcement cooperation here and, on the other hand, strengthen protection for victims?

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Combating the causes of flight is undoubtedly the right thing to do, but it does not help in the short term. We must now face up to our challenges. It is important to point out once again that it is not the European states that are taking in the largest number of refugees. It is precisely for this reason that it is intolerable that people on their way to Europe risk their lives and all too often lose their lives. We now need new approaches to protect people fleeing war and persecution. Fighting criminals - yes! However, if I no longer want any escape workers at all, then we should open up more safe routes to Europe. So far, there is a resettlement. But this is voluntary, and many Member States do not participate, some take in just a handful of refugees. All in all, therefore, we need more solidarity, a better distribution of refugees in all our Member States. That is why we also need a binding distribution key in order to involve the Member States, which have so far shied away from their responsibilities. To make a point, I believe that a distribution key would not only help to relieve countries such as Greece or Italy, it would also help countries such as Germany and Sweden if all the Member States finally joined in a distribution according to their own responsibilities. Finally, we also need legal routes to Europe, and we must also think about this ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the situation of migration into the Mediterranean is one which is one of the most important issues for the whole European Union. Europe must approach immigration with respect for fundamental rights, international obligations, human dignity and life. We need to have a sensible and balanced approach. There is a significant increase, year on year, in the number of people dying while attempting to make the journey to Europe. This is unacceptable and unsustainable. Europe needs an approach which is achievable but not idealistic. There is no simple answer, but what this Parliament needs most is what the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) has asked for: a holistic approach which looks at all the tools available to the EU in order to respond to the crisis. This includes looking at the responsibilities of Frontex and how we can save those vulnerable and exploited from dying at sea, as well as confronting the appalling actions of the human traffickers and smugglers who are so often responsible for their plight. We need to deal with third countries strongly and effectively to tackle immigration at source, and how we can work on resettlement and returns policies with them. There also needs to be a period of reflection where Member States take responsibility for processing efficiently, quickly and immediately in the first place of arrival. This is something benefiting the asylum seeker and the EU as a whole. Neither opening Europe’s borders wide nor slamming them shut is the solution to this problem. Instead, we must put away ideology and populism and we must find a realistic and workable way forward to solve those problems.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Everyone remembers the tragic pictures of the 366 white coffins after the disaster on Lampedusa just over a year ago. What we forget to say is that there is a Lampedusa every day, because already this year more than 3 000 people have died in Mediterranean waters – compared to 600 people last year. Even though we said it must never happen again, it happens again and again. Today the Pope was here and he said that we must never make the Mediterranean a cemetery, a graveyard. In fact, that is what the Mediterranean is developing into. We must now ensure that we put an end to it and put an end to the traffickers, because it is, in fact, the case that people are entirely in the hands of the traffickers.  It is not possible to get to Europe legally. That is why our major political challenge is now to create safe and legal routes to Europe. I am pleased that we have a Commissioner with us today who has spoken about this – not only with the brain and with words, but with heart and conviction. I am very hopeful that this political challenge will be brought closer to its solution with the new Commissioner in place. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

Are you going to force member states to receive a certain number? Percentage? Or what do you mean? And have you thought that we can help more people on the ground?

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: answer ("blue card"). Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This was a wish ful question for me. Only 14 countries in the EU are currently participating in the resettlement programme. Several of them take fewer than 100 people a year. What I mean by legal and safe roads, yes it is that we set up temporary asylum offices in camps and in EU embassies. This is the only way to knock your feet away...

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I was not satisfied with what Commissioner Avramopoulos said, on the contrary. They are regrettable, because the EU's asylum policy has actually failed. This is behind the more than 20 000 people who died at the external borders simply because they wanted to come here. This is hidden behind the so many relatives who fear for their missing persons and have called on the EU to finally take action and support the relatives so that they can find their people again to receive information about them. This silence is inhumane, the asylum policy of the EU and also of the Member States is not human! I say that the EU must once again be at the forefront of a humane asylum policy and not its preventer. We do not need Triton, we need a European Mare Nostrum to save people. Asylum policy is always humane where the Dublin principle is broken and abolished. The Member States must take joint and binding responsibility for refugees, create fair and decent prospects. That is what it is all about, that is what we need to talk about now, not Frontex! Ladies and gentlemen, the right to asylum is one of the most important achievements after the Second World War, because millions of people were not granted asylum at that time and were extradited to the Nazis. Asylum is an individual right, inalienable. That is what we need to defend, and I would like to hear you say that, Commissioner, that is what we need to say.

name: Ska Keller
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Europe cannot ignore it, and we cannot ignore people drowning in the Mediterranean. These are people who have had to flee war, persecution, discrimination, people who very often suffer the consequences of Europe's actions or inaction. They embark on an incredibly dangerous journey. Why? Because we leave them no choice. Because we are giving them no choice but to entrust themselves to the smugglers. We are the accomplices of the smugglers. First of all, we are giving the smugglers the opportunity to take advantage of the situation of those seeking protection and to blackmail them, because we are closing the door to Europe. If we really want to counter the smugglers, we must finally open up legal, safe routes to Europe. As Claude Moraes said, we have the tools to do so, but there is no political will.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of my colleague, Mrs Ferrara, who is absent for health reasons. One year after the Lampedusa tragedy, the European Union is still looking for a good idea to deal with a situation that we can no longer call an emergency but a routine one. The police and repressive approach of the Stockholm Programme and the Dublin Agreements has resulted in 22 000 deaths, 3 000 of them this year alone in the Mediterranean. Do we realise that Europe's southern border for irregular migrants is the most dangerous border in the world? Do you think it is possible to continue with this irresponsible management of a complex and unstoppable phenomenon such as immigration? Do you think it wise to continue erecting walls around this fortress called Europe, allowing the Mediterranean to turn into a great cemetery? Migration from the south of the world is a direct consequence of the processes of globalisation implemented by the north of the world, of which we are part and for which we as legislators are jointly responsible. We are increasing and making more efficient the legal access channels for asylum seekers, for family reunifications, for job seekers.  The emergency approach has created another monster that is the reception machine, where unscrupulous speculators are teeming alongside people working in a genuine spirit of solidarity. We denounce the criminal economy of drug dealing, prostitution, theft and unead work that thrives in that limbo without clear rules that are the reception centres, especially in Italy. Furthermore, what idea does Europe have of integrating migrants into its social fabric once they have been regularised? Migrants are often young, cultured, in good health and eager to contribute to the welfare of the society that welcomes them. The time has come for the European Union to overcome its fears and to review its approach to migration policies: no longer migrants but citizens to be welcomed and integrated.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this seems to me to be a temple of hypocrisy and racism. We must help immigrants fleeing war and hunger, you say. The same wars that this European Union supports and fuels – I am thinking of the Arab spring – and the same hunger that the idiotic rules of Brussels and a meaningless single currency are bringing back not to Africa, but to Italy and Europe. Helping them at home and spending the money we are banging away with Mare Nostrum and Triton is the only solution. Don't help the smugglers, the British Government was right to say 'I don't put a penny on it to help the smugglers fuel a new slavery', so I would like there to be more Britain in here and less hypocrisy.  Three thousand drowned, 150 000 immigrants landed in Italy, of which only 10% were refugees – the other illegal immigrants – and many people who earn millions and millions of euros. This is slavery, it's not generosity. Borders, if they make sense, must be defended, and as a League we will never tire of repeating them, until the end, until the end, until the end. It is too easy to clap Pope Francis's hands when he gets up and leaves, and then Pope Francis leaves a Chamber like this, which spends billions of euros to fuel new social unease, new chaos, new conflicts in our suburbs, not to help immigrants, let alone to help European citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: Question "blue card." Mr President, Mr Salvini, I will simply say that France and Great Britain have an overwhelming responsibility in the destabilization of Syria and Libya. Today we are witnessing a migratory explosion in the Mediterranean.  Should our continent - the European Union - be a machine for making undocumented immigrants?

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. 500 million European citizens cannot answer for the macro-strategic and economic policy mistakes of some states, because in Syria I remember that someone wanted, and perhaps still wants, to bomb the wrong side that is now allied against international terrorism, and this House has supported economic sanctions against Russia that make no sense whatsoeam. , which are bringing more hunger, more misery and more risk of war. So I think that here we often and willingly choose the worst ways that run counter to the interests of European citizens.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the years the European Union has taken important steps towards a single asylum system. However, this did not seem sufficient in the face of the crisis which has been heavily affecting the Member States of the Mediterranean basin since last year. Frontex is not, nor is it (and is not enough) Triton, the answer to the pressures of migratory flows on the borders to the south of the Union. Today, more than 90% of Syrian refugees are granted political asylum, which is very close to refugees of other nationalities, such as Afghans or those from horn-of-Africa countries. Why is it making it so difficult for them to enter the European Union? Why are we not in a position to restore hope, through European asylum seekers, to the crowds of desperate refugees who flock to the Mediterranean every year? The time has come to emphasise the values on which our institutions are founded, and in particular to rediscover solidarity and fair responsibility between states. I believe, Mr President, that the time has come for the Member States to achieve harmonisation of the effective treatment of refugees on European territory, and for the Commission, for its part, to regain its role as guardian of the Treaties and not hesitate to undertake infringement proceedings in the face of non-application of existing legislation.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR). -
text: Mr President, during the first eight months of this year almost 120 000 irregular migrants crossed the Mediterranean between Libya and Italy. That was almost six times more than in 2013. The Mare Nostrum operation dramatically increased these numbers and also the number of tragedies. Despite the risks, the sea journey remains a very attractive option for migrants, because once you make it to Europe it is very likely that you will get a residence permit of some kind and be entitled to family reunification, even if you do not meet the criteria for asylum. We need to address the pull factors, the rules concerning secondary protection, family reunification and social benefits. A message must be sent that risking your life and paying the smugglers is not worth it and will not be rewarded. Of course, such measures must be coordinated and Union-wide. Last year, Sweden received twice as many asylum applications as Italy. Germany received five times as many. This kind of asylum shopping is against the principles of the Dublin mechanism and it undermines the acceptability of the Schengen area. We need a responsible, long-term strategy. Opening new legal routes to Europe is not a solution, because European societies cannot indefinitely afford this kind of immigration, be it legal or illegal.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, once again in this Chamber, we share tragic observations, we are talking about the thousands of deaths, the tens of thousands of deaths mentioned this morning twice by the Pope, who spoke of the cemetery in the Mediterranean, of the cemetery of indifference, as Sandro Gozi recalled. Tonight, once again, we share the observations that our migration policy is not working well enough, to say the least , and this comprehensive strategy, which we all call, basically, of our wishes, is a necessity.  You have spoken, Commissioner, of political will. We expect you to really drive this momentum, this momentum to push States to consider that external borders are European, that there are real welcoming measures - and we will be close to you - that are the expression of European solidarity, responsibility or shared responsibility, as you said.  I have a request in the short time allotted to me, namely that as part of the development of this comprehensive strategy in the Mediterranean, in particular, we have a special attention for minors, vulnerable beings that are children, it is a ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to two statements. The first is that of the Italian Minister of the Interior, according to which Mare Nostrum has closed and after an interval thanks to Frontex will no longer spend one euro on rescues at sea. The second is the British Immigration Minister, who says that rescues in the Mediterranean must be saved as soon as possible as they encourage fugitives.  I invite you to meditate on these words so that they announce a possible crime against European civilisation. The law of the sea, the right to life, to asylum, are a dead letter. It is not untenable to cause mass drownings, it is not to leave hundreds of Syrians alone on hunger strike at this time in Athens, it is untenable to spend euros to save shipwrecked people. The applause to Pope Bergoglio is hypocrisy, if this Parliament does not change course starting with the Regulation ... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Bodil Ceballos (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The Mediterranean and atlantic have been cemeteries for many years already. The more we in the EU countries have closed our borders, the more people have died on the way here. We have not seen the whole of migration policy. Instead, the policy has focused on stopping people and sending back those who have managed to get in anyway. Frontex, return agreements, carrier responsibility, etc. give people smugglers a very thriving market. The only way I see actually fighting the smugglers is to create legal pathways to migration. The situation in our neighbourhood is terrible in many places and we must be prepared for many more to come here from war or from poverty. I am therefore pleased that the Commissioner also raised the issue of resettlement. I would like to see a resettlement system that becomes mandatory for all Member States, so that everyone is involved and actually takes responsibility.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, (inaudible as microphone not switched on) ... the so-called Arab Spring, the idiotic foreign policy of the British Government and others was to support insurgent groups against their oppressive rulers. Unfortunately, the liberators turned out to be more savage and tyrannical than those they sought to replace. The unfortunate inhabitants of these countries now leave in droves by any means that they can. If we want to have a holistic approach to this problem, then it has to recognise the root cause, and the root cause is, of course, a fundamentalist and extremist interpretation of Islamic ideology, most notably expressed by the so-called Islamic State. The countries best placed to tackle the problem and with the money to do so are, of course, the vastly wealthy, oil-rich Islamic states such as Saudi Arabia, etc. These are the countries that should take these people because they can afford it. They share similar cultures and the same religion.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
