text: Mr President, five hundred people, including 25 children, went on hunger strike yesterday and are asking the state for shelter, food and health care and work. They try to move to neighbouring countries but, once they are arrested at the border, they are repatriated to the country of origin. This is common in countries such as Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan. But this is happening in my country, Greece. These five hundred people are from Syria, have already remained concentrated for six days in Syntagma Square in Athens and yesterday began a hunger strike. So you have become Greece, like other countries in the Europe of the South, similar to the countries you accuse of being responsible for the emergence and rise of the Islamic State. Rest assured that, if you continue the same policy on illegal immigration, Greece and the other countries of the South will no longer be the only problem. You've let explosives be placed on your doors and windows while you, inside your house, argue about how to distribute dinner. That is what you achieved with the Dublin II Treaty. Remove it! Border security and stability at the borders of the European Union must be your biggest concern. The European Union has the economic power. Let him use it to deal with illegal immigrants, let him tackle the problem in the countries of origin and not in the countries of entry! Money has no borders, but states do. If you continue to give weight to money, you will wipe out the states. Is that what you're after?

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cause of emigration is mostly poverty. Emigration and development go hand in hand. We Europeans know this well, because we have had to emigrate many times to achieve prosperity. Europe, on the one hand, has to regulate orderly emigration and, on the other hand, increase development aid for migrant countries of origin. Today the Pope told us: the Mediterranean cannot become a great cemetery. To this end, we must reconcile the rights of Europeans which we cannot, under any circumstances, put into play and an adequate and dignified reception for migrants. Italy is a good example of what I'm saying. Italy is a good example that more money will not suffice, no more euros will suffice, if there is no unitary European policy on irregular immigration. My country, Spain, is the only one in the European Union that has a land border with Africa. There, every day, the security of the border and also the safety of the people who try to pass it on is guaranteed, and that is not, every day, easy. I have to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that the problem, I insist, is poverty. We fight poverty. Emigration is the consequence. Poverty is the cause. Our fight has to be against poverty, not immigrants. Europe must rebel against poverty, never against the poor. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: blue card question. – Mr González Pons, the speech on the need for development cooperation is very nice, but I would like you to respond to me how that works with the fact that the Government of the People's Party in Spain has annihilated the policy of development cooperation in recent years, dividing by seven practically — to give just one example — the budget of the Spanish Agency for International Cooperation for Development.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Of the migrants arriving at the borders of Ceuta and Melilla, only 1.5% are asylum seekers. The rest comes for financial reasons. If we do not fight economic motives, we can never order the emigration process. Of course, development aid must be improved, but - I insist, and I have said it before - without a common European policy on immigration, no country will be able to do anything on its own. Not Spain, not any.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D). -
text: We are aware of thousands of victims in Mediterranean waters every year, and we do nothing. Refugees are forced to flee because of war, because of violence, because of poverty, as you mentioned, and we warn again and again, as we have also heard today, that the Mediterranean must not become a graveyard, but it still seems to me that we are waiting for a new tragedy before anything changes. You are in front of you, Commissioner, an extremely serious test, to formulate a common asylum and migration policy that will truly serve its purpose - the dignity of people who are looking for a future. I therefore call on the Council and the Commission to step up their efforts to establish a more effective, comprehensive migration policy based on solidarity and truly humane. We must provide newcomers with safe routes to Europe and sufficient legal opportunities for all who really want it. The thousands of deaths, twenty thousand over the last 20 years, remind us every year, in fact, of how asylum systems in Europe work, and I really hope... (the President interrupted the speech).

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! We are talking today about migration to the EU and not about political asylum and persecution. I am not talking about that now. Pope Francis said this morning that 'it is unacceptable that the Mediterranean will become a great graveyard' and 'Europe can overcome the problems of immigration if it helps to develop in the migrants' countries of origin'. It is necessary to influence the causes and not the consequences. Peter Scholl-Latour said that we cannot save Calcutta by bringing Calcutta to us. The cause of migration is poverty in the world. The UN estimates that 4 billion people in the world have to live on less than 2 dollars a day. As a result, thousands of people are fleeing and dying in the Mediterranean. This is a tragedy and we must put an end to it. If we manage to give hope to the people of their countries, they will no longer board boats and will not have to leave their homes and families. Development aid on the ground saves lives. Let us help the poor so that they do not become migrants!

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Why do people go out in overloaded leaky boats?  Is it because they're fleeing war and persecution? For these people, we already have legal routes into the EUROPEAN Union. The UNHCR has the quota refugee system, and sweden at least assumes its responsibilities there.  Is it because they want a better life? We already have some mobility agreements with North African countries. We have the Blue Card, we have the seasonal workers' directive and so-called variable migration.  Is it because they get ripped off? Yes, I would think so. The EU has an unprecedented signalling policy. We guarantee permanent residence, we look between our fingers when it comes to illegal labour, we tolerate trafficking in human beings and exploitation.  These people pay large sums to be smuggled from countries in Africa into the EU. We do not want a situation where people smugglers know that Frontex can act as a ferry service between the middle of the Mediterranean and the EU.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI). -
text: It is now more than a year since a boat carrying hundreds of immigrants sank off the coast of Lampedusa. I wonder: have we learned anything from it? The answer is no. Every week there are reports in the newspaper about immigrants who make the crossing and are taken out of the sea by Frontex. Public authorities in Italy and France that are no longer able to cope with the influx and thousands of asylum seekers who, once on European soil, are knocking on the door of other Member States. Because our borders are just leaking! This Parliament's solutions are more solidarity, more money and more legal routes to the European Union, measures that only make the problem worse. I am from the Netherlands and we currently house 29,000 asylum seekers. An estimated 40,000 more will be added next year. As our government cuts our country and closes care homes for the elderly, reception centres for asylum seekers are appearing. It can't go on like this. The influx must be stopped, the borders must be closed and we must focus on reception in the region. This is the only way to prevent tragedies at sea and to stop mass immigration. When do you finally intend to do this and what has been done to help with reception in the region?

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we always find ourselves making speeches and saying a series of good intentions about the emotional drive of disasters happening at sea. But up to now we have to say that we have not been able to give concrete answers at national or European level and that they deal with the problem in a truly concrete and decisive way. I do not want to say that Operation Triton is a happy one given to Italy, but let me say that operations such as this cannot be considered permanent solutions either for migrants and refugees seeking assistance and protection, nor for the European Union, which needs to regain control and management of its borders.  There are three aspects that I particularly do not like: firstly, that it was conceived along the lines of Mare Nostrum, which is a very expensive bankruptcy operation and which has had the contrary effects, whatever they say, because there has been an increase in exorbitant flows (480%), an increase in the business of smugglers and human traffickers beyond all decent limits, and in addition we have the disasters at sea that have increased. We also say that only a few members of the European Union will make contributions, with a commitment which, we have to say, is really not exceptional in terms of men and means. In addition, it does not address the basic issues of a resolution.  The Pope has also said this today: it is necessary to intervene on the causes and not only on the effects. Please adopt these concrete and courageous policies – always words of the Pope – that help the countries of origin in socio-political development and in overcoming internal conflicts.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the Lampedusa tragedy has triggered urgent measures and focused all efforts in the Mediterranean. Results were achieved, thousands of people were saved. At the same time, some of the laws already passed have shown breaches. The need for a revision of the Dublin Agreements, which have brought the greatest burden of refugee flows to countries at the Union's external borders, is evident. The solidarity principle is violated, new rules for quota distribution and integration are also needed.  The focus today is the Mediterranean, but no less are the problems at land borders. In the last few days alone, refugees have been found dead from freezing at the border between Bulgaria and Serbia, for October nearly a thousand and five hundred have infiltrated from the border with Turkey. A policy for the so-called "no-fly zone" is needed. legal avenues, general legislation to combat trafficking and trafficking in human beings, increased powers of Frontex and one more thing that you, Commissioner, did not mention: the fight, prevention and danger of importing terrorism.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR). -
text: For me, in the area of migration policy, in addition to trust, coherence and coordination are the key words. At present, the available budget is fragmented across different budget lines and funds, each with its own finality and administrative framework. A global vision and approach is lacking. A more streamlined and ambitious EU policy on migration and asylum would provide a good alternative to dangerous crossings to Europe and reduce the scope for people smugglers. We must also fundamentally tackle the many causes of illegal migration. My question is: what steps will the Commission and the Council take to achieve greater coherence and coordination in the field of migration policy, both internal and external?

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in your comprehensive approach to the issue of migration dealt with by the European Union, Mr Moraes and Mr Avramopoulos, moreover, carefully avoid the fundamental problems, really not enough to reassure us for the future.  We know that in Italy, out of 12 identification and detention centres, 8 have been closed because of the illegal revolts. The situation is explosive and, As Mr Salini said, Italians have suffered the arrival of 150,000 to 160,000 illegal migrants on their shores in 2014.  Despite the effects of Frontex and the budget that goes with it, the UNION's policy has transformed Italy into a gigantic sorting centre before the dispersal of these illegal migrants in the various Schengen countries and in particular in my own country, france.  Being elected from Nice, near the Italian border, I see that we are overwhelmed by the influx of illegal immigrants: more than a thousand a week. The Council said in October, and I quote: "Measures must be taken to better manage migration flows". The only measure is to immediately reverse these immigration policies, suspend the Schengen agreements and restore states' sovereignty and control of their borders.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I have noted another phrase in the Holy Father's speech this morning that the lost sight of these people calls for support and acceptance. Today in my homeland, off the coast of Crete, 30 nautical miles from the coast, sails ungoverned a boat with six hundred souls, including many women with babies. All these people are asking for support and welcome. It does not matter whether my country is a first host country, a country of transit or a country of final destination. What matters is whether we actually manage in the European Union to distribute asylum seekers fairly. We all know that this is primarily a matter of solidarity, but does solidarity depend - it seems - on specific interests as well? I am sure, Commissioner, that it has also been made clear from your recommendation that there is indeed the political will to take additional measures to manage migration flows properly, as well as to lay down rules for the practical application of the principles of the European Union, solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. As you know, these principles are reflected in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is my conviction that all Member States should understand that immigration is not a problem, migration is a matter for all the countries of the European Union. Finally, I must point out that it is not in line with the principles and values of the European Union, that solidarity cannot be expressed at two or more different speeds.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D). -
text: Mr President, we are concerned about the reports on migration issues. Between the calls for solidarity, for firmness, for the hasty revision of European rules, there is as much information as disinformation.  One thing is certain, however, and many colleagues have mentioned it before me: the Union is struggling to adopt a long-term, strategic and, above all, readable global migration policy. This is not abnormal when vision is too often fragmented and short-term.  Therefore, as a new era opens for our institutions, we must achieve a profound change in migration policies. I am convinced that we must be engaged and proactive, and propose another policy that promotes, for example, a better movement of people and skills, existing legal channels of migration or to be promoted, which also promotes effective access to asylum procedures and the development of alternatives for people seeking international protection, and which also promotes a renewed partnership with third countries.  I have listened to you very carefully, Commissioner, and I have noted many points of agreement. Therefore, I look forward to your concrete proposals to respond to the emergency, of course, but also to act on the long term.

name: Michał Boni (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Migratory pressure will increase. The reasons lie in differences in living standards, but also in the violation of freedom in countries of war and authoritarianism. Europe will be an increasingly coveted place for third-country nationals. Indeed, the Mediterranean must not be allowed to become a great cemetery, nor symbolically the Black Sea, ever. Migration waves are problems, but also europe's chances, even demographic and economic ones. This requires a comprehensive migration policy in the long term. This requires harmonisation of action so that no EU country is left alone in the face of migratory pressure and that everyone respects the values of treating migrants and asylum seekers with dignified treatment. Cooperation with third countries aimed at the growth of their economies, mobility partnerships, resettlement programmes are therefore important. The question is: what action will the Commission and the Council take to develop cooperation with these countries, including through neighbourhood policy instruments, which will reduce economic migratory pressures? This is complemented by the question: how to effectively implement the Common European Asylum System? How do Member States maintain the standards of the asylum package? What adjustments does this system require to respect fundamental rights and to help integrate people fleeing violence into specific European countries?  Preparing a new framework for Europe's migration policy is a key task today to...  (The President has taken the vote of the Member)

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr Gozi, one year after the tragic events in Lampedusa, Europe wanted to open its eyes to the problem of immigration. Thanks to the commitment of the Italian Government, we have moved from a problem of the land of first reception alone to a properly European approach, with proposals for quotas for the distribution of immigrants and shared responsibilities. But the emergency remains. As Pope Francis recalled in his exciting speech, the Mediterranean cannot be a graveyard.  Italy has done its duty with Mare Nostrum, saving many lives. Operations are now continuing with the utmost commitment, but under Frontex leadership. In this regard, I would like to ask: what obstacles prevent frontex's competences from being increased? What obstacles stand in the way of an increase in its budget to enable it to implement mediterranean control policies effectively? Today we are here to ask for more, Commissioner, because Triton is not the final solution. We must change our strategy boldly and work to focus our efforts on the African coast, investing in countries in crisis where the problem exists, with bilateral agreements where possible or with European leaders. We must change the rules, and that is why today we are asking for maximum commitment and courage to protect European citizens and, at the same time, for the dignity of human life.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, welcome to a debate on the absence of an integrated immigration policy in Europe which, sadly, takes place in this legislature for the first time, but which surely will not last, because we had this debate many times in the previous parliamentary term and in all I intervened to deplore the absence of this integrated policy, to demand to build it , but above all, to change the focus. Because it is part of a prejudged and negative approach against immigration, which closes the floodgates to regular immigration and therefore advocates too many people for irregular immigration. For this reason, the Mediterranean has become worse than a cemetery: it has become a mass grave of corpses of unidentified human beings who did not have the opportunity to say goodbye worthily to their own. It is really sad, therefore, and demands an urgent response. And that answer cannot be to respond to lampedusa's tragedy with a life-saving operation at sea, immediately deplorated because it further incentivizes, with the rescue of lives, the illicit trafficking of people, and replace it with an exclusive border management operation. Therefore, (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Frank Engel (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I believe that we, as elected representatives of the people, have a duty to direct public opinion towards true representations.  When I hear the stupid, narrow-minded and populist statements of the right of this house, I feel the need to provide you with some figures. Around the world, you now find 480 million Europeans who have emigrated and their descendants. It is the equivalent of the population of the European Union that left Europe at some point in its history. Few did so for pleasure. They are just as rare today those who leave their homelands for pleasure or simply to enjoy our social security.  The young colleague from the Netherlands wants to tell us something about the need to close borders? I wanted to tell him that there are 15 million Dutch emigrants and their descendants around the world, more than there are Dutch people inside the Netherlands.  So if we want to be fair, if we want to follow the example of what His Holiness the Pope, who was with us this morning, wanted, let us keep this in mind: Europe is a continent of emigration before it is a continent of immigration. If people are knocking on our door today, we are not allowed to leave it closed.

name: Kati Piri (S&D). -
text: The importance of a European asylum and migration policy was painfully underlined a year ago by the Lampedusa disaster. Unfortunately, this disaster was not an incident. More than 3,000 people have drowned in the Mediterranean since the beginning of this year. I therefore hope that the new Commission will consider solving this issue as one of its main priorities. A year after the Lampedusa disaster, there are still no safe routes and no legal routes to the EU for asylum seekers. I am pleased to hear that the Commissioner is talking to the Member States about increasing quotas for relocation. This is currently the only legal way to reach the EU. I also hope that an agreement can be reached on the issue of humanitarian visas soon.  Finally, there is a great deal of misunderstanding between the countries of southern Europe and the destination countries in Western and Northern Europe. It is essential that this misunderstanding is removed so that we can finally work towards a common policy based on solidarity between all European countries.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, human disasters in the Mediterranean Sea have proved that when it comes to migration policy, the Union cannot simply focus on the security of its borders. The internal and external dimensions are closely linked. I would like to emphasize three things. First, with regard to Frontex, we must clearly establish the role front will play in an integrated approach to migration. Finally, Operation Triton is strictly limited to border control as the budget is limited and its technical equipment remains suspended from the promises of equipment from the Member States. There are still many open questions about the steps that will be taken to complete Operation Triton in the Mediterranean Sea. Secondly, it is crucial today to put a stop to the trafficking of migrants. The only instrument we have is the UN Protocol against the smuggling of migrants. The Union must have a mechanism to monitor the protocol and, above all, to do an enormous amount of work in terms of information and data on traffic, on the road to be taken, on recruitment techniques, on the most vulnerable people.  Finally, there is the issue of cooperation with third countries. The causes of refugee flows and irregular immigration, both economic and political, must be addressed. It is clear, for this reason, that migration policy must be fully integrated into the Union's external action in economic and trade relations, in conflict prevention and in development policy.  Therefore, what I would like, Commissioner Avramopoulos, is for you to work with High Representative Mogherini, Commissioner Hahn. Your joint actions will have our support because they will make Europe more up to the level of the people.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been saying this for a long time: the Mediterranean is a European sea and we cannot see it reduced to an open-air graveyard. The Pope has even said so in this House today. It is an impression that some European leaders can argue that people must be allowed to die at sea in order to discourage others from leaving. I would like them to come and explain it to those who count the bodies in Lampedusa.  It is the increase in wars on the Mediterranean, it is the increase in discrimination and torture that is increasing the flows. Well, it's clear that the only difference from before, when we didn't have ships there, is that before many of us didn't see them die and frankly I find it outrageous that there are people in here who prefer not to see.  Unfortunately, Triton will not be enough: he has too few resources at his disposal and the range is too short (only 30 miles), and I hope that it will be strengthened. The border countries alone cannot do it, but the responsibility for being shared presupposes the need to anticipate our intervention with humanitarian corridors or at least with humanitarian visas. I would like to hear from the Commissioner on this subject how the debate is going.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, immigration is an absolute European emergency, not only in Sicily, my home country, in Malta, Spain or Greece, which paid the highest price, especially at an early stage, amid the indifference of many other Member States. Operation Mare Nostrum is finally over. As my group leader, Mr Gardini, said, I believe that it has played a multiplying role in landings. This was also said by the executive director of Frontex, which in the LIBE committee pointed out that in the first four months of 2014 they increased by 823%, exactly two months after the launch of operation Mare Nostrum. You have to turn the page. I hope, although I am very perplexed, that Operation Triton will play a role in this; however, it is an innovative aspect in the involvement of 26 Member States. But the Dublin III Agreement must also be amended, where the task of granting or not granting the right of asylum is attributed exclusively to the port State, sharing this burden to all Member States.  Among other things, some recent judgments of the Court of Justice have indirectly enshrined this principle. Immigration must therefore, therefore, Commissioner, in my view be tackled very clearly, without demagogy, in an attempt to reconcile solidarity requirements with those of protecting the security of the Member States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D). -
text: Fl-opinjoni tiegħi dan huwa mument opportun biex niddisutu dan is-suġġetti. U qed ngħid hedge mhux biss għaliex hemm bżonn urġenti ta' azzjoni imma wkoll minħabba l-mod kif qegħdin jiżviluppaw l-affarijiet fil-Mediterran. Qegħdin nitkellmu dwar l-att kriminali ta' min jagħmel eluf ta' euro minn fuq l-isfortuna ta' ħaddieħor. Ta' min jibgħat jaqsmu l-baħar Mediterran persuni fuq dgħajjes li bilkemm kapaħi jbaħħru, biex jispi大大大aw jegħrqu.  U min-naħa l-oħra, għandna ħj-ikeittadini Ewropej jgħidulna li jsir ħafna paroli fis-sajf meta l-problema tkun fl-aqwa tagħha, imma mbagħad fix-xitwa bħal donnuwiekkta kollox. Jgħidulna: qisu m'hemmx ħeġġa biex jinbidlu l-affarijiet.  Dwar dak li għaddej fil-Mediterran b'mod partikolari fil-Libja, fejn ma' hawk jum li jgħaddi s-sitwazzjoni qed issir aktar delikata u fejn l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha tieħu rwol ikeentrali. Irridu naħdmu flimkien. Ejja nimplimentaw dak li ilna nitkellmu dwaru: politika komprensiva li tinkludi kooperazzjoni ma' pajjiżi terzi. Strateġija li tinkludi wkoll żoni li bħalissa huma f'kunflitt bħal-Libja u s-Sirja.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I will try, in three words, to describe the problem. The first word is "solidarity." Solidarity with refugees coming from countries and from war and disaster zones but also solidarity between European states. Solidarity by force? Not! But, as Europeans, we pride ourselves on always finding ways to agree. So here we have a problem for which we must agree. The second word is "rules", rules on legal economic migration, rules that take into account both the terrible needs of our old continent and the limits of its possibilities. The third word is "time." Time is something we don't have. President Moraes quite rightly told us that we have the tools. Commissioner Avramopoulos has assured us that the Commission has the will. But what we don't have is time. That is why, from Parliament, there is only one thing I can say: hurry up!

name: Der Präsident
text: . - As I have already announced, I can really only give the floor to five speakers. We have considerably more requests to speak. I also took into account in the selection that I had to withdraw the floor from several speakers from different groups because they had exceeded the time.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE). -
text: Mr President, almost all the speakers spoke of the Pope and the expression that the Mediterranean cannot be a cemetery. To avoid this, seriously, there is much to do, but there is one thing we have to do now: set as a priority to save lives.  In the previous mandate, we adopted a regulation setting out this priority for Frontex missions. This Parliament was fine, the Council was reluctant but eventually gave in. In order to take this seriously, and not to be hypocritical, we must do two things: firstly implement this regulation well and, secondly, to extend that priority to the tasks which are the responsibility of the Member States.  My question is this: do you agree with this, Commissioner?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Commissioner, welcome to the European Parliament. I am very pleased that in this first appearance I too have the opportunity to set out my thoughts on the issue of illegal immigration. As you know, this is a phenomenon which mainly affects the countries of the European South which are suffering, which have been impoverished because of the memorandums and because of the tough budgetary policy and which, therefore, are difficult to cope with the huge migratory flows that exist. I will stick to the issue of solidarity: it must be distributed at European Union level and this distribution should be based on three elements. It should depend on the extent, population and GDP of the Member States of the European Union. Greece, as you know, cannot afford other illegal immigrants. The same applies to Italy. Dublin III should be amended. It is not possible for Greece to be turned into a warehouse of souls.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I think that if there is one big question that requires a common European answer, it is the question of migration. I think it is really time for the Heads of State or Government to realize this and move forward to build a common policy on immigration that must be based on four pillars. First pillar: we must have real security, real surveillance and protection of our external borders by air, land and sea with, why not, European coastguards.  The second pillar is the corollary of the first: we must have a regulated right of entry into the European Union with, why not, country quotas on immigration. The third pillar is urgent, as you all said; we need a harmonization of our right to asylum. We can no longer continue with countries where, basically, it takes six months to get something and for others it takes five years. This is not reasonable.  The fourth pillar is, of course, a development policy, a real partnership with the countries of origin and a foreign policy that contribute to the stability of the countries around us.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Mr. President! About a year after the great shipwreck in Lampedusa, we are again discussing the flow of refugees, but again only about symptoms, and we are not tackling the problem at its root. And as positive as Mare Nostrum measures like Triton are to rescue those in distress at sea, they are ultimately just a reaction to the onslaught of millions. We must define a common European objective, bring stabilisation and democratisation to politically uncertain areas, but also put an end to the unbridled exploitation of resources in developing countries. It is therefore necessary, as Pope Francis aptly pointed out, to address the causes. We must create a good framework in the emigrants' home countries so that they do not want to leave their home countries in the first place. Although some dreamers in this House see it differently, we will not be able to bring the whole of Africa, the Middle East and perhaps Central Asia to Europe. It is also good that there are Members of this House who say this clearly, because the citizens will appreciate this more and more.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall speak for less than a minute. Mr Gozi, Commissioner: unaccompanied foreign minors are children, it is not true that they are often almost all below the threshold of majority age. They're kids, they're scared, they're just a number. I saw them in Lampedusa. We voted on a joint motion in the House and senate to give them legal status, because they are only a number, and the numbers are lost. They get into the crime net and you can't find them anymore. An appeal for this: they must have a legal status.

name: Δημήτρης Αβραμόπουλος
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the questions put by members of the European Parliament. I conclude, first of all, that, in general, everyone, with few exceptions, agrees that this is a very important issue, with social and humanitarian implications, which puts to the test every day the principles on which Europe was born and founded. I didn't come here to beautify any situation. I don't intend to. I have only been in this position for three weeks, but I have known and studied the problem for many decades. If I may make a personal reference, some eighteen years ago, when the first waves of illegal immigrants gathered at the doors of Europe, I was Mayor of the city of Athens and I do not hide from you that I was surprised. The Greek state was taken by surprise with me, as were all the states of the European South, when all these fellow human beings who were asking for a place in the sun and a better life began to knock on Europe, pushed by the difficult situations they faced, by poverty, by war and by the tragedies that brought together the personal drama of each.  You referred to Lampedusa, which has become a symbol for the whole of Europe. It wasn't just in Lampedusa that we mourned people. There are those for whom we will never know where they are because they are lost in the depths of the Mediterranean and because there are many more than the Member States of the wider region have recorded so far. Ladies and gentlemen, many people believed at the outset that this was an issue that concerned only the European South. Within a few years, however, it became one of the biggest problems in the whole of Europe. It is a pan-European issue. But there is one thing we must not forget. There is an answer that we must give to all those who cultivate xenophobia and who unfortunately are unraveling, or at least trying to unravel the principles and values on which the European construction is based. Mr Engel said this earlier and I agree with him: we are a union made up of peoples and nations that have sent millions of our ancestors around the world. Large countries, today's superpowers, consist of mosaics of ethnicities dominated by the European element. Our people at the time, our relatives and grandparents were treated with xenophobia, with racism. All this is not a foreign experience for Europeans, but the time has come to judge ourselves, in the light of our own values, on the other hand.  But how is that going to happen? Certainly not with a fragmented policy. Nor by blaming each other - because such voices were heard here. It will be done with a holistic, coherent immigration strategy. I assure you there is the political will. The Commission is determined to adopt a new Charter on migration because the problem we are concerned about today will not be resolved until many years have passed. You are aware of the geopolitical developments along this whole arc of instability that starts in Tunisia and reaches Ukraine. At the moment, on the shores of Turkey, Libya, Egypt or elsewhere, hundreds of thousands of souls are waiting to find a way to cross over, victims of smugglers and intermediaries who, as I said before, we are determined, in cooperation with the Member States, to strike lightly. There are countries, including Greece from which I come, that have already taken very strict measures. Life imprisonment is a sentence imposed by the courts of the country. I don't want to hear about the human rights of smugglers again. They have no right to sell out human souls. Behind the issue we are discussing here today lies a well-functioning industry, equipped with the best systems, with new technologies, an industry which in many cases is better equipped and organised by the States themselves. Europe reacted. The policy, which we are now criticising, in the past year has begun to give results. Some programs have been tested. Any programs that fail stop. We support the Member States in their policies; Member States are not alone. Europe stands by them; Europe will show its solidarity in practice, Mrs Vozenberg. It is its obligation because solidarity is one of the principles on which the European construction is based, with daily social, humanitarian and political implications. Here, in this sacred site of the European Parliament, in the Temple of the European Republic, all these principles are tested every day through your own debates. The Commission needs your help, your support, your ideas and your sensitivities, sensitivities which we all share, regardless of the institution of Europe we serve.  I repeat that it is our intention and will to adopt a new Charter on migration that protects human rights, fundamental rights and all the humanitarian values that were born in this place called Europe and which today are the brightest example of democracy in practice for the whole world. Europe is attractive not only because it prospers, but also because people here know that it will be respected. We know where the system is suffering. We know what his weaknesses are. The experience gained by the previous Commission and all of you here is not unknown to us. We feel an absolute responsibility to adopt a coherent, integrated policy that responds to the issue with sensitivity, humanity and values that are confirmed in practice. The time will come when we will all decide to clarify the concept of European borders. It will not be borders that will lead us to what was a slogan of the interwar period. You know who that slogan came from. It's not even worth naming them in this room. We don't want a fortress Europe. Europe will not become a fortress. Europe will not lead to isolationism. Europe is made up of citizens of the world and has its doors open to the other citizens of the world, those who have been brought to us in search of a human welcome and a better environment. They want to live with us and we want to give them this opportunity but within an organised framework, according to a web of principles, values and directives that will come from our own cooperation in this very area.  I want to give you this assurance today that the Europe of values will be judged in practice and that Europe will be able to stand up against all the ills we have described before, first and foremost the exploitation of man. I hope it won't be long before we all experience this result together. I really hope from my heart, when at the end of next year we have the same debate, that we have made the great leap forward and upwards and found genuine answers to these questions, so as not to continue this situation which, after all, offends us and the values on which we have founded our common European edifice.

name: Sandro Gozi
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to all those who have spoken. Frankly, it has been an interesting debate, not a new one in many respects, but it is very important that it takes place at the beginning of this parliamentary term. It is clear, as has been said and I also said in my introduction, that in this political cycle Europe either makes a difference on issues such as immigration or will find it very difficult to regain credibility in the eyes of its citizens.  Immigration is precisely one of the test cases on which we will have to check how much Europe will be able to do together. And the more integrated approach is certainly an approach that starts from the external dimension that is linked – several of you have said this and as the Council we fully agree with it – to development policies and security policies. It is clear that there is a direct link with the contribution that the European Union as such - however we are the world's largest donor - will be able to make to the fight against poverty.  It is also true that there is an aspect linked to security, starting with border security. And I would remind you that, on the initiative of the Presidency, the Council has set a medium-term objective - and this has also been mentioned in the debate - of achieving a European external border police force. This is something that is now in the Council documents and that we will certainly have to work on in the new parliamentary term.  It is clear, and we have also mentioned this in the Council's work, that we need much more cooperation between the European Union and countries of origin and transit. In particular, one thing I would like to add to the debate is the commitment that the Council has made to work much more effectively and with much more intensity for voluntary resettlement programmes, for initiatives in crisis-related regions outside the European Union, together with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. This is an operational commitment that was made in the Luxembourg Council of Interior Ministers, on which the Council and Parliament will certainly have to work much more and much more together. The question of rescues at sea has also been raised. I would remind you that the duty to assist people in difficulty at sea is part of international rights. It binds all the Member States, binds all those who intervene, including in the Mediterranean, and binds them to save regardless of their nationality and, I would stress, regardless of the status of the people to be rescued. It is not that if a person is an irregular immigrant we can drown them, whereas if they are an economic immigrant or a potential asylum refugee we can save them. This is a very important point to emphasise.  Of course, therefore, this duty to assist people in difficulty, which binds the Member States, also applies to operations with the help of Frontex, such as Operation Triton. Of course, Operation Triton is the beginning of a shared response, it is the beginning of a shared assumption of responsibility, it is a good starting point, around which we must build much more.  Of course we need more money, starting with Frontex. But funds without new common policies certainly cannot be enough. It is very important that in the strategic agenda for the new parliamentary term the European Council has identified the commitment to fully develop common legal and illegal immigration policies, but that is why – I repeat again – we need confidence and we need solidarity. And if we do not rebuild a relationship of trust and solidarity between us within the European Union, much of this and much of what you have also hoped for will remain on paper. In today's debate, too, two approaches have emerged which are only apparently opposed. There are countries that complain that there are a disproportionate number of asylum seekers on their territory. There are other countries that complain of uncontrolled, sometimes difficult-to-control, massive arrivals of illegal immigrants on their shores. And it seems that sometimes there is a competition for those who have more rights or those who need joint intervention most. But it is clear that it is precisely the absence of a common policy, whether legal immigration or illegal immigration, that is costing disproportionately both countries with a very large number of asylum seekers and countries that are exposed to massive irregular influxes on their coasts. It is clear that, in both cases, the answer may be a new common European policy on legal and illegal immigration. It is not that we can continue to play the game of those who need it most, which also means the game of an absence of trust between us. It is a policy to be built step by step, proposed after proposal.  In the negotiations between the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament, a new directive on access to the European Union for research, study and voluntary reasons. Another piece of that common legal immigration policy that we absolutely must build, because it is clear that all this will be built over an entire parliamentary term, step by step, piece by piece. In his opening speech, the Commissioner referred to the Commission's possible proposal for better distribution and burden-sharing. Of course, this is another very important point.  With regard to unaccompanied foreign minors, I indicated in my introduction that, first of all, we must certainly make use of all the margins that the existing Dublin rules on unaccompanied minors allow, that have not been exploited and on which we must work, and I would remind you that some Member States are working on legislative proposals to this effect. I fully agree, and that is one of the issues that we have also discussed in the Council's work. It is impossible, Mr President, to respond to all the speeches. But of course we will either really have the courage and the will to have a common approach or we will all lose and also lose the credibility of the European Union to our citizens.

name: El Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the next part-session. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Comodini Cachia Therese (PPE)
text: in writing. – Mediterranean Member States deal with a surge of illegal immigration by sea that continues to bear on their financial, social and administrative difficulties. A new European strategy must adopt a holistic approach to migration management, respecting human rights, establishing coordination among Member States and with countries of origin and/or passage. The EU must play a bigger role in promoting security and create an effective political framework for comprehensive, enhanced and tailor-made dialogue and cooperation. We need to tackle causes and not only consequences. Malta receives a high number of immigrants in ratio to its population, while the Mediterranean serves as a vast EU border. Member States such as Malta do not need only financial but even operational support. Proper systems must be put in place to assist migrants when they arrive, process applications faster and integrate or resettle them if they are granted asylum. The EU must offer resources and cooperation across Member States, and come up with a true and real common asylum system. Triton is not enough: we need missions that search and rescue but also measures that bring smugglers and traffickers to justice and collect data that would enable better and more effective actions in the future.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. One year after the Lampedusa tragedy, the EU is still looking for a strategy to deal with a situation that we can no longer call an emergency but a routine one. The repressive approach of the Stockholm and Dublin Agreements has resulted in 22 000 deaths, 3000 of them in the Mediterranean this year alone. Europe's southern border for irregular migrants is the most dangerous in the world. Immigration from the South of the world is a direct consequence of the processes of globalisation implemented by the North of the world of which we are part and for which we co-legislators are responsible. We need to increase access channels for asylum seekers, for family reunification, for job seekers. This emergency has created a monster that is the reception machine where, alongside people who work in a spirit of solidarity, speculators emerge mercilessly. We are here to denounce this criminal economy that thrives as a result of this tragic situation. Irregular immigration is not a national issue but a matter for the European Union, which must overcome its fears and review its approach to immigration policies. The Union must do everything in its power to bring this tragedy to an end.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: Written. The shipwreck off Lampedusa reminded the EU that the Mediterranean is still at the centre of a critical situation that continues to cause countless deaths. This is no longer an emergency but has become a structural problem requiring a coherent and unified response from the Union and its Member States. The European strategy on this issue needs a different approach. The lack of clear responsibilities creates too many grey areas for the benefit of human traffickers. The common European asylum system is working badly and collapsing. Human rights are constantly being violated in centres for those fleeing war and persecution. Focusing only on more border controls does not deter migrants from risking their lives at sea and does not stop those who profit from such trafficking. That is why today we have asked for a clear answer from the Commission and the Council on specific questions highlighting the different aspects of the migration problem. We want consistency and we call on Parliament to be able to conduct an inquiry to shed light on the shortcomings and to propose the necessary actions to adopt a common strategy so that the Mediterranean does not turn into a great graveyard.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: During the hearing in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I asked Mr Avramopoulos how soon he could develop a common legal and economic migration framework, what outstanding measures he would take and what most recent action he would take with regard to migratory pressures at Europe's borders if elected.  I am pleased that today, these questions have been provided with much more in-depth analysis and data. I welcome Mr Avramopoulos's stated political will and determination of the Committee to develop a holistic approach in the form of a common Migration Charter to overcome fragmentation in this area, calling for accelerated deadlines for its development and, above all, for a focus to be placed on the solidarity of responsibilities between Member States.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. – Over 3,000 people lost their lives in an attempt to get their hands on Europe in the first 9 months of this year. That's almost twice as much as last year. And as the number of migrants killed grows, funds earmarked for emergency rescue operations are decreasing significantly.  Operation Triton won't have any serious resources. Its reach will be lower even than the Italy-funded Operation Mare nostrum. It is welcome but by no means a solution nor an adequate common response of the European Union to the tragedy it faces. The migrant problem must not be a problem only for member states whose borders and shores migrants arrive in search of a better life. Increased border control and denial of support upon their arrival will not prevent others intending to seek asylum in Europe.  If the European Union is going to be judged by how it treats the neediest in society, and migrants certainly belong there, then we need to quickly rethink our current approach and reform it thoroughly. Because the score for what we're doing today isn't high.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: written.– For two years, the European Union has faced unprecedented migratory pressure sparked by protracted conflicts and unstable situations in neighbouring countries. Member States such as Bulgaria - external borders of the European Union, are the first to welcome the thousands of refugees – in 2014 some 30,000 people tried to cross our state border illegally. Unfortunately, however, countries such as Bulgaria do not have the capacity and financial capacity to cope with the pressures. As a result, crises within the European Union arise – crises in refugee camps, crises at the external borders, crises at internal borders, such as in Calais, public opinion crises and, accordingly, a crisis of tolerance. The only possible answer is more solidarity between Member States. I'm not just talking about financial solidarity, though it's necessary. I am talking about concrete measures to be taken by other EU members on the resettlement and reception of refugees. The current situation proves that even the renewed Dublin Regulation is not sufficient to effectively manage refugee flows in Europe. I welcome Commissioner Avramopoulos's promise to review European legislation, but I also call for this analysis to be carried out as soon as possible in order to find quick answers to the urgent problems.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union's migration policy should not escape the right of the European Parliament and civil society to review it. Democratic control is essential to ensure respect for the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers. However, Frontex is not known for the transparency of its actions. The Agency's "labour agreements" with third countries, because they are "technical", are not subject to any external control. They would enable Frontex, in cooperation with the police authorities of the countries concerned, to set up return and surveillance operations in non-European territorial waters. It is legitimate to doubt that these agreements respect the fundamental rights of migrants, in particular the right to seek asylum and the principle of non-refoulement. The Commission can no longer turn a blind eye and remain inactive in the face of disrespectful practices of migrants' rights. What does it intend to do to inform the European Parliament about these general agreements between Frontex and third countries? Is it considering ensuring that these agreements are in line with EU legislation and the Charter of Fundamental Rights?

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The EU is seen by many of the most vulnerable and oppressed people of the world as a zone of stability and safety. Migrants risk and lose their lives trying to reach our shores. According to the IOM, the journey from North Africa via the Mediterranean is the most lethal migration in the world and has killed at least 3 000 migrants this year alone. The situation in the Mediterranean is a pressing issue and it is only going to get worse; war in Syria, Libya and elsewhere is creating millions of new refugees, and the next exodus is underway in Iraq. Faced with the most dangerous border crossing in the world, Europe is deciding to make that journey even more dangerous – betting that, if we make it hopeless enough, no one will attempt to cross. This ‘cruel to be kind’ approach means politicians get to look tough on ‘illegal’ immigration for political benefit back home, but the transformation of the EU into a fortress has created the conditions that have led to deaths along its borders. This is not something we should be proud of as a union of member states, hence we need to act together so our actions reflect our common values.

name: El Presidente. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question with request for oral response to the Commission on summary expulsions and proposal for the legalisation of 'hot returns' in Spain, by Birgit Sippel and Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, Cecilia Wikstrom and Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz, on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, Judith Sargentini and Josep-Maria Terricabras, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, Cornelia Ernst and Marina Albiol Guzmán, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, and Laura Ferrara and Ignazio Corrao, on behalf of the Group Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy (O-000085/2014 - 2014/2959(RSP)- B8-0043/2014).

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank I would like to begin by saying that I understand the need to limit speaking time. But I would be happy if this strict adherence to speaking time were to apply to everyone. On the subject: The Spanish Government is currently planning a change in the law to legalise immediate deportation on the border strip of Ceuta and Melilla. We all know the pictures of rubber bullets being fired from the coast off Ceuta on refugees armed only with rescue tyres, people panicking and drowning. And we remember the pictures when in Melilla – we all saw the film, I think we all saw it – a man was knocked down and carried back to the Moroccan side without respect for his rights. This approach has been strongly criticised by both Mrs Malmström and the European Commissioner for Human Rights. It is not acceptable for people to be treated in this way at our borders, in the middle of Europe, because the entire fence is Spanish territory. We have heard a lot about dignity this morning. But human dignity is indivisible, and it does not only apply to European people. The amendment could therefore now be incorporated into The Spanish Security Act. The European Commission is now called upon to do everything possible to prevent this change in the law. This amendment is not only contrary to Article 13 of the Spanish Constitution, it also violates the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Geneva Convention on Refugees. Ladies and gentlemen, the way in which we manage migration and asylum, the way we talk about migrants, is no longer sustainable. We urgently need a change in our policy, and we need those changes now.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: Author. - (C) Yes, it is shocking when we need to watch videos of the police shooting people with rubber bullets so that fifteen people die and it is equally tragic that we should see people brutally beaten down by Spanish police. This is nothing more than brutal assault by a police force that takes the law into its own hands. This action is contrary to international law and to EU law, the asylum legislation that we have put in place with great effort. All EU countries are, of course, bound by common legislation on the reception of asylum, processes and the return of migrants who do not have asylum grounds. We are also bound by the Geneva Convention and we are governed by the principle of non-refoulement. These 'hot returns', i.e. the immediate deportation of migrants, are incompatible with EU law. Not everyone has the right to asylum, but everyone has the right to a normal return to their country of origin. Sending someone back without individual testing is incompatible with our legislation. It is very worrying that Spain is now discussing adopting legislation that allows these hot returns, because that would lead to collective expulsions – incompatible with European and international law.  The Commission must act vigorously here. Strong reactions from the Member States are required and if the law comes into force, it must be examined by the Court of Justice of the EU. The Commission, and I call here with all my heart Commissioner Avramopoulos to look at what really happened on these occasions. I make it clear that, like international law, EUROPEAN law has been infringed. This cannot be tolerated.

name: Ska Keller
text: author. - Mr President, ‘hot returns’ are an illegal practice, and this is not going to change simply by changing a law. The Spanish state is knowingly acting in breach of European and international law by pushing people back through the doors in the fences of Ceuta and Melilla. International borders are established by international treaties. It is not up to the Spanish Government to simply decide where jurisdiction applies and where it does not. The territory between the fences, as well as Spanish territorial waters, clearly belongs to Spanish territory. The EUʼs asylum law, and notably the Reception Directive, clearly also refers to territorial waters. The EU law and the European Convention and international refugee law all forbid returning people without checking, on a case-by-case basis, whether those people are in need of international protection. Likewise, ‘hot returns’ are in breach of the principle of non-refoulement, which is a key principle of international law as well as of European law, and the Spanish Government cannot simply ignore this. But it is not enough to simply look at Spain here. Ceuta and Melilla are part of Spain, but they are also part just as much of Europe. Spanish borders are European borders, and the refugees and migrants there merit European attention and European solidarity. What happens in Spain, what happens at the borders of Europe, is the responsibility of all of us, and we cannot simply ignore it. The rule of law has to apply to everybody, be they citizens of the European Union, of Spain or of any other country, or be they refugees and migrants who come to Europe to look for protection.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, this is the reality in Ceuta and Melilla: beatings on the fence, meats torn by knives, drowned in the sea of insolidarity, while here they fill their mouths talking about the Europe of freedoms. So much hypocrisy! Hypocrisy is also applauding the Pope when he asks that the Mediterranean not become a great cemetery when it turns out that the dead of the Mediterranean are the result of his policies. I don't know, maybe they'll all go to hell. And here's what's going on in Europe. And the "hot returns", which the Government of the People's Party wants to legalize, are this: a beating and for Morocco. They are illegal deportations and have been practiced for a decade. Consented and driven by many of those who here today claim to be shocked. They want to legalize the illegal, because "hot returns" violate, in the Spanish State, the Law on Aliens, the Asylum Law, the Spanish Constitution and the Penal Code. And in Europe, the Return Directive, the Asylum Directive, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights. They also violate the Geneva Convention, the Refugee Statute, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. And these deportations are for many women a death sentence, a condemnation of rape or forced marriages. You have made them the no ones Galeano was talking about. Nobodys. No one's children, the owners of anything. The nobodys, who cost less than the bullet that kills them. The no ones, who have nothing but are rich in dignity. And look, because no ones are more and, fortunately, someday their fences won't be able to stop them.

name: Laura Agea
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again a gloomy European scenario emerges from the Mediterranean in terms of the protection of fundamental human rights. It is illusory to think that the excessive use of force by the authorities, the deaths of migrants, summary expulsions and the violation of human rights are to be considered isolated cases or unfortunate accidents. People have been dying in the Mediterranean for years because thousands of people are prepared to risk their lives in order to cross the border that separates them from Europe. There are not only the recent events in Ceuta and Melilla and the Spanish Government's intentions to confirm this disturbing reality, but also the European Court of Human Rights. It has recently pointed the finger at Member States such as Italy and Greece for their inability to guarantee Article 3 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights, which prohibits inhuman or degrading treatment.  We can therefore only hope, especially in the Mediterranean area, for policies to control borders and manage migratory flows that are more effective and more respectful of human rights than those adopted up to now, the result of which is in everyone's eyes.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks to Parliament for putting this question on the agenda. I believe that the situation in Ceuta and Melilla is really very important and deserves all our attention. In my capacity as Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship I intend to closely monitor and address the situation in Ceuta and Melilla while, at the same time, continuing to support Spain in managing the situation at its external borders. I myself have had the occasion to discuss this matter with the Spanish Minister of the Interior, Jorge Fernández Díaz, just two weeks ago. I have also accepted an invitation from the Minister to visit the two areas concerned in the coming months. I am satisfied that the Minister of the Interior himself and the Spanish authorities are willing to engage in dialogue with the Commission on this issue. However, the situation remains disconcerting and requires our attention. The Commission is concerned by all the allegations as well as the recent proposals to amend the relevant legislation. The Commission is concerned by reports coming from NGOs and the media alleging the summary removal of migrants from both Ceuta and Melilla to Morocco, as well as ill treatment. We take these allegations very seriously. For this reason the Commission is in contact with the Spanish authorities over this matter. It is also important for the Commission to know more about the procedures put in place to ensure the correct application of the principle of non-refoulement and effective access to the asylum procedures. I want to be clear on that. Any border surveillance measure must be proportionate to the objectives pursued. It must be in compliance with respect for the EU Charter on Fundamental Rights and the principle, as I mentioned before, of non-refoulement, and it must respect human dignity. In accordance with these obligations, border control must be carried out while respecting the rights of refugees and persons requesting international protection, in particular as regards the principle of non-refoulement and effective access to the asylum procedures. Any cooperation with third countries must be carried out in full respect of these principles. It is necessary to guarantee effective access to the asylum procedure for those third-country nationals who are on Member State territory, including at the borders, in transit zones or on the territorial seas, and who express a wish to apply for asylum. The Commission is also concerned that the interpretation by Spain of what constitutes an external border, and recent proposals amending relevant legislation – what some have called ‘hot returns’ – might not be in conformity with obligations arising under EU and international law. My predecessor, Commissioner Malmström, had requested that the Spanish Minister of the Interior provide the Commission with information concerning these draft amendments. In addition, my services have already addressed the Spanish authorities at the technical level to better understand the implications of these draft amendments and their conformity with Spain’s obligations under European Union law. As guardian of the Treaties, the Commission follows closely the actions of Member States, and it is the responsibility of the Commission to draw attention to actions which may constitute a violation of European Union laws, in particular when it concerns the protection of the fundamental rights of individuals. The Commission will not hesitate to take appropriate steps where there is evidence that a Member State has violated European Union laws. But I am confident that the dialogue we have opened with the Spanish authorities will have positive results and will lead to the necessary changes, and I am planning to accept the invitation of the Minister and confirm, together with him, the improvements in such a difficult part of our common European borders.

name: Lara Comi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the – Señor Presidente, yo soy italiana, however, I am speaking en la primera parte del debate en español para afirmar con fuerza que el problema de la inmigración es europeo y no sole nacional, y no only italiano, y no only español. All forms of violence must be condemned: it must be condemned when it is carried out by the police and must be condemned when it is also carried out by immigrants and illegal immigrants. The absence of an effective European strategy leads the Member States to individual solutions, as we will see with regard to Spain, which are necessary for the protection of land, security and internal public order, but which are sometimes in danger of being a violation of rights.  There are different interests at stake. First of all, we cannot abandon the boats to their fate. The Member States must therefore also accept illegal immigrants and refugees, and they must also have very rapid timetables for understanding whether they are refugees or illegal, precisely because the difference is important. We must take in the refugees, but we must repatriate illegal immigrants while respecting their rights. I strongly call for the rapid negotiation of agreements with countries of origin and faster procedures, as I said, with regard to the status of refugees. The watchword is zero tolerance of illegal immigration, which gives rise to even more crime. I will end very briefly by saying that I am very pleased that almost the whole Parliament, apart from my colleague, has shared the Pope's words, because we have understood that there are no more Eurosceptics because the Pope said that more Pro-Europeans than this we continue to move forward with solidarity. He did not say that he was leaving either Europe or the euro.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, Nelson Mandela said that discrimination and arbitrariness degrade those who suffer from it, but above all degrade those who practice or promote it. Witnesses and images prove the unacceptable practice of 'hot returns'. For everyone to understand: a hot return consists in the delivery to the Moroccan authorities of a foreign citizen, intercepted as irregular on this side of the fence, by the forces and security forces dependent on the Government of Spain. And this practice is contrary to Spanish law, it is contrary to the Spanish Constitution, it is contrary to European law, it is contrary to international treaties for the protection of human rights and, in particular, the protection of refugees. And the Spanish Government knows that this practice cannot be validated by legal reform, in so far as it remains contrary to international law and international human rights law. The Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe, Mr Nils Mui-nieks, has expressed his opposition to this practice and his concern. Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom has done the same in a blunt letter to the Government of Spain. Now it is your turn to speak to the current Commission, it is your turn to speak, Mr Avramopoulos, to set a clear position on unacceptable practices which worsen when, moreover, they are accompanied by abuses which harm fundamental rights — as we have seen in those images of people who are forcible and dragged across the fence, as if they had never been on Spanish territory. Therefore, here we have a real fire test of the quality of European law, which is our raison d'etion. If there is one thing that distinguishes, which is a real test of quality, a legal order as a civilization based on law is precisely the treatment of the other, the treatment of the different, the treatment abroad. That is why it is so important that the European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, should say as soon as possible what it thinks of these practices — in our view manifestly illegal and contrary to European law — and what it intends to do to prevent the consumption of such legal reform, which in no case can be validated, because it remains contrary to international human rights law. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – The Spanish Government is breaking European law. I am interested to know how you would deal with this. If they continued to defy it, would you like to see the Spanish Government forcibly replaced by the EU? Then, if there were more immigrants allowed in as a consequence of this, would you like to see the EU nation states forced to accept quotas of those people who come into Spain, to lessen the blow to Spain?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – The answer is very simple. Every time a Member State fails to comply with European law, the Commission, which is the guardian of the Treaties, intervenes. And it is debated in this European Parliament. But you know what I'm saying? That is not only contrary to European law, it is also contrary to Spanish law, which does not allow 'hot returns'. Spanish law provides for expulsions, in accordance with a rules of procedure and on a sanctioning basis, which is not the case with an irregularly intercepted person. Spanish law also provides for rejection at the border, but at the points enabled and in agreement , equally - with a rule of procedure, but in no case provides for a direct surrender to the Moroccan authorities that involves ignoring or violating the procedure governed by Spanish law and that does not offer any guarantee, nor of legal assistance, nor of information of their rights , nor as an interpreter. That is contrary, first of all, to Spanish law, but it is equally contrary to European law and refugee protection, in so far as it does not give any opportunity to the percentage, even if it is a minority, of those fleeing persecution or deserve subsidiary protection to prove that they are in a situation which deserves protection by a Member State of the European Union.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner has said, the situation in Ceuta and Melilla is very politically and humanely worrying. Although it does not account for most of the irregular entry of people in Spain or the European Union, it challenges us, because the situation in Ceuta and Melilla rots. Time passes and one Commissioner after another is asked, as we asked you today, Mr Avramopoulos. He has answered us, as guardian of the Treaties, saying that the management of immigration and borders must be done with strict respect for human rights and, we would say, even, the working conditions of those who protect them. The Government of my country intends to legalise 'hot returns' , which it calls border rejection, therefore, a practice which could violate the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, will be integrated into the Spanish immigration legal system. You have spoken of knowing on the ground, of dialogue, of the necessary changes... In any case, we follow the debate on the previous point, Mr Avramopoulos. The Spanish governments have failed to guarantee the inviolability of the border, despite having resorted to methods of deterrence , such as those known as concertinas – and border staff work in difficult conditions, sometimes with vague orders. In any case, we act as an emergency. We have a wall, it's going to make a moat. In the long run, there are no possible borders for the desperate. There are no possible shortcuts to the Treaty either. The change in the law will not solve the problem, but it will eliminate the right of immigrants to deal with legal guarantees and the possibility of applying for asylum at the border. The European Union needs to be involved in the situation of these borders and ensure great challenges, be a guarantor of human rights, support Spain in order to be able to make effective and fair management of the border, assuming the establishment of safe corridors for asylum, the transnational management of entries into the European Union and, above all, we have to act in development aid , ensuring the effective use of European funds. We continued in the previous debate.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President: "We entered Melilla but the Civil Guard stopped us. We got hit with pounds for five to ten minutes. They handcuffed us and then opened the gate of the fence and handed us over to the Moroccan forces. Then, there, they beat us with canes, forced us to lie face down on the ground without taking our handcuffs off and stayed on the ground for an hour as they beat us." Joseph is Cameroonian, he's my age, and as he tells this, he's got a swollen eye and he's lame. Commissioner, your predecessor wrote a very short letter to my country's home minister denouncing this practice, which has been so common , by the way, for more than ten years — as illegal. The rules in the European Union prohibit countries from forcibly taking people to territories where they would be exposed to inhuman and degrading treatment. Well, everyone knows that, even if you lack proof. There are videos, there are photos, there are testimonies of all kinds. In Spain they are dispensed with this treatment directly and then carried away by the door of the fence as the one who throws the garbage, so that they continue to be treated as such on the other side. And what are we going to do? What will you do, Commissioner? What will this Parliament do? What is a Parliament that does not care about the application of its own laws, but a very expensive circus?

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that you are obliged to act at the moment, for a very simple reason. As my colleagues have already said, on 15 October Commissioner Malmstrom sent a letter to the Minister of the Interior saying that such a practice – 'hot returns' – constituted a violation of European Union law. I don't say this, the letter said it. In addition, the letter mentioned which laws were violated: the Schengen Borders Code, the Asylum Procedures Directive, the Charter of Fundamental Rights. So, here the question is very simple. If the Commission has acknowledged in writing that 'hot returns' are not in conformity with European law, will you allow nothing to happen, for a State to make it national law without you acting? I say this because this would create a very worrying precedent in the implementation of European legislation throughout the Member States.
