I do not think that you want to allow legal loopholes in which European law does not apply at the moment, in the European Union. Really because, if that were the case, the Commission's role as guarantor of European law and its application would really be called into question. I believe that you have no choice but to act and prevent that from occurring.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today in this Chamber the Pope has reiterated very simple concepts, of a disarming humanity and perhaps a little too much used for our use and consumption. Addressing those women and men who need help and acceptance, he spoke of the repeatability and uniqueness of every human life, of dignity that can only be there when fundamental human rights are guaranteed. He said that we must prevent the Mediterranean from becoming a great graveyard. For many people it has already become so, many families will never mourn the people who died. Let us not forget that. Europe cannot take the form of a fortress under siege by the peoples living on the other side of the Mediterranean. The Member States in that area, which are most affected by migratory pressures, cannot be left alone. The money that the European Union and the individual States are allocating to the system of managing flows and reception must be subject to stricter controls, in order to prevent fraud, speculation and waste. A greater joint effort is still needed to ensure that the Eu ropean Union and the individual Member States have immigration legislation that is rigorous, effective and essentially respectful of human rights.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE). -
text: Mr President, yes, I too will quote the Pope. This morning he said 'appropriate legislation to ensure the reception of immigrants' and I say 'amen' to that. I mean it honestly. The Spanish Aliens Law, reformed five times, includes seven legal figures: refusal of entry, prohibition of entry, return, compulsory departure, expulsion procedure, readmission and containment of entry. I would say that it is a guarantee law, which provides for legal assistance, interpreter, hearing, reasoned decision of the competent authority and appeal. Moreover, the so-called Community law: the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, in Article 77 there, proclaims that 'the European Union shall develop a policy which shall aim at ... ensure people's checks and effective border surveillance." Ceuta and Melilla are considered the Union's land border on the African continent and also have extraordinary migratory pressure. Irregular immigrant inscations to Ceuta grew by 73% and these borders have been violently assaulted by 17,000 people. The contents of the oral question, plagued by partial or singular and uninformed interpretations, are essentially pending a very unique judicial decision, in one case, and in another, which we essentially debate here, of intentions. Here's a debate about intentions. See what's scientific and political about it. I believe in international protection and defend it — and my country too – but access to international protection is subject to Community rules. I want a common asylum, I want a Common European Asylum System (SECA), but here we are in the presence of a majority group - with the exception of 1.5% seeking asylum - that what it does is not to seek asylum, is to storm borders, as has been shown. I also believe in subsidiary protection and rejection, which is clear, if it were to occur in Spain or any other country, any action outside the legality. Border rejections, Mr President, are covered by four rules: a Community Directive, the Shengen Convention, the Spanish Penal Code ( in Articles 89 and 96 ) and the Frontex Regulation. I, never, as the House know, refer to immigration with the adjective of "illegal", ever. I never give a criminal dimension to any immigrant. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: blue card question. – Mr Díaz de Mera, look, depending on European law, anyone arriving on European territory has the right to be heard. And if you are an asylum seeker, you have the right to have a whole procedure done to see if that person is worthy of asylum. In all the images in Ceuta and Melilla it is seen how the Civil Guard catches people who have already entered Spanish territory and they are automatically expelled outside the European territory. In that case, there are only two explanations for this: the first, that the Government considers ceuta and Melilla not to be European or Spanish territory — which, if defended, would seem a little surprising to me; the second, that all procedures laid down in this area should not be applied. In that sense, I'd like to ask you what your opinion is on that.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you very much, Mr President. I would be happy to answer such a thoughtful question. I don't know if the answer will live up to the question, but in any case, I answer it. No, no, I'll get back to you. Look at you, Mr. Urtasun. Everything you say is judicialized. A question that is judicialized and pending resolution can in no way be an issue that is discussed in a House like this, where what seems, more than anything else, is not that we are in the presence of a political debate, but that we are in the presence of an ordeal. What is an ordeal? An ordeal is God's judgment. Well, here's a big court, very singular courtroom, divided into two big groups: three and the rest. For what? To judge on intentions and to judge on cases that are subject to judicial jurisdiction. That is my answer, with the plea of your consideration.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D). -
text: Mr President, despite the very long plea of Mr Daaz de Mera Garcia Consuegra, what an irony of fate and, perhaps even, what schizophrenia for Europe!  We have only just concluded the previous debate which, in general, reflects the need for a comprehensive approach by the European Union on migration. In any case, that is what I understood, and our discussion is now about summary expulsions of migrants to Spain and the Spanish government's attempts to make these practices legally possible. How can we succeed in the challenge of a truly coherent, protective and effective migration policy if, at the same time, there are attempts to unravel European legislation and values? More specifically, with regard to the situation at hand in Ceuta and Melilla, the questions we address are simple and fairly direct, and the answers must be just as simple.  What makes it possible for a Member State not to comply with the safeguards provided by the Returns Directive? What allows us to be exempted from the principle of non-refoulement and effective access to the asylum procedure?  If Europe and its Member States simply apply the logics of 'everyone at home' or 'everyone for oneself', we will not meet these challenges presented by migration, and I believe that we will not live up to the collective challenges of our continent.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, as has already been detailed here, the Spanish Government violates all the laws which have taken place and because it expels in summary terms, without asking for origin or destination and without asking, of course, whether they wish to benefit from asylum — by the way, as has already been said, another of the great victims of this waste in the European Union. The repression of The Spanish and Moroccan security forces has caused the deaths of dozens of people. How many more must die? I repeat the question which has already been launched here: what other evidence does the European Commission need? The Spanish Government now says that it wants to legalise summary expulsions and this is very serious, and I do not yet know what the European Commission will do about it, because I want to assume - I want to think that at least - that these summary expulsions would still be illegal at European level. We talk—and it sounds like a lie—about people. The European Commission must be much more involved, not just accepting pantomimes of collaboration offered to it by the Spanish Government. You must act.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, we must remember that there have already been many dramatic actions in Spain to use force against immigrants, with very serious consequences for them. This does not depend on my intentions or my interpretation. These are facts. Now, the Spanish Government wants to reform the Law on the Rights and Freedoms of Foreigners in Spain so that foreigners – obviously the poor – can be expelled without the necessary legal procedures, and that is not done either to protect the state or to protect internal order. They are illegal expulsions, surely in contravention of the third article of the Spanish Constitution and all fundamental rights. The Spanish government wants to legalize illegality. This should not be possible in a Member State of the European Union. My parliamentary group opposes this and I reject it myself. I hope the Commission will too.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE). -
text: Mr President, this is certainly a matter of state because we are talking about people, but we are also talking about borders. Ceuta and Melilla have a geographical, political and migratory uniqueness unlike any other territory. The world's greatest inequality is concentrated there in just a few kilometers. It is the only land outer border in Western Europe. It is the only border located in Africa. That is why the Government of Spain, always in accordance with legality, tries to combine the balance between the undeniable humanitarian dimension that has the situation of millions and millions of human beings who are playing their lives every day in order to find a better life and respect for the whole acquis of fundamental rights, which must undoubtedly be combined with the indispensable responsibility that any State has with regard to border control. It is substantial to the very idea of a state, as recognized by the Organic Law on State Security Forces and Bodies and also the Schengen borders code. I have to say that the Government of Spain applies the principles of opportunity, proportionality and convenience, and the protection of the integrity of immigrants always prevails in any action. As for the right to asylum, it is not constilled. The United Nations High Commissioner congratulated the Government of Spain on the establishment of offices and units for the care of asylum seekers and international protection at these borders in Ceuta and Melilla.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Avramopoulos, despite what some are declaring lately, the images are obvious, so is the news. Hot returns are common in the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla. And they are thanks to the complicity of the Spanish police and the Moroccan police, who act outside the law. A Moroccan policewoman, let us not forget, repeatedly denounced for her actions against human rights. Any attempt to legalize or tolerate such returns involves abandoning people returned to a government that does not respect their rights. As my colleagues in the Caballas de Ceuta Coalition say, to which I have the honour to represent in this House, these returns ensure that human rights end in Algeciras. Returns will not stop the exodus of a desperate African population, without any possibility of future, a victim of war and hunger. Europe must condemn these practices without mitigation and bet, once and for all, on a joint, coordinated immigration policy, where the right to asylum, the free mobility of people and the guarantee of human rights are the priority. Mr Avramopoulos, you said that you are going to visit the city of Ceuta. I invite you to speak, to talk, to receive the people of the Caballas Coalition, the second political force in the city. Will you meet with them? Will you know your version of events? Will you know your work with these people and with this problem? I'd love for you to say yes. I'm sure they'd be very happy.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the situation we are debating today is of such complexity that only joint, supportive and responsible action by all the countries of the Union, in cooperation with third countries where immigrants come from, can move us towards the goal that we all , and I repeat, all of them - want to achieve. This goal is nothing more than to confront immigration by respecting two important words with capital "d", which are the human rights and dignity of people who see in Europe a paradise that, on so many occasions, becomes hell. Or is it that the dream of so many women and girls who come cheated by mafias doesn't turn into a nightmare when they have to practice prostitution? And that's just one example. Behind each person is a story, often of frustration and pain, due to the cruelty of traffickers, the main enemies of immigrants. We have to stop being hypocrites, ladies and gentlemen. You can't talk about controlling immigration flows without offering the means to do so. The constructive thing would be to help countries that are overwhelmed by migration pressure and which, assuming the Schengen Code, are trying to fulfil their obligation to offer citizens safer borders. Because let us not deceive ourselves: in my country, Spain, the person who wants to apply for asylum can do so legally. What our legislation and no European directive do not envisage is for borders to be asalred by force. Nothing's going to get better if we keep blaming each other, because governments change, ladies and gentlemen. So do we parliamentarians come and go. But the human drama of immigration will remain there as long as we do not face it with the necessary realism, without the political opportunism that we are sadly seeing here today.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it seems that in Spain we are now facing the first serious issue of human rights violations and that is where your action must be immediate and effective. It is obvious that a brutal violation of human rights is being committed in Ceuta and Melilla. There is a strong attack on European culture. Human dignity is being shattered. You must therefore take immediate action and you must make use of both your visit and those legal projects and instruments provided by the Treaty, in particular these. But the situation itself shows that we must move forward, using integrated instruments, and formulate a development policy for the Mediterranean, a guarantee and development policy for the region and at the same time comprehensive arrangements on migration and asylum issues. These are very important issues. You should also consider how Dublin III will be abolished. This situation cannot continue. That's why we have these phenomena.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, for diversity, perhaps the only one in this Chamber today, I will not quote the Pope, but I will try to draw your attention to a problem that seems to me extremely significant, namely the problem of illegal immigration, which is at the borders of the European Union. Yes, of course, when we talk about refugees, when we talk about people in need, we have a duty to help, but when we talk about illegal immigrants, things are completely different. Yes, Spain has a problem, yes, Greece has a problem, yes, Italy has a problem, yes Bulgaria has a problem with the illegal crossing of our state borders by tens, by hundreds, by thousands of people. And yes, the European Commission must propose a fair option to spread the burden, both financially and humanly, in relation to these illegal immigrants, but what needs to be known is that the increased flow of illegal immigrants on our territory has increased the criminologist factor and increased cases of public order violations. It's something we can't keep letting happen.  I respect the right and obligation of every country to protect its national borders, it is its fundamental right and obligation. The border furrow must be crossed, but only at the crossing points. And let's not forget, dear colleagues, let's not forget that there is a country that organizes trafficking, and this is the state of Turkey, which directs illegal immigrants in the direction of Bulgaria and Greece.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to propose that we refer Pope Francis' speech this morning to the Spanish Minister of the Interior. In this way, you will know that the concertinas and wounds that produce, in that we agree, the beatings between fences or the shooting of people trying to make landfall on 6 February 2014 are policies that fill the Mediterranean with corpses, because they are policies based on injustice, that produce violence and that oppose the values of the European project. Legalizing hot returns clearly violates the Charter of Fundamental Rights — and I will not mention Commissioner Malmstrom's letter again. But, in case the papal arguments fail, I would ask you: does the Commission believe that an infringement procedure for abuses already committed would allow Spain to understand that they cannot legalise with internal rules the expulsion of people fleeing poverty with internal rules, without any legal guarantee? I'd like you to answer me, Commissioner.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, the behaviour of the Spanish authorities towards these desperate Africans is a reflection of the true attitude of Madrid towards the rule of law. We heard last week that the Catalan President is to be charged with the crime of disobedience because he held an unofficial referendum on Catalan independence. He may now face up to a year in prison and be banned from public office for 10 years. Does anyone in this Chamber imagine that the Spanish officials who are breaking the law by throwing migrants back over the fence will ever be threatened with such a punishment as a year in prison? They will not be threatened with any punishment at all. As for the transgressions against Gibraltarian sovereignty, I rest my case.

name: Δημήτρης Αβραμόπουλος
text: Member of the Commission. - I heard your views on the seriousness of the events. In my introduction I set out the Commission's line and policy, the steps that have been taken and what is to follow. I would also like to stress that I will work with and work with everyone, both with the European Parliament and with the Member States, without suspicion and without prejudice, on the basis of the same principles that I believe we all respect and demand to be respected in this area.  I can assure you, Mr Maria, because we discussed this in a previous debate, that it is our political decision to adopt a holistic, coherent and principled immigration policy. That's where we're going to move. I am sure that the Spanish authorities will give us clear, convincing and reliable answers to the rumored amendment to which you referred. I am optimistic that the situation in this region will improve immediately. I repeat that neither Spain is alone nor any other of the countries under enormous pressure and you know that there are too many of them. However, Spain, like all countries, must respect the European acquis and make immediate adjustments and changes when practices such as those denounced are applied and recorded. We have opened a dialogue and we hope that it will give the desired results. On the basis of the results of this dialogue, we will proceed with our next moves.  As I said earlier, I have indeed accepted the invitation and preparations have already begun for my visit to Spain, namely Ceuta and Melilla. I will convey a double message: that Spain is not alone and that all of us who welcome asylum seekers or those who have come as migrants to our external borders must do so in the name of Europe, respecting, honouring and applying the common principles.

name: El Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Spanish borders in the Mediterranean are subject to extraordinary migratory pressure. We all understand the reasons why thousands of people try to cross our borders every month, but it is also true that all Member States implement a migration policy according to which access to the European Union is not unlimited. The Spanish police have no easy task: to prevent the clandestine entry of waves of immigrants who sometimes use violent means. Certainly, its action must be proportionate and in accordance with Spanish and European law; it would also be necessary to have strong support from the European Union for the control of what is no longer its borders, as well as an explanation of what is meant by 'hot return', since airports in all European capitals proceed to return those migrants arriving by plane from Africa who are not eligible to enter the country , without this fact having raised any complaints, even though the airports are the national territory of the Member States.

name: El Presidente. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question with an oral response request from the Commission on the EU Strategic Framework on Occupational Health and Safety 2014-2020, Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000075/2014 - (2014/2861(RSP)) - B8-0034/2014).

name: Marita Ulvskog
text: questioners. - (C) In the Europe of the crisis, security and justice have been put at an exception. This is also very much true in the labour market. It is definitely about the working environments that have become harder and more dangerous. Having strong common rules for the working environment is a profit-making business for all of us. Not only for those who work, not only for all citizens, but also for businesses. According to an international study, companies investing EUR 10 in preventive work environment can expect a return of more than double. Having strong common rules for a good working environment also means ensuring competition on equal terms. In order not to distort competition in the internal market, a common minimum standard is required. However, this must not, of course, prevent Member States and companies from keeping and demanding a higher standard. Regulatory simplification and reduction of bureaucracy must never be allowed at the expense of people's lives and health. Proposals to exempt SMEs from health and safety requirements do not help anyone, either companies or workers. Quite the opposite. Large companies have the resources to cope with if an accident occurs or when staff are on long-term sick leave. In a small company, the margins are smaller, there it is exactly the opposite: every single employee means an enormous amount and you often have neither insurance nor staff who can handle if something happens. That is why health and safety issues are so important for very small companies as well.  Everyone should have the right to the same good working environment no matter what company you work in. That will be my given conclusion. The proposals that have so far been on the table here in the European Parliament have taken a different starting point. They would exempt over 90% of all employees in the EU from living by health and safety rules. Such a proposal is, of course, totally unacceptable to many – I would say with certainty a majority of Members of this House. If these proposals are repeated in the coming parliamentary term, they will face very strong opposition. That is why it is so important that we address this issue at the beginning of this parliamentary term. The solution is not to erode the rules, but to make it easier for companies and individuals to comply with the rules. This requires an offensive EU programme. Support systems, new risk management tools for small businesses are needed to facilitate osh work and strengthened trade union training that can make conscious workers even better at dealing with complex work environments and also contribute to real simplification – real simplification, without deterioration in the working environment. The EU therefore urgently needs a new aggressive strategy on health and safety at work covering everything from workplace accidents to cancer risks and psychosocial damage and stresses. That's thinking long-term. It's thinking radically. It's thinking humanly. It is a good union for working life and competition rules that allows us to continue to be strong producers of goods and services that we can then sell or use ourselves.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the Commission is firmly committed to improving working conditions and, in particular, health and safety at work. The new EU strategic framework that was adopted in June reflects this commitment. The European Union has a comprehensive body of legislation on health and safety at work in place already. Our new strategic framework complements the legal acquis by promoting a holistic culture of prevention. It also provides a framework for coordinating national policies and improving implementation. The framework identifies three main challenges: to improve implementation of occupational health and safety legislation, in particular by enhancing the capacity of small and micro enterprises to put in place effective risk preventive measures; to improve prevention of work-related diseases by tackling existing, new and emerging risks; and thirdly, to address demographic change and the ageing of the workforce. On these points we can make progress only with the active collaboration of all the relevant stakeholders. The Commission is working closely with the Member States, the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work, the Tripartite Advisory Committee on Health and Safety at Work and the Senior Labour Inspectors Committee to ensure appropriate implementation of these existing rules. The Agency and the two Committees are reviewing their work programmes in light of the new strategic framework. I will continue to involve the social partners, including through sectoral dialogue when appropriate. With the assistance of the Tripartite Advisory Committee on Health and Safety at Work, the Commission intends to develop a tool to monitor better the implementation of the framework. I take note of your request in the oral question to introduce specific indicators in this regard. Several measures are being implemented already, such as the online interactive risk assessment tool developed by the Agency and a Europe-wide training programme for labour inspectors. A study on improving labour inspections in small and micro enterprises in the area of health and safety at work is currently under preparation. A number of user-friendly good-practice guides are already available with a view to supporting SMEs and micro-enterprises. In line with the Regulatory Fitness and Performance programme, the new strategic framework sets as an objective simplifying and rationalising the legal framework, in particular for SMEs, while at the same time ensuring the same level of protection. In this regard, the Commission has launched an ex post evaluation of 24 existing directives. The results are expected for the end of 2015. Furthermore, the framework highlights the need to address the impact on physical and mental health of changes in work organisation – a point which Parliament also underlined. It further acknowledges the need to improve statistics related to occupational safety and to set up a database. Statistics are critical to identify the various hazards, and your suggestions will be taken into account. Finally, let me mention that the results of the ongoing evaluation of the occupational safety and health directives will be determined to decide about possible new legislative initiatives. Occupational safety and health legislation should be evidence-based, and any new proposal will be based on a thorough impact assessment.

name: Heinz K. Becker
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. By a majority of 46:1:1, we in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs adopted this question to the Commission, thereby making it clear by common agreement that we are not yet satisfied with the state of play as far as the priorities for the coming years are concerned. We very often have serious consequences due to the working environment and occupational health problems, which are associated with high costs for medical treatment, with corresponding absences and with loss of income for workers and employers. I can see from what you have said, Commissioner, that you have clearly recognised this. I know because otherwise you could not make that definition, and I was also pleased to note that the holistic approach seems to be taken into account here. However, we know that even clearer targets and more binding deadlines are something that is missing from this strategic framework. I believe that areas such as the monitoring of health risks and the definition of an accident at work and occupational illness are also necessary here. All in all, I believe that we are not yet at the end of the road here, and I would be pleased if, at a further stage of cooperation with you, Commissioner, it would be possible to see the fulfilment of this plan in a very concrete way.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Commission's proposal came rather late, as the European Parliament had already called for a succession strategy in 2011. I must admit that what is on the table is not really a strategy. As my colleague has said, there are no concrete proposals, improvements, targets, a timeframe, especially because we always have new challenges due to technological changes, including new forms of work, new forms of illness. Just one example: more than 80% of cases of depression occur at working age. One in ten employees is absent due to depression. We need education and prevention programmes. Health and safety at work must be taken seriously. As legislators, we have a duty to ensure that all those who work are healthy. We must protect them. I am also concerned that, because of the red tape, small and medium-sized enterprises may be exempted from certain provisions. This is said to increase competitiveness. What is concealed, however, is that burdens and consequences are then transferred to the general public, away from companies to people, to society. We believe that it is better to support small and medium-sized enterprises in prevention and implementation. This is better than passing on risks.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I welcome the review. We need a health and safety framework which reflects changing work patterns and new and emerging risks. With any review we also need to embrace the principles of better regulation and the approach that we have heard expounded by Commissioner Timmermans. We need regulations to keep people safe, and I will never support measures which make workers less safe. There is a misconception, though, that better regulation means a race to the bottom in terms of workers’ protection and health and safety. That is not the case. We should reduce the complexity of health and safety legislation, because if we do, we can increase compliance. We can achieve our policy goals of enhanced health and safety, while reducing the burdens on business. I strongly believe that health and safety inspections should concentrate on what is actually happening in the particular workplace, rather than on whether they have got the right document in the filing cabinet. So I welcome the commitment to simplifying legislation and reducing administrative burdens, and we really must consider how risk assessment documentation for small enterprises in low-risk sectors could be made easier.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her response. However, I think it is important that we underscore what we are talking about here, because every year, more than 4 000 workers die in the EU due to accidents at work. More than three million workers are victims of accidents that mean they have to take more than three days off work. I mean, those are hugely significant figures. We are talking about 11 people every day who die from workplace accidents and over 8 000 who are injured. That is why this question was put to the Commission, and while there are a number of specific questions here, and I do not expect the Commissioner to answer all of them – I just want to ask, maybe to tease out one or two of the issues that we have raised here. When we talked about measurable goals with fixed timetables and periodic evaluation, I just want to ask: has any progress been made on, let us say, improving coverage of statistics, on reliability, on comparability, on the timeliness? Is there any specific progress that we can point to? What actions have been taken in order to promote exchange of good practices? For example, where SMEs might be mentored or supported by larger enterprises in the contractor-supplier-purchaser chain, have we any examples of that? We have heard a lot of talk about straightforward legislation and user-friendly guides. I think some of those may have been provided by OSHA, but again, if the Commissioner can give me any detail on that? The issue of gender and age-specific disaggregated statistics is very important, because I believe that if we can get our hands on that information, it will deliver better policy outcomes. So again, is there is any progress on that? Two final points. In a recent Eurobarometer study, workers considered stress to be the main occupational risk – 53% of them. Now I know that the European Agency for Health and Safety at Work is running an awareness-raising campaign – the Healthy Workplaces Campaign – but, given that it is such a high risk, I think that we need greater intervention on this issue and I think more needs to be done. I just want to ask the Commissioner if there are any proposals at all to promote a healthy environment and mental wellbeing at work. Finally, you will be aware that during the last mandate the Commission were proposing, at least, that we might have a directive on musculoskeletal diseases. That was dropped by the Council, but again, if we go to that same survey carried out by Eurobarometer, we see that one in every four says that ergonomic risks are very significant. So in that context, again, while I am not suggesting that we might look at a directive – but the last Commission thought it was necessary – has the Commissioner any thoughts in mind as to how we might deal with that issue in a more effective way?

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity for this debate on health and safety in the workplace, and I welcome the Commission’s declared desire to protect workers. However, I feel we cannot on the one hand introduce measures to protect workers while on the other hand we pursue policies that are leading to precarious and insecure working conditions. Part-time and precarious work is becoming the norm, and Ireland – my country – has had a 46% increase since 2008 in the number of workers who are underemployed. The psychosocial health impacts this phenomenon has on workers cannot be underestimated. Job insecurity and the pressure of irregular hours causes significant stress for workers and leads to sick days. Many of these workers are trapped in jobs that do not pay a living wage. These low wages then negatively impact on their ability to access healthcare and nutritious food. So if we are to truly engage with the issue of health and safety for the working population, then we must also tackle the issue of low pay and insecure working conditions.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my report in 2011 aimed to improve the health and safety of Europeans at work with ambitious objectives. That was three years ago, colleagues. Three years! And today, for 2014-2020, the Commission's framework is light years away. Every year, 168,000 people die in Europe as a result of work-related accidents and illnesses. These are cancers for more than half and cardiovascular disease for a quarter. It is a moral fault to turn a blind eye to suffering at work. This is an economic fault because accidents and diseases cost our social security systems and also our businesses dearly.  So what indicators do you intend to put in place, in particular to measure the inequality between men and women in the workplace? Do you really intend to involve the social partners, which was not the case in 2006? Do you intend to give a definition of occupational accidents and illnesses?  Your policy framework is not up to scratch, and Jean-Claude Juncker often says that his Commission is the last chance. Rather, I would say that this is the European Commission's last chance to reconcile Europeans with work, simply because European citizens can no longer lose their lives to earn it.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest estimates by the International Agency for Research on Cancer state that more than two and a half million European citizens fall ill with cancer every year. 8% of these citizens fall ill from occupational exposure. These occupational exposures still include exposure to asbestos fibres. 56% of cases of pleural mesothelioma and 41% of asbestosis cases occur in Europe, where we have only 13% of the world's population. And if it goes wrong with regard to exposure to asbestos fibres, it is certainly worse for the petrochemical sector, as far as steelworks, steel works and cement plants are concerned. Do we want to put an end to this crap, don't we? So I already know, someone from the Commission will say 'these are matters for the Member States'. However, the Member States are like Italy and the Eternit scandal, so thousands of citizens have not received justice in order to save just one politician. Let's put an end to this crap!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI). -
text: Mr President, the important thing in this respect is to realise that health and safety at work is not just something that should be imposed. Entrepreneurs themselves need to understand that the health and safety of workers significantly increases their productivity and performance, and thus also the growth of their companies. One factor inextricably linked to the issue we are discussing is prevention. I am referring not only to occupational accidents often caused by the lack or inadequacy of protection measures, but also to occupational diseases, which are a relatively neglected area. Many workers are affected by various cancers, skin conditions, musculoskeletal problems and other diseases due to working conditions and the materials with which they come into contact.  But how can there be prevention when, because of the crisis and the policy of austerity, countries such as Greece are experiencing a complete collapse of their health systems? I only mention that a patient in Greece, for a simple examination, faces an average waiting time of six months. So you understand that, under these circumstances, it is unrealistic to talk about prevention. Prevention saves lives, but some people are actually only interested in the well-being of numbers and not of peoples or people. With the professional imposition of austerity, with the memoranda and with the troika's imperatives, workers are simply left to their own luck.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Improve working conditions in the EU together – agree! Do we also want to be able to take the lead in health and safety worldwide? Is that too high? To my colleagues on the far right, more Europe is needed here. 3 million workers suffer accidents at work and 4 000 die every year. One notices the importance of this issue. The 1989 framework directive was a breakthrough in the approximation of working conditions in the Member States – that is a long time ago. Now we need a new strategic framework, the approach is right, and we have said in the field of employment that we need the 'yes' to new objectives, 'yes at reasonable times' and, above all, 'yes' to cooperation with the social partners. Small businesses need the greatest need for action. Company sizes are a key factor in employee risks. In micro-enterprises in particular, the rules tend to be adhered to only to a small extent, mainly because of high costs. I would argue that no new bureaucracy should be created, but that companies should be supported in terms of concrete health and safety at work, that we adapt legislation and that small and medium-sized enterprises should then be at the centre of the 2016 revision, so that we ensure that concrete measures finally take effect.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I really do hate to say it, but the Commissioner has done again what she did this morning. She has come with warm words and all the right noises but she has presented a strategic framework that is not strategic and is not a framework. To be honest, it is blarney: there is no content. Where is the carcinogens provision? Cancer, we know, is the largest single killer of people at work. It is not in this apparently strategic supposed framework. Where is asbestos, which kills tens of thousands of people a year now? Where is it in this supposedly strategic so-called framework? What about blacklisting? Three thousand people in the UK were blacklisted, mainly from construction sites, for daring to raise concerns about health and safety. Where is that important issue in this supposedly strategic non-framework? What about the transposition of the list of occupational diseases into something that actually can be used at EU level? I am sure the Commissioner is sincere in her warm words and benevolent noises but, unless we have some content and some action to actually make a difference, then it starts to look like a smoke-screen.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI). -
text: Mr President, occupational health and safety is a pillar of the operation of a company and the well-being of employees. In the face of increasing technology and the emergence of new occupational risks, more than ever, regulatory requirements in this area must be maintained. However, the crisis that we are going through and which we will continue to suffer as a result of an economic environment that is still fragile is a severe blow to prevention and safety at work within companies, which are certainly expensive but essential. Let us make no mistake, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is not the solution. The Ultraliberal Commission does not intend to support occupational health and safety, and attempts at harmonization will result in an obvious social less than not. Technocracy at the behest of multinationals dreams of a large free labour market in Europe, at the expense of rules protecting workers. Let us remain on our guard, the European Union is not the doctor, it is the disease.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the new framework has been delayed, but we must still recognise that progress has been made. However, the challenge remains dying. Indeed, the figures were quoted: every day, eleven people die at work and more than 8,000 people have serious illnesses. This means that during my speech, eight workers will suffer serious accidents at work. It is a terrible human tragedy but also an impact on the economy, businesses and social security. I can welcome the will of this plan, but we cannot be content with intentions, we need numerical and evaluable objectives. The key word must be prevention, a permanent action that involves all actors and social partners at all levels, it is crucial. We must also provide social inspections with human resources and training opportunities to respond to new risks associated with new ways of working, new products and longer careers. The communication rightly cites the importance of targeting small and medium-sized enterprises, they need to be helped and supported.  Finally, I would like to stress this point: it is necessary to simplify regulations, but it can never be done by jeopardising the health and safety of employees. Their health and their lives cannot be priceless.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D). -
text: It is a good thing that the Commission wants fewer rules for companies, but securing good working conditions must be above all else. I therefore hope that you will proceed carefully in the development of this new approach. A Europe that works is primarily for people and not just for businesses. In addition, in recent years we have seen a proliferation of all kinds of new forms of work: working as bogus self-employed, flexible workers or working under persistently precarious temporary employment contracts, without any firmness and also without the same employment protection. My question is: does the Commission intend to use a targeted approach to ensure health and safety at work for these people? I would also like to point out that there are still groups of workers who are completely outside the strategic framework. For example, police officers and military personnel do not have the same guarantees for health and safety at work. My question is therefore: will the Commission soon come up with concrete measures to also offer these people, who are responsible for our safety, the same guarantees for the protection of their work in the workplace?

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: In the European Union and in capitalism, the health, safety and life of workers are seen as a cost and sacrificed on the altar of profit. Enforcement is loosening, audit services are being abolished, employers are being acquitted of accidents at work and for killing workers, workers are being blackmailed into silence about working conditions and accidents, workers are themselves being burdened with hospitalisation and rehabilitation by living on wheelchair-spoofing allowances. Hundreds are murdered, disabled workers in shipyards, factories, transport in Greece. Pregnant women are threatened with dismissal to terminate pregnancy. Thousands suffer from occupational diseases, migrants live and work in squalid conditions. Hundreds of thousands die in the Union from occupational diseases and there are thousands of fatal accidents every year. The safety, health and life of workers is a top priority for the labour movement and for communists who demand strict legislation on preventive measures and rehabilitation of the disabled and sick from occupational diseases at the sole expense of the state and employers, imposing penalties on those responsible and granting adequate pensions to the families of the victims.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the subject we are dealing with is a subject which has touched a great deal on the economic, political and cultural debate in my country too, namely Italy. Mention has been made of the strange and very long deaths and processes in the asbestos case, and the scourge of this strong subject is really rightly occupying the debate in my country and in Europe.  Europe is a community with very advanced legislation on the subject of safety at work. Unfortunately, this good legislation in individual countries often turns into formalism and bureaucracy. So how to achieve the goal? First of all, I remember the great lesson of a lawyer who lost his life in Italy because of his ideas, Marco Biagi, who taught us that topics like this must be addressed by putting the objectives first and not the rules.  So, what's our goal? First of all, training and information. But not only of the workers: also of the young people who are preparing to reach the world of work. They come to you with the awareness of what a good job means, how you choose it and, if you cannot choose it, how you defend it: with what rules, with what objectives, with what dignity in the relationship with the employer. But on the other hand, we need an approach that does not put the employer in a position to be considered a danger from this point of view. We know that a mature and technologically advanced economy will promote secure work. We call on the Commission to work on this.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D). -
text: I agree that risk prevention and the promotion of safer and healthier working conditions are essential not only for improving the quality of work, working conditions, but also for promoting competitiveness. However, I want to stress that here we are not talking about an automatic work tool or any machine. This new strategy must be aimed at a person who works hard, works hard and is increasing life expectancy. Demographic change in Europe must therefore be taken into account, as employers will have to recognise changes in the workforce and increasingly use older workers. The fact that the health risks of older workers are also significantly different from that of younger workers should therefore be assessed. Therefore, in order for people to be able to work longer, occupational health and safety measures must also be adapted to workers of this age. Another problem is that there is still little focus on the psychosocial risk aspect, i.e. the intimidation of workers. For example, they can lose their jobs at any time, because there is now a crisis because there are hundreds of jobs, thousands of those who can replace them. We are therefore also paying too little attention to the stress caused by the workload. And these issues are becoming increasingly important, as the working environment is changing dramatically when new technologies, materials, work processes, design, work is organized and administered in a different way. Not all workers can adapt to new changes at the same pace, which can lead to a significant deterioration in their mental and physical health. Thank you very much, and I call on the Commission to take into account all the proposals, because it is really very important what people's health will be like.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, ar maidin sa Pharlaimint thug an Pápa Proinsias I an-óráid dúinn agus insan óráid sin luaigh sé dínit, go háirithe dínit an duine. Dúirt sé gur ceann de na slite is fearr chun dínit a thabhairt do dhuine ná jab fiúntach a thabhairt dóibh; mar tugann sé sin luach ar a saol agus tugann sé féinmhuinín agus féinmheas agus, dar ndóigh, ioncam dóibh.  Ach ní haon mhaitheas jab a thabhairt do dhaoine muna bhfuil siad slán sábháilte in áit a gcuid oibre, agus tá sé le feiceáil go soiléir nach bhfuil sé sin ag tarlú ina lán áiteanna trasna na hEorpa. Fiú amháin tamall beag ó shin bhí ar Phríomh-aire na Laitvia,  éirí as a chuid oibre de bharr tubaiste uafásach a tharla i monarcha ann de bharr drochthógálaithe; taispeánann sé sin an dainséar atá ann.  Luaigh mo chomhghleacaí Marian Harkin staitisticí maidir le daoine á ngortú agus á marú in áit a gcuid oibre a chuirfeadh sceon ort. Dar ndóigh, taispeánann sé sin go bhfuil sé an-tábhachtach díriú ar an ábhar seo agus an straitéis a luaigh mo chara Marianne Thyssen a chur i bhfeidhm chomh luath agus is féidir linn. Más féidir linn é sin a dhéanamh beidh ionad a gcuid oibre slán sábháilte do na hoibrithe agus tugaimid an dínit a luaigh an Pápa ar maidin dóibh trasna na hEorpa agus beidh gaisce déanta againn ansin.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ...... the old occupational safety and health strategy dimension 2012, and it worked. We have data that during that period it was able to reduce the number of actions that caused accidents at work by more than three days by almost 30%. A new strategic framework has now been adopted, and we know that the objectives in Europe are for longer working lives and, in order for them to genuinely become a reality, we also need a safe working life. It is part of European competitiveness and cannot be economically underestimated either. I would like to hear from the Commissioner how you intend to give concrete light to that strategic framework. And I hope that you will also take active measures more broadly when TTIP is being processed, when refit is being processed, which worries people interested in occupational safety and health. It would be great to hear today that you would like to give concrete effect to this strategic framework and to put into force a complete strategy, as it was before 2012.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would just like to give my opinion on the other side of the matter. It is a belief that legislation can currently lead to a reduction in risks in the workplace.  I believe that the current situation has already led to some overregulation in this area. I feel sorry for every victim, every accident in the establishment, but excessive and too much legislation can also make us an uncompetitive economy, meaning a European one. It also increases costs. My colleague Mr Mann has already said this.  I think that we need new legislation on the protection of employees, but indeed one that is clear. I therefore like the conservative approach presented by the Commissioner, and I thank her very much for that.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I have tried to get to know this issue more deeply before, and at the beginning of the summer I asked the Commission a question in July, and a lot of the arecims of the answer I received were very interesting to me. We are talking about 27 directives governing this issue, but it is, of course, the responsibility of the Member States to transpose the directives into national legislation, and even to control their implementation. I feel a little bit that the Commission is here as a toolkit. I therefore urge everyone to develop a strategy by 2020 or more that will make the community of European countries a genuine union for health at work and a genuine union for safety at work.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the issue of health and safety at work is very important and has been a concern for society for many years. First of all, it has a human dimension because health is an important, essential commodity for the individual himself. It also has an economic dimension because, if not everyone respects the legislation that has been adopted, different companies are given the opportunity to distort competition and have lower costs. Of course, it should also be pointed out that, when health and safety rules are not respected at work, there are also increased costs to the health systems of the Member States themselves, which is important to take into account especially in those countries whose policies have been damaged by the memoranda and the measures imposed on them.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, precarious employment and the exclusion of trade unions from decisions affecting occupational health and safety are risk factors which the Commission does not seem to take into account. Despite the disproportionate destruction of jobs in high-accident sectors, workplace accidents and fatal accidents have increased in the past year. And they will continue to do so if worker representation institutions and recruitment security, as well as labour inspection measures, are not strengthened. I also regret the Commission's lack of ambition in the absence of reliable statistics and the profound mutations experienced in the labour market. Many areas require active and specific interventions. On the contrary, the Commission seems indifferent, even in the implementation of existing legislation, betting on laxity and deregulation, as has already been done in other related areas such as chemical protection. This position perverts, once again, the meaning of the work, treating it as a cost rather than as a space that generators rights and guarantees.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Mr President, dear Commissioner, very few lawyers in Hungary protect the rights of workers, but I have now received a text message from one of you on the subject. She mainly deals with victims of violations by multinational companies, and writes that we do not have the guts to take sick leave, they work sick, they are terrified at work, they are not allowed to eat properly, they cannot even go to the toilet, they cannot move away from the ribbon, they have to lift enormous burdens as women. All for a starvation wage, which we know is a fifth of westerners. What do you know about this, dear Commissioner, and what do you want to do to end this enslavion in Hungary or in other so-called new Member States or peripheral countries in the European Union?

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. I would like to thank you for today's debate. It gives me the opportunity to reiterate my commitment to improve people's working conditions and, above all, to pay attention to the protection of health and safety at work. I have taken note of many of your concerns and concerns. I cannot comment on everything, that would go too far, but I understand that you feel that this strategy has come rather late. We have to do it and we will now try to implement it as best we can. In any case, the framework is now in place and that is a good thing. It is aimed at an effective implementation of the agreements that are made. It is aimed at prevention and it is also aimed at responding to demographic developments, including the fact that we are dealing with an ageing working population. As I have said, we are currently undertaking a post-evaluation of the acquis communautaire, of everything we have on legislation - more than 24 directives are being scrutinised. We will continue to investigate what we need to do in a transparent and organised way. Let us now wait and see what emerges from this evaluation of the legislative texts, and when we know that we can see how we can tackle everything in its entirety in a structured, organised way, both legislative action and the political actions needed to improve the situation in the workplace. I understand from the debate that you are calling for a great deal of attention to safety and health in the workplace in SMEs. Rightly so, SMEs create a lot of jobs. So, and certainly there, the safety and health of people must be guaranteed. I agree with you that fewer rules should not come at the expense of protection. That is not to say that we should not investigate whether we can provide good protection with fewer rules, and that is one of the exercises that will also take place. As far as the number of accidents is concerned, that number remains high. Some of you have mentioned figures, every accident is one too many, so we can never be satisfied. However, what I have learned from the evaluation of the previous strategic framework is that the number of accidents has decreased. At the same time, we must be aware of the emergence of new and other risks, and we must take into mind this in the future approach to this important policy area. You have also mentioned one of them, namely mental health and stress at or after work. In the previous strategic framework, attention was already paid to this and I am satisfied that in the current strategic framework mental health is a priority as one of the challenges. We all know the situation of people who are constantly attainable. Everyone is connected 24 hours a day. We all carry these instruments with us, these are things that can, of course, create additional stress and need to be looked at in more detail. Whatever is happening in this area, the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work is currently campaigning for healthy workplaces in Europe, and this is being done under the name Healthy work places manage stress. These are matters which are still in the early stages, but they are issues that clearly show that this is not just about words, but that political action is being taken in this matter. There is also a joint action on mental health and well-being at work coordinated by our Directorate-General, together with DG SANCO. That DG has been renamed, consumer protection is off, and is now called DG health. Here, a number of people are brought together from Member States looking at mental health in the workplace, including in the care professions. I believe that we will probably be able to learn a great deal from that too. Special attention has also been drawn here to, among other things, the dangers of asbestos. We know that asbestos has been banned in Europe for years, but that it is still present in a number of buildings and that, among other things, people in the construction sector, certainly those responsible for maintenance or who are active in the field of building demolition, can still be at risk; we are well aware of this. However, we also know that there is legislation in this area that protects people, and I would like to add that this piece of legislation is also involved in the evaluation process of the 24 directives that we are currently reviewing; only after the completion of the evaluation can we come up with an outcome. Only then can I tell you what political direction we think we should go in. Asbestos is certainly also a concern. Mrs Jongerius asked the question: what about soldiers and police men? I have to admit, I didn't know that this sector wasn't covered. I can there is something to suggest that it is not covered, but we must at least look at what prevents us from doing anything for that sector and I will certainly have that checked. Ladies and gentlemen, I have found that you are very motivated to cooperate in the field of health and safety in the workplace. I look forward to this cooperation and I can assure you once again that we will ensure good cooperation in this area too with all those involved and without a doubt also with the social partners. They really are our partners in this. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to further cooperation in this matter with you.

name: Puhemies. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. - Of the 217 million workers in the European Union, 3 million suffer a serious accident at work each year. Unfortunately, 4,000 of them end up fatal. These are human destinies that affect entire families and it is ungrateful to say how much work injuries cost states in terms of lost working hours and sick leave.  The fact that each euro invested in the prevention and improvement of occupational safety measures returns two, must encourage the Commission to step up decisively. The strategic framework on occupational health and safety is a significant step, but lacks determination. As key measures, I see better protection for non-standard labour professionals, adapting existing regulations to an ageing working population and developing European statistical mechanisms for monitoring work-related diseases.  In conclusion, I join colleagues interested in why the Commission has not included specific work-related legislative measures in the Strategic Framework. In a work environment where job insecurity and pressure on workers are greater than ever, this is unfortunately necessary.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Communication summarising the work on health and safety at work over the last few years shows that considerable progress has been made on this issue. Almost all Member States have put in place national OSH strategies. The number of accidents at work has been reduced, while the sense of safety of workers has increased. This shows that cooperation between The Member States and the Commission and coordination can have good results and have a positive impact on the safety of European workers. This does not mean that we are not facing any further challenges. I believe that the priority for 2014-2020 should be to simplify health and safety legislation and harmonise it. This will allow for faster and easier adoption and observance. In particular, small and micro-enterprises, which have less resources and are therefore able to implement complex standards, are waiting for facilitation. Harmonised rules will also allow for the exchange of good practices and cooperation between countries, as well as facilitate access to EU funding.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Despite the significant successes achieved by the previous strategy for health and safety at work, many Europeans still suffer accidents at work and lose their lives. The importance of this threat is demonstrated by data showing that more than 3 million people in the Union suffer serious health injury each year in the performance of their professional duties. To this should be added people suffering from so-called occupational diseases, the numbers of which we do not really know.  The risks associated with work are largely the same in all Member States, so it is appropriate to take action at Union level. Despite the fact that all employees deserve the same protection regardless of where they work and how big their employer is, it is not the quantity, but the quality of the legislation will be effective in this case. Multiplying EU legislation in this area is not the right solution. It seems more appropriate to focus on reviewing existing legislation, implementing existing legislation and promoting good practices. In the coming years, we should focus on small, medium-sized and micro-entrepreneurs, as they are the ones that tend to deviate from the current rules. However, this must not be done at the expense of increasing the amount of burdens imposed. We should remember that small, medium-sized and micro-enterprises create the most jobs, and it is their development that will allow us to emerge from the economic crisis.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – Safe and healthy working conditions are a fundamental right clearly enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. That is why the European Union also has a responsibility to ensure that this fundamental right is respected. But that is precisely what the European Commission has not done. On the contrary, not only will responsibility be deported, but measures such as the EU social partner agreement for hairdressers will also be actively hindered. The strategy now being presented by the European Commission is very disappointing and hardly deserves the name Strategy. There is a lack of commitment, the necessary objectives and, above all, the concrete measures on how these objectives are to be implemented. I call on the Commission to fundamentally improve its strategy. People who work on freezers, to store shelves or to lace up packages, for example, also need good and healthy jobs. Bear in mind that this is a fundamental right and not bureaucratic hurdles. The legislative changes and facilitation for SMEs called for in the REFIT programme harm workers and create an unjustified division of employees: in one part that deserves health protection and the part that is denied it simply because the company in question is not large enough.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the ageing of the working population and the average lengthening of working life, it is essential to strengthen the current European strategy on health and safety at work. Reducing the number of accidents and effectively preventing occupational diseases is necessary, not only to enable European workers to have better working conditions, but also to promote the EU's competitiveness and productivity. In this regard, we need a joint effort by the European institutions and the Member States to ensure greater prevention of emerging risks, better implementation of existing legislation and more effective use of European funds to finance initiatives for safe, healthy and sustainable employment. We must also not forget the important role played by local and regional authorities in promoting appropriate standards and new competences in this sensitive area. I therefore hope that today's debate will be part of the broader context of fruitful cooperation with the European Commission in defining the new framework for 2014-2020 in order to ensure an ever higher level of worker protection.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: Written. – Given the current context, in which we are faced with a considerable number of deaths and conditions caused by working conditions in the workplace, it is clear that we have a duty to EU citizens and, of course, the claim to achieve an improvement in the legislation in this area. The Commission must come before Parliament with concrete legislative proposals.  All employees are entitled to adequate and high protection at work, regardless of the Member State, the size of the employer or the type of potential conditions. Businesses, in turn, need support for better and fairer implementation of the related rules. We have a new Commission and a new Parliament that must commit to improving this legislation. We can no longer overlook the number of cases of cancer associated with working conditions or the worrying number of musculoskeletal conditions in the Member States. All this has a direct impact on the health of the population, but also on the performance of employees.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – The delay in the implementation of the cohesion funds planned for the 2014-2020 horizon is already a reality. The delay in the approval of partnership agreements was, in this Portuguese, dramatic and is conditioning the finalisation and approval of operational programmes. The impasse over the Community budget could in the same way seriously jeopardise the whole process, at a time when late payments are already around EUR 25 billion. At a time when the EU is stagnant from the economic point of view and still under the threat of deflation, there is an urgent need to forge an ambitious public investment plan that can boost the economy. I therefore believe that the Commission, instead of shuffling the agenda with its 300 billion plan which no one has yet quite understood, should have concentrated on the transition between the two multi-annual frameworks, thus avoiding yet another unnecessary gap, which is highly damaging to our economies.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – On the front page of the Communication, the European Commission is at least a questionable objective, which I quote: Preventing workers from being victims of serious accidents or occupational diseases and promoting the health of workers throughout their working lives is essential for them to work until later. We can't help but praise sincerity. Let us explain another version of history: the right to safety, hygiene and health in the performance of professional activity is a social right of workers, conquered by decades of struggles, which imposes respect for the right to physical integrity, the prevention of accidents, occupational diseases, work-related diseases and health promotion in the workplace. In Portugal there are several health and safety problems at work that result, from the outthen, by the lack of supervision of the laws that are already enshrined, which means complacency with the employer. There is no inspection because state services, which must monitor business infringements in this area, are simply being dismantled in the name of meeting the deficit target. This is the reality that makes reality so far away, resulting from EU guidelines, and a discourse supposedly concerned with workers.

name: Talmannen. -
text: The next item is an oral question to the Commission on the implementation of the Directive on equal treatment at work. I give the floor to the questioner Marita Ulvskog on the committee on employment and social affairs (O-000074/2014) (2014/2862(RSP)) (B8-0033/2014).

name: Marita Ulvskog
text: questioners. - (C) The Treaty of Rome already established equal treatment as a crucial fundamental principle of European cooperation. This protection of equal treatment has subsequently been extended and deepened. The Court of Justice has also acted as a defender of citizens' rights, while several directives have been adopted to promote equal treatment. Unfortunately, however, work on this is not over. It continues. It must continue to combat any direct or indirect discrimination on grounds of nationality, sex, origin, religion, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. That is a central task.  All Member States have now also transposed the directives. However, according to the Commission, there are a number of problem areas. These are obstacles to access to justice, inadequate sanctions, a lack of awareness of the rights of citizens through EU legislation, under-reporting on things, a lack of data and so on.  Many are therefore unaware of their rights. Here, of course, a responsibility rests with all of us, but especially on the Commission to disseminate information, quite simply, about what citizens can do and should do if he has been discriminated against.  A key area of discrimination is precisely about the labour market. All workers in Europe must be given the right to protection against discrimination. That is also why I have put this oral question up for discussion here today. We want this to be included and resolved and strengthened in the term of office before us. That is also why today we have raised the problems of underreporting, which must be resolved, and lack of access to justice. We must strengthen our preventive work as well. We must combat prejudices and underlying structures that lead to discrimination and which, in turn, can ultimately manifest in lost life chances or even physical violence. So what can we do to make what was already recorded in the Treaty of Rome become a reality for more of the people living in this Europe today?

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I want to thank the Committee of Employment and Social Affairs for giving me the opportunity to stress the importance that the Commission attaches to effectively fighting any form of discrimination in the labour market and beyond. This engagement is not new. The Union adopted in the past a comprehensive framework for tackling discrimination and ensuring respect for fundamental rights to equal treatment throughout the Union. This framework includes the Employment Equality Directive, the Directive on Racial Equality and the directives on gender equality. But to provide full effect, directives must be properly implemented in all Member States. The implementation report issued in January this year highlights, indeed, that more needs to be done to ensure effective implementation of the directives on employment equality. Member States have put in place implementing legislation, but effective protection to victims of this discrimination on the ground still has to be improved. Easy access to justice, availability of remedies and effective sanctions are not yet sufficiently secured everywhere in the Union and, on top of this, the report makes clear that today many victims of discrimination simply ignore their rights. The Commission will on a continuous basis carefully monitor the national developments, including any new legislation and the development of national case law. We will also pay more attention to what happens at regional and local level, and I am ready to use all available means, including the use of infringement proceedings, to ensure correct application in all Member States. But the Commission will also act itself to address the problems identified. We have a booklet which is currently under preparation, with practical guidance for victims of discrimination. The Commission is also providing funding for both awareness-raising and for training on equality law. In order to address the lack of information on discrimination, the Commission is assessing the means to promote collection of such data in cooperation with other players, such as the Fundamental Rights Agency. The disadvantages faced by women in employment, including the gender pay gap, are not specifically covered by the Employment and Equality Directive itself, which deals with discrimination on grounds of religion or belief, disability, age and sexual orientation. But there is a legal framework on equal pay, which includes the Employment Gender Equality Directive, clearly prohibiting any pay discrimination. It is reinforced by a recommendation on equal pay adopted earlier this year, and from now on I will strongly focus on the correct application and enforcement of the EU legal framework at national level and on the measures taken on the transparency of pay.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I will try not to pass the time. Commissioner, the existing legislation provides a good legal basis, but the main problem is that it is not always applied correctly and, in order for equal treatment to be a reality, Member States and civil society must be more involved. I would like to focus my speech on two groups. First, in people with disabilities. In order for them to work on an equal footing, in many cases, it is only necessary to make small adjustments in the workplace, adopting mechanisms that do not involve a disproportionate or undue cost to companies, but that guarantee their full participation. Secondly, I would like to refer to ethnic minorities and, in particular, to the Roma community. The employment exclusion rate is more than 78%. The problem is structural and requires rapid and long-term action, through awareness-raising campaigns aimed not only at society as a whole, but in particular for trolling and trade unions to eliminate once and for all the social stigma suffered by this minority. But, fundamentally, measures are needed to prevent absenteeism and drop-out, because, as my country's awareness campaign says, 'Gypsies with studies, Roma with a future'. And to achieve this, it would be necessary to strengthen the role of NGOs, which are closest and those that can provide the necessary assistance.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The directive has been in force for more than a decade now, and yet there are still problems with implementation in the Member States. Thank you for actively addressing the issue. Discrimination in the workplace is precisely serious. The number of unreported cases is still very high. Recent data from the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights show that 82% of respondents who were affected by discrimination did not bring the case to the attention of the public.
