Either because they were not informed about their rights, or because they were afraid of a dispute with their employer, or because they were also afraid of the cost of a legal dispute. Discrimination must not take place. It is our duty to do everything we can to prevent this from happening in Europe. That is why we need clear common definitions of when discrimination occurs. And indirect discrimination in particular is often difficult to prove. We need information, information and appropriate penalties. The Member States need to become more ambitious. It is precisely people with disabilities or people who can only partially or not participate in the labour market that need to be better taken into account. I hope that we will go a long way with you, Mrs Thyssen. I am counting on your word!

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group. – For more than 10 years, protection against discrimination has been one of the areas where European law seeks to positively influence people's daily lives in the European Union, yet many children, women and men still face discrimination on a daily basis. As I have been helping people with disabilities or people from socially disadvantaged backgrounds as well as education for a long time, I see unequal access to education as one of the main areas of discrimination in Slovakia. Although our legislation talks about integration, it is hardly happening at all in practice. The employment situation is similar, with many employers paying punitive levies rather than hiring a person with disabilities. According to a recent survey by the Institute for Financial Policy of the Ministry of Finance of the Slovak Republic, if the job applicant has a name that suggests that he belongs to the Roma national minority, he/she has a significantly lower chance of being invited to an interview at all. However, our society is paying for and will pay for such segregation, not only in the huge economic losses from the untapped potential of these people, but also in the consequences of denying the self-realisation and human dignity of this broad group of people. I therefore call on the Member States not only to create a legislative framework to help discriminated against groups of people, but also to create the conditions for its real application, so that individual governments ensure that, if someone is denied such a right, they have someone to turn to for effective help and redress.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for her response, and I note her concern about the implementation of these anti-discrimination directives. What I would say to you, Commissioner, is that there is a paradox with regard to anti-discrimination legislation at EU level, and it is this: I believe many Europeans are generally aware that we have anti-discrimination legislation, and indeed that we have equality in the area of employment. Yet, reading your own reports, all available information suggests that there are very low levels of reporting, and indeed, in your report which was published last January, you gave the commonest reasons for this. These include: the belief that nothing will happen as a result of reporting; a lack of knowledge on how to go about reporting an incident; and also negative experiences in relation to inconvenience, bureaucracy and, crucially, the length of the process. So again, your report goes on to say that there is a need to make further efforts at awareness-raising and reporting, and a need to make the complaint system more consumer-friendly, as it were, or customer-friendly. I think we need proposals on how to deal with these barriers on access to justice. We could look, for example, at the length of time during which a complaint could be made, getting rid of the short time limits that are there. We could also look at the cost of proceedings, and I think in all of that we need to link in with national actors on the ground. I think the issue of remedies – and one of our colleagues said a few moments ago that some employers would prefer to pay the costs rather than comply with the legislation – is a very important one, and the practice seems in most Member States to be that national authorities apply the lower scale of the sanctions available. I know the Commission perhaps cannot intervene directly, but it is an important issue and it is one that makes a difference, because if sanctions are not dissuasive then they are meaningless. On the whole issue of the shift in the burden-of-proof argument, where it is up to the respondent to prove there has been no discrimination, is that working satisfactorily and do you feel that any further action is needed? Finally, in the context of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, we have ratified that and, of course, that has certain implications for our legislation, particularly in the area of reasonable accommodation for disabled persons. Do you believe that the ratification of the UN Convention will be meaningful – that was the second question we asked you – without any further action to make the non-provision of reasonable accommodation a discriminatory action? As Ms Lope Fontagné has already said, it does not need to be costly.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this report speaks of access to swift and effective justice as a vitally important mechanism for victims of discrimination. But in my country, Spain, since 2012, has said goodbye to public justice, since Law 10/2012 came into force, which represents an increase in judicial fees of up to 750 euros. These fees also apply to labor trials. This is a situation of inequality and helplessness for citizens, especially those with fewer resources: immigrants, young people living in a state of permanent precariousness and women who continue to suffer an absolutely immoral pay gap. We cannot talk about access to swift and effective justice as long as there are laws in the Member States that put on the balance, on the one hand, the fundamental right to defence and, on the other hand, the payment of a fee which is often inesumable. We cannot speak of equality when justice becomes an object of luxury. What the Government of my country has done is a disgrace and I would like to know whether the Commission will do anything about it.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would certainly welcome the opportunity to look at the way in which the anti-discrimination directive is working. It was a ground-breaking piece of legislation at the time, but I do not think it has had all the results we would have hoped for. When we look at the breakdown of unemployment figures, it is still very clear that there are still groups that are really suffering discrimination, whether they are people with disabilities, older workers, people from ethnic minorities, or whatever.  So we are not, as our colleague said, using the skills and the talents that are there, and a lot of the time we are not developing them in training either. People have talked about the awareness of rights; the Fundamental Rights Agency said that maybe about one in four people in the EU were aware of their rights under the legislation. So this begs a question about whether we can put in practice a strategy to improve that figure, measure the outcome and, hopefully, improve the results. Others have spoken a bit as well about the way in which we apply rights. We are aware that many national equality bodies have actually had their funding cut over the last few years. In the UK that has been about 60% and has included a lot of local project funding. Yet these are the clear contact points for people to report and to develop cases. So we really need to be doing a lot more here to make sure that this legislation is really working to help people develop their talents and their future.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we have already got anti-discrimination laws in the UK, and meddling bureaucrats in Brussels complicating our laws without any accountability do not help the situation. Of course, there should be no discrimination against people in the workplace: full stop. It is already illegal in the UK, obviously. We are all human beings and should have the same rights and protection. Employment should be solely based on merit, skills and enthusiasm that individuals have for a particular job – which brings me to the other side of the debate, which is positive discrimination. It is the EU that promotes discrimination, with all its targets and quotas for employment. The EU wants the employer to choose the person with arbitrary characteristics that could be something like gender or ethnic origin. So before you can all take the moral high ground and sit there and say everything is perfect about the EU, you really need to get your own house in order; and you do not fight discrimination with more discrimination ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, first I want to thank Mrs. Thyssen, our new Commissioner for demonstrating her ambition to address this issue and of course thank the Employment Committee that raised this issue.  I believe that you will really have fun implementing European law at national level and in fact that the most important problem and biggest problem of this Directive, it was adopted as we know 10 years ago, but unfortunately its implementation or implementation is lagging behind. That's what we all have to deal with together. We know that the labour market is a fertile ground for discrimination. We also know that poor information is also a fertile ground for discrimination and that discrimination as we have heard here before can escalate into violence.  And that's why it's up to us to address the most vulnerable groups, women, people with disabilities and minorities. I believe that you, Mrs. Thyssen, will stand up, knowing your work so far, and that together we will be able to conduct a campaign to raise awareness. That's what's missing, I think.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D). -
text: Indeed, ensuring equal opportunities for all in employment and protecting citizens from discrimination between Member States is still a major challenge. The Equal Opportunities Directive affects everyone's daily lives, both young people and people with disabilities, women, the elderly. I would like to stress that demographic changes in Europe, as well as the increase in the retirement age, make the issue of age discrimination against older people increasingly relevant. Therefore, if we are already raising the retirement age, we must ensure that those people also have access to the labour market as fully-fledged workers. Secondly, women in employment and social protection are also affected by many inequalities. There are still huge pay gaps for the same work, and women are much more likely than men to work temporary, socially precarious jobs, all of which affect women's lower pensions, and women are increasingly in poverty in old age. Thirdly, I would like to stress that we are still failing to protect the most vulnerable members of society, people with disabilities, from discrimination. It is painful to hear that some Member States are in breach of this directive because they are unable to adapt jobs for persons with disabilities, do not provide them with decent working conditions, and do not guarantee equal opportunities in education and vocational training. I therefore very much ask the Commission not to remain indifferent to the most sensitive groups in our society, because directives should not lie down simply in the drawers of the institutions. They should serve the Member States as a tool for everyday life, protecting and improving the lives of all people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I am afraid this is more than usually Kafkaesque that we are sitting here, discussing this more than ten-year-old piece of legislation about anti-racial discrimination in the workplace, in an almost entirely white Parliament serviced by an almost entirely white Secretariat, being dealt with by a European Commission that has 35 000 employees, almost every single one of whom is white, and a European Council with 3 500 employees, almost every single one of whom is white. In the last few months I have tabled dozens of parliamentary questions, none of which have yet been answered, asking questions like: how many of your employees are of BAME heritage? No answer does there come. No answer do I expect. Surely you people – surely all of us – rather than sitting here in liberal pomposity discussing a piece of nonsense legislation like this, should be looking at our own houses and asking: where are the black, Asian and minority ethnic employees in the European Commission and in the European Parliament in these tens of thousands of well-paid jobs?

name: Jan Keller (S&D). -
text: Infringement proceedings are currently taking place against the Czech Republic. It concerns the fact that a certain proportion of Roma children are included in so-called special schools, where pupils with poorer learning outcomes accumulate. I would like to point out that the problem is much, much deeper. Special schools existed in our country even before 1989. Yet before 1989, there was no Roma unemployment, there were no ghettos for Roma, Roma were not threatened by fascist ultra-right struggles, and Roma children did not work as drug dealers from the age of 12. Simply including Roma children in another type of school does not solve the problem. Much of the work that the Roma used to do is now done by illegal migrants. real estate pekulants took their apartments from the Roma. In these circumstances, the fact that Roma children attend special schools is not a cause, but a consequence of circumstances.

name: Javi López (S&D). -
text: Mr President, democracy is based on equality between its members and, unfortunately, today in the European Union it is clear that we have brutal inequalities and discrimination on the basis of origin, by race, by sexual orientation, and also between men and women. We have been creating legislation over the past decade to alleviate this problem, but we are a long way from solving it, which is quite obvious. The UGT, the General Union of Workers, Spain's most important trade union, recently recalled that women have to work eighty-four more days in the same job to get the same salary.  And we know, from the recent study we have here today, that we don't have enough data—we know that; we know that people don't know the rights they have; we know that sanctions on states are not yet powerful enough and that access to justice is very difficult for many people. So, with everything we know, let's take action and improve our legislation.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the principle of equality and non-discrimination is also entreiled in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Charter of Human Rights. The Directive on employment equality has been transposed into law by all Member States, yet people with disabilities in the EU are still socially and economically discriminated against. Unemployment of persons with disabilities is twice that of the general population. This is because few jobs offer accessibility or other reasonable adaptation solutions for these people. We have to move on. Reasonable adaptation should not only be the subject of positive discrimination, but also a legal requirement. At the same time, we must combat the trap of disability support culture and develop active labour market policies. But first we need to clarify where we are and what our objectives are. Member States should collect disability and equality statistics and develop strategies based on good practice.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR). -
text: Mr. President, equal treatment for employees in employment and upsundation, regardless of gender, age, racial or religious affiliation, is a fundamental prerequisite for quality business, a stable economy and a fair society.  At every opportunity when I discuss this or similar topics, such as quotas for women in company governing bodies, I feel bitter, because we still have to deal with inequality in employment, even though we have well stepped into the new millennium. It is difficult for me to comprehend that even today there are employers who discriminate on the basis of gender, age, race or religion. Instead of paying first and foremost attention to knowledge and ability, unfortunately such really exist and are not good for themselves and their company, but also for the European economy as a whole.  The damage they inflict on themselves in terms of business, choosing eligible and not capable personnel, is not enough, but I believe that we must punish them severely, because they represent a blow to the rule of law and value damage to our societies.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - I would like to thank you for this fruitful discussion. Some of you will remember that, during my hearing, I made it clear that promoting equality and fighting against discrimination, especially in the labour market, is one of my priorities, and I can only repeat that. It is therefore also my commitment now to ensure that there is better implementation of equal opportunities directives and that there is better protection for citizens against discrimination. There are several things we can do about it: having good laws is one, making sure they are applied is two. But, of course, we must also - and this has been addressed in the debate - ensure that we have more data. Because if we have data, problems become transparent, we make them visible, then we bring it up, then we qualify them, and then awareness of the fact that there is a problem will increase. The directive itself does not provide for mandatory data collection by the Member States. That is why we are exploring whether we can do something y-ness by, as I said in my introduction, by including the European Fundamental Rights Agency. Awareness-raising campaigns are another tool we can use, and I may like to remind you again. You have just asked for examples of the row - in the context of equal pay - of the pay gap, which is still there between men and women. For those who were to doubt it: we organise an equal pay-day every year, which clearly draws attention to this issue. It also calls for greater transparency in the context of a recommendation recently adopted, so that awareness is increased and something is done at the bottom to reduce and ultimately eliminate that pay gap. As far as the UN Convention and disabled people are concerned, this legislation prohibits discrimination against disabled people and there is an obligation for employers to ensure that disabled people are provided with an adapted workplace. However, there is also a limitation to that obligation: it should not cost the employer too much. That is a lot of giving and taking, because one also takes into account the cost effect for the employer. However, I believe that the ratification of the UN Convention will give us extra motivation to ensure that this aspect of our directive is finally properly implemented. With regard to the Roma and other points that have been raised here and which are a little outside this directive, I can only promise you that I will work very well with my colleague Jourová and that we will work together to ensure that anti-discrimination and equal opportunities for all are monitored.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Mr President, I just want to ask why you and your colleagues pretend to give catch-the-eye opportunities to people, and you keep them here at 10 o’clock in the evening. This is absolutely not fair. Out of 751 people, there are 12 who are taking part in this important debate, and even they are not allowed to have catch-the-eye opportunities. Yet you let the Commission representative talk on and on and on ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. -
text: Ms Morvai, as I said, the debate has been closed and we now move on to the next debate. We are seriously running over time because of earlier delays. We have to be rigorous with the speaking time, and I divide the speaking time as equally as humanly possible. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – For persons with disabilities, insufficient access to the labour market may mean that they are in socially vulnerable situations and exposed to serious risks of discrimination, poverty and social exclusion. In EU countries, 49% of women with disabilities and 61% of men with disabilities are employed, compared to 64% of women without disabilities and 89% of men. This results in a terrible consequence of the 70% above-average poverty rate for people with disabilities due to limited access to employment. In view of this data, special attention is needed to eliminate, or at least reduce, job inequality in the field of disability, and to adopt so-called 'reasonable adjustments'. In this regard, the EU has proclaimed in different provisions that compliance with the principle of equal treatment in relation to persons with disabilities entails reasonable adjustments. This means that employers will take appropriate measures, depending on the needs of each particular situation, to enable persons with disabilities to access, take part in, or progress professionally.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – MePs are asking, among other things, how the European Commission will promote equal opportunities for people with disabilities when they are denied reasonable accommodation. According to the UN Convention on Them, this constitutes discrimination. This issue is particularly topical, because next year a panel of experts monitoring the implementation of the UN Convention will examine the EU's commitment to this and the steps taken so far, as the EU is a party to the Convention. I would like to hear about a concrete plan of action in this regard, because I am convinced that ensuring the principle of reasonable adaptation is a key issue!

name: Puhemies.
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the assessment of bank stress tests (2014/2977(RSP)).

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am very glad to have the chance to make this statement on the EU-wide stress tests and the comprehensive assessment. Together they have delivered the most stringent scrutiny that European banks have ever faced. The adverse stress test scenario was the most severe anywhere in the world. This has required a huge investment. Over 6 000 officials and experts worked on this project at its height, but the result was worth it because it has given us a health check of the European banking system, which enjoys broad international credibility. Overall, the results confirm the significant improvements there have been in the strength of European banks in the past six years. The capital ratios of EU banks are now at around 12%. Capitalisation levels are on a par with US banks. Between 2008 and 2013, more than EUR 200 billion of capital was raised by the 130 banking groups participating in the full comprehensive assessment, and a further EUR 57 billion has been added since January 2014 alone. As a result, our banks are much better placed to withstand financial shocks than they were before the crisis; and the rigour and transparency of the exercise mean that these results are credible across the world. This will, in turn, reassure investors about the quality of EU banks’ balance sheets, help restore confidence, and allow banks to carry out their core function: lending to the economy. Some banks still have work to do to strengthen their positions. The tests were carried out on the basis of the situation at the end of 2013 and identified a capital shortfall of EUR 25 billion for 25 banks. Taking into account capital raised in 2014, this shortfall falls to EUR 10 billion affecting only 14 banks. When adjustments are made to take account of additional capital available, two of these 14 banks do not need to proceed with capital-raising. One is in the process of being resolved. To protect taxpayers, the first port of call to address capital shortfalls should be private sources, and the remaining 11 banks therefore have a short window to raise money on the market. Should a public capital injection be necessary, it will be subject to state aid rules, as set out in the 2013 Banking Communication; and these rules require burden-sharing from shareholders and junior debt-holders before any public support is provided. Stress tests are now part of the European supervisory toolbox. They must be used regularly and in a robust manner to provide a clear and accurate picture of the robustness of our banking system, to detect vulnerabilities and to pave the way for timely intervention. The comprehensive assessment also marks a turning point for the supervision of eurozone banks. On 4 November, the baton passed from national supervisors to the Single Supervisory Mechanism, and I shall work closely with Ms Nouy and other key players in the SSM to ensure the success of this change. We have entered a new chapter in our efforts to make the EU banking sector healthy, resilient and transparent. We have much better capitalised banks, we have exacting rules and processes for their oversight, we have new tools to resolve banks in a crisis, and we have a powerful and independent new banking supervisor in the eurozone. Now I hope we can build on these foundations and start to turn the page on the financial crisis, focusing on the pressing challenges of regenerating growth and investment. The G20 in Brisbane emphasised the need for a comprehensive programme to restore sustainable economic growth. This is the priority of the new Commission, reflected in our investment initiative and the capital markets union, which will promote non-bank sources of finance. Bank lending, though, remains the principal funding mechanism for European businesses, and I believe that the stress test and the comprehensive assessment should make us feel more confident that our banking system is now better placed to play its full role in supporting economic growth.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The balance sheet test took place when the Single Supervisory Mechanism was still at a provisional stage. Existing structures of the European Central Bank have therefore played a special role. That, of course, must now change. The SSM has a duty to institutionalise itself in order to maintain a necessary separation between monetary policy and supervision. There are certainly also critical comments during the test, for example with regard to the communication of the catalogue of requirements, the involvement of external consultants and the agreements with the national level. Nevertheless, the balance sheet test has remained within expectations and is a good basis for the start of the new supervisory structures. Many financial institutions have already significantly strengthened their capital base. Risk awareness has increased significantly and, finally, we need to return to the point where the risks are taken where they are taken. The balance sheet test was a first step. What is much more important, however, is how the SSM can now establish itself in the coming months. The right conclusions must be drawn from the test. The capital plans of institutions in difficulty need a political, rigorous examination. Strong and credible oversight must have a range of options for action. However, there is no carte blanche to do so. The legislative requirements must continue to be the stipulation. Democratic legitimacy is essential. The European Parliament will certainly use its hard-fought powers of control, I would say. For us, cooperation with national supervision is an essential point. Clear structures must apply, particularly to the indirectly supervised banks. It would be a terrible development if there were competition between the supervisors at the expense of the banks. Therefore, supervisory structures must remain consistent and predictable. Specific supervision is appropriate depending on the business model. The balance sheet has now been examined. However, the examination of the supervisory mechanism has only just begun.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, welcome to this plenary. Stress tests and the assessment of the balance sheets of eurozone banks have made a huge step forward in the construction of the banking union. It allowed the start-up of the ECB's new single supervisory system at the beginning of this month.  It is, however, essential to ensure that, in these exercises, the evaluation criteria will be the same for all banks, regardless of the importance of the countries where they are situated. This alone will ensure the credibility of future exercises.  The banking union project will continue with the entry into force in early 2015 of the new rules, on which the single resolution system is based, and we are currently working on building a competent and independent resolution board.  We've taken essential steps, but we can't stay here, we have to complete what's missing. First of all, Parliament and the Council have to complete the rules on the contributions of banks to the resolution fund, and I call for this process to be completed quickly, ensuring that each bank will pay according to its risk profile.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the stress tests of the banks have shown that the majority of systemic banks in the European Union can cope even with adverse economic scenarios. But the stress tests of European society show that Europe is full of armies of unemployed and poor. You are all aware, after all, that the recapitalisation of the banks has been carried out out of the pockets of taxpayers. In Greece in particular, the old shareholders still remain in the management of the Greek systemic banks, although they hold a minority of the shares. Mr President, since the beginning of the crisis EUR 1.6 trillion has been allocated to the rescue of banks. The banks were rescued but at the same time public debt increased. In some countries, such as Cyprus, depositors paid for it with the well-known bail in. The main problem is dealing with "red loans" and this needs to be addressed immediately. At the same time, banks are not channelling liquidity into the real economy to support small and medium-sized enterprises. These are the issues that need immediate attention.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Lord Hill! The German chancellor promised after the G20 summit in Brisbane that taxpayers would never again be liable for zombie banks. The EU promises something similar. If I may say so, this is stupidity. The resolution fund will be worth EUR 55 billion over eight years. Since the crisis in the EU alone, we have pumped more than EUR 1.6 trillion into ailing banks. Taxpayers in the EU continue to be too big and too connected to fail for gamblebanks that do not lend to invest but are too big and too connected to fail. Yesterday, the Financial Times reported that the financial lobby is running a storm against a separation from serious banking and investment banking. You have written to Lord Hill, not to us as Parliamentarians. These bankers are soft eggs. They are afraid of the market economy. Deutsche Bank and Co. want to gamble, and when things go wrong, they play state bank. Nor is the argument that financial market regulation is repeatedly argued that it would hinder lending. It is austerity: if public investment, when wages, when pensions fall, then companies will not ask for loans for investment. The stress test does not give a warning. Shadow banks were not covered. The crisis scenario was softer than in the last crisis. Deflation was ignored. So is the networking of the banking sector. For example, if institutions sell off bad papers in fire sales, it also has an impact on other solvent institutions. Banks continued to work on the internal risk models that failed so reprehensibly during the crisis. I fear conflicts of interest at the ECB. As supervisor and lender of last resort, it will be subject to permanent conflicts of interest. The ECB could now use the purchase of junk loans, known as asset-backed securities, to rehabilitate the very 25 banks that have fallen through the test. So far, at least, the ECB has not denied this. I would also be interested to know what the European Commission's position is on such an incentive for banks to then offload their scrap from the ECB. Instead, we need real structural reforms in the banking sector, such as the strict separation of investment banking and the dehydration of shadow banks.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, while the recent stress tests of European banks have shone the spotlight on some of the weakest sections of the banking sector, this should not divert attention from the need for decisive structural reform of the banking industry. The two most important causes of the financial crisis have still to be addressed. First we need a clear-cut separation of retail from casino banking activities, and secondly we need to reduce the size of individual banks so that no single financial institution can threaten the whole financial system. This problem of ‘too big and too interconnected to fail’ is more important and more urgent than the capital position of any individual bank. Recent news about the Royal Bank of Scotland misleading regulators and deliberately undermining their own customers suggests that banks are still no way near the responsible corporations serving the real economy that we need them to be. If it is not too cheeky on the day the Pope has visited Parliament, I recommend you to check the Green Group’s Seven Deadly Sins website to assess the performance of your national banks. Finally we need to confront head-on the vast and growing levels of debt which are the fundamental cause of instability in the monetary system globally. We should establish a citizens’ audit of how that debt was acquired and to what extent it can be considered legitimate, and we should reconsider the nature of the money creation system, which relies on allowing private banks to create money with a simultaneous creation of debt.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulatory process that should have led to the neutralisation of systemic risk from the 2009 crisis to today is once again in danger of being ineffective and rewarding for speculation. These stress tests are proof of this. You, Lord Hill, say that the European banking system is now solid and credible. But do you really think it's solid? The risk weighted asset parameters used actually penalise the most exposed banks on credit-related banking products and reward banks exposed to poor or dubious financial products such as derivatives. For example, the amount of derivatives in the 2013 financial statements of one of Europe's largest banks, Deutsche Bank, is EUR 54.7 trillion, which means about 20 times Germany's GDP or 5.7 times the GDP of the whole of Europe.  Now tell me if it makes sense to talk about the success of these stress tests and whether the banking system is solid and credible when there are banks in our house with this systemic risk scale, when the shadow banking system has reached immense and equally systemic volumes, when some of these market realities by agreeing can move volumes of money so that they can blackmail entire nations , threatening the democratic process of decision-making and self-determination of peoples.

name: Bernard Monot (NI). -
text: Mr President, the satisfaction shown by the ECB and all the policies when reading the balance sheet of the stress tests at the end of last October must be nuanced. Indeed, 13 of 130 major banks still need to be recapitalised, but there is even more worrying. About a fortnight ago, on the sidelines of the G20, the Financial Stability Board - the FSB - published its annual list of thirty private megabanks, including European and French banks, that would not withstand the next crisis, a crisis of which it is no longer a question of when it will take place but whether it will take place. The FSB calls for stricter solvency standards than the current Basel III regulations and recommends that these banks increase their capital by up to 20% of their assets. Who's right? The ECB, who tells us to sleep easy? Or the FSB, which raises fears of another catastrophe?  The stakes are high because, when these systemic risks are realized, you will now have to enforce, as in Cyprus in April 2013, the Frankfurt MUR - the single resolution mechanism - and its famous lease-in which will drain the deposits and savings of customers to enable the countries concerned to bail out their own bankrupt banks. Count on us to alert our French compatriots to this financial repression in preparation.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, comprehensive assessment was undoubtedly a key step towards the implementation of the Banking Union, and I share your view that this was a positive, serious and rigorous exercise, which strengthened the credibility of the European banking system, offered a positive incentive to strengthen the capitalisation of banks and also showed that European banks have sufficient capital to sustain a possible adverse scenario. However, of course, we cannot hide a few critical issues: the role of internal models, a mechanism for assessing the budget which in some way penalises those banking systems that are more oriented towards credit to households and businesses. We therefore need to work to improve our risk measurement capacity and avoid providing the wrong incentives. From this point of view, Parliament's ECON Committee will work actively to further strengthen our risk assessment and measurement capacity.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! Lord Hill, it is very good that this stress test has been carried out. But it would be foolish to be confident that this stress test has now turned the banks out as resilient. Because a single adverse scenario has been tested. The events that led us into the great crisis of 2008 and 2009 have not been tested. The collapse of a systemically important bank, in the case of the collapse of an American bank at the time, this scenario has not been included in any stress test. We know nothing about the second-round effects that occur when a systemically important bank collapses. We have no guarantee that we will not end up in a similar crisis if we repeat the scenario that we have already experienced. We need to see the stress test as a starting point, as an exercise that needs to be repeated over and over again and in different variations. However, we must not trust that the European banking system is already stable today.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I have three points. First, yes to the stress test. Stress testing and new European banking supervision go hand in hand. One is the prerequisite for the other. The second is that we must, of course, learn from the experience and consider what we can do better and what additional assumptions we have to make in the next stress test. Thirdly, the stress test is not complete. The credibility of the stress test depends on the procedure and how independently we now deal with those banks that have failed and how we deal with those banks that do not yet fully meet the Basel requirements and the assumptions of the stress test.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I hope I am not mistaken in saying that it is one of the European customs, that if there is a problem in the banking system, we will pour the money on it with a fire extinguisher, but obviously there are institutions that are also concerned about the use of this money. I would like to focus on one issue at the time, namely that if a bank has a state government owner and receives a recapitalisation, for example from this direction, the European Commission usually proposes restructuring, spending cuts or certain outsourcing. At the same time, there are some opinions that the European Central Bank interprets these public funds as private investments. I ask you, is there a contradiction in this matter, and if so, how can it be resolved?

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I think, from the comments we have heard, there is a broad welcome for the stress test but a clear feeling that the job is not yet done, and that is a conclusion that I would share. I think in terms of the credibility of the test, which is one of the themes of the debate, I would argue that the exercise was credible because a robust methodology was followed; there was a great deal of detail in the quality assurance; there was strong governance and multiple layers of accountability. I think, since, that investors and analysts have praised the degree of disclosure and the degree of transparency about how the tests were run, and I think that there has also been a broadly positive market reaction, since the results were announced a month ago, and I believe that is testament to the credibility of the exercise. One of the points that was raised repeatedly – in slightly different ways – was the question of whether this is enough and whether it will lead to the pickup in bank lending that we all want to see. The purpose of the exercise was to identify and address vulnerabilities in the banking system and to try and dispel some of those doubts about its health – but it was not an exercise for its own sake; rather, the purpose was to try to restore investor trust and confidence. I believe that the European Banking Authority and the ECB did an excellent job and that they have successfully met the objectives of the exercise. We have devoted a lot of attention to the supply side, but in order to get lending going again, we need the demand side to pick up as well, and that is also something we need to look at. Our foremost priority at the Commission is to create an environment conducive to growth so that businesses can create jobs and our economies can prosper once more. That, of course, is the background to the investment initiative, which President Juncker will be announcing to Parliament tomorrow; and it is also the prism through which I intend to look at the question of regulation and regulation of the banking sector. I believe that a healthy European banking sector is one that supports growth and benefits EU citizens, businesses and society as a whole. It is a system, as a number of colleagues said, where taxpayers are no longer exposed to the risk of bank failures; it is a system that is solid; it is a system that is stable, without banks which are too big to fail, too costly to save or too complex to resolve. That means it needs to be a system that is responsibly regulated, managed and supervised, based on strong ethical standards and sound governance. Ms Ferreira reminded us of the need for the next steps on banking union, and I agree with what she said about that. An important task has been started, but there is more work to do, and she reminded us of some of the immediate steps that I know she and her colleagues are working on at the moment. I also take the point that we need to be alert to new risks and to look, as I said, in particular at the question of ‘too big to fail’. But I believe – although there is more work to do – that the results of the EU-wide stress tests have brought us one step nearer to a healthy banking system, and that the stress tests and the comprehensive assessment will help restore confidence in our banks. That will allow them to turn their attention to supporting growth for the benefit of us and the benefit of European citizens.

name: Puhemies. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 26 October, the European Central Bank and the European Banking Authority released the results of the overall analysis of the European banking system consisting of the review of the quality of banking assets (AQR) and so-called stress tests, which analysed the solvency of 150 banks in the countries of the Union and, in particular, of eurozone countries. First, these tests are based on a simulation exercise. In addition, the evaluation method, which is chosen by the European Central Bank, is to ask the different banks to send it a balance sheet report, leaving room for them to misrepresent the accounts. An example of the low neutrality in such tests occurred in 2010 when the resistance tests were passed by many Irish and Spanish entities, including Bankia, which had to receive public aid shortly after passing such tests. Therefore, we cannot consider bank stress tests to respond to reliable mechanisms. Asking citizens who have paid the consequences of allocating public money to private banks to trust such results is practically an act of faith.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – It is not surprising that banks regain their solvency when citizens are forced to contribute to their rescue with all kinds of sacrifices. Less so when preparing a custom exercise, smoothing, as in the case of Spain, macroeconomic forecasts or omitting an analysis of systematic interactions between banks and other unregulated parts of the financial system. If the goal of stress tests was to allow credit to flow, I'll warn you of your failure. Without a restructuring of private debts, families and SMEs will remain more concerned about reducing their indebtedness than negotiating new loans: neither companies will invest as long as demand remains depressed, nor will families, punishable by unemployment and low wages, think about foreclosure. Also in Spain banking was solvent and regulation exemplary; it happened that it was the economic system as a whole that could not resist its dependence on indebtedness. When the bubble bursts, it can only be followed by stagnation. The return to growth requires a productive alternative to financing that they insist on imposing.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Stress tests and asset quality assessment of the major European banks are also significant for the economies of Member States not in the euro area. Most of the banking assets in these Member States are in banks whose majority shareholders are euro area banks. Noting that no particular problems have arisen as a result of these tests for many banks in the euro area, we note that economic sanctions against Russia, as well as the situation in Ukraine, can put those high-exposure banks in the two countries in difficulty. We are also waiting for proposals from the European Commission for proposals for the implementation of the political decisions taken by the G-20 leaders on 'banks too big to fail'.

name: Puhemies.-
text: The next item is the joint debate – the report by Kay Swinburne, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions – (10896/2014 - C8-0090/2014 - 2014/0807(CNS)) (A8-0028/201 (11200/2014 - C8-0109/2014 - 2014/0808(CNS)) (A8-0027/2014) by Roberto Gualtier on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Parliament has been called upon to give its opinion during the consultation procedure on the proposal for a revision by the ECB of the regulation on the collection of statistical information to the Council. A regulation which, together with the regulation on the ECB's powers to impose sanctions, is one of the pillars of the European Central Bank's statistical activity. The reason for this proposal lies in the entry into force of the single banking supervision mechanism, which gives new powers to the ECB and therefore makes it necessary to update the mechanisms for collecting and processing statistical data.  Once adopted, the legislative act will allow the ECB to use confidential statistical information in a similar way to what national central banks, which perform prudential supervision functions, do. In addition, the ECB will have the opportunity to disseminate confidential statistical information to the national authorities responsible for financial supervision or stability of the financial system, as well as to the European Stability Mechanism to the extent and level of detail necessary for carrying out their respective tasks. The position adopted by the ECON Committee on 11 November welcomes the ECB's proposals and supplements them with a series of suggestions aimed at extending the scope of the report. The amendments I have tabled as rapporteur aim to ensure better transmission of data and greater protection of its confidentiality. In particular, an amendment introduces an obligation on authorities and bodies, including the ESM, which receive confidential statistical information to take all necessary measures to ensure its protection. The ECON Committee also adopted other amendments which reinforce certain points not covered by the ECB recommendation. In particular, transparency in the ECB's statistical acts is strengthened, calling for the ECB to make public decisions to exempt particular categories of subjects from reporting obligations. In addition, it is asked to extend the type of data collected, so as to include raw data as well. An important reference to the principle of proportionality is added, in the definition and imposition of statistical reporting obligations. Finally, with regard to the sanctioning part, a clear distinction is made between negligent or intentional conduct in infringement cases and in the transmission of data by statistical agents, which is particularly relevant precisely from the point of view of compliance with the principle of proportionality. The adoption of this review is therefore of particular importance, as it falls within the more general framework of strengthening the ECB's supervisory tasks within the framework of the Banking Union design. I therefore hope that Parliament will welcome the recommendations of the ECON Committee in order to allow rapid adoption by the Council and also, of course, that the broad consensus that has been expressed around the report, for which I thank the shadow rapporteurs and the political groups for their cooperation, will provide an additional incentive for the Council to take into account the recommendations of the ECON Committee.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, may I extend a welcome to Commissioner Hill. I would like to begin by thanking Mr Johan Van Overtveldt for the excellent work he did in drafting this initial report before leaving Parliament to become Belgian Finance Minister. I have tried to continue working on this report using his methods and vision. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs from all the political groups for their cooperation on this report and, despite some of the differences on minor parts of the report, I hope this goodwill will extend to the overall report being voted through tomorrow. In the last Parliament we made an unprecedented change to the role of the European Central Bank. Instead of just acting as a central bank with power over monetary policy, we gave it powers to supervise the largest banks in the eurozone, with the option for those Member States outside the eurozone to also join the single supervisory mechanism. The Banking Union has fundamentally changed the role and responsibility of the ECB. While the ECB should continue to be independent from political influence in terms of monetary policy, it is imperative that in its new function as banking supervisor it is accountable. During earlier trialogues the Parliament tried to include scrutiny processes and transparency in the ECB’s operations and was often rebuffed, yet we did make some huge steps forward in terms of information-sharing with Parliament, so some democratic accountability is present within the process. I have tried in this report to continue in this vein, adding accountability and transparency wherever possible. In the initial draft of this regulation, when the ECB imposed a sanction upon a financial institution it could decide whether or not this sanction was made public. There were no conditions or time limits attached. It was entirely within their mandate to decide on whether or not to disclose. While I can see reasons why, in some circumstances, not immediately publishing the fact that they have been sanctioned might be necessary, for example in the case of a wider financial crisis situation or, indeed, worries about bank runs, this should not be the norm. The normal operating procedure should be immediate public disclosure. The prospect of a fine may not faze large financial companies, but being on the front page of every newspaper poses a much larger reputational risk. For this reason we have a compromise between political groups to ensure a three-year time limit so that the ECB cannot wait any longer to disclose the fact that they have sanctioned a financial firm. I am disappointed that there is one area that we have not been able to find a compromise on so far. I am a firm believer in the concept of innocent until proven guilty. Therefore, if we consider that part of the punishment for breaking the rules is that of reputational damage, using a ‘naming and shaming’ approach, then it seems to me logical that if a decision is subject to an appeal and may still be overturned, we should allow a longer time period before disclosure to the wider market. Failing to provide this safeguard may otherwise cause a bank to lose significant value in its share price based solely on accusations that are later overturned on appeal. I believe adding in this safeguard ensures the fairness of the disclosure process and will increase the effectiveness of the sanctioning regime, which will then increase the effectiveness of the ECB itself when exercising its supervisory powers. I therefore hope that the majority of the European Parliament political groups can continue to support this centrist position calling for increased transparency. Specifically on the Gualtieri report I have little to add, because quality of regulation depends on quality of the statistics that the supervisors are working on. I honestly believe that the only way we get good quality supervision is good-quality data. Therefore I hope the proposals in these two reports are supported tomorrow.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am grateful for the opportunity to discuss ECB sanctions and ECB statistical information, and I would like to congratulate Ms Swinburne and Mr Gualtieri on their work. The ECB sanctions recommendation is important because it is part of implementing the banking union, and we need it because it will give the ECB the means to enforce EU banking law and its decisions. So the Commission fully supports the objectives of the ECB recommendation. Since sanctions can have a major financial and reputational impact on banks and can be subject to legal challenge, the rules should be clear and consistent and provide legal certainty. So the Commission has no serious concerns with the approach taken by the ECB in its recommendation and by Parliament in its opinion. The Commissionʼs legal services have, however, detected two legal inconsistencies between the ECB recommendation and Parliament’s draft opinion, on the one hand, and the Regulation on the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) on the other. One of those points relates to a legal-base issue and concerns the power to sanction not only the ECBʼs own decisions and regulations, but also directly-applicable Union law, and the other point refers to the publication of sanctions. The ECB and Parliament’s opinion, as we just heard, proposed to grant the ECB the flexibility to delay publishing sanctions until after any appeal has been concluded. Personally, I understand the logic of that approach and I can see why the ECB might want this discretion. There is, however, a legal inconsistency with the SSM Regulation, which states that the ECB shall publish a sanction whether there has been an appeal or not. I think, therefore, it is worth having a look at this point in order to try to resolve it in a common-sense way. In terms of next steps, the Commission will adopt its own opinion in the weeks to come, and we will continue to work with the Council, the ECB and Parliament to ensure that the ECB possesses all the tools necessary for the effective enforcement of the applicable EU banking rules. As far as statistical data is concerned, the Commission issued its opinion on 13 October. We welcome the ECB’s proposal to align the Regulation on the collection of statistical information to the central bank’s new competences in the area of prudential supervision of credit institutions. The proposed changes will enable the transmission of confidential statistical information between all authorities responsible for supervision and macro-prudential oversight. It will also minimise the reporting burden on undertakings by ensuring that data needs to be collected only once, so we welcome the report of the European Parliament and we agree with Parliament’s view expressed in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) report on the confidentiality of statistical information and are happy with what they propose in this respect.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the As a Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we naturally welcome today's debate, which is about clarifying the competences of the ECB and the SSM in terms of statistical requirements and the possibility of sanctions. The ECB and the SSM cannot switch and act as they wish. The ECON Committee has already made its position known, and I can say that we parliamentarians will also exercise our supervisory role on these two points. In the case of statistical requirements, the ECB must ensure that confidential data remains confidential. As the EPP, we would like to express our concerns about how comprehensive the ECB's data claim could become. Proportionality is an important issue here. It is important to ensure that reporting obligations do not become excessive, especially with regard to small and medium-sized institutions. We do not need additional separate data collection points if the national authorities collect the relevant data anyway. In this way, the duplication of reporting channels must be counteracted. Clear structures are important and the basis for ensuring that data collection and analysis work well. What we, as legislators, have decided in the sectoral directives must be taken into account and, in the end, the ECB must not undermine it. This must also apply to the scope of the report and to the reporting rhythms. With the possibility of sanctions, we would like to stress the importance of cooperation with the national authorities. The ECB and the SSM are bound by confidentiality. Publications are then possible as soon as the legal redress has been exhausted. I would also like to highlight the international component. Thus, the issue of a level playing field with regard to the proportionality of penalties also plays a role. The ECON Committee has called for an international exchange on this.

name: Costas Mavrides
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this review of the existing regulation regarding the ECB’s powers to impose sanctions on undertakings for failure to comply with regulations and decisions was made in order for the ECB’s tasks to be in line with the Single Supervisory Mechanism Regulation. The scope of the ECB’s powers to impose sanctions was extended in order to establish a coherent regime for the imposition by the ECB of all administrative penalties relating to the performance of its supervisory tasks. In this aspect, in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs our proposal to the Council aims to improve the text concerning several points, including the following three: firstly, it emphasises that the ECB shall act based on equal treatment of credit institutions and without any discrimination against any Member State; secondly, it specifies that the period to impose penalties starts to run from the date on which the decision was taken to initiate infringement procedures, rather than the date on which the infringement occurred; and thirdly, it ensures transparency by publishing the decision without undue delay, with a possibility to delay publication until three years after the date on which the decision was taken in the event that immediate publication would jeopardise the stability of financial markets. At this point I would like to raise our great concern regarding the PPE’s amendment introducing a broader derogation which allows delaying, in an open-ended manner, the publication of the decisions imposing penalties with the phrase ‘until all legal means of appeal have been exhausted’. This wording is in contradiction with the transparency principle. We strongly believe that there could have been a way to have a balanced phrase servicing transparency and fairness.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The recent financial crisis has led to a lack of confidence in the banking sector. It is very important to guarantee such supervision and transparency in order to prevent situations before and during the crisis in the future. While the proper use and exchange of statistical information between authorities are key elements, the protection of relevant confidential or sensitive information should nevertheless be ensured. I agree in principle with the content of both reports, and I believe that the amendments proposed by Parliament are well balanced, but I am afraid of the political threat posed by the transfer of such important national competences to the Level of the European Union. However, as the provisions are part of a much larger puzzle for the deep integration of the systems – and not only financial – of the Member States, I would like to emphasise my scepticism. Thank you.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. First of all, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs and the other colleagues who have contributed to these reports very much for the work they have done. Recent years have shown that inadequate supervision of banks can have disastrous consequences for the stability of financial markets and for the economy as a whole. Now that the Banking Union has been launched on 4 November and the main European banks have been placed under the direct supervision of the ECB, it is therefore of the utmost importance that the ECB can act quickly, correctly and effectively when banks break rules that can lead us back to pre-and financial crisis practices and problems. That is why the subjects of these two reports are so important. In working on and assessing these reports, the following three things have been leading us: firstly, strengthening the financial sector. Adequate supervision and addressing abuses in the banking sector are necessary to restore confidence, both within Europe and internationally, in the European banking sector. At the same time, the financial credibility and resilience of the sector must also be strengthened. Fines imposed on banks that do not comply with the rules should therefore go towards strengthening the banking resolution fund, under the motto 'the polluter pays'.  The second point is to prevent financial instability. This means that investigations into breaches by banks must be initiated and completed within a reasonable period of time. Ensuring financial stability also means that any decisions on sanctions or fines are published when the outcome of those investigations is final. The last point I would like to mention is to improve the provision of information by banks to regulators. As far as we are concerned, this must be done as effectively as possible, and we therefore support the amendments that make this possible.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Kay Swinburne, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Union. We are largely in agreement on these reports. There were nupts in many conflicts. Thank you for the good cooperation. I have two things to do in particular. The first point concerns statistics for joint supervision by the European Central Bank. Here, the problem seems to me to be less in legislation than in practice. I wonder whether it is appropriate for the ECB to create a kind of credit register up to EUR 50 000 and then have data on every single loan movement down to the smallest bank. I wonder who is actually paying attention to the principle of proportionality there. As Mr Balz pointed out, we have more problems there with multiple reporting and a tendency towards overzealousness. Perhaps the Commission can also look at whether this is consistent with the principles of proportionality. With the aim of sanctions, and this is the main point of contention that we still have here: on the question of whether sanctions should now be published directly, even if an objection is lodged, our basic legal principle is actually very clear. From the point of view of the rule of law, it is actually a kind of prejudgment if one can no longer defend oneself against a sanction under the rule of law, since this sanction has in fact already occurred through publication. That is why we support the EPP's concern in principle to say that this should not happen. However, I would like to know from the Commission whether they see a way to solve the problems with Article 18(6) of the SSM Regulation? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Patrick O’Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, at the last meeting of the meeting of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs I told Mr Draghi that I felt sorry for him – and I still do. The problem here is that you can make as many ad hoc adjustments to the powers and remits of the ECB and its quangos as you like, but you will still have a seriously suboptimal currency zone. Only by abolishing national governments, national elections and, indeed, any feeling of national identity among national populations could you create the conditions for a smooth-running single currency zone. You would need popular consent for massive and permanent transfer payments from the stronger parts of the zone to the weaker. You would need to deploy ruthless political power to impose structural and, indeed, cultural changes on the non-powerhouse nations. You do not have any of this, and I, for one, pray you never get it, because the right outcome is to dismantle the euro and let national currencies presided over by national governments accountable to national populations come into being once again. That way, interest rate decisions could be taken to suit national economies and the exchange rate could serve as an adjustment mechanism to protect economic activity in the weaker parts. Your wish to indulge in incremental deepening of the ECB is perhaps understandable in the circumstances, but this is a bodged repair job on a fundamentally unsound vehicle. It is time you allowed the peoples of Europe to cut their losses. It is time to send the euro to the scrapyard.

name: Michał Marusik (NI). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Dear! Since we sit here almost until midnight, it means that we are not indifferent to these matters. We are focusing on the details of the functioning of the European Central Bank, but the crisis we fear is rooted elsewhere – it is rooted in the very systemic essence of this institution, which is the European Central Bank. After all, this bank functions as an institution controlling the outflow of euro money. This has the effect that inflation, or depreciation of the euro, gives profits to this central bank in the amount of money issued, while at the same time giving the same losses to all users of the euro, depreciating that money, and that is the root of the crisis. All national economies have so far kept their money in their budgets and in their national banks as long as they used national currencies. And at the moment we are fattening the giant parasite of Europe, which is causing the crisis of this Europe, and we cannot, by analysing the trifles, lose such an important factor that has stopped our development. We should continue to grow and return to traditional national currencies. Thank you very much.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This is not a question of the euro yes or no, but of how the banking union will enable the European Central Bank to do its job. To do so, it needs statistical material, and to do so it must also be able to impose appropriate sanctions on the banks in which it has assumed supervisory responsibilities if the supervisory requirements are not met. So everything that national supervisory authorities have done so far must be transferred to the ECB for the banks that are under the control of the ECB. That is why we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcome the two proposals. I want to focus in particular on the issue of sanctions, because I was able to deal with this for my group. This is about the fact that we do not carry out double punishment – that is, publication obligations only when the legal proceedings have also been completed. I believe that this is a normal procedure, as is also the case with national supervisory structures. Secondly, we have the exciting question to answer as to where the money is going. I am surprised that the resolution mechanism is now suddenly to be financed by sanctions. I would be pleased if the Members who have requested this should consider whether this exercise is the purpose. I can only point out that it will not help to fill the resolution fund very quickly with a great deal of money. The administrative sanctions at issue here are, in rare cases, subject to high contributions. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have also requested that international exchanges be held. I hope that the Council will take up this issue in particular.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the banking union is underway. The single supervisory mechanism, headed by the European Central Bank, has already begun its work and we will soon have a bank resolution fund waiting, Mr Hill, for a new initiative to approve deposit insurance. In any event, the funding provided for in the current resolution fund is very low: it will only be EUR 55 billion by 2024. The Socialist Group has therefore tabled an amendment which seeks to ensure that the revenue from the sanctions imposed by the ECB in its supervisory work can also feed that resolution fund. We would support, Mr Ferber, an additional way of income to that fund, which right now is very scarce, and also a fully European route. For this reason, I am asking for a vote in favour of our amendment in this Parliament, because it strengthens the draft banking union, therefore providing a faster exit from the current crisis.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! There is nothing wrong with this report if the Banking Union is affirmed, if it is accepted that the European Central Bank now oversees the main banks in the eurozone. But that is precisely the point. The question is: should an institution responsible for the provision of money also have the supervision of credit at the same time? Don't conflicts of interest arise there? The fact that such conflicts of interest exist is already clear from the way in which the European Central Bank is now pursuing monetary policy by providing liquidity at the long end of the yield curve with the purchase of ABS papers. Then we have an institution that is or feels responsible for our money, for all our financial and credit systems and for providing small and medium-sized enterprises with adequate credit. This is a super authority that is not subject to democratic scrutiny. This should not be tolerated in Europe.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI). -
text: From the majority here today, we are taking yet another step in the euro story, which in itself has long since got completely out of hand. Once again, we give special power to the European Central Bank, which has previously systematically appropriated itself powers which it did not in fact have. The rhythm at which powers are being transferred to technical and unelected EU institutions here in this house has reached an unprecedented rate, and this is increasingly happening with the knife to the throat, namely the overriding argument that the currency and therefore the socially stable economic field must be kept afloat. In your inverted world, we, the critics and the sceptics of the European Union, are being accused of wanting to impose the ideology of nationalism, but it is the other way around!  We are advocating against the euro because the single currency is a political delusion. You are the ideologically blinded EU elite, alienated from the people and from the victims of your unitary machine. We are not on the ideological side, but on the pragmatic side, when we say that a currency must be the reflection of an economic reality.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE). -
text: Banks are very often on our schedules, on our agenda. We talk a lot about them, and I thank both rapporteurs for their extremely good work. We all probably agree that the global crisis, which has been slowly eding by some Countries of the European Union, was largely the result of mismanagement in the banks. I am talking about a banking system that has not been well managed, much less well controlled. And since, of course, we do not want history to repeat itself, it is essential that the ECB be the guardian and protector of the interests of all of us, consumers, be it savers, businesses, state banks, anyone. If we want an efficient system, however, we need the right levers. The regulations offer these levers to make business supervision more effective, and that's a good thing. However, greater powers, on the other hand, also require greater transparency, which we all expect.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I will support the Council's proposals to put the powers conferred on the European Central Bank in line with the new supervisory function of the most important banks in the European Union. We can discuss that by this power, without the power to impose sanctions in the event of a breach of the rules, the decisions of the European Central Bank, and without the power to obtain the information necessary for the exercise of the supervisory function, the credibility of the entire supervisory process, as well as the credibility of the European Central Bank, would be affected.  I would also like the European Central Bank and the Council to take into account Parliament's recommendations, as they bring more clarity, both in terms of the transparency required for those processes and as regards the relationship between the European Central Bank and the central banks of the Member States.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE). -
text: Mr President, first of all let me take this opportunity to congratulate the previous Parliament and the Council for guiding the process of the creation of Banking Union to the end. I think this is a fantastic success for Europe, and it is good for all of us. I also want to wish the ECB all the best. The process for us is almost, but not quite, at an end, because there are still some leftovers which we should work on, and we should also focus to make sure that the legislation works as intended. We are talking about what should be done: for example, I believe we should focus on the issue of emergency liquidity assistance in the environment of the Banking Union. As regards the report, I think this was a good proposal and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) has done very good work, so let me first comment on the sanctions. To find a trade-off between transparency, efficiency and firmness is very difficult in the financial sector, because too early disclosure of the fines can be a very costly error. That is why I support the compromise reached by ECON. As regards statistics, as a former central banker, I have to say that statistical requirements imposed by the central banks are excessive. I would kindly ask the ECB and the Council to consider using the Banking Union to reduce the burden of statistics on the financial sector.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, respected commissioners, respected rapporteurs, the preconditions for effective oversight are quality inputs on the one hand, and strong treatment of perceived shortcomings on the other. These two reports reinforce exactly that and contribute to strengthening the Banking Union, which is really our goal.   That is why, for the most part, I agree on the proposed reports and this debate shows it. I agree that in order to perform its supervisory role, the European Central Bank must also have access to confidential statistics. However, the system must be clear and simple and take into account national procedures. When we talk about imposing sanctions, supervision must of course also monitor measures that seriously encourage banks to address perceived shortcomings.  But in doing so, it is important to share well the roles and rights to impose sanctions, supervisories at national and European level. I think so far these issues in the reports have been well resolved.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We say 'absolutely' to the banking union. We are therefore pleased that both reports provide for two additional instruments for the ECB, namely statistics on the one hand and the sanctions mechanism on the other, in order to be able to operate efficiently in the Banking Union. There is still a lack of proportionality in the statistics. This has not yet been sufficiently implemented. With regard to the sanctions mechanism, we say clearly yes, because a regulation without sanctions is like a fish without meat and like a teeth-free bite. But we do not want to penalise twice.
