That is why we want a distinction between the issuing of sanctions and publication. Publication should not take place until the legal recourse has been exhausted, otherwise there would be not only a double penalty, but also a strong influence of the market mechanisms, which may also have an impact on those banks and on the financial market in general that are not directly affected by the sanction mechanism. The designs are balanced and an important building block to make our economic and financial system safer and more sustainable.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to support Amendment No 4, which is the international dimension of sanctions, in my speech. I have the impression that European banks operating in the United States operate under a stricter legislative administrative framework than american banks operating in the European Union. This can create conditions of unequal competition in a globalised banking market and can act as a stimulus for the US side to impose exorbitant fines. Reading the international press one can find such cases. However, I think that with this amendment we are moving in the right direction. Otherwise, I think the picture is good because we see that there is a political decision on the banking union and because we see that the Governor of the European Central Bank is very competent and takes initiatives, with dynamism and efficiency. I think we should also say good things about Lord Hill because he moves with characteristic comfort and efficiency. I also believe that the officials of the economic committee responsible for all these manipulations have demonstrated their good quality. I therefore see a positive message in a European Union that is being tested and challenged.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I come back to the issue of conflicts of interest because the European Central Bank, as we know, plays a decisive role in the conduct of monetary policy, and with very increased powers. At the same time, it has now acquired enormous supervisory powers and even controls the 130 systemic banks which have 81% of the total assets of the banking sector. But it is also a creditor of the States, because it has already bought on the secondary market and even at a discount government bonds worth at least EUR 217 billion. Euro. At the same time, he is also a member of the troika, acting as a so-called technical adviser. We have a conflict of interest and an over-a-millionth European Central Bank without the corresponding political awe towards it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I am intervening to denounce what we believe to be a complete extravasation of the ECB's role in the framework of its mandate by its statutes.  Gradually, as the Eurozone crisis deepened, the ECB has been extending the dominance of its powers, increasingly becoming more and more in the economic area. He began by buying industrial amounts of sovereign debt on the secondary market. It went from liquidity lender to long-term financier. It is now moving forward with the purchase of ABS, potentially toxic securities that threaten to turn the ECB into a real dump.  It today imposes structural reforms on Member States in areas as wide as health, education or social security. With banking supervision, it assumes powers that no other European institution has. How can monetary policy and banking supervision be gathered in the same institution? It's Friedman himself who must be going around the coffin right now. It is not possible to give all these powers to the ECB without a counterpart in terms of democratic legitimacy. All reforms, in addition to those we are discussing, involve a complete subversion of the institutions, devalue the voice of citizens and move them away from democratic life. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Very briefly, I must say that I am a bit fed up here. We are having a debate about two specific pieces of law, and yet some Members explain to us why the euro is not good; another complains about the Troika; and you give us general statements about the ECB. Can we not stick to good parliamentary discussion? We have had all the debates about the banking union, the euro and so on. Can you not stick to the topic of this debate? I must say that I am really annoyed about this. You must decide whether you want to be part of this debate here or not.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. " I appreciate it, because I had more things to say, so I thank this question that allows me to complete the reasoning. It is not, in fact, possible for the ECB to be limited to a technical function anymore. The ECB today has a political mission, and taking refuge in this debate on the strictly technical issue is a mistake, and we, as long as we give us a voice, will not allow that to happen.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the hour may be late but the debate has been an interesting one, and Mr Giegold brought us back to the technical nature of what we are here to discuss. It shows the significance of the implementation phase that we have entered into – into this area of financial services – and it underlines the old saying about the devil always being in the detail. As I said at the beginning, the Commission has already adopted its opinion on the statistics recommendation, and it will adopt its opinion on the sanctions recommendation in the coming weeks. I have heard the comments made this evening by Members – some of whom are still here – about the importance of data remaining confidential, about proportionality in reporting, about equal treatment for all and the need for good supervision, and I will obviously reflect on those. I am grateful to the ECB for having prepared the two recommendations, which I think provide a sound base for the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council. I think it is essential that we have strong and legally sound sanctioning regimes in place. As I indicated earlier, there are some technical legal issues about the legal base of one of the recommendations, so I will continue to work closely with the Parliament, the ECB and the Council to see that we can get a balanced outcome, which I believe is what Members want. I would just like to end by thanking Ms Swinburne and Mr Gualtieri for their reports; they have given us all a lot to think about and they have pointed to some extremely helpful ways forward.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think I will even need to use both minutes, because I seem to note that there is broad agreement and also a positive agreement with the European Commission on the report on the collection of statistics. I therefore believe that we will be largely consensual tomorrow and I naturally reiterate the hope that the Council will take account of our recommendations and those of the Commission. On the other hand, I have some political and legal problems with the other report and, of course, I consider the Commissioner's statements about doubts about the legal basis and the consistency with the SSM Regulation to be very important, and I therefore hope that these critical issues and these elements, which are certainly very important, will naturally be taken into account, including in tomorrow's vote on the Swinburne report.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I call on my colleagues tomorrow to send a strong message to the Council on the need for increased transparency and public disclosure with respect to the sanctions. I appreciate that, as has become fairly obvious tonight, there is a matter outstanding that has proven to be very controversial: that of whether or not an appeal should be allowed before public disclosure. I am sure the Commission will advise the Council on how they might balance the need for information to be made public versus the right of a company to appeal, also bearing in mind that they need to balance the requirements of the SSM legislation with this report, and indeed the procedures for disclosure by listed companies throughout the EU and the possible market abuse regulation and directive requirements too. I am sure the Commission will find a solution to this, and I call upon my Members tomorrow to send a strong message on the need for public disclosure.

name: Puhemies. -
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 26 October 2008. Adopted on 15 November 2014. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The proposed documents concern the ECB's powers over banks in the euro area. However, I would like to point out that the situation of these banks also affects the credibility of the banking system of countries that have not adopted the euro, because the European banking system is a system of connected vessels. I strongly support the increase in the ECB's supervisory powers over euro area banks. It seems particularly important to me to extend particular supervision to all banks whose assets exceed at least EUR 30 billion or represent at least 20% of gdp in their countries. In practice, this will mean the supervision of 130 euro area banks. Europeans need to be sure that these banks operate lawfully, are managed professionally, have liquidity. The serious problems of one of these banks would not only affect its head office, but could also affect the situation of its subsidiaries in other countries. Therefore, the ECB's additional supervisory powers over euro area banks are economically and socially justified.
